DOC.HEAD: President Trades Quips At Broadcasters' Dinner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous last graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush joked to an audience of radio and television correspondents Thursday night that he got even with the Iranians for a phony phone call from President Hashemi Rafsanjani. ``Your broadcasts hit me pretty hard a while back about a guy claiming to be Rafsanjani _ a little confusion with the phone call,'' Bush told the broadcasters. ``Today I got him back. Called him up and asked if he had Prince Abdul in a can,'' said Bush to laughter from the crowd of more than 2,000. ``But then I forgot how to say, `Let him out,' in Farsi.'' Bush said he had also got a call from a ``very upset'' Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader. ``He heard me say at the last press conference that I have no faith in polls,'' the president quipped. The annual black-tie dinner of the Radio and Television Correspondents Association drew leaders of Congress and top administration officials as well as broadcast executives and journalists. For the second time in five nights, the president and Barbara Bush watched impressionist Jim Morris do his send-up of Bush, Ronald Reagan and other politicians. The Bushes had originally planned to leave before Morris' act, but they decided to stay. ``There's something in the Constitution about cruel and unusual punishment. But we had planned to leave, but I want to hear this thing one more time,'' said Bush. ``Barbara likes his act.'' Then, mocking his own disjuncted speaking style that Morris and other mimics love to imitate, Bush said, ``I'll be honest. He's good _ too good. That's as far as I'll go. Not going to comment. Not going to criticize Jim Morris at this juncture. Wouldn't be prudent.'' The Bushes laughed along with most of the jokes told by Morris and talk show host Larry King, who served as interlocutor. Reporters asked Mrs. Bush, walking pet dog Millie upon her return to the White House, if she had had her fill of Jim Morris yet. ``Haven't you?'' she replied.

DOC.HEAD: Plutonium Contamination Cleanup to Start at Rocky Flats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with DOE and governor's comments Thursday; picks up 4th graf pvs: `But a ...'
DOC.TEXT: Colorado's governor on Thursday urged the Energy Department not to reopen Rocky Flats until it has solved a safety problem that left the nuclear weapons plant's air ducts clogged with 62 pounds of plutonium. The amount of lost plutonium, a deadly carcinogenic poison, stunned environmentalists monitoring the plant northeast of Denver. Rocky Flats was shut down by the Department of Energy late last year because of safety and management problems. ``I have some comfort that the plant now is shut down,'' Gov. Roy Romer said Thursday. ``And, it should not be restarted unless they cure this problem. The buildup of plutonium in ductwork has been known since last summer and the State of Colorado has been urging DOE to take strong action to correct the problem.'' DOE spokesman Pat Etchart said late Thursday that the department will address Romer's concerns. ``We're going to continue to evaluate this data.'' He said it did not appear the issue would affect the plant's plutonium processing operations, scheduled to resume in June, but that would be decided as part of the continuing evaluation. A DOE official said Wednesday that crews might not finish cleaning up the plutonium-clogged air ducts before opening. ``I don't know if all the activity will be completed prior to restart. But if there are any safety questions, the energy secretary won't order restart,'' Catherine Kaliniak, a Department of Energy spokeswoman, said Wednesday. But an environmentalist who has been monitoring the situation for the governor says news of the amount of plutonium contamination illustrates the need for a review of safeguards against an explosion at the plant. If enough plutonium gathers in one spot, it can reach criticality, the point a nuclear chain reaction could take place. Plant officials have said the amount in the ducts does not threaten an accidental chain reaction. Melinda Kassen, an attorney for the Boulder-based Environmental Defense Fund, had raised questions as a member of Gov. Roy Romer's Rocky Flats monitoring council about the amount of plutonium in the air ducts. ``Operations should not be restarted until they can make sure they're not going to have those releases in the future,'' Ms. Kassen said. EG&G Inc., the Wellesley, Mass.-based contractor that operates the plant for the federal government, gave her the figure of 28 kilograms, or 62 pounds, on Wednesday. That amount is enough to build six to seven nuclear bombs, but officials said it did not pose a threat to workers or residents. ``We think the figure of 28 kilograms is pretty solid,'' said Bill Heimbach, an EG&G spokesman. ``We have a lot more measurements to do before we can restart.'' EG&G had been studying the matter since federal inspectors estimated in October that up to 15 kilograms, or 33 pounds, may be in the 4,000 feet of glovebox exhaust ducts at the nation's only plant for making plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. Technicians handle the deadly radioactive material with gloves attached to arm coverings in sealed gloveboxes. Last fall, federal inspectors said employees did not maintain air filters in the gloveboxes. That could have allowed plutonium dust to escape into the air ducts, the inspectors theorized. Rocky Flats, the only plant that makes plutonium triggers, is the target of a criminal probe into allegations of illegal hazardous waste handling. A federal grand jury has been convened to consider evidence gathered in a raid at the plant last June 7, but no charges have been handed up. Federal investigators have found a variety of safety and management problems at the 16 major facilities in 12 states involved in making nuclear weapons, and some have led to production shutdowns and interruptions. The problems include a lawsuit by Ohio residents who say they were harmed by radioactive spills from the Fernald plant near Cincinnati, poor training of safety inspectors at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, near Richland, Wash., and the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C., and inadequate fire protection at Savannah River.

DOC.HEAD: San Jose Mercury News Wins Honors For Earthquake Coverage
DOC.TEXT: The San Jose Mercury News won top honors in the 1990 National Headliner Club's 56th annual competition for coverage of the California earthquake. The newspaper won first place in the category of news reporting in daily newspapers with a circulation greater than 150,000 for its earthquake coverage last October, the awards panel announced Monday. The Arizona Republic won the best investigative reporting award for the Phoenix newspaper's coverage of the collapse of Charles Keating's savings and loan empire. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer won the outstanding public service award for a series written by James A. Wallace that exposed the health dangers posed by transporting poisonous materials in large tank trucks. The Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram received a special citation for creating extraordinary local involvement and pride with its coverage of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. The Press Club of Atlantic City, sponsors of the award competition, is to present the honors at a dinner May 12. This year's competition drew a record 1,600 entries in categories for newspapers, magazines, syndicates and broadcast outlets. Awards in non-print categories are to be announced later in the week. The winners in print categories: _ Outstanding news reporting for circulation of up to 50,000: 1. Eileen Welsome, Mark Taylor, Shonda Novak, The Albuquerque Tribune, ``A Price on Their Heads,'' wildlife profiteering; 2. DOC.HEAD: Woman's Crash into Home Stuns Homeowner
DOC.TEXT: A woman fleeing an angry boyfriend was thrown 50 feet from the car she was riding in, crashed through a shingled roof and landed feet first on a refrigerator, authorities said. ``She got up, walked into my living room and lay down on my couch,'' said Syble Cherry, owner of the home Denise Williams crashed through on Tuesday. ``I don't see how she even walked. I guess anything is possible,'' Cherry said. Williams, 27, suffered fractures to both wrists and her left ankle and had extensive cuts and bruises. She was in fair condition Wednesday at Mount Carmel Mercy Hospital. ``All she said was, `I need some help and I need it quick.' I was shocked,'' said Cherry's son, Oscar Cooper. Williams was riding in a Ford Escort that was hit by the car driven by her irate boyfriend, said Police Officer Thomas Martinelli. He said the Escort sideswiped a tree, spun and hit a curb when Williams was flung out of the passenger door and into the air. It was undetermined if Williams was wearing a seat belt, police said. ``The car hit a curb and witnesses say it rolled over numerous times before the woman was thrown from the vehicle,'' Martinelli said. The car then slammed into Cherry's brick house. The driver of the Escort was not seriously hurt, Martinelli said. Police planned to charge the boyfriend, who was in custody, with felonious assault with a moving vehicle. Cherry said it was the second time in less than year that a car crashed into her house, which is second from the corner. ``I still have it in my mind to move out. I'll never be able to lay down in the living room and relax and watch TV. I'd be too nervous,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A sort of purplish-pink mauve officials hope will soothe tempers and blunt aggression has been painted on the walls of the Polk County Jail's new booking area. ``If it reduces aggression, fine,'' said Sheriff Lawrence W. Crow Jr. `If it has an opposite effect, then we would consider changing. But we feel like it will work well.'' Crow said Tuesday the length of time the color affects inmates waiting to be booked may not be long. Some studies suggest only about 30 minutes, he said. ``Several jails have tried this in their book-in area,'' Crow said. ``I have read about it in publications and it seemed to be working well where they have tried it.'' Psychologist Dr. Joyce Brothers, however, is doubtful the color will produce the desired effect. ``Most people are so emotional when they are booked in, whether they are guilty or innocent, I don't think the background color could make that much of a difference,'' she said in a telephone interview from New York.

DOC.HEAD: Bar's Name Changed from Russian to Lithuanian Lady
DOC.TEXT: A Lithuanian-born tavern owner is so upset about his compatriots' quest for freedom that he changed the name of his popular downtown haunt from Russian Lady to Lithuanian Lady. ``It may not affect much, but whatever I can do is important,'' said John Rimscha, who came to the United States in 1955. Rimscha on Tuesday had the name painted over the bar's facade and ordered his staff to pour the bar's Russian vodka down the drain. He did the same thing in 1983 when a Soviet fighter shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007. Then, he changed the bar's name to American Lady to protest the incident. Rimscha, 46, said the tavern's new name will stay at least until Lithuanians obtain their independence, an event he's sure will occur. ``How could they possibly not succeed?'' he said. ``They are such determined people. They've been fighting for the last 50 years for their freedom.'' He said when that happens, he'll consider returing his bar to its original name. ``But it's more than likely that I'll stay with the Lithuanian Lady, since I'm of Lithuanian descent.''

DOC.HEAD: Last Experiment Removed from Rescued Satellite
DOC.TEXT: NASA technicians have removed the last experiment from a scientific satellite that was rescued in January after nearly six years in space and survived far better than expected. ``It really looks like brand new,'' said William Kinard, chief scientist for the Long Duration Exposure Facility, or LDEF. ``The surprising thing to us is although there was a lot of weathering apparent on the outside, most of that weathering was really only skin-deep,'' he said Wednesday, a day after the last experiment tray was removed. The satellite's condition is so good, in fact, it demonstrates long-lasting space facilities such as the Freedom manned space station are feasible, Kinard said. The proposed space station has come under attack in recent weeks because of a Johnson Space Center study that concludes an unusually high number of astronaut spacewalks would be needed for maintenance. By the time it's completed and manned in 1999, the space station is expected to cost more than $30 billion. ``It (LDEF) certainly gives you a great deal of confidence in the ability to build things like space station and any spacecraft that has to function for a long period of time,'' Kinard said. ``With reasonable care, there's no reason why you can't get extremely long lifetimes.'' The laboratory was placed in orbit in April 1984 for an expected 10 months. Because of delays, however, the satellite was not retrieved until January, when astronauts aboard the shuttle Columbia snared it 200 miles out in space. It is the longest time a spacecraft has been in space before being retrieved for study. Barring a rescue, the $15 million to $18 million laboratory would have come crashing down through the atmosphere right about now and all 57 scientific experiments attached to its exterior would have been lost. If not for gravity, the structure could have lasted many more years in space although some of the experiments may have decayed, Kinard said. None of the experiments were lost as a result of the satellite's unexpectedly long stay in space. Some even were enhanced because of the additional exposure, Kinard said. Most of the experimental trays have been returned to their principal investigators for further analysis, including one involving 12.5 million tomato seeds. The seeds were sent into space for eventual planting by school students. Those seeds currently are being distributed to schools around the country so students can monitor the growth process and report the findings to NASA. Now that LDEF is empty, technicians plan to spend the next few weeks inspecting the 8,000-pound aluminum shell then pack it for storage at Kennedy Space Center. The laboratory was designed to be reusable and could venture into space again, Kinard said. ``It is worth keeping,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Skin Ailment Strikes in Kentucky, Two W.Va. Counties
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious skin disorder that has children in two states ``scratching the skin off their arms'' has prompted school closings and protests from frustrated parents, officials said. The rash, which varies from a minor skin irritation to inflamed bumps, has appeared on the necks, arms and backs of students in Jackson and Doddridge counties in West Virginia and in McDowell, Ky., officials said Wednesday. ``We're looking for a pattern and we can't establish one,'' said Loretta Haddy, an epidemiologist with the West Virginia Department of Health. ``Unless it really starts getting out of control, we're just assuming it's a viral rash.'' Teacher Brenda Hamilton of McDowell, where dozens of students suffered rashes, said the children's skin looked ``like they'd been scalded with water.'' ``Children were literally scratching the skin off their arms,'' said James Bennett, school superintendent in Doddridge County in north-central West Virginia. At Gilmore Elementary School in Sandyville in west-central West Virginia, 50 students reported suffering from the rash, according to schools Superintendent C.L. Staats. Jackson County Health Department and private doctors who examined the children gave different diagnoses, Staats said. Some said the rash was Fifth Disease, a minor childhood skin disorder. Others classified it as ``contact dermatitis.'' The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta tested blood samples taken from the Kentucky youths and ruled out Fifth Disease, the health officials said last week. Jackson and Doddridge counties are not adjacent to each other. Neither is adjacent to McDowell, in eastern Kentucky near the West Virginia border. Parents kept more than 450 elementary and high school students home on Tuesday in McDowell, and about 40 people held a protest over officials' inability to identify the rash, which first appeared in the small town March 12. Protest leader Brenda Cook, 34, said parents were afraid because no one knew anything about the rash, or its long-term effect. She said they wanted the school closed until the problem has been identified. ``It's something in the air _ or inside that school,'' Cook said. Jane Bond, a health adviser for the Floyd County Health Department, said: ``It's upsetting the parents, but we really don't have any answers for them yet.'' Examinations in West Virginia showed no pattern and gave no indication the school environment was causing the rash, said Herb Loy, director of immunization for the West Virginia Department of Health. Gilmore Elementary School was closed Friday so that biological and environmental testing could be done to see if the school was causing the problem, Staats said. It is expected to remain closed for at least two weeks, pending the release of the test results, he said. In Doddridge County, officials said 20 fourth-graders at Big Isaac Elementary School broke out in rashes in January and February. Most of the children are back to normal but have been moved to the school gymnasium to isolate them from others, Bennett said.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Activists March On Capitol
LaserPhoto AB11
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of chanting AIDS activists besieged the state Capitol on Wednesday, wrapping parts of the historic building in red tape and chanting slogans. Police arrested 80 people. The demonstrators blocked entrances to the Capitol and marched through the hallways to pre-selected areas where they fell to the floor or otherwise disrupted government operations. Police dragged dozens of demonstrators away to waiting paddy wagons. Some had handcuffed themselves together, and police used bolt-cutters to separate them. By the time police escorted the last demonstrator into a waiting bus Wednesday evening, there were 80 arrests. Most were charged with disorderly conduct, said said Thomas Tubbs, spokesman for the state Office of General Services. One man was charged with harrassment for pushing a police officer and a woman was charged with criminal mischief for spray-painting slogans on the Capitol steps, Tubbs said. No police were injured. One arrested demonstrator was treated at a hospital for a head injury and released, Tubbs said. Earlier, members of the New York City-based AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, picketed the Executive Mansion. They shouted down Gov. Mario Cuomo when he tried to speak to them. ``We're closing down this Capitol,'' Walter Kawandler of New York City, said as he and about two dozen others sprawled on the floor outside the state Senate chamber and wrapped themselves in more red tape. The AIDS activists are seeking, among other things, more state money for AIDS treatment and prevention programs. They used yards and yards of the red tape to protest what they said was a slow-moving government bureaucracy in the face of AIDS deaths, said ACT UP's Leslie Feinberg. Outside the Capitol, demonstrators banged drums loudly and splattered red paint on marble steps. They taunted police, chanting, ``the whole world is watching,'' as protesters were carried away. Several state troopers wore rubber gloves. Some state officials tried to carry on a normal day amid the chaos. The Assembly and Senate met behind heavily guarded doors. Tour guides led groups of schoolchildren through the hallways. The demonstration began shortly before noon outside Cuomo's state-owned mansion several blocks from the Capitol. There were about 700 people involved, said Albany Police Chief John Dale. At one point, Democrat Cuomo stepped outside to speak with the protesters, saying they should ask Republican legislators to help raise taxes to pay for new AIDS programs. ``I asked you to prod the whole system,'' said Cuomo. ``I'm not the only one in the system. To be objective, you have to prod the whole system.'' Cuomo's comments were soon drowned out by activists chanting ``Programs, not promises,'' and ``Shame, shame, shame.'' The governor eventually left. The state has budgeted $200 million for AIDS programs as part of the current state budget. Cuomo has proposed raising that to $266 million for the fiscal year that begins Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Former boxing champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler and his wife, Bertha, have agreed to a divorce settlement. Neither Hagler, 35, nor his wife would reveal details of the agreement, which was reached Tuesday. Their seven-year marriage will end officially in three months. Bertha Hagler had been seeking a $4 million settlement. ``I'm glad it's all over,'' Hagler said as he left the courtroom. Bertha Hagler, 36, had testified the former champion hit her in the face and punched her in the ribs hard enough to make her knees buckle in 1987, the year he lost the middleweight title to Sugar Ray Leonard. Hagler denied striking his wife. Hagler won the middleweight title in 1980 when he knocked out Alan Minter in the third round. He has not fought since he lost the championship in 1987 in a 12-round decision.

Tennis star Billie Jean King and politician Barbara Jordan will be two of the next four members of the National Women's Hall of Fame. The four were chosen from a field of about 1,000 nominees, Sally Parr, the hall's executive director, said Wednesday. The four are: _The late Margaret Bourke-White, a photojournalist who worked for Life and Fortune magazines. _King, who was ranked the No. 1 women's tennis player four times in her career and is the first woman athlete to earn more than $100,000 in a year. _Florence Siebert, a medical researcher who in the 1930s isolated and purified protein, paving the way for an accurate test for tuberculosis. _Jordan, a Texas Democrat who served in Congress from 1972 through 1978. She was the first woman and the first black to give the keynote address at a national political convention. The four will be inducted into the hall in Seneca Falls, N.Y., on Aug. 26.

Andrew Dice Clay's ex-wife is seeking $3 million in a palimony suit against the foul-mouthed comedian. The suit filed Wednesday by divorce attorney Marvin Mitchelson seeks half of Clay's property holdings, which Mitchelson estimated at $6 million. Kathy Swanson, Clay's former wife, claims their 1986 divorce settlement granting her $18,000 in alimony defrauded her of half the couple's accumulated possessions. ``She was basically supporting him,'' Mitchelson said of the couple's relationship, which spanned five years of living together and two years of marriage. ``He agreed when he hit it big that they would share the proceeds.'' The complaint also alleged that Clay threatened Swanson with violence if she contested their divorce. Neither Clay's manager nor his publicist returned phone calls. Clay's expletive-laden routines have prompted record stores to yank his recordings. He was banned from the MTV cable network after uttering an obscenity during a live broadcast of the 1989 Music Video Awards.

Dar Robinson was one of the greatest stunt men of all time, actor Danny Glover told a jury in a lawsuit stemming from Robinson's death when a stunt went wrong in the Arizona desert. Glover, who saw Robinson work his stunt magic in the film ``Lethal Weapon,'' was called as a witness Wednesday by attorney Jerry Kroll, who represents Robinson's family in a multimillion-dollar suit against Dino De Laurentis Entertainment Group and Productions Ltd. Kroll maintains that Robinson died because an ambulance was unavailable at the remote desert location where he had a motorcycle accident while filming ``Million Dollar Mystery'' in 1986. DEG and Productions Ltd. maintain there was no ambulance on the set because Robinson felt it was ``bad luck'' and an insult to his stunt abilities to have one around. But Glover, who referred to Robinson as ``one of the greatest stunt men ever,'' testified that an ambulance and fire engines were present when Robinson executed a dangerous stunt on the set of ``Lethal Weapon'' earlier in 1986.

He doesn't wear a badge, but Mayor Sonny Bono figures he has enough moral authority to chase down speeding motorcyclists. Straddling his black Harley-Davidson last weekend, his honor spotted a motorcyclist rocket through an intersection on Palm Canyon Drive, the main thoroughfare in the desert resort 100 miles east of Los Angeles. ``I chased him down,'' Bono said Tuesday. ``He said something about not being able to read my shirt, and I told him, `You'd better learn to read real fast unless you want to spend the night in jail.''' That's when the young rider noticed ``Mayor Sonny Bono'' printed on Bono's T-shirt. The mayor, who became famous singing ``I Got You Babe'' with ex-wife Cher, got his man. ``We have had hundreds of those bullet bikes come in in the last three years,'' the mayor said. ``If they want to behave, fine. But most just go screaming through here.''

DOC.HEAD: Cohen Sees Congress Cutting Bomber Buy
DOC.TEXT: Congress favors limiting production of the B-2 bomber, says a senator who predicts that recent estimates of $155 billion to buy and operate the stealth aircraft will cause ``sticker stupefaction.'' ``I think the consensus for capping production is there this year. Whether it's there to terminate the program is too early to say,'' Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, said Wednesday of the radar-evading plane. Cohen spoke at a news conference where the Union of Concerned Scientists released a report that questioned the mission of the stealth bomber and Air Force estimates on its cost. The service has said its planned fleet of 132 bombers will cost slightly more than $70 billion. But the science group, which is frequently critical of Pentagon programs, said the price of the plane more than doubles if operation and maintenance costs are included. ``The B-2 force would probably cost in the neighborhood of $155 billion or more to acquire, operate and support for 25 years,'' said the group's report. Cohen said figures reported by the Union of Concerned Scientists ``will not simply be sticker shock but perhaps even sticker stupefaction.'' Michael Brower, author of the report, said the expense of fuel, spares, personnel, tanker aircraft and other items significantly increases the cost of the radar-evading plane. ``We do not see a compelling need for the B-2 bomber,'' Brower said. ``Its major missions that have been announced are either not credible or they can be handled more cheaply by other types of weapons such as air-launched cruise missiles.'' Air Force Secretary Donald Rice said recently that the purchase cost of the B-2 bomber probably will be closer to $75 billion when inflation is included. In addition, the service has said it will need more than $1 billion for special climate-control hangars for the planes. Cohen, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee who last year voted to terminate the B-2 program, said support among his colleagues for the bat-winged plane is decreasing. ``I'm not sure the votes are there to terminate the program, but I think there is an emerging concern that has been expressed to me by other members of the Armed Services Committee about the cost and indeed the mission,'' Cohen said. In the House, Rep. John Kasich, R-Ohio, said this week he has obtained at least 130 cosponsors for an amendment that would terminate the B-2 program. Priced at more than $530 million a copy, the bomber is considered the most expensive plane in history. Members of Congress expressed shock over the cost last year and withheld funds for one less plane than the Pentagon sought in the current defense budget. In the $307 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991, President Bush has proposed spending $5.5 billion for five B-2 bombers.

DOC.HEAD: Optimism Prevails At Antiquated Car Plant
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Horst Bauernsachs looks at the blackened, prewar factory buildings where outdated Trabant cars are built and says, ``It can only get better.'' ``I may well wind up unemployed for a time, but that's not the end of the world,'' says the 47-year-old forklift driver, one of 11,500 workers at the plant. ``I'll just have to look around. We won't starve.'' Optimism prevails at the Sachsenring plant. Even though many of its workers are likely to lose their jobs, they are looking forward to the promise of Western-style prosperity once Germany is united in a free-market economy. Volkswagen, West Germany's largest car maker, has signed a nearly $3 billion deal to build models for the Western market at the plant, which dates back to 1904 and uses virtually no automation. Modernization will mean layoffs in a workforce accustomed to making the Trabant, a plastic-body compact of 1957 vintage with a sputtering two-cylinder engine. At the same time, chassis welding foreman Dieter Blank says approaching capitalism has already raised morale and removed some notorious aspects of the state-planned economy. ``We had considerable problems with discipline in the past, but they've drastically gone down,'' says Blank, 39. ``Right now, all of us are fighting for our jobs. The workers know that VW will only pick the best.'' Trabants became a symbol of freedom last summer when East Germans drove them through Hungary to the West in an exodus that helped trigger last fall's democratic changes. Now the ``Trabi'' seems more like an inescapable reminder of the past. Blank says the mood is hopeful after the conservative victory in East Germany's free elections March 18. The winning three-party alliance, heavily backed by the conservative Bonn government, has promised quick union with rich West Germany. The conservatives did especially well in East Germany's southern industrial areas of Thuringia and Saxony, where Zwickau is located. West German flags waving from the windows of the city's aging apartment buildings show which way the wind is blowing. But as West German companies rush to get a foothold in the eastern market, Trabant workers realize their economy's immediate future is uncertain. ``My friends and I expect a dry spell of 2-3 years,'' says engineer Dieter Hildesheim, 35. ``Then things will look up again.'' Sales of the little car are plummeting because East Germans are waiting for economic union with West Germany, planned by this summer, so they can buy a car of their choice. Volkswagen production is expected to reach full steam only in 1994, so Sachsenring hopes its revamped Trabant with a VW engine will sell in Eastern Europe and Canada in the meantime. It's a far cry from East Germany's closed market last year, which buyers faced waits of 15 years or more for a Trabi and the plant advertised 700 openings. Trabis now are available for immediate delivery. The giant job notice board at a plant entrance is conspicuously empty. Dieter Voigt, chief of the state vehicle building conglomerate IFA, has said up to 70 percent of the workers in the automotive and supply industries _ about 100,000 people _ could lose their jobs in the switch to a free-market economy. Guenter Noetzold, an economist at Leipzig University, predicts 2 million East Germans, a quarter of the labor force, will be jobless for a limited period. But Blank, who has a wife and two children, is convinced East Germans will find enough work in rebuilding their land after decades of neglect. ``Because of the mess, for example in road and housing construction, there will be jobs,'' he says. However, some Zwickau residents do not hide their bitterness and sense of helplessness. Henry Hofmann, a lifetime employee, knows he'll be among 5,000 Sachsenring employees Volkswagen is expected to dump. The 33-year-old engineer is in charge of making the Trabant's hard plastic body panels. ``We'll all have to search for new jobs,'' he says of his shop. But he adds, ``I'm not looking yet. What would be secure now?'' State planners decided on plastic for the Trabant's body because it was cheaper than metal and postwar projects like housing and social programs had priority. Until the end, East Berlin refused to invest in overhauling the Trabi, leaving it just another doomed relic when change swept Eastern Europe. ``We were told: no funds available,'' Hofmann says.

DOC.HEAD: `The Day Has Been Splendid,' Says the New Nixon
DOC.TEXT: Another new Nixon emerges from Richard Nixon's new book _ at 77, a man at peace with himself who says that despite the ordeals and crises ``I can look back and say that the day has indeed been splendid.'' Nixon still has the media to kick around _ ``too often they shoot first and literally ask questions later,'' he says, adding that Watergate ``has elevated Peeping Tom journalism and character assassination to a new level of respectability.'' Still, instead of an enemies list, Nixon prints a list of his friends among journalists and says, ``I could not possibly have gone as far as I did in the political arena without having the benefit of some balanced as well as negative coverage.'' ``In the Arena,'' his seventh book since leaving the presidency, is his most personal. ``In the end what matters is that you have always lived life to the hilt,'' he writes. ``I have won some great victories and suffered some devastating defeats. But win or lose, I feel fortunate to have come to that time in life when I can finally enjoy what my Quaker grandmother would have called `peace at the center.''' The book sums up a lifetime of victories, defeats and comebacks. Almost dropped as the Republican vice presidential candidate in 1952 because of questions about a ``slush fund,'' he saved himself with an emotional television address. In 1960, he was defeated for the presidency by John Kennedy in an election that he says his wife, Pat, still thinks was stolen from him. Two years later, he ran for governor of California against Pat's advice (``she was right,'' Nixon says) and bitterly announced his retirement from politics, only to bounce back in 1968 to finally win the presidency. But his second term was spoiled by scandal. Midway, he resigned. A tape recording showed that he had tried to cover up White House involvement in the Watergate break-in at Democratic headquarters, and impeachment appeared certain. Nixon offers his standard defense on Watergate _ that he was held to a higher standard than others. ``All administrations have sought to protect themselves from the political fallout of scandals,'' he writes. The break-in at Democratic headquarters and the coverup were illegal, but ``not unusual in political campaigns.'' Other presidents, he adds, taped private conversations and suffered no rebuke for it. And most people and other presidents used foul language, he says. ``But since neither I nor most other presidents had ever used profanity in public,'' people were shocked when he released the White House tape transcripts and all its notations of ``expletive deleted'' _ especially when the expletives were subsequently published. Nixon says that despite his spats with the press _ ``you won't have Nixon to kick around any more,'' he told reporters after the gubernatorial defeat in 1962 _ he has had good relations with many journalists. He lists 73 of them by name, but leaves some others out ``since being considered fair on Nixon by Nixon would almost certainly put them in dutch with their colleagues.'' To make his case that he was judged by a higher standard than other presidents, Nixon writes that ``some of my critics'' said he should have paid to take his dog on Air Force One flights to vacations in Florida and California. He recalls incidents involving dogs owned by Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon D. Johnson. ``When Roosevelt's dog Fala supposedly rode on a destroyer, it was a good laugh,'' he writes. ``When Johnson's dog rode on a plane, it was what everyone _ the dog included _ expected. When Nixon's dog rode on a plane, it was a crime for not reporting the air fare as income, even though the animal did not take up a seat.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release at 9 a.m. EST; time set by source
More Money for Aging Research Sought to Ensure Healthy `Senior Boom'
DOC.TEXT: The nation should put more money into research on aging so Americans can enjoy a healthy ``senior boom'' when the baby boom generation gets older, an advocacy group said today. ``Serious gaps in research are placing the successful aging and independence of older Americans at risk,'' the Alliance for Aging Research reported. The alliance, which is supported by businesses and foundations, said the nation is pouring increasing amounts of money into ``sick care'' for older Americans while it fails to adequately finance research to help the elderly stay healthy. ``Compared to the health care costs attributed to older Americans, there is a wide and growing gap in our commitment to find cures and preventions,'' the group said in a report. It said that as the baby boom generation turns into the ``senior boom'' in the next century, older Americans will account for one-half of a health care bill approaching $2 trillion a year. The alliance called for spending $1 billion a year on research to help prevent, postpone or cure chronic conditions that affect older Americans. This would require a $600 million-a-year increase in research on aging, and would bring research funding on aging up to par with that for other major health concerns such as cancer, AIDS and heart research, it said. ``The successes in health and medicine in the 20th century have primarily saved lives in youth and middle age,'' the report said. ``Advances affecting the cure and prevention of chronic illnesses in late life have been few.'' Americans age 65 and older represent more than 12 percent of the population, and the oldest-old, those 85 and older, represent the fastest-growing segment of the population. By the year 2020 the over-65 population is expected to more than double to more than 65 million, the report said.

DOC.BYLINE: Cancer Cells Killed by Genetic Sabotage, Researcher Says ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Cancer cells have been killed in the test tube by sabotaging their genetic machinery, an early step in what could someday become a new form of therapy, a researcher says. Scientists used a molecule that latched onto a key substance in cancer cells, preventing a crucial gene from relaying its orders to the cells. The research is among early work in the so-called ``anti-sense'' strategy that seeks to block the effect of particular genes in cancer cells. The new results were described Wednesday, at an American Cancer Society science writers seminar, by Dr. John Reed of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. His work was in lymphomas, cancers of the body's lymph tissues that strike more than 40,000 Americans a year. Lymph tissues play an important role in fighting infections. Reed focused on a gene called BCL2. It is activated for limited periods in some normal cells when the body's disease-fighting immune system gears up. But at some point very early in the transformation of a normal cell to a lymphoma, the BCL2 gene tends to become overactive, Reed said. That occurs in about half of lymphomas, as well as maybe 5 percent to 10 percent of leukemias, Reed said. It results from a breaking and defective rejoining of chromosomes, the threadlike structures that carry genes, he said. The normal function of the BCL2 gene is not known, Reed said. Like other genes, BCL2 relays its orders to the cell by sending a sort of Morse code message in chemical messengers called ribonucleic acids. Reed's experiment involved invading lymphoma cells with a substance that seeks out and binds this messenger, stopping its function. That killed lymphoma cells in the test tube, showing that the BCL2 gene plays a key role in lymphoma cell survival, Reed said. He cautioned that any therapeutic use is many years away and must overcome some significant hurdles. One is that a single dose of the messenger-binding substance would now cost about $100,000, he said. Future developments might produce a binding substance that clings to abnormal genetic material associated with an overactive BCL2 rather than the messenger, he said. That could keep therapy from harming normal cells in which BCL2 happened to be switched on, he said. Another step toward that goal would be developing binding substances that seek out an abnormal form of the BCL2 messenger that frequently appears in lymphoma cells, he said. Dr. John Laszlo, the cancer society's senior vice president for research, called the work fascinating. Reed's early successes are ``very exciting,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Proposes New Regulatory Body for Transportation
DOC.TEXT: A new study concludes that airline deregulation has brought higher fares, more danger and less service, and recommends a federal commission to regulate all modes of transportation. The report published Wednesday by the liberal Economic Policy Institute called for price setting within a range that would prevent airlines from overcharging in thin markets or undercharging to drive out competitors on heavily traveled routes. The study called for airlines to be limited to one hub operation to avoid a system that its author, Paul Stephen Dempsey, said has ``destroyed the inherent advantages of the air transport system.'' Dempsey said it is cheaper to take a taxi from Kansas City to St. Louis than to fly at full fare, and that many flights take much longer than they did several years ago because so many pass through hub airports. ``The time has come to reconsider the experiment of airline deregulation,'' said Dempsey, a University of Denver professor who supported deregulation in the late 1970s when he was a lawyer for the now-defunct Civil Aeronautics Board. Dempsey's study challenged reports by the Transportation Department and the airline industry that hail deregulation as a boon to travelers. ``The phenomenon of jet lag has been replaced by the phenomenon of hub lag,'' said Dempsey. He referred to the formation of hub airports where a single airline dominates flights _ decreasing competition and increasing fares on some routes. The report said deregulation has increased airlines fares for the average traveler by 2.6 cents per mile over prices they likely would be paying without it. The cost per trip may be as much as 33 percent higher and is likely to take longer, Dempsey said at a news conference releasing the study, ``Flying Blind: The Failure of Airline Deregulation.'' The crux of the report's economic conclusion is that airline ticket prices had been declining for several years before deregulation but the decline slowed after the government stopped regulating fares. Federal Aviation Administrator James B. Busey, responding to a question about Dempsey's report at a separate news conference Wednesday, said deregulation has provided increased access to the air traffic system for millions of Americans. He said the U.S. system is the safest in the world. ``If people are upset about the rates they're paying, then demand is going to control that,'' Busey said. ``Encouraging competition in a deregulated market is the best way to lower rates.'' The institute study says that of the 514 non-hub communities with air service before deregulation, 312 have suffered declines in flight frequency while 143 lost all service. The institute study says complaints filed against U.S. airlines skyrocketed from 7,326 in 1983 to 40,985 in 1987 and cited a poll of pilots that said 97 percent believe deregulation has made flying more dangerous. It also said the number of near-collisions soared from 311 in 1982 to 1,058 in 1987, that the average age of pilots has decreased while the age of planes has gone up and that spending for maintenance has declined. Dempsey acknowledged that fatalities and accidents have declined, but he credited that to safety improvements by manufacturers rather than airlines, which he said are ``treating their aircraft worse, not better.''

DOC.HEAD: FAA Chief Frustrated by Delays in Explosive Detection Installation
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are facing resistance to placement of sophisticated bomb-detection devices in foreign and American airports, and the head of the Federal Aviation Administration says he's frustrated by the delays. Agreement to install one of the $1 million thermo neutron analysis, or TNA, devices at London's Gatwick Airport will be announced soon, FAA Administrator James B. Busey said Wednesday. But he said negotiations have been delayed by sovereignty and other issues at Frankfurt, West Germany, and by insurance questions at Washington Dulles International Airport. ``I'm very frustrated that we have not been able to get the original six machines in place,'' Busey told reporters. ``We are experiencing more difficulties than anticipated.'' Only New York's Kennedy International Airport and Miami International Airport have the machines under a program stepped up after the December 1988 bombing of Pan AM Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people. In West Germany, negotiators are going through a long, structured process that will include a trip by German authorities to the United States next month to test their own explosives on TNA devices at U.S. airports, Busey said. An installation in the Philippines is ``tied up in diplomatic negotiations,'' he said. The Dulles talks are in their final stages, Busey said, adding that he wants to put the equipment in a public area where it can be seen. The bulky machines generally are expected to be in luggage areas out of public view. Earlier plans to place two of the first six devices at the San Francisco and Detroit airports were scrapped because the FAA, the airports and the airlines failed to agree on an arrangement, said FAA spokesman Fred Farrar. The TNA devices emit a neutron cloud over checked bags that interact with the contents and allow the machine to analyze characteristic gamma rays emitted by various explosives, including plastic that cannot be detected by the X-ray machines now common in airports. The government had set the goal of installing 40 of the machines at high-risk airports around the world by the end of the year. U.S. airlines are to pay the cost of all but the first six, which are being purchased by the FAA. Farrar said three of the units have been built, one is near completion and the other two are on order from Science Applications International Corp. of San Diego. Hundreds more TNA or comparable units would be installed in a second phase, with the largest airports having 20 or more machines to handle all baggage. Airlines have objected to government directives that force them to pay for and install the detectors before the technology has been adequately tested in airport operations. They say the devices are needed primarily because of the terrorist threat against the U.S. government, not against individual carriers. Busey said he intends to keep the pressure on airports and airlines to place the expensive machines and is not yet prepared to cut back on the timetable for installation but will if necessary. He said that as more TNA devices are put into use, they should become more efficient and less expensive.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Touts Tax Cut as Economic Boost
DOC.TEXT: Cutting taxes on capital gains eventually would produce an economic boost equal to all current federal spending for education, job training and social services, the Bush administration is telling Congress. ``Over the next five years ... the president's proposal would raise gross national product by roughly $60 billion; over the next 10 years, by roughly $280 billion,'' Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said Wednesday. ``Increases in GNP represents new jobs, better opportunities and better standards of living for Americans,'' the presidential adviser told the Senate Finance Committee. By the year 2000, he said, the economic growth would be equal to all current private spending for basic research. Boskin and Treasury Department officials told the committee that reducing capital gains taxes would generate more revenue than it would lose. Analysts for the Joint Committee on Taxation and the Library of Congress disputed that point. A cut in the tax on capital gains _ the profit on the sale of investments _ is at the top of President Bush's legislative agenda. He contends that taxing capital gains at lower rates than apply to wages would boost investment and allow U.S. companies to be more competitive with foreigners. Democratic leaders in Congress oppose a cut on grounds it would worsen the budget deficit and produce a huge tax cut for high-income Americans with no assurance the economy would benefit at all. The Senate committee failed to get a consensus from non-government witnesses Wednesday. For example: _Tax lawyers N. Jerold Cohen of Atlanta and David G. Glickman of Dallas said a lower rate for capital gains ``violates all goals of sound tax policy ... It is difficult to convince the wage earner who has income of $50,000 that he should be taxed at a much higher rate than the trader who earns $50,000 speculating in the market.'' _Mark Bloomfield, president of American Council for Capital Formation, the business organization leading the fight for a capital gains reduction, called the cut essential to a high sustained rate of investment. That investment, he said, ``is the only way our high-wage economy can restore the productivity growth that allows us to compete with low-wage industrial nations around the world.'' _Alan J. Auerbach, chairman of the Economics Department at the University of Pennsylvania, disputed the argument that a capital gains cut would so spur the economy that it would generate more money that it would cost and nobody would lose. ``In reality, however, there would be losers: the taxpayers who would have to supply the lost revenue,'' he said. _``The capital-gains exclusion is about the most regressive tax proposal advanced with a straight face in my memory,'' said economist Henry J. Aaron of the Brookings Institution. _``Opposing capital gains on the grounds that the wealthy stand to benefit ... fails to answer the question of whether lower taxes ... is good public policy in revitalizing our economy,'' said Mitchell Kertzman, chairman of the American Electronics Association. A preferential tax rate long enjoyed by capital gains was repealed in 1986 in a general overhaul of the tax law. It was one of several special benefits eliminated in order to allow a sharp reduction in individual and corporate tax rates. President Bush contends it was a mistake to eliminate the capital gains preference. The House approved a lower rate for capital gains last year, over objections of Democratic leaders, but it was blocked in the Senate. Bush wants to tax only 70 percent of gains from the sale of assets owned for more than three years, with smaller incentives for property held for a shorter period.

DOC.HEAD: Exotic Vegetables Showing Up in U.S. Shopping Carts
DOC.TEXT: Bean sprouts and other specialty crops are puny compared with the major commercial vegetables such as tomatoes and sweet corn, but consumers are still adding exotic names to grocery shopping lists. The Agriculture Department says about 12.5 million hundredweight of specialty vegetables reached U.S. consumers in 1989, a 13 percent increase from 1988. Fresh herbs also have caught shoppers' fancy. Supplies from domestically grown crops rose 10 percent to 9.3 million hundredweight, while imports increased 24 percent to 3.2 million hundredweight, according to a report by the department's Economic Research Service. ``Imported specialties are often vegetables that are common in foreign countries, such as jicama, which is a widely eaten root crop in Mexico,'' the report said. ``Imports also include crops that a relatively uncommon but which are receiving new promotional efforts.'' Fancy lettuces make up most of the specialty category, and those supplies generally increased last year. For example, domestic Romaine lettuce increased 16 percent, while imported shipments were up 76 percent. However, escarole and endive, mostly from Florida, were down. Domestic shipments of various Oriental vegetables, including daikon and bean sprouts, increased 23 percent in 1989, while imports soared 333 percent, the report said. Even with the sharp percentage increases the total for specialty vegetables _ 12.5 million hundredweight _ was relatively small compared with the 1989 output of fresh market vegetables. Those were estimated at 255 million hundredweight, up 2 percent, not counting potatoes. Another consumer surge has occurred with fresh herbs used by home cooks and the food service industry. The 1987 census of agriculture shows ``dramatic increases'' in U.S. herb production, the report said. Production includes older standby such as garlic, parsley, watercress, dill oil, ginger root and mint oil. Also, the 1987 figures included production of an ``aggregate category'' for miscellaneous fresh herbs such as basil, cilantro and rosemary. Those increased to 9.8 million pounds from 2.1 million pounds reported in 1978. The harvested acreage of garlic, which is concentrated in California, declined slightly in 1987 from earlier census tabulations made in 1978 and 1982. However, the number of farms producing garlic increased to 448 from those earlier years. ``The increase in farms, but not acreage, may reflect a surge in the number of small farmers producing garlic for farmers' markets, country fairs and other direct-marketing outlets,'' the report said. Farms producing parsley have increased steadily since 1978 and are located mostly in California, Florida and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON (AP) _ An Agriculture Department report says fish farming _ aquaculture _ is young but growing rapidly into a major provider of food for an expanding world population. ``The 1990s should be an important decade for growth,'' the report said Wednesday. ``World population grains and limits on wild catch from the oceans should increase the demand for aquaculture products.'' Aquaculture refers to commercial production of a wide variety of fish, shellfish and seafood products. It includes baitfish, hatchery operations and the stocking of fish farms. ``If U.S. seafood consumption continues to grow, the rise in demand will likely be met through increased imports and higher domestic aquacultural production,'' the report said. Fish farmers and other aquacultural producers ``have an advantage over capture fisheries in that production can rise without endangering future supplies.'' Catfish are the leading species grown commercially in the United States. Production in 1989 rose 16 percent in volume to 342 million pounds delivered by farmers, the report said. Overall, including the wild catch, catfish ranked fourth in 1988 behind pollock, salmon and cod, and may have moved into third place ahead of cod in 1989, the report said. Prices paid to catfish farmers last year averaged 72 cents a pound, down 6 percent from 1988 because of the larger supply and lower prices paid by processors for large fish. But catfish prices have risen since October and by February had reached 75 cents a pound, the report said. Also, growers have formed a bargaining association that has negotiated prices with many processors for the first half of 1990. The most recent survey of trout growers showed a decrease in the number of producers to 478 in 1989 from 518 in 1988. However, sales of trout and trout eggs rose to $72.6 million from $66.4 million in 1988. Domestically grown farm salmon output was estimated at nine million to 10 million pounds in 1989, a sharp increase from six million pounds in 1988. The gain was attributed to larger output on both the East and West coasts. Oyster production has increased in the Northwest while disease problems reduced oyster harvesting in the Chesapeake Bay, formerly the largest producing area, the report said. Pacific Coast oyster production grew from 6.7 million pounds of meat with a value of $5.6 million in 1980 to eight million pounds valued at $14.5 million in 1988, the most recent figures available.

Field tests have been approved by the Agriculture Department for squash and cantaloupe altered genetically to resist two major crop diseases. The tests will be conducted by the Upjohn Co. of Kalamazoo, Mich., in California, Georgia and Michigan. James W. Glosser, head of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said Wednesday the squash and cantaloupe have been altered to resist cucumber mosaic virus, or CMV, and papaya ringspot virus, PRV. Glosser said the agency has reviewed the field-test procedures and determined ``Upjohn is following the necessary steps to assure the safety of the field tests.'' The tests will be conducted in May in Kern and San Benito counties, California; Worth County, Ga.; and Kalamazoo County, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Poindexter Kept Off Stand to Avoid `Putting Noose Around Neck'
DOC.TEXT: The defense kept former national security adviser John M. Poindexter off the witness stand at his Iran-Contra trial to keep him from ``putting the noose around his own neck,'' one legal observer says. Having Poindexter testify would have risked destroying any doubts about the prosecutors' case planted by defense attorney Richard Beckler, said Georgetown University law professor Paul Rothstein. Prosecutor Dan Webb would have asked, ```Did Reagan ever authorize you to lie to Congress?' Poindexter would probably have to say `No,''' Rothstein said. ``He would hit every one of those points where a seed of doubt has been laid and the last thing the jury would hear is Poindexter putting the noose around his own neck,'' Rothstein said. The general rule among white-collar criminal defense lawyers is to put the defendant on the witness stand, experts say. ``Acquittals are very rare when a defendant does not take the stand,'' said Rothstein, who has attended Poindexter's Iran-Contra coverup trial. The defense rested its case on Tuesday, and final arguments are scheduled for Friday in U.S. District Court. Beckler, asked Tuesday why he did not call Poindexter to the stand, said, ``Because I don't believe the government proved its case.'' Rothstein said, ``When a defendant does not take the stand, the jury supposes you are covering up something,'' even though the judge instructs ther panel not to hold the accused's silence against him. Poindexter avoided what observers agree would have been withering cross-examination by Webb, who hammered away at former White House aide Oliver L. North for 3{ days. The decision probably focused on the question of ``were there any facts he could clarify or bring to the table that weren't already there,'' said E. Lawrence Barcella, a prominent defense lawyer in Washington. ``Or were you just going to give a very good lawyer an opportunity to cross-examine him.'' Generally, the accused would be expected to testify ``if you've got a case where the only person who can explain things is the defendant,'' Barcella said. ``But here you have all kinds of people who were explaining the events.'' Poindexter is accused of conspiring to obstruct congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair by lying and destroying documents. He also is accused of making false statements in meetings with lawmakers and in a letter to Congress denying that North was secretly helping the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. Another danger Poindexter avoids is the possibility of a perjury charge if he contradicted sworn testimony he gave congressional hearings about the Iran-Contra affair in 1987, Rothstein said. Poindexter told lawmakers he didn't tell President Reagan about the diversion of U.S.-Iran arms sale profits to the rebels. Poindexter testified then that he kept Reagan in the dark to give the president credible deniability if the covert Contra aid operation were exposed. But Rothstein said that version of events doesn't support Poindexter's contention that he had no motive to lie to Congress because he acted with Reagan's authority. And he would be courting a perjury charge if he provided a different explanation to the jury, Rothstein said. The defense tried to show that a 1986 meeting with lawmakers, at which Poindexter is accused of lying, was really a formal congressional proceeding to which the former national security adviser made false statements about the Iran-Contra affair. It raised the possibility that the document North said he saw Poindexter tear up was not a politically embarrassing document signed by Reagan that authorized U.S. involvement in a 1985 shipment of Israeli Hawk missiles to Iran. The defense also tried to suggest the document was superseded by two other documents Reagan signed in 1986 to authorize U.S.-Iran arms sales. The defense ``had a lot of alternative explanations that raised doubts,'' Rothstein said. ``All of these can coexist as long as Poindexter doesn't take the stand,'' he said. ``But if Poindexter took the stand he would have to commit himself to one of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Scholar Says Presidents Hampered In Hiring Help
DOC.TEXT: President Bush takes about four times longer than John Kennedy to fill his administration's top jobs, but much of the delay is because of ethics laws, snooping reporters and _ yes _ politics, a presidential scholar says. ``We find ourselves ... with a presidential appointment process that greatly complicates and elongates the change in policy directions that democratic elections are designed to permit,'' G. Calvin Mackenzie wrote in the April issue of Government Executive magazine. ``Procedural changes, new legislation, escalating media scrutiny and more complex politics have all slowed the appointment process,'' said Mackenzie, a professor of government at Colby College in Waterville, Maine. ``The Bush administration has survived this process because it took over a friendly government and brought no great agenda for change,'' said the author. ``But the consequences of this new complexity would not have been viewed with such equanimity if a Democrat had won in 1988, nor will they be so viewed in future transitions where the government changes hands from one party to another.'' The time it takes to fill a position by presidential appointment and Senate confirmation has lengthened steadily since the administration of President Kennedy, wrote Mackenzie, director of the presidential appointee project of the National Academy of Public Administration. After Kennedy's election in 1960, it took 2.38 months for the average appointee to a high-ranking job to be confirmed by the Senate, Mackenzie wrote. In Bush's case, it will be more than eight months. Figures for other presidents who entered the White House by election during the period were 3.39 months for Nixon, 4.55 months for Carter and 5.30 months for Reagan. The figures were based on a study of 964 nominees during the five administrations, covering more than half of the appointments to positions at the assistant secretary or deputy director level or above in departments and major agencies. Mackenzie said that ``the White House does not deserve all the blame it has received for the slowdown.'' ``Both the Reagan and Bush transitions have been slowed by the impact of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 and subsequent efforts to tighten even further the regulations of the actions and personal finances of executive branch officials,'' he wrote. The article said an increasing amount of time is taken up explaining the rules to potential appointees, completing and reviewing financial disclosure forms, and altering investment portfolios to avoid conflicts of interest. Chase Untermeyer, director of presidential personnel at the White House, was described as believing that the attention to ethics was ``a principal cause of delay in making appointments'' early in 1989. The article said staffing of the Bush administration also ``took off much more slowly than Reagan's efforts in 1981'' because Bush chose not to have extensive personnel recruiting processes developed months in advance of his election, as Reagan and Carter did.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,026.16, down 237.41 points, or 0.75 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Being Average Weight Increases Heart Attack Risk
With PM-Cancer Sabotage, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The thinner the better. That's the conclusion of a study released today on U.S. women and their risk of heart attack. ``Average weight is overweight when it comes to heart attack risk, and being even mildly to moderately overweight substantially increases the risk in women,'' said Dr. JoAnn E. Manson, who directed the study at Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital. In fact, the study blames 40 percent of all heart disease among women on the consequences of being too heavy. Carrying just a little extra weight or even being average size makes people more vulnerable to heart trouble. Manson's findings were part of the Nurses' Health Study, an eight-year review of 115,886 healthy U.S. women, aged 30 to 55. The researchers divided the women into five weight categories and counted the number who had heart attacks or developed chest pain. The results were published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. The leanest one-fifth of the women in the study weighed in at 5 percent or more below the 1983 Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. tables of desirable weights. A 5-foot-4 woman in this category weighed less than 125 pounds. These slim women suffered the fewest heart attacks. Those considered in the tables to be average weight _ about 130 pounds for a 5-foot-4 woman _ had 30 percent more heart disease than did the thinnest women. Mildly obese women fared substantially worse. Those who were 15 percent to 29 percent above their desirable weights had 80 percent more heart disease. And the heaviest women _ those 30 percent or more over their ideal weights _ had more than three times the lean women's risk. Putting on weight during middle age appears to be especially risky. The study found that women who gained more than 20 pounds since age 18 doubled their risk of heart attacks. Although the report is not the first to suggest that being chubby is bad for the heart, it suggests that the hazard may be greater than previously thought, especially for women. ``Obesity is a major cause of heart attacks in U.S. women,'' said Manson. ``The risks of obesity have been underestimated and underappreciated.'' In an accompanying editorial in the journal, Dr. Theodore B. VanItallie of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York agreed that doctors have failed to take obesity seriously enough. But because of the latest study, he said, ``any remaining confidence that some degree of obesity in women is safe is likely to be replaced by deep concern.'' The study concludes that obesity is harmful to women largely because it increases blood pressure, raises cholesterol levels and contributes to diabetes. About 34 million U.S. adults are considered to be obese because their weight is 20 percent or more above their desirable level. Whether fat is bad for men's hearts, too, is unclear, because studies have produced conflicting results. Heart attacks are the leading killer in the United States. About 987,000 men and 513,000 women suffer heart attacks annually. Gaining weight is a common condition of aging. Only about one-fifth of young women are considered to be overweight, but this increases to one-third by middle age. The researchers said that because weight is so hard to take off and keep off, women should be encouraged to keep from adding extra pounds as they grow older. ``No one should minimize the difficulty of avoiding the weight gain that comes with middle age,'' Manson said. ``But with a good deal of effort, this is potentially preventable.''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Dividend Proves Elusive, Even in Army Surplus Store
DOC.TEXT: If your mother wears Army boots, they're not getting any cheaper _ peace dividend or not. Last year's outbreak of democracy in Eastern Europe, coupled with hopes for wrapping up assorted minor wars around the globe, could still produce big savings from the Pentagon budget, someday. And Third World generals may be able to strike great deals for the secondhand tanks and late-model fighters about to be made unwelcome in Europe, if conventional arms talks stay on track. But when Sunny's Surplus in Georgetown trumpets ``World Peace Means Bigger Savings For You'' in its posters and television ads, it turns out they're making a little joke. Sorry, prices are not tumbling on army boots or canteen belts thrown aside by unemployed Cold War soldiers. Store manager Mike Carpenter, patiently explaining the humor in an interview at his two-floor emporium of tents, trenchcoats and camouflage hats, said he hadn't really noticed any price drops since the Berlin Wall's demise. For that matter, most of the store's merchandise, such as sweatshirts and socks, is surplus or seconds from some civilian manufacturer, not anybody's army or navy. Gamely, Carpenter suggested that prices for army-surplus type goods are not as high as they would be if, say, Vietnam or World War III were in progress right this minute. ``It makes the prices a lot lower. You can buy a decent entrenching tool for $4.99 on up,'' he said, grabbing a folding shovel originally made for the Dutch army. Then he looked around at other piles of clothing and gear and asked, ``What are they going to use this stuff for?'' The store's advertising campaign shows a smiling soldier in helmet, pack and army boots, collecting gear on a deserted battlefield, presumably to be sold at bargain prices back in Washington. Too bad it hasn't worked out. But Sunny's is still probably the only boutique in swank Georgetown where you can buy West German wool pants for just $14.99, U.S. Navy sailor middies for as little as $2.99 or a heavy Army raincoat for under $20. That could be enough to get by until the peace dividend check comes in the mail.

DOC.HEAD: Appliance Recalls Shake Japan as High Tech Outraces Inspectors
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The race to cram more technology and power into Japanese television sets and computers sometimes has left quality inspectors behind, leading to smoking appliances and an embarrassing wave of recalls. The recalls, following a series late last year involving some new model Japanese cars with faulty parts, have revived recollections of a time when ``made in Japan'' was a label of derision in the United States. Since January, four Japanese electronics giants _ Sony Corp., Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Pioneer Electronics Corp., and Toshiba Corp. _ have issued nationwide public notices recalling hundreds of thousands of color TV sets that suddenly smoked or caused minor fires. Seiko Epson Corp. recalled laptop computers that smoked. None of the recalls affected products exported to the United States. Most were made for the domestic market, and some were shipped to Taiwan. ``Safety for consumers has been ignored while (companies) concentrate on technology and sales to survive in the competitive market,'' said Michiko Aoyama, a director at the government-backed Japan Consumer Information Center. ``I'm afraid the quality of Japanese products is declining due to imperfect quality control that cannot catch up with the speed of technological advance,'' she said. Toshiba spokesman Yuji Wakayama said: ``We have tried so hard to add as many features as possible while reducing the cost as low as possible. The accidents mean production under such conditions has reached the limit.'' With the increasing popularity of home videos, electronics companies have been making larger screen televisions that require higher voltage. The recent smoking cases were traced to defects in high-voltage circuits. Late last year, Toyota recalled thousands of its luxury Lexus cars in the United States after defects were found in the cruise-control mechanism and a brake light. Nissan earlier recalled nearly 38,000 cars in Japan. The most recent recalls brought a warning from the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. It told the Electronic Industries Association of Japan, which groups 600 manufacturers, to investigate thoroughly, tighten safety and quality control, and adopt regular procedures for recalls. On Wednesday, a special committee of the association announced a draft for tighter safety standards in TV sets' high-voltage circuits, to be adopted voluntarily by 11 Japanese manufacturers, and standardized procedures to handle defects. The changes could be reflected in new products within one year, said Ryuji Iwasaki, the association's vice president. ``Generally speaking, our new voluntary safety standards require a substantial change in designs and production,'' said Hiroshi Wada, Sharp Corp.'s director of product planning. This probably would result in a 2 percent price increase, he added. Except for motor vehicles, Japan has no law or government guidelines on recalls or reporting of defects in products, giving companies a great deal of leeway in responding to problems. ``We think it is our mission to repair defects to ease our conscience,'' Toshiba's Wakayama said. He added, however, that while the problem televisions smoked or burned the tables on which they sat, they ``did not kill and hurt people, or burn down houses.'' Industry and trade ministry official Takashi Yonehara said: ``The recent TV accidents resulted mainly from complex designs and lack of quality controls.'' In the ministry's last annual inspection, more than 30 percent of manufacturers were found to have violated government safety standards in products, and MITI will start announcing the names of violators, he added. A government report in February criticized companies for not promptly giving public notice and reporting defects to industry and trade officials. Pioneer quietly began repairs for 9,135 defective TV sets last spring, and already had fixed some 8,000 before issuing a public recall notice nine months later, company officials acknowledged. Sony's public recall notices for six color TV models came almost four months after the first report last October of a Sony set starting to smolder in a home in western Japan. Sony said it took time to trace the problem to a high-voltage component that had a tendency to overheat after long use. ``We admit our reaction was not quick enough. ... I guess we could have done better,'' said Koichi Izukura, a Sony spokesman. Naokazu Takeuchi, spokesman for the Japan Consumer Union, one of the largest Japanese consumer groups, argues that notification of possible dangers should come before anything else. He also says the government should help process consumer claims, to speed remedies and spread information more widely. Atsushi Nakamura, a spokesman for the Japan Bar Association, said consumers should be protected by a product liability law, as in the United States, so that victims of product defects do not have to settle for small compensation from manufacturers. Industry and trade official Tomosaburo Yano said the ministry has urged electronics and auto makers unofficially to make safety a top priority when considering whether to recall their products. ``Companies that don't work hard to improve their products will become losers in the market,'' Yano said.

DOC.HEAD: First Soviet Visit to Secretive US Nuclear Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: In a sign of the Cold War's passing, the Bush administration is opening the doors today of the long-secret Savannah River nuclear weapons plant to Soviet officials. The Soviet delegation is visiting the South Carolina installation and other U.S. defense nuclear facilities this week as part of a fact-finding mission designed to exchange information on ways of handling and disposing of radioactive wastes. For most of its nearly four decades of operation, the Savannah River plant has been one of the most secretive sites in the nation. It contains three reactors that produce tritium, a gas needed in the production of nuclear warheads. The reactors have been shut down for two years for safety reasons but are being repaired. Also on the site are a weapons laboratory, a Navy nuclear fuel processing plant, facilities for disassembling retired nuclear warheads and related operations. The Soviet delegation, led by Boris V. Nikipelov, first deputy minister of atomic energy and industry, was to be briefed by U.S. officials at Savannah River on nuclear waste management and disposal programs and other environmental activities. Bob Griffin, an Energy Department spokesman, said the Soviets would not tour the nuclear reactors at Savannah River, which are in a restricted area that can be entered only by U.S. personnel with the highest security clearances. Griffin said it was the first time Soviet government officials had visited Savannah River, although Soviets have toured other parts of the nuclear weapons complex, which includes 17 production facilities and research laboratories in 12 states. The Savannah River visit is part of a four-stop tour for the Soviets, who arrived in Washington on Monday at the invitation of Energy Secretary James D. Watkins. The Soviets visited the Oak Ridge nuclear weapons complex in Tennessee on Wednesday and are scheduled to travel Friday to Carlsbad, N.M., where the Energy Department is building an underground facility to permanently store nuclear wastes. A U.S. government delegation plans a reciprocal visit to the Soviet Union in May or June, Griffin said.

DOC.HEAD: Abolishes Censorship, Allows Expatriates To Regain Citizenship
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has changed a law under which Czechoslovakia's former hard-line Communist leadership stripped thousands of people of their citizenship after they fled the Soviet-led invasion in 1968. Parliament on Wednesday also enacted a press law abolishing censorship, which was installed following the invasion. The moves were the latest by the non-Communist government, which took office in December following a popular uprising, to rid itself of four decades of Communist control. According to the new law of citizenship, Czechoslovaks can be stripped of their citizenship only at their own request. Thousands fled the country after Warsaw Pact tanks crushed the Communist-led Prague Spring reforms and installed a hard-line government. According to the new law, those people may regain their citizenship by the end of 1993. On Wednesday, the Parliament also passed laws allowing Czechoslovaks and foreigners to publish their own periodicals. However, deputies left intact a constitutional provision that radio, television and the film industry _ controlled for decades by the Communists _ are national property. Parliament also approved an amendment to the law on copyright which will, for the first time, also apply to comptuter software, and revised a law on citizenship. Deputies also approved a law opening domestic flights to airlines other that the official Czechoslovak Airlines and Slovair. Other organizations now will be able to compete with the established airlines but must seek permission from the Federal Transport Ministry, the official news agency CTK reported.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Suggests Taking Lithuania Status to World Court
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration should seek an international court ruling that the Soviet Union would have to observe on the status of Lithuania, Sen.
