Daniel Patrick Moynihan says. ``I do ask why no one in the administration seems the least interested in pursuing a legal approach to a settlement of the Lithuanian issue,'' the New York Democrat said Wednesday in a speech at the National Press Club. Moynihan is among the growing number of lawmakers of both parties who are concerned that President Bush isn't doing enough for Lithuania, a Baltic state that has declared its independence from the Soviet Union. Soviet troops have been dispatched to the rebel republic. Bush met Wednesday with Republican lawmakers and then had a separate session with four House members who work with the informal Baltic Freedom Caucus. Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, assistant House Republican leader, said GOP members had a ``very spirited exchange'' over Lithuania. Gingrich said he was persuaded after the Bush meeting that any overt U.S. action _ such as formal recognition of Lithuania _ would trigger the immediate use of force against Lithuania by the Soviet army. Rep. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., a Lithuanian-American who wants the United States to grant immediate recognition to Lithuania, said his meeting with Bush was ``frank and candid.'' He said Bush didn't seem willing to recognize Lithuania as an independent state but indicated a willingness to take an interim step, such as meeting with a Lithuanian diplomat. ``A symbolic gesture is important,'' Durbin said. Moynihan promoted his novel approach. History has shown that the Soviet Union paid $7.5 million in gold dollars to Germany for Lithuania in 1939, an illegal act, Moynihan said. ``The administration cannot seem to grasp that at its core this is an issue which involves violations of law,'' he said. He suggested asking the U.N. General Assembly to request an opinion from the International Court of Justice on the issue. ``Only by holding (Soviet leader Mikhail) Gorbachev to his own professions about international law can we provide him with a way out of the situation he finds himself in,'' Moynihan said. ``The point is to do something. Now.'' Some members of Congress were reluctant to criticize Bush. ``I don't criticize the president at this moment in recognizing that circumstances are very delicate, very serious, and I think he (Bush) could be given the benefit of the doubt as he deals with this,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. ``The president is correct not to be rattled by day-to-day events in the Soviet Union,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. But Durbin said he sensed that Congress is becoming increasingly agitated over Lithuania, particularly since Gorbachev's decision to expel foreigners from the republic. ``The bottom line is that we ought to be standing by the Lithuanian people,'' said Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla. Last week, the Senate passed a non-binding resolution that called on Bush to ``consider the call of the elected Lithuanian government for recognition.'' First, however, senators rejected a tougher measure seeking to pressure the president into giving Lithuania immediate diplomatic recognition. The House is preparing to debate later this week a companion resolution that asks Bush to plan for normalizing diplomatic relations with Lithuania and to take steps in that direction. Lithuania maintains a two-member diplomatic office in Washington. In an explanation of the status of the Lithuanian legation issued Wednesday night, the State Department underscored the United States' longstanding refusal to recognize the Soviet takeover of Lithuania. It described Stasys Lozoraitis, the head of the legation, as the fully accredited representative of the last free government of Lithuania and as head of the Lithuanian diplomatic service. ``He enjoys the confidence of the president of the Lithuanian Supreme Council,'' Vytautas Landsbergis, the brief statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Hawke Set For Record Fourth Consecutive Term; Peacock Concedes
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke formally claimed an election victory today, ending five days of political uncertainty and setting his Labor Party to govern for a record fourth straight term. Hawke said he informed Governor-General Bill Hayden it was clear from Saturday's election that he had a workable majority in the 148-seat House of Representatives, which choses the government. In his statement, the 60-year-old prime minister said Hayden agreed he had won. Hawke, in power since 1983, said he expected to announce his new Cabinet before next Wednesday. Andrew Peacock, who came close to becoming the next prime minister, conceded defeat and said he will resign as head of the conservative opposition. It was Peacock's second attempt to become prime minister. The 51-year-old Liberal Party leader had allied his party with the National Party for the race. Hawke said the vote would set the course for Australian politics into the 21st century. ``It is the commitment of myself and my colleagues that we will, from the first day of the new government, set about undertaking the hard work needed to secure an Australian future of greater prosperity, social justice, fairness and security,'' Hawke said. Peacock had attacked the government for 18 percent interest rates and a $100 billion foreign debt. At a news conference in Melbourne, Peacock congratulated Hawke on his success and said he hoped the Labor government will live up to its election promises to Australia's 16.5 million people. A final tally of seats is still not in, but according to political analysts Labor was expected to have 77 seats against 70 for the coalition, with one going to an independent. Labor previously had 85 seats in the lower house. Peacock said he will quit Tuesday as leader of the Liberal Party and head of the opposition coalition. Political analysts said it may mark the end of a 26-year career for Peacock in politics. ``It is now clear that Labor has won the election,'' Peacock said. ``I congratulate Mr. Hawke on his success and I trust for Australia's sake that Labor will govern well. ``Some of you have wondered why we have delayed making this announcement. I can tell you it has been no pleasure but the fact is it has been extremely close.'' Peacock would not speculate about his replacement. The final outcome has been delayed by the counting of mailed ballots from Australians residents overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says Patient's Wakeup From Coma Still A Mystery
DOC.TEXT: The doctor of a man revived by tranquilizers after eight years in a vegatativelike state cautioned against raised hopes the treatment would help other brain-damaged people. ``It makes me nervous that people are going to see this as a possibility'' for treating such patients, Dr. Andres Kanner, a University of Wisconsin neurologist, said Wednesday. ``I think we are getting excited prematurely. ``Every patient is different. Why this happened with this patient, we don't know.'' After the case was reported Tuesday, the university received inquiries from around the world, said hospital spokeswoman Priscilla Arsove. Kanner said the 45-year-old man was awakened temporarily after being injected with Valium during a routine dental procedure March 12. The patient, a former airline pilot who is married with children, had suffered injuries in a car wreck 10 years ago. He was in a coma for about three months after the accident, then improved, but lapsed into a vegetativelike state about eight years ago, the doctor said. The patient, whose identity was being withheld at his family's request, was being cared for in a nursing home when the drug was administered, the doctor said. Kanner said the patient is being observed at University Hospital and Clinics in Madison, and doctors are experimenting to find the right dose of tranquilizers that would allow him to return home. When medicated, the man has remained fully conscious for up to 12 hours at a time, Kanner said. During the initial discovery, he was able to walk with assistance, talk and perform complicated math calculations. When not treated with the medication, he returns to the vegetativelike state, Kanner said. The patient remained in that state Wednesday while doctors experimented with oral administration of the drugs, Kanner said. But that procedure so far has not had the same effect as when the drugs were introduced intravenously. The doctors will experiment with dosage levels for a few weeks. But continuous injections of the tranquilizing drugs ``has its risks,'' including depression of the respiratory system or heart, Kanner said. A vegetative state is different from a coma because vegetative patients have sleeping and waking patterns, often open their eyes and sometimes utter words, experts said. Kanner said Wednesday the man was in a ``vegetativelike state'' rather than a ``true vegetative state.'' The man had some reactions that would not be characteristic of someone in a permanent vegetative state, Kanner said. For example, he would sometimes pull his arm away when someone tried to give him an injection. Experts said the man's reaction should stimulate more research and cause doctors to re-examine some of their patients, but it probably wouldn't have a significant immediate effect on medical practices. ``It must cause caregivers to be more cautious,'' said Dr. Richard Foa of Washington, a member of the American Academy of Neurology's Ethics and Humanity Subcommittee. ``But an anecdote like this wouldn't alter my practice.'' Foa said the vegetative state _ and more particularly the persistent vegetative state _ has been studied as specialists try to narrow the definition of the condition. Usually, a persistent vegetative state patient is given that prognosis after six months to a year. It is a condition that many doctors believe justifies the removal of life support systems, Foa said. Kanner said one theory is that benzodiazepines, such as Valium and barbituates, inhibit certain nervous system functions and may have blocked the effects of the vegetativelike state on the patient. But Dr. Nathan Zasler of the Medical College of Virginia said drugs such as Valium typically would have a worsening effect on vegetative state patients. The American Academy of Neurology in Minneapolis said there were about 10,000 persistent vegetative state patients in the United States in 1988. Dr. Catherine Bontke of the Institute for Rehabilitation and Research in Houston, who is currently caring for four vegetative patients, said she feared the ``freakish'' report would give families of vegetative state patients false hope, ``and as a doctor, that is so painful for me to watch.''

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Urge Stricter Regulation of Lawn, Agricultural Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: Americans deserve better government protection from contamination by chemicals used in lawn care and sold to foreign countries as agricultural pesticides, witnesses told two Senate committees. The Environmental Protection Agency needs to step up its regulation of lawn care chemicals, the General Accounting Office said in a report to a Senate committee on Wednesday. Another Senate panel was told the United States should ban the export of agricultural pesticides that are not permitted for use in this country. The import of produce sprayed with these chemicals is a ``circle of poison,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. The GAO report released by the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee followed a 1986 study that found the EPA had made little progress assessing the health risks of lawn care pesticides. The GAO is the investigative arm of Congress. The earlier report said the EPA had taken little enforcement action against advertising claims made by the pesticide industry. Peter Guerrero, the GAO's associate director for environmental protection issues, said the new report shows the EPA still has more to do. ``We also found that prohibited pesticide claims that EPA classifies as false and misleading are still being made by the lawn care pesticides industry,'' he said. ``Yet, EPA has taken even fewer formal enforcement actions in recent years than it did during the 1984 and 1985 period we reviewed for our earlier report.'' One of the most popular chemicals, diazinon, was disallowed for use on golf courses and sod farms because it killed waterfowl and other birds. After several people were poisoned by diazinon, the EPA required special warnings on its label and said only certified applicators could use it commercially. But Guerrero said the restriction does not apply to commercial lawn care companies and homeowners. A spokesman for the EPA said migratory birds that fed on golf courses were dying, but the agency doesn't have similar evidence against diazinon for birds that light in people's yards. ``The law says you have to prove a substance has reasonable adverse effects before you can take it off the market,'' said Al Heier, the spokesman for EPA. In the Senate Agriculture Committee, witnesses testified on a bill that would stop U.S. companies from exporting agricultural chemicals that are banned in the United States. ``One fourth of the produce we eat is imported,'' said Leahy. ``That's 135 pounds of fruits and vegetables for every man, woman and child.'' An agriculture official from Ecuador supported the bill, saying her country, ``like many developing countries, is not in the condition to guarantee that highly toxic pesticides will be used in even a relatively safe manner.'' Mercedes Bolanos de Moreno, chief of Ecuador's plant protection program, said her country has no national pesticide policy. The United States buys large amounts of bananas, coffee, cocoa and sugar from Ecuador. In the last two years, federal inspectors have found U.S.-banned pesticides in beef from Honduras, pineapples from the Philippines and beans and carrots from Latin America. Jay Vroom, president of the National Agricultural Chemicals Association, defended the industry in testimony at both hearings. ``Some pesticides produced in the United States and sold overseas are unregistered here because the specific pest controlled is not a U.S. problem, or crops concerned are generally not grown in America, like coffee, rubber, cocoa, bananas, tea,'' Vroom said. He said attempts to control how other countries use agricultural chemicals would amount to U.S. imperialism. He told Reid's committee, ``Lawn insecticides greatly contribute to the protection of human health by warding off potentially harmful bugs, such as ticks, mosquitos, fleas, ants and roaches.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Years After Impeachment, Mecham Still Dominates Political Landscape
DOC.TEXT: Two years after he was impeached and removed from office, former Gov. Evan Mecham and his right-wing populist agenda still dominate Arizona's political landscape. Few believe he could win back the governor's office, but Mecham is running hard for the GOP nomination. Meanwhile, the state bureaucracy, ruled by three wildly different governors in the last four years, is virtually paralyzed as it awaits yet another master after November's election. And the Legislature is wrestling with two Mecham legacies _ a $250 million deficit and a battle over a holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. Mecham, campaigning as an outsider battling the ``power brokers'' of state politics, has staked his career on opposition to taxes and government meddling. He won the governorship on his fifth try in a three-way race in 1986 but soon got into trouble by rescinding the state's King holiday and by making remarks that offended blacks, Asians, Hispanics, women and homosexuals. Thirteen months after he took office, the state Senate convicted him on impeachment charges of misusing $80,000 and trying to thwart an investigation of an alleged death threat. He was removed on April 4, 1988. The Senate, however, declined to pass a Dracula clause that would have barred him from running again, and he has risen from his political coffin. ``When the public decides we've had enough even communist dictators are overthrown,'' Mecham said last week during an interview between campaign stops. ``The Mecham Militia is stronger than ever.'' Political analysts say Mecham could win the Sept. 11 primary, given the crowded field. No polls have been taken in more than a month. But in any case, some say, polls have been ineffective in showing Mecham's level of support. ``Evan Mecham has a hard core of supporters that is unidentified in most polls,'' says Rick DeGraw, a Democratic strategist. ``Evan Mecham's voters are not average. Everyone that hates anyone feels comfortable with Evan Mecham. It doesn't matter if they hate trees ... or old people, or lawyers. They'll feel comfortable.'' Mecham has his own woes. The federal government is trying to foreclose on his office building, and a state judge assessed him more than $35,000 in penalties and fees over the allegedly misused funds. But Mecham said of his problems, ``We have it all in hand.'' He added that he has already collected more than $100,000 in campaign funds. The others in the five-way GOP field are millionaire developer Fife Symington, former congressman and Mecham aide Sam Steiger, former Maricopa County Supervisor Fred Koory and former Mecham aide Bob Barnes, a part-time teacher. Symington was the early GOP front-runner. But some say Steiger's recent entry into the GOP race will take more votes from Symington and Koory than from Mecham. Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard is the Democratic front-runner, with businessman David Moss and attorney Ray Brown considered longshots. Gov. Rose Mofford, the former secretary of state who replaced Mecham, declined to run for election. The shift of governors _ from liberal Bruce Babbitt in 1986 to right-wing Mecham in 1987 to the moderate Mofford in 1988 _ has left state agencies adrift, said lobbyist Bill Jamieson, who was Babbitt's chief of cabinet. ``When that happens, the bureaucrats tend to dig in and erect barricades,'' said Jamieson. ``Nobody wants to do anything that the next governor may dislike.'' After a long battle over a proposed King holiday, opponents of the holiday gathered enough signatures to put the issue on the November ballot.

DOC.HEAD: Aides Say Jesse Jackson May Seek Non-Voting Seat From D.C.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, who has ruled out running for mayor of the nation's capital, may try to become its delegate to Congress instead, top aides to the civil rights leader say. Although Jackson issued a denial, sources said Wednesday that he is considering running for the non-voting House seat this fall to boost his presidential prospects and help the District of Columbia's drive for statehood. ``It gives him a base to operate from without eliminating any of his other options, including the possibility of another national campaign,'' said one Jackson associate who like others spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He's seriously considering it.'' Jackson's political plans have been the subject of great speculation since he moved to Washington from Chicago last summer. In February, the two-time Democratic presidential candidate announced he would not run for mayor and stressed his desire to serve as ``a national leader.'' He said Wednesday he not considering the delegate post. However, advisers said Jackson's National Rainbow Coalition is trying to dismantle a city law that would keep him from running for delegate. The law requires that congressional candidates live in the city for three years before seeking the office. One effort is aimed at persuading members of Congress to amend the law and another option under consideration is challenging the law in court, advisers said. ``So far, people on the Hill have been generally receptive,'' one aide said. ``It is a non-controversial law, and changing it should not be difficult.'' The Rainbow Coalition also has asked a law firm to study whether the three-year residency requirement can be challenged on grounds it is stricter than those throughout the rest of the country, aides said. Officials at the law firm did not return calls seeking comment. One Jackson adviser predicted Jackson would make a decision on a congressional run within the next six weeks. Sources said Jackson believes the delegate's job would give him a better opportunity to lobby Capitol Hill for statehood, but that he is unsure whether it would leave him enough time to push voter registration drives or run for president in 1992. Bert Lance, former President Carter's budget director who was an adviser to Jackson's 1988 campaign, said Jackson's presidential chances would be enhanced by first serving in Congress. ``It makes him a peer immediately with all the other office-holders who are likely to run for president,'' Lance said. Lance said he had not talked to Jackson about his political plans recently, but that Jackson considered the delegate's job an option at the time he decided not to run for mayor. The incumbent delegate, Democrat Walter Fauntroy, announced earlier this month he will run for mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Keating, Ungaro, Hall and Shine Involved in Publishing Moves
DOC.TEXT: William J. Keating, president and chief executive officer of the Detroit Newspaper Agency, is returning to Cincinnati as chairman and publisher of the Cincinnati Enquirer. It was one of several newspaper publishing shifts announced Wednesday. Keating, who also serves as chairman of the board of The Associated Press, will be succeeded in Detroit by Joseph M. Ungaro, Gannett Co. Inc., said. Ungaro is a Gannett vice president and president and publisher of its Westchester Rockland (NY) Newspapers. Knight-Ridder Inc. announced that Robert J. Hall, publisher and chairman of the Detroit Free Press, would assume the same duties at Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., the company that publishes the Philadelphia Inquirer and the Philadelphia Daily News. Named to replace Hall was Neal Shine, former senior managing editor of the Free Press who retired last June. Shine has continued to write a column in the newspaper and was teaching at Oakland University in Rochester, Mich. Keating, 62, moved to Detroit from Cincinnati but had retained his post as chairman of the Enquirer. The Detroit Newspaper Agency is responsible for sales, business and production operations for The Detroit News, owned by Gannett, and The Detroit Free Press, owned by Knight-Ridder. The two papers are under a joint operating agreement which was upheld by the Supreme Court in November 1989. Keating was named to his Detroit Newspaper Agency post in 1986. Previously, he was publisher and president of The Enquirer in Cincinnati and a regional president of Gannett from 1979 to 1984. Before that he was president and CEO of the paper from 1974 to 1979. As publisher in Cincinnati, he replaces John Zanotti, who recently resigned to become publisher of the Arizona Republic and Phoenix Gazette. The announcement was made by John Curley, chairman of Gannett and James Batten, chairman of Knight-Ridder. ``Under Keating's direction, the Detroit Newspaper Agency is up and running and we have a budget calling for a profit for the year 1990,'' they said. Ungaro, 59, has been at the Gannett paper in New York since 1974. He is a past president of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association. The Gannett announcement said Ungaro's replacement would be named later.

DOC.HEAD: List's Chilling Letter to Pastor: I Did It for Their Souls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grammar in quotes from letter, L'E. in 3rd graf are cq
DOC.TEXT: John E. List thought he was ensuring salvation for his wife and children by killing them 18 years ago, according to a confession letter released by prosecutors. ``At least I'm certain that all have gone to heaven now,'' List wrote in a 1971 letter to his Lutheran pastor. ``If things had gone on who knows if that would be the case.'' The five-page letter was released Wednesday after Superior Court Judge William L'E. Wertheimer allowed it as evidence in List's murder trial. ``I know that many will only look at the additional years that they could have lived but if finally they were no longer Christians what would be gained,'' List wrote the Rev. Eugene A. Rehwinkel. ``Also, I'm sure many will say, `How could anyone do such a horrible thing.' _ My only answer is it isn't easy and was only done after much thought.'' Police found the bullet-ridden bodies of List's wife, Helen, 45; and children, Patricia, 16; John Jr., 15; and Frederick, 13, lined up on the floor of the ballroom in their 18-room Westfield mansion when they entered the house Dec. 7, 1971. They also found the body of List's 84-year-old mother, Alma, upstairs. ``Of course Mother got involved because doing what I did to my family would have been a tremendous shock to her at this age. Therefore, knowing that she is also a Christian I felt it best that she be relieved of the troubles of this world that would have hit her,'' List wrote. Afterward, List said, he prayed for the family. ``That was the least I could do,'' he wrote. The judge released the letter after denying a defense motion that the document was protected by the priest-penitent privilege. Opening statements are set for Monday. List, arrested in Richmond, Va., in June, argues that he is innocent because of his mental state at the time the slayings occurred. Handwritten in script on yellow-lined paper, the letter was dated Nov. 9, 1971. It had been the subject of intense interest since police found it Dec. 7, 1971, in a filing cabinet in List's mansion. Police read the letter and called Rehwinkel to the house, where they let him read it. List began by apologizing to Rehwinkel for ``this additional burden to your work.'' He said his actions went against all he had been taught and that his account ``will not make it right.'' He then enumerated his reasons. List, then a 46-year-old accountant who was selling insurance, said he wasn't earning enough to support the family, and was near bankruptcy. He also worried about what Patricia's aspirations as an actress ``might do to her continuing to be a Christian.'' And he was upset that his wife said she wanted to remove her name from the church rolls. He gives detailed instructions for funeral arrangements, but returns to religious themes. God could have helped, ``but apparently He saw fit not to answer my prayers,'' he wrote. ``This makes me think that perhaps it was for the best as far as the childrens souls are concerned.'' List said in his letter that he shot his family members from behind because he ``didn't want any of them to know even at the last second that I had to do this to them.'' None suffered, but John Jr. ``got hurt more because he seemed to struggle longer,'' List said. Police said he was shot 10 times. List said he had planned to kill them on All Saints' Day, Nov. 1, ``an appropriate day for them to get to heaven.'' But the day passed, he said, because his travel plans were delayed. He signed it ``John,'' and added a postscript: ``P.S. Mother is in the hallway in the attic-3rd floor. She was too heavy to move.''

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Ban on Civil Jury Trials Called Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: In 1987 Harriet Smith was the victim of a truck accident that left her partially paralyzed, with broken bones and double vision. Now, a budget-cutting measure that put a moratorium on civil jury trials is adding insult to her injuries by frustrating her pursuit of much-needed cash from the driver whose truck hit her. Without that money, the wheelchair-bound mother of two teen-agers cannot receive the extensive physical and other therapy she needs, said her attorney, Mary Kirkpatrick. Smith's lawsuit against the driver and the college he worked for was headed for jury selection on Jan. 22 when the Vermont Supreme Court imposed a five-month ban on civil jury trials at the Legislature's behest. The moratorium should save about $75,000, said Lee Suskin, director of trial court administration. But the Vermont Trial Lawyers Association has filed a class-action lawsuit to overturn it on behalf of 18 Vermont residents, saying the ban violates the constitutional right to speedy trial. ``It has a disruptive effect on people every day,'' said Jerome O'Neill, the lawyers association president. ``They're out there suffering individually and they certainly continue to.'' Requests for civil jury trials are pending from more than 3,000 Vermonters, he said. Similar bans were overturned by the North Dakota Supreme Court in January and by the U.S. Supreme Court several years ago, he said. The association's challenge has been filed in the Vermont Supreme Court _ the court that made the cut. During a typical six-month period, Vermont juries decide about 50 civil trials, which usually involve divorces, property disputes, personal injury claims, malpractice suits and breaches of contract, Suskin said. Hundreds of other cases are settled before they go to trial. O'Neill said the people hurt most by the ban are in cases involving medical expenses and other debts. The ban allows litigants to request an exemption for special cases. Administrative Judge Stephen B. Martin has granted one exemption and is considering Smith's case. Since no trials are being held, lawyers have largely abandoned their civil cases, meaning few out-of-court settlements, Martin said. ``The importance of setting jury cases and jury hearings is to get the parties to come to terms and finally resolve the case,'' Martin said. ``That's where the loss is.'' The ban's impact will be felt long after it is lifted on July 1, he said. ``The attorneys that have jury cases are not giving attention to these files,'' Martin said. ``It's an area of business that the attorneys are not addressing because there's no push from the courts to do so.'' O'Neill said the blame for the moratorium lies not with the Supreme Court, but with the Legislature. ``They did an across-the-board cut and the judiciary didn't have the fat,'' O'Neill said. ``They've had to cut heavily into the meat.'' The Legislature is considering a budget adjustment that would give the judiciary an extra $25,000. Suskin said that money would pay for civil jury trials in May and June. Vermont, with much of New England, is suffering an economic crunch. As part of Gov. Madeleine Kunin's belt-tightening plan, state departments were ordered to cut spending 2.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Said Sleeplessness Among Elderly is Not Inevitability of Age
DOC.TEXT: Disease, emotional distress and poor sleep habits are the cause of sleeplessness among the elderly, not just age alone, according to a new study by a National Institutes of Health panel of experts. ``The (common belief) that you don't need as much sleep as you age is not true,'' said Dr. Robert J. Joynt, vice president of health affairs at the University of Rochester and chairman of the NIH panel that studied sleep problems among the elderly. ``In healthy, older people without an accompanying medical disease, there are very few complaints of sleep disorders,'' Joynt said Wednesday at a news conference. ``Sleep problems are not because of the aging process alone, but because of other diseases.'' Attempts to treat troubled sleep among the elderly often lead to an overuse of drugs or over-the-counter medications that are ineffective or even make the condition worse, the report by the 14-member panel said. More than half of those over 65 who live at home complain of sleep problems, the report said, and in long-term care facilities, such as rest homes, about two-thirds of the patients say they have sleep disorders. And yet, Joynt said, many in medical science know little about normal sleep or how to treat sleep problems. ``Knowledge about sleep and its disorders is lacking and education is needed at all levels,'' including by physicians, he said. In desperate attempts to treat themselves, the panel said, elderly patients often resort to the habitual use of over-the-counter sleep medication. ``They (over-the-counter drugs) are used to deal with the symptoms of sleeplessness,'' said Israel Hanin, a Loyola University professor and the pharmacology expert on the panel. ``These drugs may help to make the patient sleepy, but they have side effects and don't treat the basic cause of sleeplessness.'' Hanin said over-the-counter sleeping pills can cause problems with vision and urination, along with a dry mouth and some heart conditions. And, he said, the pills become ineffective after long use. Powerful prescription sleeping pills are even more dangerous because they can lead to more serious health problems and addiction, the panel said. ``Our report is quite clear in condemnation in the use of sedatives for sleep disorders,'' said Dr. Morton C. Creditor of the University of Kansas Medical Center in Kansas City. ``A major problem we have to deal with is over-medication among the elderly.'' Joynt said that people tend with age to develop a different sleep pattern, but will generally sleep just as much as the young. ``For the elderly, sleep at night may be fragmented and not as deep,'' Joynt said. ``But the elderly often sleep some during the day so that their sleep is about equal'' to that of younger people. Studies, he said, show that many who complain that they can't sleep at night are actually sleeping more than they believed. Sleep problems often are caused by poor sleep habits such as drinking caffeine at night or drinking fluids that cause people to awaken at night to go to the bathroom, Joynt said. The report said exercise, going to bed the same time each night and ``the use of the bedroom primarily for sleeping and sexual activity'' may help. Emotional and social developments may also disrupt sleep. Events such as retirement, depression or changes in natural sleep-rest cycles can lead to sleep disorders. Many sleep problems, the panel said, are caused by medical conditions that must be treated before the sleeplessness will go away. Some of the common physical problems that can interrupt slumber include obesity, alcoholism, breathing difficulty, arthritis and cardiovascular disease. The report called for more research on normal sleep patterns of the elderly. It also said that sleep disorders should be treated by specialists using advanced diagnostic tools, and that there should be controlled clinical trials to evaluate new treatments for sleeplessness.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Broadcasters Back Preferential Awards of Licenses
DOC.TEXT: Minorities say they've gotten a small toehold in broadcasting thanks to 18-year-old rules that give them preference in seeking radio and television station licenses. Once representing just 1 percent of the nation's station owners, minorities now comprise about 3 percent of the people who control what Americans see and hear on the airwaves. The Federal Communications Commission's minority and female preference rules have allowed ``missing voices'' to be heard, backers of the rules told the Supreme Court on Wednesday. Opponents, however, said the rules discriminate against white males. They contended the rules should be dropped and the marketplace should determine the bidding. The two cases involve challenges to broadcast minority preferences in Florida and Connecticut. ``It's clear that the court is very troubled by what the FCC is doing,'' Andrew Schwartzman of the Media Access Project, a supporter of the rules, said following Wednesday's oral arguments. ``It's always dangerous to guess (what the court will decide) but I'm not too optimistic.'' The Supreme Court upheld a federal public works set-aside program in 1980, saying Congress had special authority under the Constitution to enact such programs. But a newly conservative majority court last year struck down a similar set-aside program for minority contractors run by the city of Richmond, Va. One of the court's new conservative justices, Antonin Scalia, took a leading role Wednesday in questioning whether the FCC's policy promotes diverse viewpoints. ``It has to do with nothing but blood,'' Scalia said, ``not background and environment.'' He suggested that a black from a predominantly white community of Scarsdale, N.Y., could receive preferential treatment under the FCC rules. But Margaret Polivy, a lawyer for a Hispanic-owned company in the Florida case, said ``whether you were born in Scarsdale or Harlem contributes to what you believe.'' She said Congress regards women and racial minorities as ``missing voices'' who should be given special consideration in awarding broadcast station licenses. Ms. Polivy represents Rainbow Broadcasting Co., which was awarded a TV license in Orlando, Fla. A rival, Metro Broadcasting Inc., argued unsuccessfully before a federal appeals court that it was denied the license unfairly. Gregory Guillot, Metro's lawyer, said the FCC's affirmative action program ``is a complete, total failure.'' He said the policy has increased minority ownership of television and radio stations by only 1 percent in 18 years. The Connecticut case is a test of the so-called distress sale provisions of the FCC rules, which allow a broadcaster faced with the loss of its license to sell to a minority-owned business at 75 percent of market value. Alan Shurberg, who is white, appealed the award of a Hartford TV station to Hispanic-led Astroline Communications Co. The Federal Communications Commission adopted the rules in 1972 and strengthened them in 1978. The FCC under Reagan-era Chairman Mark S. Fowler tried to rewrite the rules, but Congress said no in 1987. The distress sale provisions were struck down in March 1989 on constitutional grounds by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington. But less than a month later, another three-judge panel of the same court upheld the minority and female preference provisions. The FCC now is defending the rules it had tried to scrap. The commission maintains that by regulating the ownership of broadcast outlets, the government will have an indirect impact on program diversity _ and thereby serve the public interest. Daniel M. Armstrong, FCC associate general counsel, told the court the FCC doesn't exactly know how minority ownership translates into more diverse views, but the agency believes it does in subtle ways, such as through news and public affairs programs.

DOC.HEAD: Boycott Hits Businesses But Major Buyer Sticks With Idaho Potatoes
DOC.TEXT: Some businesses already are snubbing the state over a tough anti-abortion law, but McDonald's Corp. said its french fries will be cut from Idaho potatoes no matter what. Gov. Cecil Andrus said he will act by Saturday on the nation's most restrictive state abortion law, passed last week by the Legislature, and that the boycott by abortion rights supporters will not be the deciding factor in his decision. Some 1,000 abortion rights advocates and 600 anti-abortion activists held separate Capitol rallies Wednesday to sway the governor. Andrus has said he opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest and to save the life of the woman. ``I'm going to do what I think is right,'' Andrus said. ``The economic things, those I'm going to have to handle no matter how it plays out.'' Susan Boresow, regional marketing supervisor for McDonald's Corp., said the company does not involve itself in personal, ethical, political or religious issues and would not take a stand on the Idaho abortion issue. ``Our customers represent all points of view, and we serve all of them,'' she said. McDonald's is a big buyer of Idaho potatoes. But officials from the state's food processing, printing, travel and resort industries have already lost orders, Andrus said. Commerce Director James Hawkins said anti-abortion forces have promised to buy more Idaho products, but those offers won't make up for the boycott threat. Andrus declined to identify the companies affected so far or to give dollar figures for losses. Nationally syndicated radio talk-show host Rush Limbaugh, a conservative, called on his listeners to send a wrapped Idaho potato to Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, who has called for a boycott if the bill is passed. In West Virginia, anti-abortion activists are adding bags of Idaho potatoes to their grocery lists. ``We're issuing a challenge to the God-fearing people of West Virginia,'' said Avis Hill, spokesman for the 200-member West Virginia Parents for Life. ``We're saying to them, if they choose not to buy Idaho potatoes, we'll buy an extra bag and give it to a food pantry.'' The bill would ban 90 percent of the more than 1,500 abortions performed in the state each year. Abortion would be banned except in cases of nonstatutory rape reported within seven days; incest if the victim is under 18; severe fetal deformity and a threat to the life or physical health of the woman. It would take effect July 1. Abortion rights activists promise to challenge the law in what could provide the U.S. Supreme Court the context it needs to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Conference on Women's Health Issues Canceled over Abortion Picket Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ACLU plans news conference at 1 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: A conference on women's health issues was canceled out of concern that anti-abortion picketing would embarrass one of the sponsoring organizations, a participant in the conference said. Organizers assumed that Grand Canyon University, which has Baptist affiliation, would want to call off the two-day conference that was scheduled to begin today when they heard about the pickets, said Bill Byron, a spokesman for Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center. But it turned out university officials were not opposed to the conference proceeding, Byron said. The medical center was another sponsor of the conference. The Fourth Annual Conference on Woman and Her Family was to have dealt with issues such as infertility, prenatal care and access to care by the poor. ``Although the conference did not concern the issue of abortion, it appears that the opponents of abortion rights have decided to shut down all discussion on the legal issues surrounding fetuses, even those dealing with carrying a fetus to term and how to combat infant mortality,'' the Arizona branch of the American Civil Liberties Union said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Serrano Sworn in as Congressman from Nation's Poorest District
DOC.TEXT: Moments after being sworn in, Rep. Jose Serrano, D-N.Y., said the first thing he wants to do in his new job is go home to the South Bronx and talk to children. ``Part of what I want to do is go right back into the classroom and tell kids all about this experience,'' Serrano said. He took the oath of office Wednesday, the 38th anniversary of his mother's arrival in New York from Puerto Rico to join her husband and seek a better life. ``Let the message go from here today to those children who are still in the projects and who are on the street corner that there is a better tomorrow,'' Serrano told the House of Representatives after the swearing-in. He was joined on the House floor with three of his five children. His wife, Mary, brother, other children and about 200 campaign workers stood in the gallery and cheered. Serrano, 46, won a landslide victory in a special election March 20 to fill the seat vacated in January when Rep. Robert Garcia, D-N.Y., resigned. Garcia was convicted of accepting bribes in the Wedtech influence-peddling scandal. Serrano is the only voting Puerto Rican-born member of Congress. His swearing-in came one day after Susan Molinari, a Staten Island Republican, took her oath of office. At 32, she is the youngest member of Congress.
DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Baker Has Malignant Growth Removed
DOC.TEXT: Joy Baker, wife of former Senate Republican Leader Howard H. Baker Jr., has had a small malignant growth removed from her right lung. The tumor was removed Wednesday during a 90-minute operation by Mayo Clinic doctors at St. Marys Hospital in Rochester, Minn., said spokesman Tom Griscom. A source familiar with her case, who did not wish to be identified by name, said the growth was ``a low grade tumor'' not a recurrence of the cancer that was removed from the same lung in 1982. She is not expected to require additional treatment, the source said. Mrs. Baker is the daughter of the late Senate Republican leader Everett Dirksen of Illinois. Howard Baker served in the Senate from 1966 until 1984 and was President Reagan's White House chief of staff from February 1987 until July 1988. The Bakers' primary residence is in Huntsville, Tenn., but they also maintain a home in Washington, where Baker practices law.
DOC.HEAD: Outspoken Civil Rights Champion to Retire
DOC.TEXT: Rep. George W. Crockett Jr., D-Mich., who came to Congress at age 70 after a controversial career as civil rights attorney and judge, says he will retire after his term expires next year. ``There is a time ... when each man or woman must decide to leave the day-to-day struggle to others,'' the 80-year-old chairman of the House Western Hemisphere Affairs Subcommittee said Wednesday. Crockett had announced his candidacy for a sixth term but faced at least two challengers for the Democratic nomination in his predominantly black Detroit district, which could be eliminated as districts are reapportioned in 1992. He said in an interview the prospect of a tough campaign did not influence his change of heart. ``I've just gotten older and wiser,'' he said. Crockett recently became the first member of Congress to advocate decriminalizing drug use, the latest of many stands that outraged conservatives and even made some fellow liberals uneasy. He gained national attention in 1949 for his spirited defense of 11 avowed communists charged with subversion in New York. His clashes with the presiding judge landed him and four other defense lawyers in prison for four months on contempt charges.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania's President Tells Citizens Not To Resist Arms Confiscations
DOC.TEXT: Hoping to defuse weeks of tension with Moscow, Lithuania's president has told citizens of the Baltic republic not to resist if Soviet troops tried to confiscate their weapons. A deadline set by the Kremlin passed Wednesday without incident in the republic, which has been at odds with Moscow since it independence March 11. Both sides showed restraint Wednesday, with Lithuania also shelving plans for border guards and the Soviet army refraining from seizing more Lithuanian buildings or rounding up more military deserters in the republic. ``At present, establishing border points would be stepping up confrontation,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told a news conference in the capital of Vilnius. Landsbergis said he advised Lithuanians not to resist if Soviet authorities came to seize their hunting guns. At the same time, he said citizens should treat the officials as uninvited guests. This is in keeping with the Lithuanian strategy of refusing to obey ``foreign'' Soviet law while avoiding violent conflicts. The developments came a day after the first violent confrontations in the standoff with the republic, with Soviet troops raiding two hospitals and rounding up at least 23 deserters. In Moscow, the Soviet military stepped up a war of words against Lithuania, complaining of increased attacks on soldiers and accusing it of a campaign to discredit the Soviet army. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has promised not to use force to keep Lithuania from breaking away, ordered the sign-up for the border guard halted as soon as it began. In the same decree last week, he ordered Lithuanians to turn in their weapons and said those not surrendered by Wednesday would be confiscated. Only about 1,000 of the 30,000 guns registered in Lithuanian have been turned in to local police, said a Lithuanian Interior Ministry official, Yaroslav Prokopovich. He said local police were refusing to hand them over to the Soviet Army as Gorbachev ordered. In Moscow, the commander of Soviet paratroopers alleged there had been an increase in attacks on soldiers since the independence declaration. The Soviet news agency Tass said Col. Gen. Vladislav Achalov reported ``a noticeable increase in incidents of provocation against soldiers and armed attacks by groups of young hooligans against both individual soldiers and military sites.'' He listed three recent attacks in Kaunas, Lithuania's second-biggest city. Two of the cases involved ``hooligans'' throwing stones at military guards, he said. The Ukrainian republic's popular movement Rukh threw its support behind Lithuania's new government and urged rallies to support its independence. But Tass said the Ukrainian government asked local authorities to ban the rallies. Independence movements in several of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, including Lithuania's Baltic neighbors Estonia and Latvia, are posing a stiff challenge to Gorbachev. Ironically, Gorbachev's political reform since he came to power in 1985 had in part paved the way for such dissent. In Washington, the State Department on Wednesday night underscored the United States' long-standing refusal to recognize the Soviet takeover of Lithuania in 1940. The Soviets crushed the then-independent Baltic republics after signing a pact with the Nazis. In an explanation of the status of Lithuanian representatives in the United States, the State Department described legation chief Stasys Lozoraitis as the fully accredited representative of the last free government of Lithuania and as head of the Lithuanian diplomatic service. ``He enjoys the confidence of the president of the Lithuanian Supreme Council,'' Landsbergis said a brief statement issued in Washington. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday spoke with Gorbachev by phone for 50 minutes and urged restraint by both Kremlin and Lithuanian officials, Mrs. Thatcher's office said. The Soviet Defense Ministry reiterated that the government considers Lithuania's declaration of independence invalid. ``No one should have any doubt that law and order will be restored on Lithuanian territory,'' said the statement, which was published in national newspapers. Gen. Valentin I. Varennikov, commander of Soviet land forces in Lithuania, said the 23 deserters were seized when Soviet troops raided two psychiatric hospitals in Lithuania. He contended they had become ``militants'' in the nationalist movement and were ``undergoing special training'' at one of the hospitals. Witnesses said some of the deserters were beaten as they were taken away, the first violence since the standoff between Lithuania and the Kremlin began.

DOC.HEAD: Vermonters Vote To Secede From Union
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev isn't the only superpower leader with secession troubles. Vermont has voted, 999-598, to quit the United States. People gathered Wednesday night at the Statehouse to hear the last of seven statewide debates on whether they should work from within to reinvigorate U.S. politics or opt out. ``Will Vermont become another Lithuania?'' state Rep. Bill Mares asked as he introduced the principal debaters. The answer is no. The debates have been a warmup to next March's 200th anniversary of Vermont statehood. And the vote to secede simply was a fun exercise in civics. Frank Bryan, a University of Vermont political science professor, argued for secession. The political culture is moribund, he said, and Congress is ``brain dead.'' ``The United States needs a sharp slap in the face,'' Bryan said. ``A century hence, America will say of us, `Thanks, Vermont, we needed that.''' Justice John Dooley of the Vermont Supreme Court argued for staying in. Vermont farmers need the national market, he said, and its elderly need Social Security. At the close of each debate, the audience has been asked to vote on the question. Each time, secession has won. The vote total was the sum of all seven ballots. A key question when considering secession would be, ``Can we get away with it?'' Bryan said. ``Vermonters are very, very practical people. We know there's no sense trying something unless you can get away with it.'' On that point, Dooley quoted a letter from a man in Georgia. ``You may have heard of an organization called the Confederate States of America,'' the letter said. ``As for secession, forget about it. We tried it, and it didn't work out too well.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court President Says Democracy Demonstrators Tried Fairly
DOC.TEXT: China's chief justice today condemned Western countries for their ``vicious slanders'' against his country's legal system and said last year's pro-democracy demonstrators received fair trials. ``The hegemonists accused us of conducting secret interrogations, handing out secret verdicts, refusing to conduct fair, open trials, and extensively trampling on human rights,'' Ren Jianxin, president of the Supreme People's Court, said in his annual report on crime. The human rights group Amnesty International, in a report released last month, said tens of thousands have been arrested since troops shot their way into Beijing in June to put down the massive pro-democracy movement, killing hundreds and possibly thousands of people. The report said authorities conducted arbitrary arrests, detained prisoners without charge or trial and imprisoned or executed others after unfair trials. Another group, Asia Watch, said thousands are languishing in cramped cells and being tortured by prison guards. ``These accusations are deliberate fabrications and absolutely groundless. These are vicious slanders on China's judicial organs and judicial system,'' Ren told the National People's Congress, China's legislature, which is holding its annual two-week session in Beijing. He said all the proceedings were handled according to criminal procedural law, and all cases that were supposed to be tried openly were public, ``thus ensuring fair judgments on them.'' However, reporters' requests to attend such trials have been repeatedly rejected. Liu Fuzhi, head of the Supreme People's Procuratorate, or prosecutor's office, said demonstrators ``who made radical statements but did not violate the criminal law'' were not brought to trial. Liu said parts of China saw ``dramatic increases'' in crime, including murder, robbery, rape and gang activity, but he did not provide details or numbers. Ren said juvenile delinquency is on the rise, but also did not give statistics. Last year, Chinese courts handled 2.9 million cases, a 27 percent increase over the previous year. Of those, 1,815,300 were civil cases, also a 27 percent increase over 1988, and 694,900 were economic cases, up 35 percent from the previous year. Eighty percent of civil and economic cases were settled through mediation, Ren said. The economic cases that were settled involved a total of $4.6 billion, a staggering 84 percent increase over 1988. More than 105,000 people were sentenced in those cases, 31 to death for embezzling large amounts of public funds or taking bribes. Pro-democracy demonstrators last year had called for a fight against corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Damage to Satellite `Skin-Deep' After Nearly Six Years in Space
DOC.TEXT: A scientific satellite that spent nearly six years in orbit suffered mostly surface damage, demonstrating the feasibility of a manned space station, a NASA scientist says. On Tuesday, technicians from the National Aeronautics and Space Administation removed the last of 57 science and techonology experiments from the space lab, known as the Long Duration Exposure Facility. ``The surprising thing to us is although there was a lot of weathering apparent on the outside, most of that weathering was really only skin-deep,'' William Kinard, chief scientist for the LDEF, said on Wednesday. A NASA study concluded recently that the proposed space station Freedom would begin falling apart before completion and would need extensive maintenance in space. But Kinard said the space lab had fared well in space, boding well for Freedom. ``All of our systems have survived better I think than predicted so you might expect the same thing from the space station,'' he said. ``The survivability of materials and systems in space is pretty good.'' Kinard said concern about Freedom is ``healthy'' but problems of duration in space can be resolved. The space station is expected to cost $30 billion by the time its completed and manned in 1999. ``We've built a lot of spacecraft that have performed for long periods of time in space,'' he said. ``The data should give one confidence that you can design spacecraft and have them work.'' The LDEF satellite was placed in orbit in April 1984 for an expected 10 months. Because of delays, however, it was not retrieved until Jan. 12, when astronauts snared it 200 miles out in space. The six years were the longest time a spacecraft had been in space before being retrieved for study. None of the experiments were lost during the long stay. Barring a rescue, the laboratory would have come crashing down through the atmosphere in mid-March and all the experiments attached to its exterior would have been lost. If not for gravity, the structure could have lasted many more years in space although some of the experiments might have decayed, Kinard said.

DOC.HEAD: Lester J. Maitland, Pilot of First Plane from Mainland to Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: Lester J. Maitland, who earned the Distinguished Flying Cross in 1927 for his pioneer flight from the U.S. mainland to Hawaii, has died at age 91. He died Tuesday night at a Scottsdale rest home, said family friend Tad Hankey of Indian Wells, Calif. The cause of death was not immediately known. As an Army pilot, Maitland and co-pilot-navigator Albert F. Hegenberger flew a three-engine Fokker called the Bird of Paradise from Oakland, Calif., to Wheeler Field on Oahu in June 1927. The 2,400-mile flight took 25 hours, 49 minutes and 30 seconds. Their navigation was aided by a radio beacon set up by the Army on the island. ``The big thing about that feat was to find the island. It didn't allow for any mistakes. They didn't have the (navigational) equipment they have today,'' Hankey said. Both airmen received the Distinguished Flying Cross. The pair were celebrated at a huge reception in Honolulu. Hegenberger died in 1983. Born in Milwaukee on Feb. 8, 1899, Maitland joined the Air Corps in 1917. Hankey said Maitland was the first pilot to hit the 200-mph mark and received a congratulatory letter from Orville Wright. During his military career he was an aide to Gen. Billy Mitchell and to the first secretary of the air, Truvee Davidson. At the outbreak of U.S. involvement in World War II, Maitland was commanding officer of Clark Field in the Philippines when it fell to Japan. Maitland became commanding officer of the 386th Bomber Group in Europe, where Hankey was his operations officer. The group, flying Martin B-26 bombers, was cited as the outstanding medium bomber group in the European theater, Hankey said. After the war he became director of aeronautics in Wisconsin in 1949, and then took a similar state position in Michigan from 1950 to 1956. Abruptly changing his life, he was ordained an Episcopal minister in Iron River, Mich., in 1956 and was known as ``the flying preacher,'' Hankey said. He retired to Red Bluff, Calif., but recently had been in a convalescent home in Arizona, where his daughter, Eileen Knoop, lives. Besides his daughter, Maitland is survived by his wife, Kathleen, and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``If they're trying to smuggle in these highly sophisticated trigger devices, that means they're very serious about making nuclear weapons, and soon.'' _ Professor Paul Wilkinson, a Bradford University terrorism expert, following the arrest in Britain of three people accused of trying to smuggle U.S.-made devices for triggering nuclear weapons to Iraq.

``I'm afraid the quality of Japanese products is declining due to imperfect quality control that cannot catch up with the speed of technological advance.'' _ Michiko Aoyama, a director at the government-backed Japan Consumer Information Center, following an embarrassing wave of recalls of hundreds of thousands of television sets.

``Even if he never invests another dollar, Peter Lynch has won a place of honor in the history of money management.'' _ Fidelity Investments Chairman and Chief Executive Edward C. Johnson III, on the announced retirement of Lynch, who managed the nation's largest stock mutual fund.

DOC.HEAD: New Estimate of Plutonium Accumulations at Rocky Flats Given
DOC.TEXT: About 62 pounds of deadly radioactive plutonium escaped into nearly a mile of air ducts during the 38 years the federal government has operated the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, officials said. That much plutonium could make six bombs and would be worth billions of dollars if sold on the black market, said Melinda Kassen, an attorney for the Environmental Defense Fund and member of a Rocky Flats monitoring committee. ``We feel the 28-kilogram figure is fairly solid,'' Jim Breen, a spokesman for plant operator EG&G Inc., said Wednesday. ``But we still have more measurements to make.'' Twenty-eight kilograms is equal to about 62 pounds. The Energy Department confirmed in October that there had been at least one accumulation of plutonium that had ``a serious potential for causing a criticality accident under certain conditions.'' If enough plutonium gathers in one spot, potentially a nuclear chain reaction and explosion could take place. Even if the plutonium poses no risk of criticality _ the point at which a nuclear chain reaction become self-sustaining _ it still is dangerous to hundreds of thousands of people in the Denver area, Kassen said. Plutonium is so toxic it is usually expressed in quantities of grams, a thousandth of a kilogram. The Energy Department estimated last year there were 12 kilograms of plutonium in the 4,000 feet of exhaust ductworks for the hundreds of gloveboxes that workers use to handle and process the plutonium at Rocky Flats. Plutonium operations at Rocky Flats were closed down last fall for routine maintenance and plutonium inventory, and have remained closed pending resolution of safety and health problems at the plant, officials said. Breen said Wellesley, Mass.-based EG&G, which operates the Rocky Flats plant under contract to the Energy Department, was working on recovering the plutonium. He wouldn't elaborate further. ``We will clean out the pipes before we restart,'' said Catherine Kaliniak of the Energy Department. ``I don't know if all the activity will be completed prior to restart. But if there is any safety questions, the energy secretary won't order restart.'' EG&G last year replaced Rockwell International Corp. as the plant's operator. Kassen, as a member of Gov. Roy Romer's Rocky Flats monitoring council, was the first one to find out about the situation, and alerted others. She said she attended a meeting Tuesday night about the proposed restart of plutonium operations at the plant. ``I asked some questions about what they were going to do before restart,'' she said, but officials were vague. So she asked specifically about the criticality report of last year, which began the assessment of missing plutonium. EG&G officials called back Wednesday morning with the figure of 28 kilograms, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Council Election Method Ruled Discriminatory; Minority Groups `Elated'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled the city's method of electing council members illegal and ordered new elections as soon as possible to offer better representation to blacks and Hispanics. U.S. District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer's ruling Wednesday gives the nation's eighth-biggest city 30 days to submit a plan for the special interim election. The judge did not set an election date. Buchmeyer said he wanted an election plan with 11 to 15 single-member districts and a mayor elected at large. Eight council members are currently elected in single-member districts, while three, including the mayor, are elected at-large. Although 51 percent of the city's more than 1 million residents are black or Hispanic, only two council members are black. There are no Hispanic council members. ``The 8-3 system for electing members of the city council violates the Voting Rights Act because it dilutes the votes of politically cohesive blacks and Hispanics in Dallas,'' Buchmeyer ruled. ``Under the 8-3 system, African-Americans and Hispanics are denied access to the three at-large seats because they cannot raise _ from their own communities _ the enormous amount of money that is required for an effective at-large city campaign in Dallas.'' Buchmeyer said an interim election would ``end once and for all the at-large election of all city council members.'' Only the mayor would be elected at large, Buchmeyer said. If the city fails to develop an interim election plan within 30 days, Buchmeyer would devise a court-ordered one, said Betsy Julian, executive director of the Legal Services of North Texas. Mayor Annette Strauss refused to comment on the ruling until she had studied it. The plaintiffs, including two former unsuccessful black council candidates, claimed the only way to achieve racial equality in the elections was to have all members of the council elected in single districts. The city had countered with a 10-4-1 plan, which it scheduled to go into effect in 1991, under which voters would elect 10 council members from individual districts, four from regional quadrants and the mayor at large. ``The judge suggests that the 10-4-1 system has the same problem as the 8-3 system,'' said the plaintiff's lawyer, Mike Daniel. The suit was filed by the two candidates, Roy Williams and Marvin Crenshaw, in May 1988. They later were joined by the Ledbetter Neighborhood Association, a Hispanic group.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Arrested, 70 Hurt in Rush For Registration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 70 hurt, some factories, shops closed, background on immigration; picks up 10th pvs, `The Portuguese...' ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Scores of people were trampled today as thousands of illegal immigrants from neighboring China stormed the gates of a race track in hopes of receiving residency rights in this Portuguese territory. Police fired shots into the air and arrested more than 1,000 people to bring the situation under control at the track, where about 40,000 people gathered for the registration program. About 70 people were taken to two hospitals, where they were treated and discharged, said Nuno Roque, chief of staff for Macao's Security Force. Several pregnant women suffered miscarriages and at least two men suffered broken bones in the rush, said Dr. Leong Chi-fai, director of Kiang Wu Hospital. The incident occurred one day after the government began an amnesty program for illegal immigrants whose children earlier received permission to live in Macao. Crowds of other illegal immigrants also demanded they be covered by the amnesty, and early today police told them to head to an athletic field near the Chinese border to be registered. As the crowd there grew, police decided to move the operation to the nearby dog racing track. Frantic illegal immigrants afraid they would miss the registration stormed the gates, pushing and shoving as police helplessly looked on. Police closed the track gates and warned the crowd outside that people without identification cards would be arrested. Three hours later, police reported more than 1,000 had been detained. Several factories, restaurants and shops were closed or only partially operating today because employees were trying to register. Thousands of Chinese have illegally crossed Macao's porous border to work in this territory, which enjoys a much higher standard of living. It was unclear whether illegal immigrants who register with police at the track will be granted permission to live in this tiny enclave of about 500,000 people at the mouth of the Pearl River in southern China. Even if the amnesty applies, the illegal immigrants would not be allowed to reside in Portugal under that country's nationality law. The Portuguese have agreed to hand over Macao to Communist China in 1999, two years after the nearby British colony of Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule. Beijing has promised both territories can maintain their capitalist systems for at least 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners Pay Respects to Happy Land Victims
DOC.TEXT: Sobs and cries from hundreds of mourners rang out at a Roman Catholic church as the caskets of 17 victims from the Happy Land Social Club fire were arrayed in the form of a large crucifix. One pink coffin for a female victim and 16 blue coffins for males were carried Wednesday from the Rivera Funeral Home in the Bronx across the street from St. Joseph's church. The dead were among 87 people, most of them Honduran immigrants, who perished Sunday in the illegal social club that was allegedly set afire by a spurned lover. It was the city's worst fire in 79 years. ``God never, never abandons us. Sudden death is also sudden mercy,'' the Rev. Henry Hill told more than 1,000 mourners packed inside the church. ``My heart goes out to each and every family,'' said Hill, a Honduran native. ``The church understands your loss and extends its sympathies and love.'' Another 1,000 people unable to fit in the church huddled outside on the street, about 10 blocks from the scene of the fire. The Honduran government declared three days of national mourning Wednesday and said 78 victims had been identified as Honduran. Most of the bodies will be buried in Honduras. But relatives who are illegally in the United States may not be able to return if they travel to Honduras to attend burial services. Before the Mass, hundreds of mourners prayed in the funeral home and then stood in the street. At least three women fainted and more than 15 required medical attention. Jose Alvarez, who came for the wake of his brother Denny, 22, left the funeral home sobbing and clinging to a cousin and friend. Across the street on the church steps, Denny's father, Pedro, railed against the man charged with setting the blaze, 36-year-old Cuban emigrant Julio Gonzalez. ``They ought to take him and give him a public hanging. People like that don't deserve to live,'' Alvarez said. Roses and daffodils in vases and coffee cans were placed in front of the the smoke-blackened red brick social club. Burned coats, some still on hangers, lay piled against the building. A paper sign on a tree listed the victims' names and ages. Nearby, family members went to a school to collect their relatives' personal effects. Carlos Pena clutched a manila envelope which held a watch, keys, and some cash his brother Eli, 26, had when he died at the club. The watch arrived with Eli from Honduras, and Carlos said the timepiece would now be his. ``It means a lot, a reminder,'' he said. The wake at the funeral home began three hours after a Bronx Civil Court refused to let the landlord of the social club reclaim the establishment until it decides whether the late tenant's widow should replace her husband in an eviction suit. The hearing, scheduled before the blaze Sunday whose victims included club proprietor Elias Colon, did not delve into responsibility for the tragedy. It only dealt with the demand of the building's landlord, One Peach Associates, for Colon's eviction for failing to pay rent. Mayor David Dinkins said legislation would be submitted today to City Council that would impose heavy penalties on landlords and operators of illegal social clubs.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Dampens South, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell throughout the South and Midwest early today, while snow fell in Colorado. Thunderstorms struck Little Rock, Ark., early today. Rain also fell in Tennessee, Alabama, and Kentucky. In the Midwest, rain dampened parts of Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Nebraska and Missouri. Elsewhere, snow fell in Denver, and a high wind warning was posted for the slopes of the Wasatch Mountains in Utah. Late Wednesday, showers and thunderstorms fell over central and southeast Texas, southern Louisiana, northeast New Mexico, Arizona and Southern California. Rain also dampened central and northeast Utah, northwest Colorado, southern Nebraska, Kansas, central and eastern Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, southern Iowa, southern Illinois, western Kentucky, western Tennessee, northwest Alabama, Mississippi, northern Florida and southwest Georgia. Snow fell over southwest Utah and from Wyoming into northeast Colorado. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was 87 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla. In Atlantic City, the mercury dipped to 18 degrees, tying the record low for the date set in 1966. DOC.HEAD: Mall Vigilante, Released by Grand Jury, Says He's No Hero
DOC.TEXT: A pizza shop owner who shot a man he'd just seen kill a woman in a shopping mall said he wouldn't do it again, although a grand jury decided against indicting him for murder. ``I was acting on my reaction to what had happened, and I wanted to stop the man from fleeing the scene,'' Todd Broom said Wednesday. ``But if the same thing happened in the parking lot when I left here, I'd probably think a lot more.'' Broom, who could have faced a murder charge, fired two shots at Eddie Edwards' car on March 12 after watching Edwards shoot Demetria Yvonne Taylor in the Irving Mall parking lot. One of the shots hit Edwards, who lost control of the car, crashed and died at a hospital a short time later. ``I'm glad this is behind me and I can go forward now,'' said Broom, 25. Prosecutor Norm Kinne said the grand jury's decision ``reflects the way the average citizen feels about the case, whether it's based on the law or not.'' But, he added, ``I fail to see that Mr. Broom's actions were in any way justified under the law.'' ``I'm not thinking of myself as a hero and I don't know what a hero is supposed to be,'' said Broom, a copier repairman and co-owner of a pizza parlor. Kinne said the grand jury's action won't encourage others to emulate Broom. ``I don't anticipate any of our law-abiding citizens are going to take this as a sign to pick up their guns and go to the shopping mall and try to deal out justice,'' he said. Broom saw Edwards, 41, shoot Ms. Taylor, 28, in the head and fired his .44-caliber Magnum twice at Edwards' car when the man drove away. After the shooting, Broom fled and did not turn himself in until two days later. He said at the time he was afraid he would be treated as a criminal. Broom said that if any money is left over from his legal fund, he will make a donation to the fund set up for Ms. Taylor's 5-year-old daughter, Tiffany.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was down against most major currencies in European trading this morning, after dropping sharply against the yen earlier. Gold was mixed. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 156.65 yen, down 1.98 yen from Wednesday's finish. Later in London, the dollar traded at 156.85 yen. ``It was about time for the yen to recover after so much dollar-buying,'' said Mitsuhiko Kunugasa, a dealer with Daiwa Bank in Tokyo. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.7022 West German marks, down from 1.7078 _1.5090 Swiss francs, down from 1.5135 _5.7285 French francs, down from 5.7410 _1.9175 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9200 _1,254 Italian lire, down from 1,255.25 _1.176 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1758 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.63, up from $1.6285 late Wednesday. London's major gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $370.75 per troy ounce at midmorning, from $370.15 bid late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $2.69 an ounce today to close at $371.93. In Zurich, the bid price for gold was $371.25 per troy ounce, up from $369 late Wednesday. Silver sold in London at a bid price of $4.96 a troy ounce, up from Wednesday's $4.95.

DOC.HEAD: Domino's Gives Driver Safety Classes
DOC.TEXT: Pizza is great in 30 minutes, but better late than never, says a highway patrolman who has been lecturing delivery drivers on how to arrive with pizza and driver in one piece. Managers of the 35 Domino's stores in the Pittsburgh area suspended their delivery service for four hours Tuesday night so drivers could listen to Mississippi state trooper Lt. Pete Collins. ``I don't know a thing in the world about selling pizzas, but I do know one subject better than anyone in this room,'' Collins said. ``That's dying.'' Critics say the Ann Arbor, Mich.-based company's guaranteed half-hour delivery has caused accidents by encouraging employees to drive recklessly. Company officials admit haste has contributed to some fatal accidents. Attorney Kenneth R. Behrend, who is representing a couple injured when a Domino's car collided with their car, said the company should drop its guarantee. ``It was a great public relations gimmick. It got them their market share,'' said Behrend, president of the American Trial Lawyers Association. ``But ... it is causing more problems to the American public than are needed.'' Behrend said he knows of 140 accidents where victims or their survivors have filed suit, are preparing to file suit or are trying to negotiate a settlement. ``We probably have a perception problem,'' said Domino's spokesman Ron Hingst. ``Most people don't know that you can have a pizza out and fully cooked in 8 to 12 minutes, and that leaves time for driving. If there's a way we can save 10 seconds in the production of the pizza, we'll do it,'' he said. Hingst said in 1988, half of the 20 accident deaths involving company drivers had nothing to do with Domino's guarantee. Domino's defends the guarantee, which helped spur its explosive growth in the 1980s. The policy, established in 1973, says if a pizza is delivered late, Domino's will refund a minimum of $3. The company bills itself as the world's largest pizza delivery company. It sold 250 million pizzas in 1989, posting $2.5 billion in sales, Hingst said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Defense Ministry Offers Amnesty to Lithuanian Desrters
DOC.TEXT: In a move that may ease weeks of tension between Lithuania and Moscow, the Defense Ministry announced it would offer amnesty to Lithuanian soldiers who deserted the army if they turn themselves in, Tass reported today. The announcement came a day after Lithuania's government made two conciliatory moves toward Moscow. It suspended plans for setting up its own border guard and told citizens not to resist if officials came to their homes to confiscate their firearms in accordance with a Soviet decree. Hundreds of Lithuanian soldiers have deserted in recent weeks, some complaining of harassment and others refusing to serve in a ``foreign'' army after their republic declared independence March 11. The issue was one of many that has led to a buildup in tension between the Kremlin and the Baltic republic. Defense Ministry officials said they ``took the decision not to bring criminal charges against soldiers of Lithuanian nationality,'' the official Soviet news agency reported. However, it said, soldiers who refuse to turn themselves in will be ``searched out, detained, and be subject to criminal punishment in accordance with current law.'' At least 23 Lithuanian soldiers were rounded up Tuesday in a pre-dawn raid on two Lithuanian hospitals where they had taken refuge. Witnesses said some of the deserters were beaten. Tass reported earlier today that at least 50 deserters have returned on their own to their units and more were expected. Soviet military officials have warned repeatedly that the deserters would be searched out and brought back to the army.

DOC.HEAD: Legal Liability Unclear in Social Club Fire
With PM-Social Club Fire
DOC.TEXT: Legal liability for the social club fire that left 87 dead depends on the answers to three questions, according to some of the city's top lawyers.
