Did the owner and landlord know about the unsafe and illegal condition of the Happy Land Social Club? What could they have done about it? And what did they try to do about it? The lawyers say those questions deal primarily with matters of fact, not law, and resist immediate answers. ``Everyone's jumping into the pot and pointing the blame, even though we don't know what happened, and won't know for sure until the pre-trial stage of any litigation,'' said Bernard Rifkin, chairman of the real property committee of the state bar association. ``It all depends on the facts,'' agreed Karl Holtzschue, Rifkin's counterpart at the city bar association. ``If they (the building owner and the landlord) knew there was something wrong and didn't do something, they might have some liability. But this is an area of law that's very fact-specific.'' Three people held varying degrees of control over the building in which the club was located. The club operator, Elias Colon, died in the fire. Jay Weiss and Morris Jaffe, whose company, One Peach Associates, held a 30-year lease for the property, subleased it to Colon. Alexander DiLorenzo III, who owned the building, leased it to One Peach. Lawyers agreed that the chance of criminal charges was slim, because the fire was apparently the result of arson. But when such a tragedy occurs, victims' families search for the deepest pockets to sue. In this case, Holtzschue noted, ``The operator paid for what he did with his life. You can't get any more out of his hide.'' That leaves the owner and One Peach, as well as those who will probably call the defense legal shots in any lawsuit _ their insurance companies. But what DiLorenzo, Weiss and Jaffe knew, what they did and what they could have done remains unclear. The unlicensed club Colon operated had been the scene of arrests for the illegal sale of alcohol. It had been cited for serious building and safety code violations and had been ordered to close in late 1988. Colon's lease from Weiss specified that the building was not to allow any person under the age of 21 years to enter. If ``any governmental authority'' complained about the club, the lease gave the landlord the right to evict the club unless it quickly corrected the problem. The city, of course, did complain, and minors were served, but did the owner or landlord know? The city says it sent copies of vacate orders out, but it appears only DiLorenzo received one. Weiss's attorneys said they never were formally notified of the violations, but declined to say if they knew about them anyway. One of Weiss's attorneys said his client was not closely involved with the property. Alan Vogeler told The New York Times that Weiss, husband of actress Kathleen Turner, had never been inside the social club and had not visited the property since April 1989. Jaffe's role remains unclear. Weiss and Jaffe, however, were trying to evict Colon; that usually would be a legal mark in their favor, but they apparently were doing so only because that Colon had not paid his rent. Rifkin questioned how much Weiss and Jaffe could have done to get rid of Colon or correct the building's problems. Because of city laws and court policies that protect tenants, he said, ``Anytime you try to evict anyone, you've got a nightmare.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rafsanjani's Brother on New Hostage Mission in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper today reported that Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani had dispatched his brother to Lebanon in a new effort to win the release of Western hostages. The conservative Beirut newspaper Ad-Diyar said Mahmoud Hashemi, Rafsanjani's brother, held meetings with leaders of Hezbollah, or Party of God, during a weeklong, unannounced visit that ended Tuesday. The newspaper said the envoy also met with Hussein Mousawi, who heads the Islamic Amal movement based in east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. The movement forms the pro-Syrian wing of Hezbollah, Iran's main ally in Lebanon. Ad-Diyar gave no further details and a spokesman at the Iranian Embassy, who declined to be named, said ``we usually do not comment on such reports.'' Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for underground Shiite fanatics holding most of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Eight Americans are among those held. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Hashemi has made several secret trips to Lebanon to try to resolve the hostage situation since his brother took office Aug. 3, following the death of revolutionary patriarch Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini two months earlier. Rafsanjani, considered a pragmatist who favors increasing Western investment in Iran to rebuild it after its eight-war with Iraq, is believed to be in a power struggle with Islamic hard-liners in his government who oppose reconciliation with the West and the release of hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam's Communist Party Purges Reformist Leader
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's Communist Party has purged a member of the ruling Politburo who advocated more democratic reform, and party leaders affirmed a commitment to socialism despite its crisis abroad. The official Vietnam News Agency said Tran Xuan Bach, the No. 9 man on the 13-member Politburo, was removed ``for his grave violations on the party's organizational and disciplinary principles which had caused many bad consequences.'' The agency was paraphrasing a communique issued at the Central Committee's eighth general meeting, a two-week gathering that ended Tuesday in the capital, Hanoi. The report, dated Wednesday, was seen in Bangkok today. The communique did not specify Bach's alleged mistakes, but it was clear they involved disagreeing with the party's attempt to avoid substantial political liberalization while easing controls on the society and economy. ``The plenum noted that many socialist countries were being enmeshed in a comprehensive and most critical crisis ever seen before,'' the report said in paraphrasing the communique, referring to recent reform in other communist countries. ``However ... the plenum was confident that socialism would certainly ... surmount difficulties and continue to march forward,'' the report said. It said the plenum concluded that initial successes showed the party's reforms were correct although ``the country had not yet gone out of the economic and social crisis.'' The 1986 party congress endorsed mainly economic changes including limited private enterprise, decreased state management and material incentives for farmers. The seventh congress will be held the second quarter of 1991, the plenum communique said. In an article by Indochina correspondent Murray Heibert, the Far Eastern Economic Review said in its Feb. 1 edition that Bach has been one of the party's leading ideological thinkers in recent years and frequently had been touted as a possible successor to party chief Nguyen Van Linh. In a speech broadcast by the official radio in January, Bach, 65, said the economy had improved but social unrest remained, with people demanding more democracy and social justice. Countries that have liberalized the economy but not the political system are facing ``a very tense situation,'' he said. But Bach did not call for a multiparty system in Vietnam, only for more democratic reforms and greater diversity of political ideas, the Far Eastern Economic Review article said.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Talks Begin; Revolutionaries Call for New Demonstrations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATE throughout with coalition talks beginning. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the two parties that dominated East Germany's first free elections began crucial talks today that could have a major impact on the pace of unification with West Germany. The talks came hours before the groups that toppled the old Communist order were to rally throughout the country, protesting the new leadership's alleged ties to the secret police of the ousted Communist regime. Lothar de Maiziere, leader of the Christian Democrat-led coalition that finished first in the balloting, said he was optimistic that a government could be formed with the rival Social Democrats. During a visit in the West German city of Stuttgart on Wednesday, de Maiziere said that a new governing coalition could be formed within the next two weeks. However, the Social Democrats, who finished a distant second in the March 18 balloting, have expressed concern about whether they will be able to work with some of the more conservative elements of de Maiziere's alliance. The Social Democrats also favor a more gradual process for unification than the Christian Democrats. ``We expect to learn where the conversations will lead,'' Markus Meckel, a Social Democrat leader, told reporters before talks began today in East Berlin. New Forum, which led the revolt last fall that brought down the government of Communist leader Erich Honecker, called for the demonstrations to force an immediate investigation of new Parliament members. In Bonn, members of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's junior coalition partners, the Free Democrats, joined with the opposition Social Democrats in rejecting a Kohl government proposal to grant amnesty to former members of the East German secret police. ``Wrongs cannot be allowed to be swept under the table,'' Gerhard Baum, deputy chairman of the Free Democrats, said Wednesday. Voting in their first free elections March 18, East Germans overwhelmingly elected a three-party coalition that favors quick unification with West Germany and a capitalist economy. De Maiziere, who heads the winning coalition; and Ibrahim Boehme, head of the Social Democrats, both were accused after the elections of having ties to the former secret police. Both men denied the accusations. Similar charges have been raised against other members of the newly elected 400-member Parliament. The 85,000-member secret police known as the Stasi and its 109,000 informers were used by East Germany's hard-line Stalinist government for decades to control the country's citizens. The unit was disbanded after Honecker was overthrown. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said Tuesday that ``a generous amnesty,'' for the Stasi may be needed to quell further instability in East Germany. ``Not everyone who was forced to report to the Stasi was a criminal,'' Schaeuble said. Kohl later told reporters he agreed ``in principle,'' with the proposal. In the East German elections, Kohl backed the coalition led by de Maiziere. Baum said former Stasi members should be allowed to begin new careers, but it is ``out of the question'' to allow them to hold important political posts. Boehme temporarily stepped down from his party post until his name was cleared of any Stasi links. Lawmaker Horst Ehmke, a leader of West Germany's Social Democratic Party, on Wednesday called on de Maiziere to also resign. In the meantime, a reform-oriented Communist government that replaced the ousted Honecker government continues to handle daily operations of the country. The retooled Communist Party was soundly defeated in the elections. On Wednesday, an East German prosecutor said that doctors will decide if Honecker is physically and mentally able to face charges of corruption and abuse of power. Lothar Reuter, East Germany's deputy chief prosecutor, told the official news agency ADN that medical specialists also will examine other aging officials accused of misusing their power during the Honecker regime. The comments further increase the likelihood that the ailing Honecker, who ruled East Germany with the help of the secret police for 17 years, may avoid criminal trial. Authorities already have decided this week not to charge Honecker, 77 and in poor health, with conspiracy and high treason.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Has Stopped Would-Be Assassins, Paper Says
DOC.TEXT: Special KGB guards who protect President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other leaders have stopped would-be assassins who tried to enter government buildings with sawed-off shotguns and knives, a news report said today. ``Every month our men in the Kremlin, on Red Square and other places expose and detain about a dozen people with criminal intentions,'' a KGB general, Yuri S. Plekhanov, told the Communist Party daily Pravda. Even in the period of Gorbachev's policy of greater openness, officials previously have not discussed planned attacks on top leaders. Several weeks ago a popular TV show referred to an effort to assassinate President Leonid I. Brezhnev in 1969. The effort had previously only been rumored to have occurred. Security for Gorbachev, compared to that for leaders of other major countries, is erratic. When the Soviet leader traveled to Washington in 1987 to meet President Reagan, U.S. security officers said Gorbachev's security operated in nearly an identical way. But Gorbachev's security details have appeared ragged on other foreign trips, and at times in Moscow security for Gorbachev and his wife Raisa appears to be lax. Gorbachev, who enjoys stepping into crowds to chat with people in the Soviet Union and abroad, presents a tougher security problem than previous Soviet leaders whose public appearances had little spontaneity. Plekhanov said that KGB security guards for the Soviet leadership have not had to use their weapons since World War II. The KGB general said that recently a man waiting in the reception room of the Communist Party Central Committee pulled out a sawed-off shotgun, but he was disarmed by KGB Maj. V. Frolov. Gorbachev is said to do most of his day-to-day work in the Central Committee headquarters, although a person visiting the reception area would be unlikely to get anywhere close to the Soviet leader. Others with bombs, knives and guns have been arrested on Red Square and in the Kremlin, he said. Last year security guards found a knife on a person among the crowd entering the Kremlin for New Year's festivities. A person was arrested with a bomb on May 1, the May Day holiday, in Red Square, where the entire Soviet leadership gathers atop Lenin's mausoleum to review a workers' parade. The next day, security agents on Red Square arrested a man with a gun that accidentally went off when he was being detained, Plekhanov said. Besides Gorbachev, the guard unit protects other Soviet leaders, provides security for parliamentary sessions in the Kremlin and cooperates with the secret services of other countries during the visits of foreign dignitaries. The KGB guards have good contacts with Scotland Yard, the U.S. Secret Service, Finnish, West Germany and other security police, he said. Without going into specifics, Plekhanov said the KGB guard is relatively small and cooperates with other branches of the Soviet security police during important political events or if it catches wind of a plot.

DOC.HEAD: Records Show City Official Runs Illegal Social Club
With PM-Social Club Fire
DOC.TEXT: The city's new commissioner of Hispanic affairs operates an illegal social club that was ordered closed last year and again Monday for safety and fire violations, city records show. Commissioner William Nieves runs the club, El Caney, in a building that is supposed to be used as a factory, according to city Buildings Department documents, the Daily News reported. Nieves, appointed to the $65,000-a-year commissioner's post Friday, denies El Caney is a social club, calling it a ``place for cultural events,'' but acknowledges knowing about fire and safety code violations cited last year, the newspaper said in a story published today. An ``order to vacate'' sign was posted on the club door Monday by a mayoral task force that is cracking down on illegal establishments in the wake of a fire at an illegal Bronx club Sunday in which 87 people died. Nieves said he planned to give up his job as operator of El Caney. ``It's not a bar or a social club. It's a place for cultural events. ... When we have parties, they can serve liquor when they have their own private activities. But you can't call that a bar,'' he said. Nieves said he had been under the impression repairs ``were the responsibility of the landlord, not me.'' The landlord, R&R Real Estate, was unaware Nieves was operating a social club there, the newspaper said. A summons issued by the Buildings Department last April cited operation of an illegal gathering place without permits, lack of emergency lighting, missing exit signs and unilluminated exit signs. The summons cited a certificate of occupancy that lists the building's function as a factory.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Karl Brown. A separate moved for PMs as a0482 on Maitland and a0509 on Brown. Davidson also moved on the sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Karl Brown, a pioneering Hollywood cinematographer who worked on D.W. Griffith's 1915 silent film epic ``The Birth of a Nation,'' has died. He was 93. Brown died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills. The cause of death was not disclosed. In the early days of Hollywood, Brown worked as a cinematographer's assistant on ``The Birth of a Nation'' and ``Intolerance,'' another historical extravaganza made a year later by Griffith. Brown created the technique of double-printing that gave a supernatural radiance to Christ in ``Intolerance.'' He also helped develop the miniature projection process that magnified models into monsters for such pictures as ``King Kong.'' He directed the 1927 film ``His Dog'' for Cecil B. DeMille. Brown's screenplay credits included ``Brewster's Millions,'' ``One Glorious Day,'' ``Ruggles of Red Gap,'' ``Merton of the Movies'' and ``The Pony Express.''

Aviation pioneer Lester J. Maitland, who in 1927 became the first pilot to fly from the U.S. mainland to Hawaii, died Tuesday. He was 91. As an Army pilot, Maitland and copilot-navigator Albert F. Hegenberger flew a three-engine Fokker dubbed the ``Bird of Paradise'' from Oakland, Calif., to Wheeler Field on Oahu in June, 1927. The 2,400-mile flight took 25 hours, 49 minutes and 30 seconds. Their navigation was aided by a radio beacon set up by the Army on the island. Maitland and Hegenberger were awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, and were feted at a huge celebration in Honolulu. Maitland, who left the military with the rank of brigadier general, became director of aeronautics in Wisconsin in 1949. He took a similar state position in Michigan from 1950 to 1956.

Giap Van Cuong, a Vietnamese navy commander who held several important military posts, died Tuesday at age 78. The cause of death was not disclosed. Cuong was deputy chief of the army's general staff and commander of the fourth military region.

Donald Davidson, special assistant to Houston Astros General Manager Bill Wood, died Wednesday of cancer at age 64. Davidson's career began in 1939, when he was a batboy for the Boston Braves and Red Sox. He began his baseball administrative career in 1948 when he joined the Braves public relations department. He joined the Astros in 1976 as public relations director. He also had served the club as traveling secretary and an as administrative assistant to the president.

Eddie J. Martin, the founder of Martin Aviation who opened Orange County's first airport, died Tuesday of cancer at age 88. Martin began his aviation career with a Curtiss JN-4D Jenny purchased with $50 he won in an American Legion auto race in 1923. He opened the Eddie Martin Airport in 1923. He also founded Martin Aviation, a charter service and flight school. Martin Aviation sponsored the record-setting globe circling flight of 11-year-old Tony Aliengena last year. His charter service boomed in the 1930s. Among his passengers was first lady Eleanor Roosevelt, whom he ferried from El Paso, Texas, to Burbank in 1933. Martin sold the airport to his brother, Johnny, in 1937 and went to work as a pilot for petroleum magnate R.S. MacMillian. He later became a P-38 test pilot for Lockheed Aircraft Co.

Giovanni Costigan, an emeritus history professor at the University of Washington and a leading political and social liberal in the Northwest, died Saturday in Seville of a heart attack at age 85. Costigan held positions at the University of Wisconsin and Idaho State University before joining the University of Washington in 1934. During the 1950s, Costigan defended colleagues from anti-communist investigations, and by the early 1960s was the subject himself of a smear campaign seeking his dismissal from the university. But President Charles Odegaard retained Costigan. Costigan wrote biographies of Sigmund Freud and Sir Robert Wilson, a British general under Wellington, and a history of Ireland.

Alex Vlahos, the 6-year-old leukemia victim whose search for a bone marrow donor was aided by former San Francisco Giants pitcher Dave Dravecky, died Wednesday from complications related to his treatment. Vlahos underwent two bone marrow transplants. He began suffering from liver and kidney failure early in the second transplant. Dravecky, who also suffers from cancer, helped raise more than $100,000 for the testing process. It was finally discovered that the boy's second cousin, Linda Snowberger, 31, of New York City, had marrow matching Alex' in five of six categories. Snowberger provided bone marrow for both transplants.

DOC.HEAD: New Reports Say `Birmingham Six' Were Wrongly Convicted In Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with government comment. Pickup 13th graf `Last week...'
DOC.TEXT: A TV documentary identified four people it said were responsible for IRA bombings that killed 21 people, and a British lawmaker said new evidence should lead to the release of the six people who were convicted. The Home Office, responsible for law enforcement, said in a statement today that all four people identified on the television program had been investigated by police and that the program ``does not put forward new evidence.'' Chris Mullin, a member of the opposition Labor Party, said Wednesday that those convicted, known as the Birmingham Six, were innocent of the 1974 bombings of two pubs. He said an Irish Republican Army informer identified one of the bombers, but that police failed to follow up the lead. ``The lie cannot be sustained much longer,'' Mullin told a news conference to publicize the third edition of his book on the case, ``Error of Judgment.'' The bombings in the northern city of Birmingham, which also left 162 injured, were the deadliest ever by the IRA in its campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Mullin based his charge on a police document _ a summary of an interview with an IRA informer _ and said it ``ought to bring the end of this scandal.'' Mullin also claims to have interviewed four men who carried out the bombings. He spoke hours before four alleged bombers were also identified in Granada Television's dramatized documentary, ``Who Bombed Birmingham?'' Mullin declined to comment on the identifications made in the broadcast but said, ``I advise you to take very seriously'' the Granada broadcast. None of those identified on the program is among the six convicted of bombing two pubs in Birmingham on Nov. 21, 1974. The program identified the suspects as a man who served 12 years for other offenses, a man serving a life sentence in Ireland for murder and two men now living in Ireland. One of those two men, the program alleged, was involved in other IRA attacks including the murder of 11 people in London in 1982 and the bombing in Brighton in 1984 that nearly killed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Granada said a fifth suspect could not be named for ``security reasons.'' The Home Office, however, said ``the people named in that report were included in the police investigations into the Birmingham pub bombings and general terrorist activities in the West Midlands at the time.'' One was not charged and no evidence had been found to link two others, the statement said. The fourth man stood trial with the six, was convicted on a conspiracy count and was sentenced to 12 years in prison, it said. West Midlands Chief Constable Geoffrey Dear said Wednesday that he would investigate any new evidence disclosed by the TV broadcast. He also said police had never claimed the convicted six were the only ones involved. The IRA's legal political wing, Sinn Fein, denounced the television program. ``The quality and strength of the evidence which proves the innocence of the six is not, not should be, dependent upon pointing the finger of suspicion at others,'' it said. Last week, Home Secretary David Waddington ordered a new investigation of several matters raised by attorneys for the Birmingham Six. Waddington has refused to say what specific points are under review. The cause of the six has been taken up by Amnesty International, the Irish government and most recently by Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, the Roman Catholic primate of Ireland. Five of the six convicts were arrested the night of the bombings as they were about to board a ferry to Belfast for the funeral of an IRA man. All six _ Johnny Walker, Patrick Hill, Hugh Callaghan, Richard McIlkenny, Gerry Hunter and Billy Power _ were sentenced to life in prison in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Thatcher About Her Lithuania Appeal To Gorbachev ^With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush telephoned Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to discuss her personal appeal to Moscow for restraint in the Lithuanian crisis, a British official said today. Bush called Wednesday after Mrs. Thatcher sent him a message about a 50-minute telephone call she had earlier with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said a spokeswoman at the prime minister's 10 Downing St. office. ``It wasn't a long call,'' said the spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``She had sent President Bush a message, and I think he really rang to clarify some details.'' British officials have given no details of Mrs. Thatcher's talk with Gorbachev or his reaction. However, government sources said Mrs. Thatcher did not seek specific assurances from Gorbachev. Officials say the Moscow call was set up partly to discuss a two-day visit to Britain by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl that begins Thursday and a meeting between Mrs. Thatcher and Bush in Bermuda on April 13. A tense standoff between Moscow and Lithuania began March 11 when the Baltic republic defied the federal government and declared itself independent.

DOC.HEAD: Report Finds Widespread Bias Against Unmarried People in LA
DOC.TEXT: Single people in the nation's second-largest city suffer widespread and often illegal bias ranging from rental discrimination to restricted hospital visits, it was reported today. The alleged bias against unmarried people in Los Angeles was documented by the city's Consumer Task Force on Marital Status and reflects a national trend, the Los Angeles Times reported. City Attorney James K. Hahn declined to comment on the 126-page report until it was formally released later today. ``Most of us aren't living in traditional American families anymore, and the rights and privileges extended to a few should be extended to everyone,'' Hahn said when he created the task force in October 1989. According to the newspaper, the report details alleged discriminatory practices that include landlords who refuse to rent to single people or unmarried couples, auto insurers that levy higher premiums or refuse policies for singles, and airlines that restrict the sharing of frequent-flier awards to spouses or blood relatives. ``Most of these practices are illegal in California,'' said Thomas F. Coleman, a family law expert and chairman of the task force. ``Discrimination based on marital status is arbitrary, inappropriate, illegal and unfair _ but it is also a pervasive national problem,'' Coleman said. ``Our report represents the emergence of a new dimension of the consumer protection movement,'' he said. ``Call it singles' rights.'' The report also noted that singles are often charged higher health club dues than married people and can be denied hospital bedside visits that are sometimes limited to spouses or family members. The task force report is the result of three public hearings where about 30 witnesses, including business representatives, legal experts and politicians, testified about alleged discrimination. The single, divorced, separated and widowed collectively make up 55 percent of people 15 years or older, said Coleman.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Adopted, Given to Orphanage Six Years Later
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with offers of new home and to CORRECT that boy was placed in orphanage at Christmas, sted on Christmas. Picks up 8th graf, `The parents...'
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy, placed in an orphanage at Christmastime by the parents who had adopted him six year earlier, has plenty of offers of a new home. The Hephzibah Children's Association orphanage in suburban Oak Park said countless people telephoned after the boy's story appeared in news accounts Wednesday. ``One man called crying and said he wanted to adopt him,'' said Annette Anderson, a receptionist at the orphanage. Dozens more calls offering a home or financial help came to the Illinois Department of Children and Family Service and Cook County Guardian Patrick T. Murphy, who has sued the parents to secure visitation rights for the children. ``It's every little boy's nightmare,'' Murphy said Wednesday. ``Mom and Dad were talking about something, and they said they were going to put me up for adoption. I thought they were kidding. They weren't,'' the boy says in a tape recording made available by Murphy. The boy blames himself for the situation, in which he was separated from his 8-year-old brother. Murphy's lawsuit, filed this week in Circuit Court, also seeks to force the parents to pay at least $50,000 in damages for emotional harm to Rick _ not his real name. ``Rick's parents told him they were going to put him into an orphanage and they did it. It's like telling a kid you're going to send the bogey man after him and then doing it,'' he said. ``He continually blames himself for what happened, thinking he's a bad boy,'' he said. The two boys were adopted by the couple in suburban Bellwood in August 1984 after their biological mother abandoned them. The parents put Rick in an orphanage at Christmas, and got approval March 9 from Circuit Court Judge Walter Williams to surrender their parental rights to him. In the tape, Rick then apologizes to his brother for a fight the two had. ``Remember that day that I hurt your nose when I beat you up? I'm sorry for that. I didn't mean it. I hope I get to see you again.'' The children's adoptive parents, identified in the lawsuit only as Joseph and Pamela Doe, said Rick did not ``bond'' to them, Murphy said. The parents said Rick ``is only out for what he can get,'' and they prevented his younger brother from seeing him, according to Murphy. The parents' lawyer, Mary C. Martin, declined to discuss the case Tuesday. Calls to her office Wednesday were not returned. Murphy said Rick was taken to an Oak Park orphanage and is now in a temporary foster home. He called Rick a ``normal kid'' who's never been in trouble with the law. ``This is not a schizophrenic kid who is climbing the walls and throwing feces at people,'' he said. ``He's a normal kid.'' The lawsuit describes the parents as a middle-class couple who own two small businesses. Murphy said the lawsuit was unusual only because parents usually don't separate adopted children. ``Before, brothers and sisters weren't separated,'' Murphy said, ``and now you've got bureaucrats and judges who say it's OK.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Denies Role in Smuggling Case; Hussein Defiant
With PM-Britain-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today denied it tried to smuggle U.S.-made nuclear triggers through London, and President Saddam Hussein accused other nations of trying to slow Baghdad's ``march of progress.'' The Foreign Ministry described the charges of smuggling as ``British allegations'' and promised unspecified reciprocal measures. The official Iraqi News Agency said Britain would be held responsible for any results of its actions. Also today, British Charge d'Affaires Robert Kealy was summoned to the Foreign Ministry and told that Iraq reserves the right to acquire advanced technology from other countries. ``Iraq, which has signed the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, maintains its full rights to the transfer of technology from anywhere,'' he was told by Deputy Foreign Minister Nizar Hamdoun. The Iraqi News Agency, which reported the meeting, also quoted Hamdoun as criticizing what he called a British campaign against the ``so-called Iraqi nuclear program.'' ``The current British campaign is trying to provide the groundwork for an Israeli aggression on Iraq, reminding us of the year 1981,'' he said referring to Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear plant. Iraq's ambassador in London told the British Broadcasting Corp. that he ``categorically denied'' the British charges that his nation was involved in a plot to U.S.-made devices for triggering nuclear weapons. British customs officials said 40 devices known as capacitors were seized Wednesday in a freight shed at London's Heathrow airport as they were about to be put on an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad. Three people have been arrested in London on charges of trying to smuggle the weapon triggers to Iraq. At a rally in Baghdad today, President Saddam Hussein said that ``enemies of the Arabs'' were trying to hinder the country's ``march of progress,'' but did not specifically refer to nuclear technology or nuclear weapons. ``The fires are intensifying, whether by aggressions or conspiracies, but the Iraqi people will not be worn down,'' Hussein told the rally. A Foreign Ministry spokesman was also quoted by the Iraqi News Agency as saying that the arrests and allegation of attempts to build nuclear weapons were part of an anti-Iraqi campaign launched by the British government, news media and ``Zionists.'' Iraq has recently complained of harsh press coverage following its March 15 execution of Farzad Bazoft, an Iranian-born British journalist who was charged with spying. Iraq ignored British requests that the reporter's life be spared.

DOC.HEAD: Black Prosecutor Quits Bensonhurst Racial Killing Case
DOC.TEXT: A black prosecutor assigned to work on the Bensonhurst racial killing case has resigned from the Brooklyn district attorney's office, reportedly because he believed he was being used as a token. Bruce McIntyre, 36, a Yale law school graduate who has worked in the office for six years, has submitted his resignation, District Attorney Charles Hynes said. The three other prosecutors working on the case are white. Seven whites are charged with murdering a young black man, Yusuf Hawkins, last summer in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, a predominantly white neighborhood. The first trial in the case was scheduled to begin next week. McIntyre resigned Monday because he believed he was playing a non-essential role and had been assigned to the case merely for appearance's sake, according to published reports. The Daily News, citing unidentified sources, said McIntyre told colleagues earlier this week that he ``didn't go to law school to be a token black.'' Hynes said McIntyre would have played a a major role in the case, but acknowledged that he had hoped to have a black on the prosecution team. McIntyre, Hynes said, was ``offered the chance to give both the opening and closing arguments and he turned it down.'' But McIntyre was ``told in some fashion that it was important to have an African-American at that (prosecution) table,'' Hynes said. ``I think that's obvious.''

DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf, He then ... to add further Watkins remark and update with Navy comment; picks up 8th graf pvs, Also out ...
DOC.HEAD: Watkins Says Rocky Flats Shutdown Threatens Weapon Deployments
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. nuclear arsenal will suffer ``severe ramifications'' if the government is unable to get its key weapons production plants back in operation soon, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins says. Testifying Wednesday to a House Armed Services subcommittee, Watkins strongly hinted that one casualty of the production breakdown could be the Trident II ballistic missile, considered by experts to be the most accurate U.S. missile. One key breakdown is at the Rocky Flats plant in Colorado, which makes plutonium triggers for nuclear arms. It has been closed since last November to correct safety and management problems. Watkins said he hoped it would be back in operation by this summer, but no firm date for restart has been set. The Energy Department owns all facilities that develop and produce U.S. nuclear arms. Reps. Norman Dicks, D-Wash., and Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., asked Watkins whether the indefinite shutdown at Rocky Flats could force delays in outfitting newly deployed Trident submarines with the new missiles. Watkins replied that he could not discuss details in public. But he added that as a general comment, ``I can guarantee if we don't move aggressively'' to get the weapons production complex back in full operation soon, ``there will be severe ramifications.'' He then added, in reference to the Trident missile program: ``That won't be the last'' to be hampered by the interruption at Rocky Flats and other weapons facilities. Watkins also said his department had notified the Defense Department, ``Yes, there would probably be a negative impact on the weapons stockpile this year and next.'' Lt. Bruce Williams, a Navy spokesman, said Watkins' comments ``came as quite a surprise here.'' He said the Navy had not been notified of any impending shortage of warheads for the Trident or other Navy nuclear weapons systems. Williams said he could not comment on specific deployment plans for security reasons. Also out of service, due to safety problems, are three reactors at the Savannah River plant in South Carolina that make tritium, a radioactive gas needed to boost the explosive power of nuclear warheads. Watkins told lawmakers he hoped to get one reactor restarted by the end of this year but stressed that questions of reactor safety and other matters remained to be resolved. The Los Angeles Times reported earlier this month that the warhead stockpile is now so small that the Navy has only enough armed Trident II missiles, known formally as the D-5, to equip two Trident subs with a full complement of 24 missiles. The first of those two subs, the USS Tennessee, is expected to go on its first operational patrol from its base at King's Bay, Ga., by this weekend, said William Arkin, a nuclear arms specialist for the environmental group Greenpeace. The Navy has declined to comment on the timing of the Tennessee's deployment. A second Trident sub, the USS Pennsylvania, is scheduled to go to sea with Trident II missiles in December, Arkin said. The Times report, citing unidentified government officials, said subsequent deployments of Trident subs are being jeopardized by the Rocky Flats shutdown. That would mean the USS West Virginia, which is to enter service next spring, might have to be armed with existing Trident I missiles instead of the new version. The first eight Trident subs were deployed with the Trident I missile, which is less accurate than the new version. The vessels are scheduled to be re-equipped with Trident II missiles during the 1990s as they brought in for overhauls. The Navy plans to build 24 Trident subs and buy nearly 900 Trident II missiles, according to Arkin, whose organization favors killing the missile program. In an interview, Arkin said the Rocky Flats shutdown is interfering with other nuclear weapons programs, including the Tomahawk sea-lauched cruise missile, the stealth air-launched cruise missile and the B-61 and B-83 gravity bombs.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Poll Finds Wide Diversity Among Soviets on Key Issues
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens are split down the middle on whether government should be responsible for people's well-being or individuals should be responsible for themselves, a new poll finds. A poll of 2,500 Soviets also found that the minority group a person belongs to _ not age, education or Communist Party membership _ governs Soviet thought on many issues. The poll, released Wednesday by former President Jimmy Carter's public policy center, found 46 percent of respondents favored the traditional Communist idea that the state is responsible for people, 45 percent said responsibility fell to individuals. ``Many of those who want rapid change to solve social problems also hold the state responsible for individual well-being,'' wrote Ada Finifter, a Michigan State University political science professor, in a summary of the findings. The fact that so many others believe in individual responsibility makes it likely that there will be ``shifting and unstable majorities for various reform efforts,'' she said. The National Center for Public Opinion Research in Moscow helped direct the poll with American researchers from the University of Pennsylvania, Michigan State and the Atlanta-based Carter Center, which is affiliated with Emory University. Pollsters conducted 90-minute interviews with 2,485 Soviet citizens in their homes last November and December. Carter, who commented briefly as the poll was presented, called it ``the first ever definitive poll conducted in the Soviet Union.'' The Soviet Union covers about half of Europe and 40 percent of Asia. Russian-speaking people live in every part of the country but are just one of more than 100 national groups; they make up only about 53 percent of the population. The pollsters said deep divisions among ethic groups could spell trouble for those seeking change. ``There is no question that the policies and reforms that will be implemented ... have to be so crafted as to take into account the fact that on the most fundamental and deeply felt questions, the peoples of the Soviet Union inhabit vastly different worlds,'' wrote Ellen Mickiewicz, a Carter Center fellow and political science professor at Emory. The poll found that only 1 percent of the Baltic residents, but 29 percent of Russians, said the Soviet Army always acted in the interests of the people. Since the poll was taken, one of the Baltic republics, Lithuania, has proclaimed its independence. Communist Party membership did not guarantee support of party policies, the poll found. Only 25 percent of party members polled expressed full confidence in the party and 12 percent expressed no confidence. Party members were somewhat more supportive of rapid change than non-members, the pollsters said. Forty percent said organized religion always acted in their best interests and 7 percent said it never does. But 38 percent gave no answer. Among Soviet Georgians, who include a heavy Moslem minority, 69 percent gave high marks to religion. Nationwide, 54 percent said they support free speech even at the cost of political disorder; 37 percent said public order should be more important. Only 11 percent of the respondents said they agreed with the ``old order'' precept of strict income equality; 84 percent want to permit varying incomes. Pollsters said that because some Soviet polling methods differ from those in the United States, no margin of error was assigned to the study.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Constitutional Plan Guaranteeing White Role
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: South Africa will propose a new constitutional plan in talks with black leaders that includes measures ensuring the political participation of whites, a Cabinet minister said today. Ministers from the white-minority government plan to hold preliminary talks with leaders of the black-led African National Congress on April 11. ``The government will come to the negotiating table with definite proposals,'' said Minister of Constitutional Development Gerrit Viljoen. In later, formal negotiations, he said, the government will demand that the white minority is guaranteed political and cultural rights in any new government in South Africa. Viljoen said the April 11 talks will center on procedural arrangements and obstacles standing in the way of formal negotiations. He said the South African delegation will be led by President F.W. de Klerk and Foreign Minister Pik Botha. The African National Congress has not yet named its delegation, but it is known that it will be headed by ANC leader Nelson Mandela. Mandela was released from prison and the ANC legalized in February. ANC leaders have called for national, non-racial elections to choose delegates to a constitutional convention, but the government has said that negotiations should include known and proven leaders of all political persuasions, without necessarily holding elections. Viljoen said leaders participating in the formal negotiations will have to show a clear commitment to a peaceful, negotiated solution and have abandoned violence. No such requirement has been made for participants in the April 11 talks, and leaders of the ANC's military wing are expected to participate in the discussions once the government passes legislation guaranteeing they will not be arrested. Six days before the talks, de Klerk is scheduled to meet with leaders of black tribal homelands and other black officials not connected to the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Rescued After Fishboat Sinks off Alaska
DOC.TEXT: A fishing boat ran aground and sank in heavy weather near Kayak Island, but all seven people aboard were rescued, Coast Guard officials said today. The skipper and six crew members donned survival suits, boarded a life raft Wednesday night and were taken aboard a Coast Guard helicopter, said Petty Officer Fritz Richter. ``This went real well,'' Richter said. ``After the accident, after the grounding, they did everything right.'' The 65-foot Attu, a long-line halibut schooner, based in Everett, Wash., sank in more than 50 feet of water with 1,500 gallons of fuel aboard. A decision on salvage efforts was expected later today, Richter said. The Attu apparently was in transit when it struck a reef about 200 miles east-southeast of Anchorage and began to sink in 8-to-10-foot seas with winds of more than 25 mph, he said. Attu Skipper Joe Hackstadt and six crew members were taken to Cordova, about 50 miles west of Kayak Island, Richter said.

DOC.HEAD: Fees Slashed for Housing Loans to Israel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, As part ... to CORRECT that Israeli would get U.S. loan guarantees for $400 million in private loans and clarify that it does not get $400 million in direct federal money.
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving toward sweetening an already sweet loan deal for Israel by slashing millions of dollars in fees the United States has always charged other countries. Israel supporters easily won concessions in the House and Senate on Wednesday to lower or eliminate fees normally charged borrowers who take advantage of a U.S.-subsidized housing loan program. The concessions are the first of their kind in the program's 30-year history. As part of a supplemental money bill that was going before the full House today, Israel would be able to arrange $400 million in private loans to build housing for the thousands of Soviet Jews now emigrating under Moscow's newly loosened policies. Repayment of the loans is to be guaranteed by the U.S. Treasury, making them less risky and therefore obtainable at a lower than normal interest rate. The House Foreign Affairs Committee on Wednesday approved a provision, sponsored by Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., that would allow the United States to charge a maximum loan origination fee of one-fourth of 1 percent of the loan amount, rather than the 1 percent charged all other borrowers in the program. That would save Israel $3 million. In addition, Berman's language would let the government charge Israel no more than $150,000 a year over the life of the 30-year loan to service the account, instead of the normal fee of one-half of 1 percent of the outstanding balance. That would save another $1.85 million the first year, and slightly declining amounts in later years. Acting on similar legislation, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was even more generous. It set the same limit on origination fees, but waived annual service charges entirely. Israel last used the housing guarantee program in the 1970s, when it obtained eight separate $25 million loans. It has paid the full fees on those loans, said Peter Kimm of the Agency for International Development, who has administered the program for most of its 30-year life. But Israel supporters successfully argued that the unusually large size of the current loan _ the largest ever under the program _ and Israel's excellent repayment record entitle it to special treatment. Kimm likened the fees to what any homebuyer pays for mortgage insurance, a sort of risk pool which helps defray the costs to the Treasury of making good on defaulted loans. Overall program fees will generate about $10 million this year on outstanding loans of about $1.5 billion, he said. Even with the fees, the loan would be a good deal for Israel, he said. ``The borrower gets a loan he could not otherwise obtain, under far more favorable conditions,'' including a lower interest rate, he said. ``That's a very good business deal for the borrower, and they're anxious to do so,'' even with the fees, he said. In addition to the financial benefits, Israel also will receive waivers of several normal requirements of the program, including some oversight and a stipulation that 90 percent of housing built is targeted to people with below-median incomes. The Bush administration has been lukewarm to the loan guarantees, saying it could accept them only if Israel promises not to use the money to settle Jewish emigres in the disputed occupied territories. Israel is the largest recipient of U.S. foreign aid, receiving $3 billion a year in military and economic support. In addition, the U.S. ally receives hundreds of millions of dollars worth of other special benefits, largely because of its clout with Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Year-Old Charged With Arson
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old accused of deliberately setting a bed on fire in his home has been charged with first-degree arson, police said. Investigators say the boy used matches to start the fire on a bed Monday morning. The Broward Sheriff's Office said the blaze caused $15,000 damage to the family's apartment in this Fort Lauderdale suburb. The felony charge will ensure state caseworkers become involved and help the boy, a sheriff's spokesman said Wednesday. The boy was released to his parents' custody. ``When you find that a fire was set intentionally by someone that young, he obviously needs psychological help,'' said sheriff's spokesman Al Gordon. Florida Health and Rehabilitative Service workers must now ``take judicial notice of this child and get him the help he needs,'' Gordon said. The boy's case will be handled through the juvenile system where records of the offense are sealed, Gordon said. The names of the child and his parents were not released.

DOC.HEAD: 25 Dead, Scores Injured in Savage Zulu Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to ADD that fighting between ANC and Zulu groups, Mandela and Buthelezi to appeal for peace. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Police and ...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people today took refuge in churches and schools after savage fighting between Zulu war bands with guns and knives left at least 25 people dead and scores injured, authorities said. Local reporters described the Edendale area of the southeastern province of Natal as a ``valley of death'' following the battle between rival groups for control of several villages. Bodies were seen lying in village streets and on hillsides in the rugged countryside. Much of the violence has been between supporters of Nelson Mandela's African National Congress and Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Zulu-based Inkatha party, which are fighting for control of black townships in the Natal province. Buthelezi's office said today that the two leaders plan to appear together at a Monday rally to appeal for peace. Police and hospital officials said at least 25 people had been killed and 32 critically injured in two days of bloody clashes. Scores of other people suffered minor wounds and more than 200 homes were burned, the officials said. A police report today said three people were killed in factional fights in other areas during the past 24 hours, including two women stabbed to death in a battle between rival groups. About 5,000 black trade union members paraded through central Johannesburg today to protest against government plans to sell off state enterprises. The chanting marchers, some of them carrying clubs, called for nationalization of the economy to aid poor blacks. Police, some of them using tear gas, broke up about 2,000 workers taking part in a similar march in Pretoria. In Edendale, hospital workers said the death toll was higher than 25 because some bodies were removed by relatives and the deaths not reported. The workers spoke on condition of anonymity. Police Maj. Piet Kitching said police had been fired on several times as they struggled to halt the fighting. One police officer had been wounded, he said. Police commanders said the situation was quiet around Edendale today, but some local journalists said they had reports of clashes in remote rural areas. South African army troops were helping police patrol roads and villages to restore order. Authorities said some roads were blocked by bands of armed men and warned travelers not to use them. Hundreds of people, mainly women, children and old people, fled their homes as bands of Zulus armed with guns, knives and sticks battled for control of the villages dotting the rugged Edendale Valley. Frightened people crammed into community halls and schools for protection and shelter. Thousands of people stayed away from work today because bus service was suspended or because they were too afraid to leave their homes. Some government offices and courts suspended operations. Opposition lawmaker Pierre Cronje of the Democratic Party appealed to President F.W. de Klerk to visit the area to witness the devastation. Cronje said police were unable to stop the killing and that the government needed to take drastic action to halt the violence. Thousands of Zulu fighters from the United Democratic Front and the conservative Inkatha movement have been battling around Edendale since Tuesday. Both groups are anti-apartheid, but Inkatha is more tribal-based and favors a Zulu state. Some 3,000 people have been killed in the factional fighting in Natal since 1986. The latest fighting began after buses bringing Inkatha supporters back from a rally Sunday were stoned by rival groups.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Press Agency Reopens, Collaborator Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 4 grafs at end to UPDATE with Israel lifting ban on private radio communication with Arab nations. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Press Service, an Arab-run news agency that played a key role in reporting the start of the Palestinian uprising, was allowed to reopen today after a two-year closure. Ibrahim Karaeen, co-owner of the agency, said police returned the key Wednesday and that the telephones began working today. ``I hope this means that (Israeli authorities) will realize that we can make peace only by letting the other side talk and not stifling us,'' he said. The agency was founded in 1977 by Karaeen and Raymonda Tawil, now a Washington-based journalist, and was long the main source of news about Palestinian causes for both the Israeli media and the foreign press. Palestinian journalists said they hoped the move would signal more openness toward Palestinian-owned media which have been targeted by authorities as a major source of inciting unrest in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Karaeen said army officials told him the office had been closed because authorities believed it had received funding from the PLO. He denied the accusation, contending the real issue was the agency's ability to report violence and unrest more quickly than the army. The reopening coincided with a marked decrease in anti-Israeli violence. The number of Palestinians killed in clashes with Israelis in February was nine, the lowest monthly figure since the uprising began on Dec. 8, 1987. Since the uprising started five Arab-owned news agencies or newspapers have been closed, six Palestinian journalists have been deported as uprising activists, and 90 Arab reporters have been detained, many without formal charges, said Radwan Abu Ayyash, head of the Arab Journalists Association. In the West Bank, a 70-year-old Arab man died today of stabbing and beating injuries he sustained Tuesday while trying to protect his 32-year-old son from a group of ax-wielding assailants, Arab reports said. They said the masked youths suspected that Said Kamous' son, who was killed in the attack, had cooperated with Israeli authorities. Kamous was the 201st Palestinian killed by other Arabs since the beginning of the uprising. In the unrest, 669 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis, and 43 Israelis and three foreigners have died. In Baghdad, Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat said Palestinians will resort to all possible means to achieve their goal of an independent state in the Israeli-occupied territories. ``We will enter Jerusalem victorious and will raise our flag on its walls,'' Arafat said at a rally. ``I tell them (the Israeli leaders), we will fight you with stones, with rifles and with Al-Abed,'' Arafat said, referring to the missile which Iraq tested in December. It is believed capable of striking targets within Israel. Also today, the Israeli government lifted a 30-year ban on contact between amateur radio operators and fellow hobbyists in Arab countries, an official at the Communications Ministry said. But Israeli radio enthusiasts are likely to meet a wall of silence on the other side since most Arab countries still bar communications with the Jewish state. The ministry official said the measure was taken to permit Israelis to contact foreigners in Arab countries. Arab nations with the exception of Egypt ban radio communications with Israel as part of their overall boycott of the Jewish state.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Bill to Create Department of the Environment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 6 grafs new with White House comment; picks up 6th graf pvs, A similar bill.
DOC.TEXT: Congress is sailing toward creation of a new Department of the Environment, but the proposal ran into trouble again at the White House today with a fresh threat of a veto. The House voted 371-55 on Wednesday to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level. The move is intended to give the agency greater prestige and influence within the administration. President Bush has said he wants to sign such a measure on Earth Day, April 22. But the White House strongly opposes parts of the House bill, saying they would infringe on the president's authority to manage the executive branch. The administration particularly opposes a provision that would give full autonomy to a new Bureau of Environmental Statistics within the department, including a requirement that none of its technical reports would be subject to administration review. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The president needs the authority to run his Cabinet as best he sees fit.'' He said the House version ``gives a degree of independence to this unit of the agency which we feel is unconstitutional and certainly is not in the best interests of separation of powers and presidential authority.'' Fitzwater added, ``We think we would have a shot at sustaining'' a veto, noting that Bush has won every veto battle so far. A similar bill elevating the EPA to Cabinet rank has been approved by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. It has yet to be taken up by the full Senate, which has been preoccupied with clean-air legislation. In addition to creating the government's 15th Cabinet-level agency, the House bill requires for the first time that the federal government comply with the same environmental laws on disposal of toxic wastes as industry. ``We're asking the federal government to live by the same rules as everyone else,'' said Rep. Hank Brown, R-Colo. He said several federal facilities in his state have violated toxic waste disposal requirements for years. The House bill also would require: _The new Department of the Environment to limit its use of private consultants and guard against conflicts of interest involving consultants and outside advisory panels. _The director of the independent Bureau of Environmental Statistics to be a civil servant who would not be subject to dismissal except for malfeasance. _A certain share of senior department officials, including regional administrators, to be non-political appointees. _Strengthening of enforcement against polluters, including the hiring of additional investigators. The number of criminal and civil investigators would be increased by 30 percent a year over five years. House Republicans argued that many of the additional provisions were ``designed to embarrass'' the president and force him to veto the legislation. ``We're not here to fine tune or micromanage,'' complained Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. But Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., a key sponsor of the legislation, said the bill was intended not only to change the name of the EPA, but to address some of its problems. The bill will ``depoliticize'' the EPA, provide reliable environmental statistics and put ``a halt to conflicts of interests'' at the agency, Conyers said in a statement. Conyers cited a 1989 incident in which government scientists were directed by the Office of Management and Budget to change their congressional testimony on global warming. Neither version of the bill envisions a significant expansion of the EPA. An independent regulatory agency, the EPA has about 16,000 employees and a budget of $5.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Takes Bus On Joy Ride
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy took a bus on a nine-mile ride through winding roads on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur before police caught up with him, it was reported Thursday. The New Straits Times newspaper quoted Assistant Police Commissioner Adnan Baharom as saying an officer saw the bus speeding by the station Wednesday. There appeared to be no driver, so the officer began chasing the bus in a patrol car. After a few miles, he forced the bus to stop. To his surprise, a small boy who could hardly see over the steering wheel came out, the newspaper said. Adnan said police were looking for the boy's older brother, who is in his 30s and apparently encouraged the youth to take the bus from a station. The brother had been following the stolen bus in another vehicle but panicked and drove off when he saw the police officer, Adnan said.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Displays Garbage Galore in Anti-Trash Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Tokyo ended a campaign aimed at reducing city garbage with a ``trash bash'' Thursday that featured a fashion show of used clothing, appliances plucked from dumps, and model apartments filled with discarded furniture. Trash was all over the Tokyo Dome Stadium as Sanitation Department employees tried to demonstrate just how much refuse this city of 11.9 million people generates. One of the displays was a collection of garbage trucks from around the world. The idea was to help people figure out how to produce less trash. According to department figures, Tokyo produced 4.783 million tons of garbage in 1988. That was enough to fill the 55,000-seat Dome stadium 15 times over. More than 6,400 garbage collectors in 3,547 garbage trucks pick up after metropolitan Tokyo residents, who each throw away a daily average of 3.4 pounds of trash. ``Tokyo is facing a major crisis,'' said Soji Agata, head of the Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly's committee on sanitation. ``We and the Sanitation Department pray every day that our city will not end up buried in rubbish.'' The tonnage had remained at a stable level for several years, but it began to grow at a much faster pace in 1985 and continues to increase by about 6 percent a year. The Sanitation Department says paper trash from computers and offices has increased rapidly in recent years and accounts for about 42 percent of Tokyo's garbage. Tokyo's 13 trash incineration plants are capable of handling only 80 percent of an annual 3.5 million tons of garbage that can be burned.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Killed, Three Wounded in Separate Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A soldier was shot to death and three others were injured by a grenade in attacks that coincided with the anniversary Thursday of the founding of the rebel New People's Army. There was no claim of responsibility for either attack. The first occurred about 11 p.m. Wednesday. Police Cpl. Rogelio Millare said three soldiers were standing near their patrol car in the Manila suburb of Pasig when assailants hurled a grenade at them from a passing car. One of the soldiers was hurt. Early Thursday, gunmen fatally shot Pfc. Ricardo Bucal as he rode in a car in Tanza, another Manila suburb, Millare said. Thursday was the 21st anniversary of the founding of the Communist rebels' New People's Army. In an anniversary statement distributed to news agencies, the New People's Army said it is ``determined to win victory within this decade.'' It urged dissident soldiers to reject coup plots and instead join the Communist-led revolution. The statement made no reference to attacks on soldiers and policemen around the capital. At least nine people, including a lieutenant colonel, have been killed in the Manila area in the past week in attacks. Police blame rebels. Also Thursday, an anonymous caller telephoned the Japanese Embassy and said a bomb had been planted there because it was ``our anniversary.'' The building was evacuated, but no bomb was found. A Japanese diplomat said the caller spoke in Tagalog, the main Philippine language, but did not identify himself as a rebel. Concern over security in Manila prompted the U.S. Navy this week to ban most non-essential travel to the capital. The order, issued Monday, applies to the 6,000 sailors at the Subic Bay naval base but not to about 9,000 airmen at the U.S. Clark Air Base. Airmen, however, were ordered not to travel at night between Clark and Manila, 50 miles to the south. Meanwhile, a group of dissident soldiers vowed to overthrow President Corazon Aquino's government. ``We reiterate our earlier pronouncement that as the corrupt, incompetent, vindictive and isolated Aquino regime has, by its own acts, lost its justification to remain in power, the Filipino soldiers are no longer under obligation to maintain its existence,'' the statement Thursday said. ``On the contrary, they are constitutionally and morally duty bound to topple it.'' The statement was from the Young Officers Union, which was linked to the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Kills 10, Injures 100
DOC.TEXT: A storm tore through southeastern Bangladesh, killing at least 10 people, injuring 100 and destroying thousands of mud-and-straw houses, police said Thursday. The storm Wednesday night packed winds up to 60 mph. It uprooted trees, toppled electricity poles and destroyed rice crops in the Noakhali district near the Bay of Bengal, the police said. The storm's full impact was not known because of disrupted communications. Storms last weekend killed 34 people and injured nearly 800 in eastern and southern Bangladesh. Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest nations, is frequently hit with storms and inundated by floods.

DOC.HEAD: `Third World' Tour Angers Appalachia
DOC.TEXT: A San Francisco travel agency's plans to sponsor a nine-day ``Third World in America'' tour has riled Appalachian tourism directors. For $500, Global Exchange will take participants on an excursion through Virginia, West Virginia and Tennessee on June 17-25 to see impoverished families, crumbling coal mining towns and appliance-strewn streams. ``I suggest that those folks could save a lot of money and get a great dose of Third World reality simply by walking through the barrio in Los Angeles,'' West Virginia Commerce Commissioner John Brown said Wednesday. Global Exchange, which has been in business for 1{ years, specializes in ``awareness'' tours to such countries as Haiti, the Dominican Republic and Brazil. Appalachia will be the agency's first domestic trip. ``What brings a place alive and what makes it so interesting are the people who live there and the problems they're confronting,'' tour coordinator Laurie Adams said Wednesday. ``People would want to see how they are dealing with unemployment and environmental problems.'' Adams said Global Exchange participants are usually students, community volunteers or government officials interested in meeting grassroots activists trying to solve social and environmental problems. ``One of the reasons we focused on Appalachia is there are people working hard to solve their problems,'' Adams said. The tentative itinerary includes a visit to a coal mining symposium in Knoxville, Tenn., talks with members of the Commission on Religion in Appalachia in Tennessee and a final stop at the Highlander Education and Research Center in New Market, Tenn. Adams said she also was considering visiting Camp Solidarity, the former headquarters for union coal miners in West Virginia during their 10-month strike against Pittston Coal Group Inc. Don Wick, director of information for the Tennessee Department of Tourism Development, said he's afraid the tour will reinforce stereotypes. He said the ``real South'' includes the ``sophisticated and prosperous'' cities of Nashville, Knoxville and Chattanooga. ``If you're looking for poverty and environmental problems, yes, you can find them in our three states,'' said Cindy Ford, spokeswoman for the Nashville Chamber of Commerce. ``But I don't think we have any more problems than any other state.'' And Brown said: ``If they want to visit West Virginia, they can come for the whitewater rafting or to visit one of our state parks. It might be a chance for them to breathe clean air.''

DOC.HEAD: Hawke Claims Record Fourth Victory in General Election
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke claimed victory Thursday in the March 24 general election, becoming the first Labor leader to win four consecutive terms. His opponent, Liberal Party leader Andrew Peacock, conceded defeat. Final results still are not in, but preliminary results gave Labor 77 seats in the 148-seat House of Representatives. Peacock's conservative party won 70, and one seat was held by an independent. Hawke, 60, has been in power since 1983 and is the longest-serving prime minister in Australia's history. He campaigned on promises of stability. In his acceptance speech, he promised to work for ``all Australians.'' ``It is the commitment of myself and my colleagues that we will, from the first day of new government, set about undertaking the hard work needed to secure an Australian future of greaster prosperity, social justice, fairness and security,'' Hawke said. Labor was hurt by Australia's $100 billion foreign debt and record 18 percent interest rates. Going into the election, it held 85 seats in the House of Representatives. Peacock, 51, a former foreign minister, campaigned against the Hawke government's handling of the economy. He also lashed out at a Japanese proposal to build a high-tech, futuristic city in Australia. This brought charges of racism from Hawke, which Peacock denied. It was Peacock's second bid for the leadership. Political analysts said his defeat may mark the end of a 26-year career in politics. Peacock said he would resign as leader of the Liberal Party, and he endorsed his treasury spokesman, John Hewson, to replace him. Hewson said he would retain Peacock in the No. 2 position.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges No Job Discrimination Against AIDS Sufferers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, proclaiming the government ``on a wartime footing'' to find a cure for AIDS, today urged an end to discrimination against AIDS sufferers in the workplace. ``We're in a fight against a disease, not a fight against people. And we will not and we must not tolerate discrimination,'' he said in a speech to the National Leadership Coalition on AIDS. Bush's comments reflected no new policy initiatives on the deadly disease, nor did he address the controversial issue of immigration restrictions on people infected with the AIDS virus. Instead, he touted the $3.5 billion he is seeking this year to fund AIDS treatment, education and research at the National Institutes for Health in Bethesda, Md., and the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. ``We're on a wartime footing at NIH and CDC. Tonight like every night, the lights will burn late in Bethesda and Atlanta, as a group of American pioneers work to solve this problem. If they do _ I should say, when they do _ it will be one of the greatest things our nation could do for the world.'' Bush was interrupted several times by AIDS activists. Urvashi Vaid, executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, waved a sign reading, ``Talk is cheap. AIDS funding is not.'' Vaid, who was escorted out by security personnel, later said she thought Bush said some good things, but should have addressed the immigration issue. Bush eventually paused and interrupted his speech to say that he hoped he could help the protesters understand that ``Not only you care but we care too, and I'm going to continue to do my very, very best.'' Five protesters were arrested before Bush arrived when they tried to gain admittance to the conference to hear the president's speech. Bush called for compassion, stating that he and his wife, Barbara, have lost friends to the disease, friends for whom their love ``was just as great and just as intense as for anyone lost to heart disease or cancer or accidents.'' Bush called on Congress to pass legislation barring discrimination against those infected with the virus, and he urged business executives in his audience to keep HIV-infected people in the workforce. ``They can serve many more productive years with no threat to you, your other workers or your companies,'' he said. The president consulted this morning with members of his presidential commission on AIDS before speaking to the Arlington audience. The immigration issue has prompted several organizations to announce they will boycott an international conference on AIDS in San Francisco this summer because they want Bush to lift immigration restrictions on AIDS-infected people. The White House, however, has been trying to deflect the heat to Congress, saying the administration has done all its authority allows. The French and Swiss have said they won't send official delegations to the Sixth International Conference on AIDS in June. The European Parliament also has called on European scientists not to attend because of the U.S. immigration policy, and other organizations _ including the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies _ have declined to participate. AIDS activists had hoped Bush would use his appearance today before the National Business Leadership Conference on AIDS _ his first major speech on AIDS _ to address the visa issue, but he did not mention it. The immigration restriction was ordered by Congress, which passed legislation in 1987 directing that infection with HIV _ the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS _ be added to the list of contagious diseases used to prevent foreigners from entering the United States. The White House last year adopted a policy granting 30-day waivers for people to attend conferences or get medical attention. It also has expedited waivers for people planning to attend the San Francisco conference. The waiver process was designed to ensure confidentiality, with no permanent identifying mark on a person's passport, said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. But administration officials say that's as far as they can go. ``We have done everything within our executive powers to facilitate travel to this country for the conference,'' Ms. Glen said. As to HIV being on the list of excludable diseases, ``it's a congressional law. It's up to Congress'' to change it, she said. Some lawmakers dispute the White House's interpretation of the law and say the administration unilaterally can remove HIV infection from the list. The federal Centers for Disease Control has indicated it wants to remove HIV infection from the list because there is no medical reason to exclude HIV-infected people from entering the country. Legislation is being drafted by Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., to direct the Department of Health and Human Services, which includes CDC, to review and revise the list, said Steve Morin, the congresswoman's legislative assistant for health policy. But, he said, nothing will happen without input from the White House. Dana Van Gorder, an organizer of the AIDS conference, said several thousand potential participants are boycotting the event, which had expected to register 12,000 participants. Groups that have said they will boycott the conference are from France, Austria, Brazil, England, Spain, West Germany, Norway, Denmark, Sweden and Canada. Also canceling were the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, the International Association of People with AIDS and the International Planned Parenthood Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Mitch Synder Hopes to Spend Time at Monastery
DOC.TEXT: Mitch Snyder, a nationally recognized advocate for the homeless has requested permission to spend at least a month at a Virginia monastery. ``I'm a religious person, and from time to time it's important to renew our relationship with God,'' Snyder said. Snyder, 46, said Thursday that he would like to spend some time with ``a community of people committed to prayer.'' He said he hoped to enter a Trappist monastary in Virginia in May. ``I'm awaiting to confirm that with them. I hope the publicity doesn't mess it up.'' Snyder works with the Community for Creative Non-Violence, a religious-oriented organization founded in 1970 by a Paulist priest. The group began protesting the Vietnam War and eventually took on the cause of the poor.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Seek $1 Billion a Year for Aging Research
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of national groups called Thursday for stepped-up government research on aging to fight the illnesses that rob the elderly of their independence. The Task Force for Aging Research Funding said the nation is pouring increasing amounts of money into ``sick care'' for older Americans while it fails to adequately finance research to help the elderly stay healthy. The coalition called for federal spending of $1 billion a year on aging research, bringing the spending level up to par with that for other major health concerns such as cancer, AIDS and heart research. The Alliance for Aging Research, which is leading the coalition, issued a report warning that the gaps in federal research ``are placing the successful aging and independence of older Americans at risk.'' ``The successes in health and medicine in the 20th century have primarily saved lives in youth and middle age,'' it said. ``Advances affecting the cure and prevention of chronic illnesses in late life have been few.'' John L. Steffens, the alliance's chairman and president and chief executive officer of Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets, said the nation pays a heavy price for its inability to cure or prevent Alzheimer's disease, osteoporosis, urinary incontinence, breast cancer, arthritis and other conditions that affect the elderly. ``Research that will help us avoid these illnesses and the costs they bring is the most effective investment we can make,'' Steffens said.
