Both sides seemed to be yielding in the war of wills over Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence, the strongest defiance of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his five years as Soviet leader. ``I think Lithuania is seeking a way out, and I think Gorbachev is seeking a way out,'' said Algirdas Brazauskas, head of the Lithuanian Communist Party, which split with Moscow in December. But the war of words did not die down entirely. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, asked about the Defense Ministry's offer, said: ``I don't have much trust in this promise. There have been instances where very high military officials have lied.'' Lithuanian leaders are angry that the military said nothing before arresting 23 deserters Tuesday. They said the military had agreed to discuss any such move in advance. Defense Ministry officials told Tass that Lithuanians who left the Soviet armed forces when their republic declared independence would not be punished if they resumed their military service. However, those who continue to hide will be ``searched out, detained and be subject to criminal punishment in accordance with current law,'' they said. Red Army soldiers on Tuesday stormed two psychiatric hospitals in Lithuania to apprehend deserters. Witnesses said some of the deserters and a policeman who tried to stop the detentions were beaten. The Lithuanian prosecutor's office said Thursday it had opened a criminal investigation into the beating of the police officer. The republic's Interior Ministry said the policeman sustained a concussion. Lt. Gen. Frants Markovsky of the military General Staff told Tass a special military commission had been set up to track down deserters. Soviet officers visited the families of 97 soldiers who deserted, and in 40 cases were told the soldiers would return, Markovsky told Tass. In 42 other cases, parents said they were willing to help the military but did not know where their sons were, Markovsky said. ``No reasoning and appeals for common sense and for parental wisdom, however, worked with the parents of the other 15 deserters,'' he said. Markovsky said 51 soldiers already had returned to their units. Soviet officials estimate 250 Lithuanian soldiers have deserted. Lithuanian figures put the number at about 900. Wednesday was the deadline for Lithuanians to comply with Gorbachev's order issued last week to turn in their firearms or have them seized. Deputy Interior Minister Vaclavas Zabarauskas said Thursday that only 1,500 of the 30,000 registered guns had been turned in. Local officials have said they will not cooperate with Moscow to collect them. Lithuania's chief prosecutor, Arturas Paulauskas, said a general of the Soviet Interior Ministry, Vladimir Maximov, had arrived in Vilnius to take charge of the collection of guns. ``I gave him (Maximov) a warning that using force to break into homes is a violation of the law,'' Paulauskas said. ``He said, `I am here to fulfill Gorbachev's order,' but I don't know how he's going to do it.'' Tass said the sign-up for a volunteer Lithuanian ``territorial defense'' border guard continued in the port of Klaipeda and in Lithuania's second-biggest city, Kaunas, despite Lithuanian leaders' assurances it was being suspended. Landsbergis, meanwhile, appealed again for the U.S. Congress to extend recognition to Lithuania, which was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. ``Support for Lithuania is support for freedom and democracy in Eastern Europe,'' he said in a telegram to congressmen and senators. ``This support would also undoubtedly help Mr. Gorbachev _ it would stop him from making a great mistake.'' Czechoslovakia's state news agency reported Thursday that President Vaclav Havel had offered his country as a neutral site for talks between Gorbachev and Landsbergis. The offer came in a telegram sent to the two men, the CTK news agency reported. It reported the telegram said: ``Any forms of force, including a mere threat, can severely damage the peaceful arrangement in Europe.'' The government of Iceland on Thursday also offered to mediate the dispute and provide a venue for possible talks between Lithuania and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Refueling: `Matter of Deep Concern' for U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Libya has conducted in-flight refueling tests for jet fighter-bombers, a key step for increasing the range of Moammar Gadhafi's military aircraft throughout the Middle East, Pentagon sources said Thursday. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams, declined to confirm the report of such tests publicly but said such a development would be ``troubling'' to U.S. officials. ``Obviously, it would be a matter of very serious and deep concern to the United States,'' Williams said when queried about the report. A Pentagon official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Thursday that the Libyans ``have been working on this for quite some time.'' ``We consider it a serious matter,'' said the source. The administration's concern about Libya obtaining such capabilities have been compounded in light of recent reports that the Middle Eastern nation has been producing chemical weapons. Last year, administration officials reported that the Soviet Union had sold Libya 6 SU-24 Fencers, high-performance fighter-bombers that can be refueled in flight. This would allow the jets to conduct long-range strikes, posing a potential threat to several nations in the region, including Israel. According to a report published Thursday in The New York Times, the recent Libyan test involved a Mirage F-1 and an American-made C-130 transport plane that had been converted into a refueling tanker. During the test, the report said, a refueling probe mounted on the C-130 was connected to the Mirage on four out of six attempts, but it wasn't clear whether fuel was actually transferred during the maneuver. Libya also has tried to obtain an aerial refueling system from Moscow for the SU-24s, the report said. ``We've expressed our concerns about it,'' to the Soviets, the Pentagon official said. According to a publication of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, the Libyans have a dozen French-made F-1s, a lightweight fighter-bomber. Another official, who also spoke privately, said the development has prompted renewed expressions of concern inside the administration. ``We'd be worried about any long-range refueling capabilities the Libyans acquire,'' the official said. Libya, under Gadhafi's leadership, has been a major purchaser of Soviet military equipment in the past 15 years. Following the reports of last year's jet purchase, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the administration has ``long been concerned with Gadhafi's erratic and dangerous behavior. ... Libya continues to act in an unacceptable fashion, particularly in its support for terrorism and international subversion.'' He said the United States had talked to the Soviets about arms sales in the region. With Soviet bombers ``Libya could threaten all of its neighbors,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Closes Off Occupied Territories to Prevent Violence
DOC.TEXT: Authorities imposed a curfew on the occupied Gaza Strip on Thursday and ordered special precautions in the West Bank and Arab areas within Israel to prevent violence on the anniversary of a bloody 1976 Arab riot. In Jerusalem, about 200 supporters of the anti-Arab Kach Party held a march and burned an American flag. They demanded the expulsion of Palestinians from the occupied territories and accused the United States of pressuring Israel to swap land for peace. The curfew took effect Thursday and confined the 700,000 Palestinians of the Gaza Strip to their homes. Arab reporters said roadblocks were set up outside Jerusalem to stop West Bank residents from entering the city and Israel on the Friday anniversary. The 47 Arab towns and villages inside Israel plan to hold a general strike Friday to mark the anniversary of the riots, which broke out over Israel's confiscation of Arab-owned land in the Galilee. Police shot to death six people in the protests. The Israeli daily Maariv reported that authorities were taking ``unprecedented precautions'' because the holiday falls on the first Friday of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan. It is normally a tense time in the occupied territories. All leaves for police were cancelled and the army readied reserve forces in case of trouble, newspapers and radio stations reported. An army spokesman said soldiers may close certain areas of the West Bank. In past periods of tension, police and soldiers have blocked young Moslems from attending Friday prayer services at Jerusalem's Al-Aqsa Mosque, one of Islam's holiest sites. The army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said on army radio: ``We will invest all the forces necessary to keep things quiet in Judea, Samaria and the Gaza Strip.'' Judea and Samaria are the Biblical names for the West Bank. In other developments Thursday: _Col. Yehuda Meir, the former army commander in the West Bank city of Nablus, pleaded innocent to charges he ordered soldiers to break the arms and legs of a group of bound and gagged Palestinians in army custody. Meir, 37, entered the plea as his trial opened in military court in Tel Aviv. He faces eight counts, including causing bodily harm with malicious intent. Meir is the highest-ranking officer to be tried for deviations in the 27-month Palestinian uprising. _A 70-year-old Palestinian man died of stabbing and beating injuries suffered during an attack by fellow Arabs Tuesday at the West Bank's Nur Shams refugee camp, Arab reports said. The victim, Said Kazmous, was wounded as he tried to protect his 32-year-old son from a group of masked Palestinians. The masked men accused the son of being an informer for Israeli authorities. Kazmous' son also died in the attack. It brought to 201 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the uprising. Most have been accused of being informers or cooperating in other ways with Israel. A total of 669 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soliders and civilians in the uprising, and 43 Israelis have been slain.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes in Favor of Legal Abortions
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Thursday in favor of legislation affirming that abortions are legal in New Hampshire. The bill returns to the House, which passed it in different form. Thursday's voice vote followed a 14-10 vote for an amendment that would permit legal abortions until the pregnant woman's doctor determines that the fetus could live outside the womb on its own. Abortions would be permitted in some circumstances afterward. The House version called for unrestricted legal abortions up to the 25th week of pregnancy, and under some circumstances afterward. Republican Gov. Judd Gregg pledged to veto the House bill, but his position on a more restrictive version isn't known. It would take 16 votes in the Senate to override a veto. During debate Thursday, supporters of the bill said it reflects a New Hampshire tradition of not intruding on the right of people to make personal decisions. Opponents said it sanctioned killing.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 300 People Reported Killed in Angola Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Angola's Marxist government claimed Thursday that its soldiers killed 270 guerrillas last week, and the U.S.-supported rebels said they shot down a government supply plane, killing all 25 people aboard. In France, the Foreign Ministry announced that a French technician abducted by Angolan rebels died during a long, rugged march with his captors through the southern African country. Angola's state airline confirmed a plane was lost and was investigating the cause of the crash. The other claims could not immediately be verified. The rebels have been fighting to share power with Luanda's Soviet-backed government since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Angola's state news agency ANGOP said 270 guerrillas of Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, were killed in fighting in six provinces in central and southern provinces last week. The report said 37 government soldiers were killed and 63 wounded in the fighting. The rebels released a statement in Lisbon saying they shot down a government supply plane Tuesday as it flew from Huambo to Cuito, the capital of central Bie province. They said all 25 people on the plane died. The Portuguese news agency Lusa reported from Luanda that a Spanish-built Casa 212 plane of Angola's TAAG airline crashed 20 miles west of Cuito, killing 25 people, including three Portuguese nationals. Lusa said the three were technicians with a Portuguese engineering firm in Luanda. TAAG officials were investigating the cause of the crash, and no government official would comment on the rebels' claim of responsibility, Lusa reported. The rebel statement claimed a Soviet-built Sukhoi 22 aircraft piloted by Cubans bombed a rebel base at Likwa on Wednesday in retaliation for the downing of the plane. That report could not be independently confirmed. The U.S. military aid the rebels receive reportedly includes Stinger ground-to-air missiles. The guerrillas are said to have used the missiles in attacks on government supply and fighter planes in the past. The French Foreign Ministry condemned the UNITA rebel movement for the kidnapping of Jean-Francois Grossenbacher and expressed regret that the rebels had been unable to fulfill a pledge to free him unconditionally. Grossenbacher, 37, was captured Feb. 21 when guerrillas ambushed a convoy of Angola's state oil company. UNITA announced on Feb. 22 that it was willing to release Grossenbacher. The French statement said the technician died ``in the course of a prolonged march through very difficult terrain.'' Under a peace accord signed in December 1988, by Angola, Cuba and South Africa, Cuba withdrew 31,000 of its estimated 50,000 troops from Angola. Nevertheless, the fighting in the impoverished nation has continued.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Narrowly Rejects Assistance Plan for Coal Miners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate today narrowly rejected a $500 million assistance plan for coal miners despite pleas from senators from high-sulfur coal states that tougher pollution controls would drive thousands of miners out of work. The senators rejected the amendment offered by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., by a vote of 50-49. The vote was a major victory for Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and the White House. Both had strongly opposed the assistance package as being too expensive and discriminatory against other workers. Byrd, saying he was making ``an appeal for justice,'' had pleaded with senators to support the aid, arguing that coal miners were being singled out under the new clean air legislation, which will require severe cuts in emissions from coal-fired Midwest power plants. Those pollution controls are expected to cause some utilities to switch from high-sulfur coal to other fuels, threatening the jobs of as many as 5,000 miners. But Mitchell and other opponents called the aid plan disriminatory because thousands of workers in other industries such as steel and petrochemical also could lose their jobs, but would have no such benefits. ``This amendment discriminates against all workers who are not coal miners.,'' declared Mitchell. The Byrd proposal has been vigorously opposed by the Bush administration and the Senate leadership because it goes contrary to a compromise agreement reached with the White House on clean air legislation. Critics of the amendment also argued that coal miners should not be singled out when workers in other industries might also face job losses and would receive no assistance. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, fearing the assistance plan might threaten the entire bill, has put pressure on fellow senators to defeat the amendment and has tried to persuade Byrd to go along with a cheaper assistance package that would include workers in other occupations. Byrd, D-W.Va., told a group of coal miners Wednesday that Mitchell's compromise ``doesn't do what needs to be done'' and that he would take his chances on the Senate floor _ a ``roll of the dice,'' as he has characterized it on one occasion. Senators have not been eager to cross either Byrd, the powerful chairman of the Appropriations Committee, or Mitchell, who can determine when a senator's pet legislation will come up for floor action. At one point, Byrd was believed to have enough votes for approval of the coal miner assistance proposal, but Mitchell refused to bring the matter up for a vote. About 500 miners and family members demonstrated outside the Capitol on Wednesday to protest the clean air legislation. ``This is a human issue with real people and real jobs on the line,'' said Robert Murray, president of Ohio Valley Coal, who addressed the miners. He said he wanted senators to ``see the faces'' of the people who stand to become unemployed.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite's Booster Falls Through Atmosphere, Misses Land
DOC.TEXT: The rocket that launched a $157 million communications satellite but failed to put it in the proper orbit burned up harmlessly in the atmosphere or fell into the ocean, authorities said Thursday. The Titan 3 booster came down at 9:20 a.m. EST Wednesday, about the time the U.S. Space Command had predicted, said Army Maj. Thomas Niemann, a Space Command spokesman. ``We don't have any indication that it survived'' the fiery descent through the atmosphere, Niemann said, but any fragments that made it to Earth would have landed in the Pacific southeast of Taiwan. The uninsured Intelsat VI satellite, launched by the rocket March 14, is about 300 miles above Earth, a temporary position thousands of miles lower than it is supposed to be. ``We can keep it there for several months, if not up to a year,'' said Tony Trujillo, a spokesman for Intelsat, a 118-nation consortium that owns the satellite. ``It's basically where we want to keep it for a while.'' Officials of Intelsat and Hughes Aircraft Co., the satellite's builder, on Tuesday held their second meeting with officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to discuss rescue possibilities, including a space shuttle rescue. ``Obviously, there are a lot of technical issues that have to be dealt with,'' Trujillo said. ``But we're very heartened by NASA's willingness to explore the possibility with us.'' NASA has said a rescue attempt is feasible but more talks are needed before any decision can be made. The 5-ton Intelsat VI satellite was intended for a geosynchronous orbit 22,300 miles high, from where it would have transmitted three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously. It was to have eventually replaced two older satellites over the Atlantic and was supposed to last 13 years. The satellite wound up in its uselessly low orbit after failing to separate properly from the second stage of the booster. Intelsat engineers managed to separate the satellite via computer commands, then maneuvered it into the slightly higher, 300-mile orbit. The second stage of the booster, however, remained trapped in an orbit that swung within about 100 miles of Earth and gradually was pulled down by gravity. Martin Marietta Corp., which conducted the $272 million launch, has blamed the failure on an engineering design error. The same problem was found and corrected on a Titan 3 rocket scheduled to launch another Intelsat VI satellite in three months, said company spokeswoman Judy Stowell.

DOC.HEAD: Palestine Press Service Reopened, Israel Ease Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Workers hooked up telexes and cleared away debris in the Palestine Press Service on Thursday after police lifted a two-year closure of the agency that once served as the main source of news on the Palestinian uprising. The reopening of the Arab-run service was one of the first easings of the tough restrictions that Israel imposed on Palestinian journalists at the height of the uprising. Yossi Olmert, head of Israel's Government Press Office, said there was decreased international interest in the 27-month revolt, so authorities adopted a more liberal attitude. ``The uprising is declining, and some of the pressure is off,'' Olmert told The Associated Press. ``We can live with the press and the uprising at the same time.'' Arab newspapers still must submit all articles to the Israeli military censor. The army also continues to block foreign journalists from entering trouble spots by declaring them closed military areas. Two weeks ago, the army gave a hint of easing restrictions when its spokesman's office issued a directive ordering its employees to respond to queries by Arab journalists. Such a practice was unthinkable early in the uprising, when Palestinian journalists often put the spokesman's office on the defensive with up-to-the-minute reports of troops firing on Palestinian stone-throwers. At the time, the Palestine Press Service was the main liaison between Palestinians and the foreign press. It distributed information from a network of dozens of stringers, accompanying foreign journalists to trouble spots and providing translation services. ``In the beginning of the uprising, hundreds of journalists would come here. We were the main source of information,'' said the agency's co-owner, Ibrahim Karaeen, speaking in his office in Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem. On March 30, 1988, four months into the uprising, police ordered the agency closed. Karaeen said army officials told him the office was shut because of suspicions it was funded by Yasser Arafat's PLO. For the next two years, the four-room office stood vacant, its door sealed by a police lock. Pigeons sneaked through an open window, leaving behind piles of droppings and three nests of eggs on a table in Karaeen's corner office. Karaeen said he was given no explanation why the ban was lifted. Karaeen said the organization now faces tough competition from more than a dozen Palestinian news agencies set up in the last two years, often one-man offices with a computer and a fax machine. Since the uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in December 1987, authorities have closed five Arab-owned news agencies or newspapers, deported six Palestinian journalists for alleged uprising activities and detained 90 others, said Abu Ayash, former editor in chief of the Palestine Press Service.

DOC.HEAD: Deaf Judge Seeking Election to Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: State Appeals Judge Richard Brown reviews court testimony using a video monitor connected to a stenographer's machine that displays words as they are spoken. Being deaf hasn't hindered his performance in court, nor has it dimmed his aspirations. In Tuesday's non-partisan election, Brown will challenge Justice Donald Steinmetz for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court. The candidate's deafness hasn't been an issue in an unusually hotly contested campaign that includes sparring over abortion, court workloads, and campaign funding. In Wisconsin, the seven Supreme Court justices are chosen in statewide elections for 10-year terms. Incumbents seldom are challenged. Brown, a district judge since 1978, lost his hearing to a brain tumor in 1983. While he relies on the video monitor during campaign debates and court sessions, he also reads lips, and can now detect sounds with a device implanted in December in his inner ear. ``My brain is still trying to figure out certain sounds,'' he said. Steinmetz, 65, was elected to the bench in Milwaukee in 1966 and joined the high court in 1980. Brown has accused Steinmetz of backing out of a televised debate because he didn't want to discuss abortion, the environment, and the Supreme Court workload. Steinmetz said the judicial code of ethics prevents him from stating his personal position on issues, but he's been endorsed by the political action committee of Wisconsin Right to Life. Steinmetz's wife is involved with the pregnancy hotline of the anti-abortion group, but Steinmetz said it was wrong for Brown to suggest that abortion is a campaign issue. Brown has said he personally favors abortion rights, and he's been endorsed by the abortion-rights group Voters for Choice in Wisconsin. But he, too, cautioned that ``legally, I have no position. I'm bound by the law of the state of Wisconsin and the Constitution.'' Brown has rankled Steinmetz as well as Chief Justice Nathan S. Heffernan with a campaign claim that Supreme Court productivity has declined and justices spend too much time bickering. Steinmetz disputes the claim, and alleges that Brown's candidacy is ``bankrolled'' by special interest groups, particularly unions and trial lawyers. Brown denies he is tied to special interests and has called on Steinmetz to cancel a television commercial that quotes reports saying Brown was offered $250,000 from lawyers to challenge Steinmetz.

DOC.HEAD: Plan to Form Government Reached, Protestors Demand Probe Into Stasi Ties
DOC.TEXT: The two major political parties agreed Thursday on a basic plan to form East Germany's first free government, but thousands of demonstrators said the leadership was tainted by ties to the former secret police. Crowds marched through major cities to demand that the newly elected Parliament be purged of members who reputedly worked for the notorious security apparatus of the old Communist order. The rallies were held a few hours after the main political parties said they had agreed on most of the conditions for forming a coalition government. Lothar de Maiziere, leader of the Christian Democratic-led alliance that finished first in the March 18 elections, is trying to form a government with the left-leaning Social Democrats, who finished a distant second. In a joint statement, the groups said they ``concurred on most basic points,'' and that their differences ``are negotiable.'' More talks are expected next week, but no date was given. De Maiziere has said he hopes to have a governent in place in two weeks. A coalition with the Social Democrats would give de Maiziere the two-thirds majority he needs to control the 400-member Parliament and muscle through his proposal for swift reunification with West Germany. The Social Democrats have expressed concern about whether they can work with the more conservative members of de Maiziere's three-party alliance. The Social Democrats also favor a more gradual process for reunification than the conservatives. The groups that led last fall's revolt, which toppled the former Communist government, called for nationwide demonstrations Thursday to demand an investigation of the newly elected members of Parliament. The groups claim many of the lawmakers were informers for the hated secret police, known as Stasi. The 85,000-member Stasi and its 109,000 informers were used by East Germany's hard-line Stalinist government for decades to control the country. Under pressure from pro-democracy groups, outgoing Premier Hans Modrow ordered the secret police disbanded after the overthrow of hard-liner Erich Honecker last fall. About 20,000 people marched through downtown East Berlin to the Parliament building to protest what they called the continued influence of the Stasi. ``Stasi equals Nazi'' and ``This is irony - Stasi in Parliament'' read placards. Tourists took photograhs, spectators lined the march route and music blared from speakers as the protesters marched from Alexander Square to the Parliament building. The state news agency ADN reported that about 10,000 people took part in a demonstration in the city of Leipzig, where the peaceful revolt against four decades of Communist rule began last year. Protests also were held in Jena, Karl-Marx-Stadt, and Dresden, ADN said. The shadow of the massive secret police network has clouded talks on forming a new government, considered a prelude to eventual unification with West Germany. Ibrahim Boehme temporarily resigned as head of the Social Democrats until his name could be cleared of allegations he was a Stasi informant. Similar allegations have been made against de Maiziere and others. Both men have denied them.

DOC.HEAD: Black Activist Gives Inflammatory Speech Belittling Slavery
DOC.TEXT: The enslavement of blacks was ``no big deal'' compared to the current ``breakdown of civilization,'' says onetime civil rights pioneer James Meredith. Meredith, 56, who in 1962 was the first black admitted to the University of Mississippi and is now an aide to conservative Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., made his remarks during a speech Wednesday at Suffolk University. ``The making of slavery as an institution does not have near the significance as is placed on it,'' Meredith said. Other races also were enslaved, including the ancient Israelites and white Europeans, he said. ``The reason we are where we are is not because we were slaves,'' he said. ``And if we continue to use that as an excuse, we're going to default the future of our children. ... ``The fact that blacks were slaves is no big deal. The breakdown of civilization is a big deal.'' Meredith said blacks remained second-class citizens, however, and he blamed the nation's liberal elite, most of them white, who he said have conspired to keep black people down. Meredith said there exists no documentation of whites ever capturing African blacks for slavery. Rather, he said, blacks sold each other into slavery. The enslavement of the blacks ``was the decision and work of the black race _ and in my judgment a wise one _ to reach the reality of the human experience at the time,'' he said. Literacy rates among blacks were actually higher in the 1800s than today, Meredith said. Ethelbert Miller, director of the Afro-American Resource Center at Howard University, said Thursday that Meredith's views should not be taken seriously. ``If he gave a seminar I wouldn't go, but he is entitled to his opinion,'' said Miller, adding that he also acknowledges Meredith's importance to the civil rights movement.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Urges Review of Nuclear Fail-Safe Systems
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union should review their nuclear fail-safe systems, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said Thursday. ``If nationalists or terrorists overran a Soviet nuclear storage site in one of the republics, would the superpowers coordinate their actions?'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., asked in a speech on the changing threat worldwide. Ethnic unrest in Azerbaijan and Lithuania's declaration of independence March 11 have led Moscow to resort to military force. The Bush administration, Nunn said, should urge the Soviet Union to join the United States in conducting separate, but parallel reviews, of fail-safe and control programs. Nunn also suggested using the Nuclear Risk Reductions Centers for talks about how the two superpowers could avoid an inadvertent nuclear war. In his second major speech in a week, Nunn acknowledged the lessening Soviet conventional threat and questioned whether the Bush administration is correctly characterizing the Soviet's modernization of its strategic forces. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said unequivocally that there has been no change in Soviet strategic forces and that the only change at all has been in improving their forces. ``The administration has tended to overstate its case,'' Nunn said. U.S. intelligence, he said, has found a cutback in the Soviet's Blackjack bomber production. In addition, the Soviets have ceased patrolling U.S. coasts with its Yankee-class SSBM and patrolling north of Canada with its nuclear-armed Bear-H bomber. In his speech, delivered on the Senate floor, Nunn also discussed: _His complaints last week that the administration's fiscal 1991 defense budget has several major holes Congress will fill if the Pentagon doesn't. Cheney disputed some of Nunn's allegations and said the Pentagon is accounting for rapid changes in Eastern Europe in fashioning a spending plan for fiscal 1992 to 1997. ``It is crucial to note, however, that Secretary Cheney made no claim that the administration's fiscal 1991 budget request reflects all these assumptions,'' Nunn said Thursday. Questioned about Nunn's comments, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday: ``It would be very difficult, if not _ dare one say _ imprudent, to send up a '91 budget on the basis of things that haven't happened yet. As events change, we will adjust our plans accordingly.'' _The likelihood of the Soviet launching a ``go-it-alone'' attack on Western Europe. The chances of such an offensive is remote, according to Nunn, who also said the Kremlin would have a difficult time re-establishing ``a credible threat of a large-scale conventional attack on NATO.'' _The dispute within the Bush administration over the potential for reversing the dramatic events in the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact nations. CIA Director William Webster has told Congress it will be difficult; Cheney disagrees. Shortly after Webster's comments, Cheney said the CIA director's testimony ``was not helpful'' to Bush's policies.

DOC.HEAD: Three Aftershocks of Upland Quake Reported
DOC.TEXT: Three small aftershocks from last month's jarring earthquake shook the area early Wednesday, but no damage was reported, authorities said. The aftershocks were centered five miles northwest of Upland. The first two registered 2.4 on the Richter scale and struck at 6:36 a.m. and 6:38 a.m. Five hours later, 2.3-magnitude tremor was recorded, said Robert Finn, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The Feb. 28 magnitude 5.5 quake jolted most of Southern California but caused only isolated damage. It has been followed by hundreds of aftershocks. Upland is east of Los Angeles in western San Bernardino County. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 can cause moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, and 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Dead in Ghana from Meningitis Outbreak
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of cerebrospinal menigitis has claimed at least 15 lives in Abrumasi, a remote area 480 miles north of Ghana's capital, health officials said Thursday. The officials said a team of doctors had been sent to the area with vaccines to treat the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Washington State Expects More Seeking Abortions if Idaho Bill Becomes Law
DOC.TEXT: Abortion providers in Washington are gearing up for the possibility of neighboring Idaho enacting legislation banning abortion as a method of birth control. ``We'll probably see an increase in the number of Idaho women coming to Washington for abortions, and we'll probably see many of these women taking chances with their lives if the governor signs the bill,'' said Joyce Cameron, spokeswoman for Planned Parenthood of Spokane and Whitman Counties. Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus has promised by Saturday to either sign or veto a bill that abortion opponents pushed through the Legislature in hopes of getting the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn the legalization of abortion. It would ban abortion except in cases of rape reported in seven days, incest if the victim is under age 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the mother's life or health. Andrus expressed concern Thursday that the bill may be too restrictive even for his anti-abortion views. ``I'm looking at that. I'm agonizing over it,'' he said. There are six abortion providers in Idaho: three in Boise and one each in Moscow, Coeur d'Alene and Pocatello. In 1988, there were 1,650 abortions performed in Idaho, said Jan Wick, of the Department of Health's statistics unit. There were 1.3 million legal abortions nationally. ``There are a lot of women who are really outraged in Idaho,'' Ms. Cameron said. ``We've had a lot of calls from women, willing to help shuttle women. They say they'll do whatever's necessary.'' Many Idaho women already travel to Washington for abortions. In 1988, the latest year figures are available, 445 Idaho women had abortions in Washington, 365 in Utah, 31 in Oregon and four in other states, Wick said. Jim Anderson, spokesman for Rescue Northwest, an anti-abortion group, said that if the Idaho bill becomes law he did not expect a dramatic increase in women traveling to Spokane for abortions. ``I'm grateful that the people of Idaho have chosen life, because the inconvenience will cause mothers to rethink their position and choose life for that child,'' Anderson said. Planned Parenthood paints a different picture. ``Young women, in particular, are going to be frightened and they're not going to know what to do,'' Ms. Cameron said. ``Abortion is much safer in the first trimester, but getting money for the abortion and then rounding up money for travel, and maybe for overnight accommodations will force women to wait.'' ``I think Idaho will probably see their rape statistics skyrocket,'' she added. ``If young women can't have abortion unless they've been raped, you'll see a lot more women saying they've been raped.'' Mayor Sheri Barnard, who considers herself pro-choice, said she anticipates an increase in anti-abortion activity if Idaho women come to Spokane for abortions. ``I presume the level of protest would rise in Spokane if we see an increase in abortions here,'' the mayor said. ``In the state of Washington, abortions are legal and it's our responsibility to see that our laws are upheld.''

DOC.HEAD: What's In a Name? Czechoslovak Deputies Argue It Out
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with legislators deciding on new name. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: After weeks of stormy discussion and mounting tension between Czechs and Slovaks, Parliament on Thursday chose a new name for the country and eliminated the outmoded ``Socialist'' label. Since the winter revolution, everbody _ even the ousted Communists _ had agreed that ``Socialist'' no longer had a place in their country's name. But should the Socialist Republic of Czechoslovakia be changed to the Czecho-Slovak Republic? The Federation of Czecho-Slovakia? Or, for those in the anti-hyphen camp, Czechoslovak Federative Republic? The anti-hyphen group finally prevailed after hours of debate, when the Czechoslovak Federative Republic won the required three-fifths majority in Parliament. The debate over the hyphen, characteristic both of Czechoslovak love of detail and absurdity, split the Czechs and Slovaks. Slovaks make up about one-third of Czechoslovakia's 15.5 million people. Taking their cue from writer-president Vaclav Havel, who proposed changing the country's name and coat of arms in January, they waged a solid campaign for the hyphen. They argued the hyphen would show the world that Czechoslovakia contains two distinct peoples _ Czechs and Slovaks. The Slovaks will hyphenate the country's title in writing, to make it the Czecho-Slovak Federative Republic. Czechs and Moravians, who speak the same language and tend to regard the natives of rural Slovakia as country cousins, felt Slovak sensibilities had received enough attention. In 1969, under Communist leader Gustav Husak _ a Slovak _ Slovakia became a separate republic. That entitled it to half of most federal resources. The name and hyphen debate raged for weeks in newspapers and over glasses of Czech beer and Slovak wine. It finally moved to Parliament after the government withdrew an attempt to get the issue put off until after the June election. Havel, hospitalized after a hernia operation, pleaded from his bed for what he termed the compromise solution of Czecho-Slovak Republic. That pleased the pro-hyphen Slovaks. ``Czechoslovakia so far has had two great presidents, Tomas Garrigue Masaryk and Vaclav Havel,'' Slovak deputy Roman Zelenay told fellow legislators. Masaryk was Czechoslovakia's first president. ``Both of them have put their signature under the same name of the republic,'' Zelenay said, referring to 1918 documents that agreed to set up a Czecho-Slovak republic. That hyphen was dropped for reasons of expediency shortly afterward. Havel had a second compromise suggestion: Czechoslovak Federative Republic. After intense debate, the Slovak deputies voted, predictably, en bloc for the hyphen. The Czechs and Moravians outnumbered them and opposed it, meaning ``Czecho-Slovak Republic'' failed to win the day. ``Czechoslovak Federative Republic'' almost made it the first time through but fell short. It was approved in a subsequent vote, after it was agreed that Slovaks can use a hyphen when writing the name. Milos Zeman, a radical economist who sits in Parliament for Civic Forum, the movement that led the November revolution, reminded the nation during the televised debate that there were more crucial issues facing the nation. ``There is no connection between the name of the country and its quality,'' he said. But Deputy Premier Josef Hromadka suggested it was a matter of supreme importance. ``When an agreement is not reached in the election of a pope,'' he said, ``the rules say that there should be a one-day break. But nobody is permitted to leave the conclave, and they may take there only bread and water, to search their conscience.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Car Fetches $18,500 at Auction
DOC.TEXT: The Lincoln Town Car that bore North Dakota license plate ``1'' with Gov. George Sinner behind the wheel now carries number ``2565'' after being sold in an effort to cut state travel expenses. The car brought $18,500 Wednesday at an auction that included sale of 74 state vehicles and a boat and trailer. The high bid for the 1988 Lincoln was turned in by Linton farmer Conrad Baumstarck. He bid for the car on behalf of his brother, Adam, a Linton insurance salesman who was in South Dakota during the auction. ``I didn't think I'd get it for that money,'' said Conrad, dressed in jeans and worn cowboy boots. He said his brother was prepared to pay $20,000 for the car, which the state bought for $19,800. Asked why his brother wanted the car, Conrad said, ``Mostly because he's a Democrat I guess.'' Sinner, a Democrat, ordered the auction as part of his effort to reduce the state travel budget by 10 percent, or $550,000. The auction raised $268,000. The car features power windows, an on-board computer and a self-closing trunk, and has only by a few small scratches. Not everybody thought the sale was a good idea. Republican Sen. Jens Tennefos noted the state is trying to improve its image, and suggested the governor ought to travel in style. ``I think in the long pull it's going to cost us,'' he said. Sinner has two cars of his own, a 1981 Oldsmobile station wagon and a new Chevrolet Suburban.

DOC.HEAD: Three Expelled from Ukraine Party for Trying to Form Rival Party
DOC.TEXT: The Ukrainian Communist Party expelled three members Thursday for trying to turn the Rukh political movement into a competing party, the official news agency Tass said. In a separate report, Tass said prosecutors in the Soviet Union's second-largest republic had declared unconstitional a decision by officials in the western Ukrainian city of Stryy to raise the Ukrainian national flag above city offices, in addition to the Soviet flag. Tass said Vitaly Donchik, Sergei Golovaty and Alexander Burakovsky were expelled by the Ukrainian party's Control Commission, its disciplinary body, for ``separatist aspirations, slander against the Soviet Communist Party and actions directed at establishing a new political party.'' The three, all senior scientists, published a letter in an authoritative Ukraine literary journal on March 8 setting out their views for greater autonomy. Tass said other Communist Party bodies are reviewing requests by Rukh members, including leader Ivan Drach, to leave the party. Mayor Igor Matiytsev of Stryy, in the Lvov region of the western Ukraine, told a rally Wednesday that the city council with the participation of 22 new members had voted to raise not only the Soviet flag but the yellow-and-blue flag of Ukrainian independence over its building, Tass said. The banner has become the symbol of many informal groups seeking greater autonomy or Ukrainian independence. Vladimir Sinyukov, first deputy prosecutor of the Ukraine, told Tass the Ukrainian constitution and laws prohibit the flying of the yellow-and-blue banner. The action ``should be curbed by law-enforcement bodies,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Say Bush `Long on Compassion, Short on Commitment'
With AM-Bush-AIDS, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the National Commission on AIDS welcomed President Bush's first major speech on the epidemic as a good first step, but AIDS activists said he was ``long on compassion, short on commitment.'' Dr. June Osborn, the commission's chairwoman, said that even though the president offered no new initiatives, it was important that he show concern about the issue and compassion for people with AIDS. ``In terms of changing the public mood, we desperately need that rhetoric'' as a first step toward action, Osborn said at a news conference following Bush's speech to the National Leadership Coalition on AIDS. AIDS activists said they were glad to see Bush talking about AIDS and said he has done more than his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, on the issue. But they were disappointed that Bush did not address some of the major issues relating to AIDS, including an immigration policy that bars people with AIDS from entering the country. ``He has shown sensitivity and concern that we have yet to witness from this office, but in the end the speech that we heard today was long on compassion, short on commitment,'' said Jean McGuire, executive director of the AIDS Action Council. ``If today is the beginning and not an end to the president's efforts, we can be hopeful. But a decade of neglect requires a more aggressive and substantive and meaningful leadership than we heard today,'' she said. She warned that ``the sensitivity we're seeing could mask the inaction we've had for the last decade.'' In his speech, Bush said his administration is ``on a wartime footing'' against AIDS and called on Congress to pass the Americans with Disabilities Act, which would bar discrimination against people with AIDS and those who are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. The president also touted his administration's budget proposal of $3.5 billion for treatment, research and education about AIDS next fiscal year. But AIDS activists said that Bush was trying to inflate the administration's commitment to the AIDS battle by including, among other things, spending on Medicaid and Medicare patients who have AIDS. That amounts to more than $1 billion of Bush's total for AIDS spending. The Public Health Service budget for AIDS _ which includes money for the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control _ accounts for $1.7 billion of the total and is 7 percent above current spending. Many activists had hoped Bush would address the immigration policy, which has prompted dozens of organizations and agencies to boycott an international conference on AIDS to be held in San Francisco in June. ``We have become an embarrassment in the global community that is dealing with this disease,'' McGuire said. David Rogers, vice chairman of the AIDS commission, whose members are appointed by Congress and the White House, called the immigration policy ``critical.'' The administration has been granting waivers of the policy to people entering the United States for conferences and to seek medical attention, but pressure is building on the White House and Congress to take HIV infection off a list of contagious diseases used to bar entry to the country. Osborn and Rogers, along with commission member Belinda Mason, who has AIDS, met with Bush at the White House for about 15 minutes earlier in the day. They said they were pleased with the meeting, although they said they received no commitments from Bush on any specific issue. ``We've set the stage for future conversations,'' Osborn said. Mason said Bush's remarks ``leaned rather heavily on rhetoric ... but we have to give the man a lot of points for coming out as far out as he has.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Poor Maintenance of Oil Pipeline Could Lead to Another Spill
DOC.TEXT: No one has been properly watching over maintenance of the Alaskan oil pipeline to prevent a land spill as disastrous as the ocean spill in Prince William Sound, says a government report released Thursday. But since the Exxon Valdez ran aground and unleashed nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Pacific Ocean last year, the appropriate agencies are waking up, the study by the General Accounting Office said. People still should be skeptical, said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on offshore energy rerources. ``I will be very skeptical,'' he said. Miller has been leading a congressional investigation of the March 24, 1989 spill and the safety of other oil industry operations in Alaska. ``The regulators and the regulated have been too cozy,'' he said of the relationship between the government and the oil industry. He said it's too early to tell if there has been significant improvement, but various studies under way by the government and the criminal case against Exxon for the spill should lead to improvements. The GAO said that while several federal and state agencies have authority over the trans-Alaska pipeline system, ``the pipeline has not received the systematic, comprehensive oversight needed to ensure compliance with operational safety, emergency response and environmental requirements.'' That's particularily worrisome because of recent news that the pipeline is corroding, James Duffus, director of the GAO's division on natural resources management, said at a hearing before Miller's subcommittee. He said that since the Exxon Valdez spill, the federal and state governments have increased check-ups of pipeline operations and efforts are under way to improve coordination among the agencies with oversight responsibilities. ``These efforts show promise if organized and staffed appropriately,'' he said. The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management has the major responsibility to make sure the oil industry is operating properly, but the Department of Transportation and Alaska's departments of natural resources and environmental conservation also have enforcement duties. The GAO said that because of limited finances, the state has relied on BLM to monitor the pipeline. But BLM has been criticized for basically allowing the Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., which runs the pipeline, monitor itself. Alyeska has been blamed for not being prepared for the spill in Prince Wiliam Sound because of cutbacks it made over the years in emergency safety procedures. Miller said Alyeska is now under new management which is being open about the problems that exist and has shown interest in making improvements. Michele Brown, of the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation, said, however, that in the past Alyeska has fought the government on environmental improvements. ``Until recently, Alyeska took an adversarial approach to state oversight,'' she testified. She said that wasted state money on court action that could have gone to collecting data relating to environmental protection and to doing inspections.

DOC.HEAD: In Moscow's Pushkin Square, Varying Views on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for AM-Lithuania-Media on news digest.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some passers-by grimaced at Yuri and the Lithuanian newspapers he hawked illegally in Moscow's Pushkin Square. But some bolstered him, calling out ``Molodyets!'' Russian for ``Good for you!'' Quite a few forked over a ruble ($1.50) and snatched up the latest edition, hoping for more news than the state-run media have been providing about the situation in the republic. The spectrum of reactions reflects the varying attitudes among Russians toward Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence and the influence it may have on the Soviet Union's other 14 republics. ``Sometimes they say, `You've done such a mean trick,' or `You sold out the union to spread this vileness,''' said Yuri. But others say, ``Good for you! We support you and we're watching you to learn from you how to live,''' said the the young Lithuanian, who lives in Moscow. The average opinion of the Lithuanian action, he said, ``is `It's not bad, what you're doing, but maybe you rushed, maybe you didn't think things through, maybe you should have waited for more support.''' Spontaneous groups of debaters have become a fixture near the Moscow News building on the square, and most voices support Lithuanian independence. ``I think every nation should choose its own road, whether for better or worse,'' said a retired economist who identified herself only as Valeriya. She said, however, that she could understand the Kremlin's reluctance to recognize the Lithuanian declaration. ``No one wants children to run away,'' she said. One circle of debaters agreed that if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev resorted to force, whether imposing martial law or arresting Lithuanian leaders, it would mark the end of current reforms. ``If Lithuania is crushed, there will be no democracy in Russia,'' one man said. Few seemed to think this would happen. Even an outspoken army lieutenant colonel with a penchant for quoting Lenin and Marx said that ``power should not come by means of a rifle, but only by political, democratic methods.'' Objections to Lithuanian independence focused on concern for the Russians, Poles and other minorities who together make up 20 percent of the population of the Baltic republic. ``Our Russian people can't live there! They're persecuting Communists!'' one woman said. An older man said: ``The mistake of the Lithuanian government was to allow chauvinism.'' He was apparently referring to new laws that favor the Lithuanian language and culture. A middle-aged, tired-eyed woman, who said she was a Russian who had left Lithuania out of fears for her safety, touched off a hot exchange. ``Why did you go there?'' a man asked her belligerently. ``They sent us!'' she replied. Her entire family worked for the military, she later said. Another group debated why the central media, including such progressive TV shows as ``Glance'' and ``Seven Days,'' have reported relatively little on Lithuania. Some said the media were intimidated by Lithuanians accusing them of one-sidedness. Others believed the media were left in a bind by a Soviet leadership that hadn't given them a well-formulated line to follow. Yuri, the young newspaper seller, also fielded questions from several buyers about what was happening in Lithuania. When the shriek of a whistle sounded the warning that the police might be coming to clamp down on his illegal sales, Yuri calmly slipped his packet of newspapers into a gym bag and went on talking.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices at Farm Rise in March, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products increased 1.3 percent from February to March, raising the overall commodity index 2.7 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Overall, the department's ``prices received'' index matched the record level set in January. The index declined in February then rose again to the January level. Higher prices for hogs, eggs, cattle and potatoes were mostly responsible for the increase from February, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. But the report said lower prices for tomatoes, milk and wheat partly offset the gains for the other commodities. Most prices are mid-March averages which will be revised next month. ``Hog and cattle prices moved up sharply from February while the all-milk price declined for the second consecutive month,'' the report said. ``Tomatoes declined sharply from February but continuing short supplies kept prices well above normal for this time of year.'' Milk prices had risen to record levels until they tumbled sharply in February, reflecting production increases. The price decline had been predicted by USDA economists. ``Prices of feed grain, food grains and oilseeds were mixed,'' the report said. ``Corn and soybean prices increased slightly while the wheat price was down. Hay prices showed a moderate increase from February.'' The report did not include new figures on farm expenses. Those are computed every three months. In January, however, new quarterly figures showed that prices paid by farmers were up 1.1 percent from October, the previous reading, and averaged 2.9 percent more than a year earlier. Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $54 billion to $58 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $45 billion to $49 billion, compared with $49 billion last year. Consumer food prices are forecast by USDA economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981. Based on the preliminary figures, the March price index for livestock and poultry was up 2.4 percent from February and averaged 7.5 percent more than a year ago. Milk prices dropped an additional 60 cents in March to an average of $13.80 per l00 pounds. Even so, the preliminary March price was up $1.10 from March 1989. Crop prices, overall, rose 0.8 percent from February but were 2.9 percent below the year-earlier level. Fruit prices, led by grapfruit and oranges, were up 7 percent from February and averaged 6.4 percent more than a year ago. The index for commercial vegetables dropped 4.9 percent from February but still averaged 39 percent more than in March 1989. ``The effect of lower prices for tomatoes was moderated somewhat by higher prices for sweet corn and onions,'' the report said. ``Even though the tomato prices declined from last month, they are still well above normal for this time of year due to short supplies brought on by the December freeze.'' The report said: _Cattle averaged $75.40 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $74.60 in February and $72 in March 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $52 per 100 pounds, compared with $48.20 in February and $39.30 a year earlier. _Corn, at $2.34 a bushel, edged up from $2.32 in February and was down from $2.60 a year earlier. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.42 per bushel, compared with $3.56 in February and $4.07 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $7.60 per 100 pounds, compared with $7.52 in February and $6.60 in March 1989. _Soybeans were $5.58 per bushel, compared with $5.57 in February and $7.51 a year earlier. _Upland cotton was reported at 62.4 cents per pound, up from 60.6 in February and 55.6 a year earlier. _Eggs were 79.3 cents per dozen, compared with 70.4 in February and 80.1 in March 1989. _Milk was $13.80 per 100 pounds, down from $14.40 in February but above the average of $12.70 a year ago. _Broilers were 36.4 cents per pound, live weight, up from 33.5 cents in February but down from 38.7 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Peace Prize Winner Dropped as Soviet Health Minister
DOC.TEXT: Yevgeny Chazov, personal doctor to Kremlin leaders and co-winner of the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize for his work with an anti-nuclear organization, was dropped Thursday as Soviet health minister. The official news agency Tass said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had relieved Chazov, 60, of his duties in connection with his transfer to other work. His new job was not specified, and no replacement was named. Such wording can signify official displeasure. Chazov signed the death certificates for the three Soviet leaders prior to Gorbachev _ Leonid I. Brezhnev, Yuri V. Andropov and Konstantin U. Chernenko. Chazov and U.S. cardiologist Bernard Lown were co-chairmen of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War. The two men shared the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize for their work in the organization. Chazov had been a deputy head of the Health Ministry for 19 years and the head of the department that provided care to top Soviet officials for two decades before being named health minister in February 1987. Soviet health care is under frequent attack for poor equipment and training, shortages of medicines, and personnel that often seems uncaring and lazy. The news agency also said Minister of Civil Aviation Alexander Volkov was transferred at the same time.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Focuses on Training Parents
DOC.TEXT: Parents would be taught prenatal care and ways to develop their babies' coordination, memory, language and social skills under provisions of a bill introduced Thursday. ``We know that parental involvement in the education of their children is the key to long-term gains for youngsters,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo. ``Parents are their child's first and most influential teachers.'' Bond was joined in introducing the bill by Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., and Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala. The bill would create a national ``Parents As Teachers'' program based on a Missouri model. A five-year, $100 million competitive grant program would be set up for states to begin or expand Parents As Teachers. The program, which operates in 26 states, uses homes visits, group meetings, videotapes and written material to teach new and prospective parents the skills of raising an infant. There also are periodic health screening of children. Bond said the average operating costs for a Parents As Teachers program in a school district are about $20,000 per year. He estimated that about 1,000 school districts nationwide could participate in the program annually with federal assistance. The bill would force states to eventually pick up the cost of the program, as federal funding would decline to 75 percent in the third year, 50 percent in the fourth year and 25 percent in the fifth year of the five-year authorization. Heflin said the legislation does not conflict with Head Start and other early childhood programs. ``This focuses on the parents while the others focus on the children,'' he said. Head Start, touted by President Bush and virtually every proponent of early childhood education, provides day care, health screening, nutritious meals and other services to disadvantaged children between the ages of 3 and 5. ``Parents As Teachers is even more critically needed than Head Start because so much of human development is at-risk during infancy. By beginning at the beginning, prevention can replace remediation,'' said Heflin, adding that all parents are eligible, regardless of socio-economic status.

DOC.HEAD: Four Ceausescu Aides Changed with Genocide, to Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: The Military Prosecutor's Office on Thursday charged four aides of former Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu with genocide for their brutal role in suppressing a popular uprising last December, the state news agency reported. The four were identified as Ion Coman, a former secretary of the Communist Party's Central Committee; Ilie Matei, a former member of the party Politburo; Cornel Pacoste, an ex-deputy premier; and Radu Balan, the party leader of Timis county, seat of the revolt that began in Timisoara. Nearly 100 people were officially reported to have died in the fighting in that western city, where the revolt that eventually led to Ceausescu's ouster started Dec. 16. The Rompres state news agency said the four, who have been in custody since December, face life imprisonment if found guilty. The four were charged with ``carrying out criminal orders given by the dictator and his wife.'' ``Through concrete actions they organized, coordinated and led the brutal armed repression of the demonstrators taking part in the popular revolt in Timisoara,'' said the indictment. They ``perpetrated the crime of genocide,'' said the indictment, according to the news agency. Rompres said the four would be tried by Romania's Supreme Military Tribunal, but did not specify when. Twenty one high-ranking officers of the hated Securitate secret police are currently standing trial in Timisoara for their role in the bloody crackdown on street demonstrations against the former Communist regime. Initial reports from witnesses and citizens in Timisoara, where security forces opened fire on unarmed demonstrators, set the death toll in the hundreds. At one point, there were estimates that 12,000 people were killed in Timisoara, including 7,000 reportedly executed by the security forces. Four of Ceausescu's closest associates were tried last January and found guilty of committing genocide. They are currently appealing their life sentences. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were found guilty of genocide and other grave crimes by a military court after their capture on Dec. 22. They were sentenced to death and shot on Christmas Day.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges Against Yen; Lower Against Other Key Currencies
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plunged against the Japanese yen and lost ground against other key currencies in choppy trading Thursday. Gold prices mostly were higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $370.80 a troy ounce, up $1.80 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $371.40 an ounce, up $2.05. Traders said the dollar's pace for the day was set in Tokyo, where a wave of selling and central bank intervention sent the U.S. currency tumbling by more than 1.2 percent, or nearly two yen. In Tokyo, the dollar ended a nine-day winning streak by plunging to 156.65 Japanese yen, from 158.63 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it fell further to 156.50 yen. The dollar continued falling in New York, where it closed at 156.35 yen, compared with 158.595 yen on Wednesday. The dollar had been advancing against the yen for several weeks as Japanese corporations bought the currency to help bolster their balance sheets at the close of their fiscal year, which ends March 31, and as the yen weakened on pessimistic economic sentiment. But on Thursday, corporate buying interest in the dollar suddenly dropped as the maket ``turned the corner on the Japanese year end,'' said Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Bank of Boston's New York office. Traders said dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve was heavy during Tokyo's trading session, and their dollar-selling activity spilled over into the London session. Jack Barbanel, a managing director at Princeton, N.J.-based First Global Managers, said there was ``substantial profit-taking from the dealer community'' in addition to the central bank intervention. ``It looks like the dealers are throwing their towels in,'' he said. Most traders had been unequivocally bullish on the dollar and believed the currency could continue its climb against the Japanese yen. Barbanel also noted that the dollar's sudden drop against the yen coincided with losses against virtually every other currencies. ``That gives another indication that we have some fundamental weakness coming in the dollar,'' he said. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6350 from $1.6285 late Wednesday. In New York, sterling rose to $1.6395 from Wednesday's $1.6270. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.6940 West German marks, down from 1.7105; 1.4935 Swiss francs, down from 1.5170; 5.7025 French francs, down from 5.7490; 1,248.50 Italian lire, down from 1,256.50, and 1.1720 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1755. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6960 West German marks, down from 1.7078; 1.5005 Swiss francs, down from 1.5135; 5.7070 French francs, down from 5.7410; 1.9083 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9200; 1,248.75 Italian lire, down from 1,255.25, and 1.1742 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1758. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $372.25 a troy ounce from $370.15 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $371.70 from Wednesday's $369. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $2.69 an ounce to close at $371.93. Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $4.946 an ounce, up from Wednesday's $4.917. In London, silver closed at a late bid of $4.97 a troy ounce, up from $4.95.

DOC.HEAD: JAMA Tries to Jump Ahead of New England Journal of Medicine
DOC.TEXT: The nation's most widely circulated medical journal is moving its release date to Wednesday from Friday, giving it a one-day jump on a prestigious rival. But the rival's editor says ``we don't feel threatened.'' The Journal of the American Medical Association says the main reasons for its publishing earlier in the week are improved production capabilities, a desire to release important findings quickly and a wish to give news reporters more time at week's end to develop spinoff stories. The change begins next week. But ``if you read the (AMA) press release carefully, they want to come out first,'' before the New England Journal of Medicine, said Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of the Boston-based New England Journal, which publishes on Thursday. ``I can't understand any other reason, beyond the obvious competitive one,'' Relman added in a telephone interview Wednesday. Dr. George Lundberg, editor of JAMA, acknowledged in a news release announcing the change last month, ``I want JAMA to be poised to be able to publish new research findings before other medical and scientific journals.'' But Lundberg maintained on Thursday that competition is a lesser motive. Lundberg said though articles appearing each week in the New England Journal and in JAMA are independent of each other, they do cover overlapping subjects ``occasionally.'' In such instances, ``we would prefer our authors to have an earlier publication date than theirs,'' Lundberg said. ``We at JAMA value media coverage greatly because one of our basic missions is to educate the public to lead healthier lives.'' Both journals are heavily covered by the media, and their release dates have more to do with determining when their contents reach airwaves and newspapers than when they reach physicians. JAMA, published by the Chicago-based AMA, the nation's largest organization of doctors, has a regular English-language circulation of 293,000, including the AMA's more than 290,000 members. The journal also has 290,000 copies going overseas each week in 12 languages, Lundberg said. The 178-year-old New England Journal, the nation's oldest medical journal, is published by the Massachusetts Medical Society. It has a circulation of about 230,000, including 10,000 society members and about 50,000 overseas subscribers, Relman said. Though it is smaller, the New England Journal carries the ``hottest'' articles, said David Pendlebury of the Philadelphia-based Institute for Scientific Information. The institute tracks how many times articles in 3,200 journals worldwide are subsequently cited in published research. Pendlebury said a study about a year ago indicated that the 100 most-cited articles in life sciences in the previous year included nine from the New England Journal and three from JAMA. ``We don't feel threatened by a change in their publication day,'' Relman said. ``It seems to me that the content of what is published is vastly more important than the day of the week on which it is published.'' Dr. Aran Ron, assistant to the medical director at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City, and a reader of both journals, agreed, though for different reasons. ``I think that JAMA has more general interest-type articles and covers ground a little wider, while the the New England Journal has more scientific, specialty and in-depth articles,'' Ron said. ``I don't perceive a big competition from my perspective for the two,'' added Ron, who has had research published in JAMA. ``I think they serve different purposes.''

DOC.HEAD: Andrus Expresses First Doubts About Abortion Bill
With AM-Abortion-Washington
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Cecil Andrus on Thursday expressed his first public doubts about signing what would be the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. ``I am concerned that this bill may narrow it to the point where a woman who has suffered rape, who has suffered incest or the mother's life is in danger might not be able to receive an abortion,'' Andrus said at an impromptu news conference. ``I'm looking at that,'' he said. ``I'm agonizing over it.'' But the Democratic governor quickly cautioned against interpreting his remarks to mean he has decided to veto the bill. ``Don't read anything into it,'' Andrus said. ``My views being pro-life haven't changed. ... But I am concerned about the bill.'' Pro-choice forces, meanwhile, staged another rally on the Capitol steps, dumping 10,000 potatoes in a show of support for the campaign to launch a national boycott of Idaho's biggest cash crop should the bill become law. To counter that threat symbolically Thursday, Wisconsin Right to Life Inc. delivered a half ton of potatoes to the Salvation Army office in Milwaukee. And a group called Concerned Women for America, which claims 600,000 members, said it will increase potato purchases to offset any boycott by the National Organization for Women. ``This is a long-term commitment,'' said Beverly LaHaye, president of Concerned Women. ``Our membership ... is committed to this cause out of respect for the courageous men and women in the Idaho Legislature.'' A day earlier, the governor said business leaders in key Idaho industries told him they were already losing sales because of the evolving boycott. But while expressing concern, he said economic considerations would not be the crucial factor in his decision. Later in the day, a major buyer of Idaho potatoes, McDonald's Corp., said it had no plans to participate in any boycott over the abortion controversy. Andrus promised earlier in the week he would act by Saturday on the legislation that would ban abortion as a method of birth control. Both sides in the debate agree it would make more than 90 percent of the abortions performed in Idaho illegal. If signed, it would take effect July 1. The bill makes abortion illegal except in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under age 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the mother's life or physical health. Some legal scholars have said it is so restrictive it will be voided by the U.S. Supreme Court. But the National Right to Life Committee helped draft the bill so that a promised challenge will give the high court the opportunity to reverse its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. Andrus, who has a longstanding record of opposition to abortion except in cases of rape, incest and a threat to the woman's life, has been consulting with legal scholars, church officials and others. He said Thursday there was no consensus on the issue. ``There is a difference of opinion,'' he said. ``But my own personal attorney in the office and some of the others, I think, are united in that question.'' He would not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Calls In Iraq's Ambassador
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to recast; INSERTS 2 grafs after pvs 2nd graf bgng ``We do ...'' to add comments from meeting; SUBS pvs 3rd graf to change Soviet Scud missile to long-range rocket
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Military, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department called in Iraq's ambassador on Thursday and registered concern that the Arab country is trying to circumvent U.S. restrictions on nuclear technology shipments. ``We do not foresee a near-time Iraqi nuclear capability,'' spokesman Richard Boucher said. ``However, we remain concerned about the danger...'' Richard McCormack, the undersecretary for economic affairs, met with Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat and ``expressed our deep concern over Iraq's attempt to circumvent controls'' over military items, a U.S. official said. McCormack also reiterated U.S. opposition to the spread of missile technology in the Middle East, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraq in December lauched a long-range three-stage rocket that is capable of reaching Israel. ``I am sure the Israelis are quite concerned,'' another U.S. official said. The other major cause for U.S. concern relates to the seizure Wednesday by British customs officials of a shipment of U.S.-made nuclear trigger components destined for Iraq. The FBI cooperated in the case. The ambassador denied on Wednesday that his country is trying to develop nuclear weapons. He said all Iraqi nuclear facilities were subject to international inspection under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Still, spokesman Boucher said ``the arrest of the Iraqis in London raises once again the administration's deep concern about proliferation in the Middle East.'' Iraq has a nuclear facility near Baghdad that Israel bombed in 1981. The Washington Times reported in its Friday editions that Iraq is installing Soviet-made ballistic missiles capable of hitting Israel, Turkey and Cyprus. The newspaper, quoting unidentified U.S. intelligence officials, said the missiles were photographed by a U.S. intelligence satellite earlier this month and are being deployed at three remote locations in Iraq. State Department officials declined to either confirm or deny the Times' story. Boucher said the seizure of U.S.-made nuclear triggers ``raised our concerns about sales to the Middle East.'' But, he said, ``we are not aware of any irregularities'' in Iraq's commitment to permit international inspections under the non-proflieration treaty. Asked if the Bush administration would impose sanctions against Iraq, the spokesman replied: ``We will be examining very carefully the information from this case and we are discussing our concerns with Iraq, both here and in Baghdad.'' Despite its oil riches, Iraq is believed to have a debt of $70 billion to $100 billion for weapons and other costs of its long Persian Gulf war with Iran. The Bush administration could hurt Iraq by trying to block loans to the Middle Eastern country. Its record on human rights also has caused concern here. Iraq was accused by the Bush administration of using poison gas against Iran and against Kurds, a non-Arab minority. President Bush on Wednesday called upon nuclear suppliers `'to exercise special restraint in providing materials related to the development of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and intermediate-range missiles in this volatile area.'' Bush said Iraqi officials ``are well aware of our views on nuclear proliferation which we have made clear on several occasions.'' On Thursday, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said Bush felt ``very strongly about this as a non-proliferation issue.'' He added: ``I don't have a decision for you in terms of any kind of conclusions about violation of the treaty and legal process. Those are matters that we'll have to consider.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, Zulu Leader Act to Halt Black-against-Black Killings
With AM-South Africa-Danger, Bjt
LaserPhoto DUR3
