DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela and Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi said Thursday they will hold an unprecedented joint peace rally to stop fighting in Zululand that has killed 25 people in two days. ``I hope that when we stand on the platform together and appeal (for) an end to violence, the people will heed our call,'' Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, told the independent South African Press Association. ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa said of the gathering to be held Monday, ``People are dying horrendously in Natal, and that is the reason it is going ahead as soon as possible.'' M.V. Ngema, administrative secretary of Buthelezi's Inkatha party, said, ``It is the most important thing in the world for them to meet.'' The two leaders were friends in their youth, but have not met since Mandela was freed Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, although they spoke on the phone. They had planned to discuss the violence, but this week's upsurge prompted the announcement of a rally at Taylor's Halt township, one of the most violent areas around the Natal provincial capital of Pietermaritzburg. Ngema said Inkatha would contact employers to let workers have the day off. Police and hospital officials said at least 25 people died and 32 were critically hurt in two days of pitched battles and assaults among war bands armed with guns, knives, clubs and sharpened sticks. Since 1983, supporters of the ANC _ mostly from the United Democratic Front _ and Inkatha have struggled for control of the townships in Natal and the adjacent Zululand tribal areas governed by Inkatha. Nearly 4,000 people were killed the past four years. The ANC and Inkatha have never met at a joint gathering. Both oppose apartheid but differ on tactics to fight the racial segregation system; the form of a future majority government; and on the status of tribal structures. White Democratic Party members of Parliament from Natal met with President F. W. de Klerk in Cape Town and asked for immediate action. Pietermaritzburg Mayor Mark Cornell suggested at a city council meeting that the national government declare martial law in the Edendale Valley where most of the fighting has occurred since Tuesday. About 200 homes were burned and hundreds of refugees fled. Many villagers were crammed into churches and schools on the outskirts of the capital. ``Edendale is burning and I really fear that `Maritzburg' itself will become the scene of full-scale fighting,'' Cornell said. The council requested more security forces. About 5,000 black trade union members, some carrying clubs, marched through Johannesburg Thursday to protest government plans to privatize transportation, hospitals and other public assets. They presented a petition to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange asking that the economy be nationalized to aid poor blacks. Police broke up a similar march of about 2,000 workers in Pretoria and arrested 39. Union officials said 40 protesters were bitten by dogs, beaten and tear-gassed. Police said no information on injuries was available. But the South African Press Association said bloodied marchers were seen in Pretoria central police station, where they were charged with taking part in a banned march. Police commanders said the situation was quiet around Edendale Thursday, but some local journalists said they had reports of clashes in rural areas. Hospital workers, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the toll was higher than listed because relatives removed some bodies and the deaths went unreported. Police denied on Thursday that officers had favored Inkatha in the fighting, as a member of Parliament, white monitors of the unrest and some township residents charged earlier. The fighting broke out after rival groups stoned buses bringing Inkatha supporters back from a rally Sunday. Police said they did not disarm combatants ``as further bloodshed would have inevitably resulted.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Mrs. Thatcher Call for Restraint
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf pvs `Bush and ...' to UPDATE with official saying Bush working behind the scenes. Picks up 4th graf pvs `Bush called ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher agree there is a need for restraint on both sides in Lithuania's struggle for independence from the Soviet Union, a White House spokesman said Thursday. ``Mrs. Thatcher has spoken out publicly about the need for restraint. We have spoken similarly,'' said Marlin Fitzwater. ``We still believe that peaceful dialogue is the best way to resolve this matter and to provide self-determination for the people of Lithuania.'' Bush and Mrs. Thatcher are ``pretty much in alignment'' on what is ``the best course for achieving peaceful dialogue,'' Fitzwater said. A senior administration official said Bush was working intently behind the scenes to prevent a blowup in Lithuania. The White House toned down its rhetoric this week after repeatedly cautioning Moscow against escalating the situation. ``It isn't in anybody's interest to have this thing blow up,'' the official said, insisting on anonymity. ``Nobody really wins from the blowup. Now, it may happen. Some things (are) just like a Greek tragedy. But nobody profits by it, and therefore what we're hoping is, with some gentle help and encouragement, that logic will prevail.'' The official said the United States hopes Gorbachev survives this test but that ``it's out of our hands'' and ``is not in the end anything that the United States is likely to have a decisive influence on.'' Bush called Mrs. Thatcher in London on Wednesday after receiving a cable from the British leader reviewing her 50-minute conversation with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Bush has not talked with Gorbachev since the Lithuanian parliament declared independence March 11. Asked why Bush had not called Gorbachev, Fitzwater said: ``The president simply feels that this is not the time to make a direct contact to Chairman Gorbechev. We believe the appropriate posture is to consider this matter with our allies.'' Fitzwater called the situation ``a complex and delicate diplomatic matter.'' ``We would not want to take moves that disrupted that diplomatic effort,'' he said. Fitzwater declined comment on the Soviet offer of amnesty for Lithuanian deserters who return to the Army. He also had nothing to say about some conciliatory moves by Lithuania's leaders. On Wednesday, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis suspended plans to set up border posts, and advised his countrymen not to resist if Soviet authorities came to seize their hunting guns. ``We don't want to put ourselves in the position of approving or disapproving of daily events over there,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Low Turnout Forces Extended Voting in Zimbabwe
DOC.TEXT: Officials Thursday extended voting in national elections to a third day because of low turnout blamed on rain and administrative problems. Election director Malcolm Thompson said there had been no reports of violence or intimidation. During the campaign, however, there were bloody clashes between the two leading parties. President Robert Mugabe, 66, is being challenged for the first time, but he is expected to easily win. His major competitor is Edgar Tekere, 52, of the Zimbabwe Unity Movement. Tekere was a secretary-general of Mugabe's ruling Zimbabwe African National Union, but he was fired from the party in 1988 after denouncing top-level corruption. Only 26.5 percent of the 4.8 million registered voters had cast ballots by Thursday, the second of two scheduled days of parliamentary and presidential voting, Thompson told a news conference. However, some results had not been received from remote polling stations by late in the day, he said. Thompson blamed the low turnout on heavy rain in many parts of the country and administrative difficultires at polling booths. Results are now expected to be announced Wednesday, he said. It is the second election for this southern African nation, the former Rhodesia, since independence from Britain a decade ago.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Exports to Iraq Are Probed After Nuclear Triggers Seized
With AM-Iraq-Military, Bjt
LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: Authorities said a U.S.-British investigation was under way Thursday into alleged illegal exports of naval equipment to Iraq, a day after customs officers foiled a bid to smuggle nuclear triggering devices to Baghdad. The Customs and Excise Department said the naval equipment had already been shipped to Iraq, but refused to give details. As three people appeared in court in the nuclear devices case, Britain rejected calls to cut ties with Iraq, but said it was contacting international agencies to try to prevent future smuggling of material for nuclear weapons. British military experts said the Iraqis have been trying to acquire sensors to develop advanced sea mines. ``It seems that the naval weapons are acoustic detonators,'' Paul Beaver, publisher of Jane's Defense Weekly, said in an interview on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' program. ``It could lead to speculation ... that Iraq is not only involved in putting warheads onto ballistic missiles but also could be involved in trying to develop a nuclear depth bomb with perhaps the idea of taking out the Iranian oil wells in the neck of the Persian Gulf. And that really sort of ups the ante considerably.'' Iraq denies seeking nuclear capability. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accused the Arabs' enemies Thursday of trying to hinder Iraq's ``march of progress.'' The State Department in Washington called in Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Al-Mashat on Thursday and registered concern that the Arab country is trying to circumvent U.S. restrictions on nuclear technology shipments. Department spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``We do not foresee a near-time Iraqi nuclear capability. However, we remain concerned about the danger.'' British customs officials said investigators seized documents on Wednesday at undisclosed premises in northwestern England and Scotland. A spokesman said the investigators want to talk to two officials of an English company who are abroad, but stressed the probe is only half-complete with no arrests imminent. Press Association, the domestic news agency, said the documents allegedly contain proof at least one acoustic detonator has already been smuggled to Iraq. The naval equipment investigation sprang from an 18-month investigation by U.S. and British police and customs that culminated in Wednesday's seizure at Heathrow Airport in London of nuclear components about to be put on an Iraqi Airways flight to Baghdad, customs officials said. Three people were charged in Uxbridge Magistrates Court in west London on Thursday with violating the Export of Prohibited Goods Control Act by trying to export 40 capacitors, essential components in detonating a nuclear bomb. Lebanese engineer Toufic Fouad Amyuni, 37 and Ali Ashour Daghir, 49, a company director with dual Iraqi-British nationality, were held over until April 5. Export executive Jeanine Celestine Speckman, 41, a Frenchwoman married to a Briton, was granted bail until May 10 provided she surrender her passport and report weekly to police. Iraqi national Omar Latif, who was also arrested, was immediately served with a deportation order. Press Association said without attribution that Latif was also coordinating the naval equipment operation. In San Diego Thursday, an indictment opened in U.S. District Court charged five people and two British-based companies with illegally exporting electrical components that could be used in the detonation of nuclear warheads. It named Daghir, Mrs. Speckman, and three Iraqis _ Karim Dhaidas Omran, Wallid Issa Ahmad and Dafir al-Azawi _ identified as representating an agency of Iraq's Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization. The three Iraqis' whereabouts Thursday were not known. The two companies, Euromac Ltd. and an affiliated company, Atlas Equipment Ltd., were both operated by Daghir, according to the indictment. It identified Mrs. Speckman as Euromac's export executive. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons: ``The attempted spread of nuclear weapons is very, very serious indeed.'' ``We shall be urgently contacting signatories of the Non-Proliferation Treaty and also those who signed the Missile Technology Control Regime to see what we can do to see that there is no repeat of this very, very serious incident.'' Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Britain was ``urgently consulting'' the 139 signatories of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, which include Iraq, ``to minimize the risk of evasion.'' He said Britain wanted more countries to sign the Missile Technology Control Regime, adopted in April 1987 by the seven major industrialized countries to control the export of missile components. Gerald Kaufman, foreign affairs spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, urged Britain to sever diplomatic relations with Iraq, raise the issue at the U.N. Security Council and ask the International Atomic Energy Agency to inspect Iraq's facilities. Hurd said the agency conducted an inspection a year ago, and added: ``I can see considerable risk and damage by breaking off diplomatic relations ... and no actual advantage.'' ``We have two empty embassies in two important Middle East countries and we do not want to add to that number,'' Hurd said, referring to Iran and Syria, with whom Britain has broken relations.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: No Force Reductions, Yet
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon officials are hopeful a resolution will be worked out with Congress to avoid tens of thousands of pink slips going to military men and women by October, a spokesman said on Thursday. ``I think we're confident that we're going to get what we need,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters. ``This is something that we continue to negotiate and discuss with Congress in a variety of ways.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is ``personnally involved'' in the negotiations, Williams said. Williams said that in light of such negotiations, ``We're not about to announce implementation of force reductions. We are confident that we are going to get an agreement that will allow us to do what we want to do.'' House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., has said, however, that he intends to stick to his position of rejecting the Pentagon request to shift $900 million from other accounts to spend on personnel. As chairman of one of the four major committees dealing with the issue, Aspin's stand amounts to a veto of the request. The Pentagon wants to realign its funds to avoid massive layoffs caused by reductions required under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-cutting law. If Congress does not allow the Pentagon to switch the money, Williams said several weeks ago that ``rough estimates'' indicated that between 44,000 and 68,200 military personnel would have to be fired outright by Oct. 1, the end of the current fiscal year. Tens of thousands of others would have to be frozen in their current jobs, promotions would be delayed and fewer men and women could be brought into the services. Currently, there are around 2.1 million men and women in uniform. The Senate Armed Services Committee has voted to grant the Pentagon part of the auhority to transfer money to military personnel accounts and avert massive layoffs. But that action has little overall effect on the department's request since Aspin has refused to take up the issue in his panel. Such shifting of funds must be approved by the House and Senate armed services panels and the House and Senate appropriations committees. Some members of Congress have argued that the administration brought the problem on itself, in light of last year's budget agreement in which the administration got Capitol Hill to agree to four months' worth of automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law. President Bush had the option of exempting military personnel from the Gramm-Rudman law, but he didn't. Aspin argued that while Bush's decision is painful for the military, the administration must realize that accepting the Gramm-Rudman cuts meant accepting the results.

DOC.HEAD: Newman Denies Offering Food Company Stock to Deli Owner
DOC.TEXT: Actor Paul Newman denied Thursday that he ever promised stock from his food companies to a delicatessen owner, and said his so-called salad-dressing trial was ``longer than the Academy Awards.'' Newman and his charity food companies, Newman's Own Inc. and Salad King Inc., are being sued by Julius Gold, who claims he was promised stock for services in helping to launch the companies eight years ago. Newman, asked to relate how the companies had developed, testified that sales were promising when he launched them back in 1982 but there was no guarantee they would succeed. ``I've had films open promising and go right through the floor,'' the Academy Award-winning actor said. ``And on the other hand, I've had some pictures that started out very badly and became successful. The most embarrassing thing is the salad dressing is out-grossing my films.'' Salad King and Newman's Own, which make salad dressing, spaghetti sauce, popcorn and lemonade, reaped $42 million in sales last year. All $28 million in profits since 1982 have gone to charity. Newman denied promising stock in the company to Gold or anyone else. He also denied ever having any conversations with Gold about giving him stock. ``This is getting longer than the Academy Awards here'' Newman said when asked to give some background about how the business began. ``It started off as a lark,'' Newman said. ``I did not expect it to go any place.'' Earlier Thursday, Newman's corporate lawyer, Leo Nevas, reasserted on the stand that he did not promise 8 percent of the companies' stock to Gold, who brought suit in Bridgeport Superior Court against the actor, his business partner A.E. Hotchner and the companies. Nevas said he recalled discussion at a meeting about Newman holding two-thirds of the company stock and some shares possibly distributed to others. But the lawyer said he had no authority to promise 8 percent to Gold. Newman and Hotchner formed Salad King in 1982 on a whim to sell the dressing Newman had been making for friends in the basement of his Westport home. The two branched into spaghetti sauce the following year. Gold, a Westport deli owner, says Hotchner contacted him for help in distributing the dressing, beginning three years of involvement in the project. He also says Nevas promised him 8 percent of the stock. Newman's lawyers deny any such deal. They have tried to minimize Gold's dealings in the venture, saying he tried to thrust himself on the project and invited himself to meetings. The tiny courtroom, which seats only 30, was full again Thursday with media and spectators. Television crews manned cameras outside the courthouse to film Newman during breaks. It is the second time the case has gone to trial. The first ended in a mistrial in June 1988 after the jury mistakenly saw depositions not admitted as evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Law Causing Discrimination, Report Finds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comments on the report, details in regard to `hiring audit' and Kennedy plan to introduce legislation to repeal sanctions. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An immigration law passed four years ago to stem the flow of illegal aliens across the southern border of the United States has caused widespread hiring discrimination, the General Accounting Office reported Thursday. ``GAO believes many employers discriminated because the law's verification system does not provide a simple or reliable method to verify job applicants' eligibility to work,'' said the report from the congressional agency. The report triggered calls on Capitol Hill for repeal of the law's civil and criminal penalties _ or sanctions _ for employers who hire illegal aliens. Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Gene McNary rejected those calls, describing the report as ``soft'' and ``hedged.'' As many as 10 percent of the 4.6 million employers considered under the GAO survey may be discriminating based on national origins because of confusion over the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act, the report said. Discrimination related to the law is ``widespread'' and ``serious but not pervasive,'' according to the 162-page report. Employers discriminate ``because the law's verification system does not provide a simple or reliable method to verify job applicants' eligibility to work,'' the report said. It indicated that those who do the hiring are uncertain about just which applicants they may hire and discriminate lest they incur federal sanctions. Bias might be reduced, the report said, by more information for employers and a simpler, more reliable system. The law requires employers to complete an eligibility form for each newly hired worker and allows employees to establish their eligibility by presenting any of 17 different documents, such as a U.S. passport or birth certificate or an alien registration card. INS and the Labor Department may inspect the forms; employers who knowing hire unauthorized workers are subject to sanctions. The provisions were part of an overall bill designed to reduce the number of illegal aliens flooding over the nation's southern border in search of jobs. Concerns were raised in Congress during debate on the bill that employers would discriminate against individuals who were ``foreign looking.'' To compile data for its report, the GAO used methods ranging from surveying employers to a so-called hiring audit in conjunction with the Urban Institute in which pairs of ``testers'' went job hunting in Chicago and San Diego. In each pair, one tester appeared and sounded Hispanic while the other did not. Both were equally qualified. Both testers applied for the same jobs. The GAO said 342 ``anglo'' testers completed job applications while 327 Hispanics did. A total of 229 anglos received interviews compared with 172 Hispanics, and 129 anglos were offered jobs compared with 85 Hispanics. Although the primary focus of the law was illegal immigration, the GAO's overall study concerned itself with discrimination based on ``national origins'' and not just bias against one group. McNary said some of the figures in the report are ``also soft because there is no base of comparison in the past.'' He cited a statement within the document that some interpreters may not agree. ``They own up to the fact that others may disagree, and for good reason,'' he said at a news conference. His remarks brought a swift retort from officials of the American Civil Liberties Union. ``The GAO grappled with this question very specifically and very carefully,'' said Lucas Guttentag, director of the ACLU immigration project. ``Who is the commissioner to question whether the documentation is soft?'' asked Wade Henderson, associate director of the ACLU's Washington office. ``This is not the victims of discrimination who are complaining. This is the employers themselves.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said the report ``confirms exactly what many of us in Congress feared when employer sanctions were enacted in 1986. The sanctions would be discriminatory against Hispanic American citizens, Asian-American citizens and other ethnic minorities, and it would be difficult to implement the law in a way that avoids such discrimination.'' Kennedy said he would introduce legislation to repeal the sanctions in an expedited fashion provided for under the 1986 law. However, Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., who has taken a leading role in writing immigration legislation, expressed strong disagreement with the GAO report. He noted that the report found that only 6.6 percent of employers said they began not hiring job applicants whose foreign appearance or accent led the company to suspect they might be unauthorized aliens. While that was the case, the survey also found that 14.7 percent of the employers began to hire only people born in the United States and 13 percent stopped hiring individuals with temporary work eligibility documents.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Depressant Drug Recalled Because Of Mislabeling
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that two lots of an anti-depressant drug called desipramine are being recalled because some bottles may contain a blood-thinner that could cause serious bleeding. The manufacturer, Pharmaceutical Basics Inc. of Denver, told the FDA it was recalling the products after distributor H.L. Moore of New Britain, Conn., found a mislabeled bottle of the drug earlier this week. The bottle was labeled as containing 25 milligrams of desipramine, but it contained 5 milligram tabelets of warfarin, a blood-thinner. The FDA said people taking the anti-depressant should examine their tablets to see if any are marked with the name warfarin. Warfarin is a non-coated pink tablet with ``5'' on one side and ``832'' and the word ``warfarin'' on the other side. Desipramine is a coated, lavender tablet with the numbers ``832'' and G254'' imprinted on it. Pharmaceutical Basics is notifying Moore's 350 customers by phone of the possible label mix-up, the FDA said. The recall applies only to desipramine made by Pharmaceutical Basics for distribution by Moore. About six other manufacturers make despiramine. The FDA said it is likely that pharmacists would catch mislabeled tablets because the two tablets are so different. However, the FDA said people who have filled or refilled a prescription for Moore's 25 milligram desipramine within the last six months should return the prescription to the pharmacy to be checked or replaced. The lots being recalled are G873-01 and G685-08. Carl Peck, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, warned that if people taking four to eight tablets a day of desipramine took the same number of warfarin tablets, ``in the worst case, they could experience severe bleeding, such as stomach or intracranial hemorrhage.''

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Says 5 People, 2 Companies Were Iraqi Agents
With AM-Iraq-Military, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout with additional details of allegations.
DOC.TEXT: A missile-development arm of the Iraqi government allegedly tried to buy nuclear-warhead triggers made by a California company, according to a federal indictment unsealed Thursday. The alleged role of Al-Qaqaa State Establishment in the scheme to illegally export the electronic triggers was laid out in the indictment against five people and two companies. Two of the five people named in the indictment, unsealed in San Diego, were arrested in London Wednesday. The three others were identified as Al-Qaqaa engineers and are believed to be in Iraq, authorities said. The indictment says that, in discussions with an undercover agent, the Iraqis did not specifically say the triggers would be used to detonate nuclear warheads. But they insisted on design specifications ``that left nothing to the imagination,'' said John C. Kelley, who directs the U.S. Customs Service's strategic exports unit. Kelley said the Iraqis also expressed an interest in obtaining other components of timing devices for the warheads. The prospect of nuclear-warhead triggers being sold to Iraq ``is not only illegal, it is a very frightening situation we are dealing with,'' Customs Commissioner Carol Hallett said. The indictment, returned last month by a federal grand jury, charges that Euromac (London) Ltd., and Atlas Equipment (U.K.) Ltd. acted on behalf of the Iraqi government to illegally obtain the devices. Mrs. Hallett said Euromac was a purchasing agent for the Iraqi government and ``had done millions of dollars worth of business'' in buying arms for Iraq during that country's war with Iran. The indictment followed an 18-month undercover investigation conducted by U.S. and British customs agents. The indictment's description of Iraq's alleged role in the scheme contradicts denials by Iraqi officials that their government is seeking to develop a nuclear arsenal. The indictment said that Ali Ashour Daghir, who was ordered held without bond in London, was managing director of the companies. Jeanine Speckman, who was released on bail after her appearance in a British court, was accused of being an executive for the companies who participated in the negotiations to buy the triggers. The indictment charges that the companies and the five individual defendants conspired to illegally export the warhead-detonation capacitors made by CSI Technologies Inc., of San Marcos, Calif. The indictment charged that the defendants did not seek export licenses from the State Department, as required by U.S. law, after ordering the detonators from CSI. The defendants are also charged with money laundering, arising from the alleged transfer of $10,500 from Britain to CSI's account with the Bank of America in Escondido, Calif., to pay for the detonators. The indictment was returned Feb. 23 and amended with an additional charge last week. The Al-Qaqaa engineers charged in the indictment are Karim Dhaidas Omran, Dafir Al-Azawi and Wallid Issa Ahmad. Al-Qaqaa is a weapons development unit of Iraq's Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization, the indictment said. It was not immediately clear when, and if, the defendants in Britain could be extradited for the crimes charged in the indictment. Mrs. Hallett conceded there was ``little likelihood'' the three engineers believed to be in Iraq would ever be arrested. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said officials were reviewing which crimes charged in the indictment were subject to the U.S.-British extradition treaty. ``While we could request extradition tomorrow, according to the treaty they would not be extraditable until they go through the British legal system.'' The indictment charges the conspiracy began in September 1988, when the two British companies allegedly contacted a London representative of CSI about obtaining the detonators. Mrs. Hallett said the company immediately notified Customs agents of the Iraqi overture. The company entered into negotiations that fall about the price and design specifications. A representative of the British company told CSI officials that a delegation from Iraq had placed the order, the indictment stated. Customs agent Daniel Supnick, posing as a CSI executive, joined the negotiations last fall in London, the indictment said. To disguise the shipment, Speckman suggested that it be labeled as components for air conditioning, the indictment also said. The money-laundering charges stem from the alleged transfer of money to further an illegal conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Hungarian Lambastes New Romanian Leadership
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Laszlo Toekes, an ethnic Hungarian whose resistance ignited Romania's December revolution, accused the new regime Thursday of abuses reminiscent of ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Toekes, 37, an outspoken Ceausescu critic, has been elected bishop in the Reformed Church. An announcement Thursday by state Bucharest radio said he will serve in the northwestern city of Oradea, near the Hungarian border. In comments Thursday in Geneva, Toekes said extreme nationalist Romanian groups were to blame for deadly clashes between ethnic Hungarians and Romanians last week in Tirgu Mures, a Transylvania city about 250 miles northwest of Bucharest. Toekes, who was traveling in the United States during the ethnic unrest, accused the interim Romanian government of failing to intervene and of spreading ``false information'' that ethnic Hungarians provoked the clashes. He questioned the value of a proposed official inquiry, saying authorities blamed the Hungarian population from the outset. Many Romanians believe ethnic Hungarians in Transylvania want to secede and join Hungary. The ethnic Hungarians say they only want more cultural autonomy. Last week's unrest in Tirgu Mures reportedly killed six people and left 300 injured. In a statement distributed to a meeting at the Geneva-based World Council of Churches, Toekes said ``misinformation'' from the interim government and the Romanian media ``reminds one of the practices of the Ceausescu-era.'' ``Ceausescu argued in the same way, in keeping with his long-standing policy of dividing the nationalities and playing ... the Hungarian minority, as if the `Jews' of the country, against the Romanian nation,'' he said. Ceaucescu was executed during the revolution, which broke out in the western city of Timisoara when demonstrators tried to evict Toekes from his church. Toekes had run afoul of authorities by championing Hungarian rights. After the outbreak of the revolution, Ceausescu loyalists tried to assassinate Toekes, but he escaped without injury. In his statement Thursday, he said allegations that ethnic Hungarians in Transylvania want unification with neighboring Hungary are unfounded and intended to incite hatred. ``What happened in Tirgu Mures was something like a pogrom; its perpetrators came exclusively from among Romanians stirred up in the spirit of Ceausescuism. ...'' he said. At a press conference in Thursday in Geneva, Toekes said former Reform Church leaders had collaborated with Ceausescu and his hated secret police. He accused senior church officials in the town of Cluj of ``harassing and persecuting'' him for his outspoken stance. He also criticized the World Council of Churches for being ``too loyal'' to hard-line Communist governments in power throughout Eastern Europe before last year's changes swept the region. He said that while the World Council had consistently criticized racial discrimination in South Africa, it had shown great tolerance toward ``atheist regimes that were most dangerous to the Christian faith.'' The World Council groups about 300 non-Roman Catholic churches in more than 100 countries. The Reformed Church is the largest Protestant denomination in Romania. It has an estimated 800,000 faithful, mainly etnnic Hungarians living in Transylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Crewman Tells of Last, Frantic Minutes Aboard Aleutian Enterprise
DOC.TEXT: Crew members fought over survival suits in the final minutes before a fishing boat sank in the Bering Sea a week ago, a survivor testified at a hearing Thursday. Crew member Harvey Dale Philpot also told the Coast Guard and National Transportation Safety Board inquiry that he couldn't close the suit he had grabbed because the zipper was corroded. Philpot, 20, testified he had received no safety training aboard the 162-foot trawler Aleutian Enterprise, which capsized and sank March 22. Nine crew members are missing and presumed dead. Twenty-two crew members survived. The crewman said there was little warning the ship was in trouble, and that he first noticed something was wrong when it began to list while he was in a freezer on the lower deck. When he went up to the next level the list had increased and the port side of the deck was covered with four or five feet of water, Philpot said. Philpot said he tried to turn on a pump, but it didn't work. Crew members then began yelling to abandon ship and he ran to the next deck up to wake up his friend, Matt Price, 19, and to get a survival suit. At a box where the flotation suits were stored, he and four or five men struggled over the suits, he said. ``People were trying to grab from one another,'' he said. Philpot said somebody tried to grab his suit, but ``I was holding on to it. I wasn't letting go.'' Once he was topside, Philpot donned the suit and tried to zip it up, but found the zipper corroded. ``It just wouldn't go,'' he said. By that time, the ship had heeled far to port and Philpot and others on deck were swept into the near-freezing water, he said. He clung to buoys and debris until he was picked up by one of the life boats, he said. The survivors later were picked up by other fishing boats. Philpot said that on another fishing boat he worked on, the crew ran through safety drills and suit zippers were waxed to ensure they worked. None of that happened on the Aleutian Enterprise, he said. Terry Baker, chief executive officer of Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp., the operator of the cod fishing and processing boat, said outside the hearing he was surprised at the testimony about the suits. ``It's the first I've heard of it,'' Baker said, adding there were more than a total of 30 suits at three locations on the boat. He declined to comment on Philpot's testimony about safety training, except to say, ``We try to give as much training as possible.'' Philpot, the lead-off witness in the hearing that is expected to continue through early next week, also said he thought he smelled marijuana in the ship's pilot house early in the voyage. Under questioning by Coast Guard officers, he said that was the only occasion he detected any illegal drugs, and that he did not know the crewman in the pilot house. The Aleutian Enterprise's captain, Mark Siemons, was outside the pilot house at the time, he said. Philpot said alcohol was banned on the boat. As the hearing opened, attorneys for Arctic Alaska and Siemons objected that it was being held so soon after the accident. Attorney Jim Whitehead, representing the company, said some family members were still conducting memorial services for the missing, and the Coast Guard was showing ``unintended insensitivity'' to them. Coast Guard Capt. Rene Roussel, the hearing's chairman, said the Coast Guard wanted to get the information about the sinking on record as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Hard-liners Thinking About Penal Reform
DOC.TEXT: Albania's hard-line Communist regime is considering liberalizing its penal code and creating a justice ministry to oversee its courts, that country's official news agency reported Thursday. Draft laws before the Council of Ministers propose penal code changes that would allow for rehabilitation of prisoners and an early release program, the ATA news agency said. Albania's leaders have steadfastly rejected the reforms that swept other hard-line Communist regimes from power in Eastern Europe last year. However, under Communist leader Ramiz Alia, this small Balkan country has increasingly emerged from decades of self-imposed isolation. In past years, it has sought more contact with other Balkan nations. This month, Albania opened direct telephone service with the West. In another sign of cautious change, the official media acknowledged last month that Romania holds 83 political prisoners. Thursday's ATA report, monitored in Vienna, gave no details of the draft law on rehabilitation and early release. It also did not explain exactly what the ministry of justice would do.

DOC.HEAD: New York's Highest Court Upholds Howard Beach Convictions
DOC.TEXT: New York's highest court on Thursday upheld the manslaughter convictions of three men found guilty in the Howard Beach racial attack case. Jon Lester, Scott Kern and Jason Ladone had appealed their convictions, contending their lawyers were wrongly prohibited from rejecting blacks as jurors in the racially charged case. Lester, Kern and Ladone, all white, were convicted in December 1987 of manslaughter, assault and conspiracy for attacking three black men in the predominantly white Howard Beach section of Queens, a New York City borough, in 1986. One of the blacks, 23-year-old Michael Griffith, was struck by a car and killed as he fled across a nearby highway. Another man, Cedric Sandiford, was beaten with tree limbs and a baseball bat. The case before the state Court of Appeals centered on whether a 1986 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that prohibits prosecutors from excluding jurors based on race also applies to defending lawyers. State Supreme Court Justice Thomas Demakos, the presiding judge in the Howard Beach case, applied that standard to defense lawyers. ``We agree with the courts below that such purposeful racial discrimination is prohibited by ... our state Constitution,'' said Court of Appeals Judge Fritz Alexander in a 7-0 decision. ``Obviously we're disappointed,'' John Pollok, a lawyer for the three men, said Thursday. He said he hadn't seen the decision, but that he would consider asking the U.S. Supreme Court to hear an appeal. Pollok argued before the Court of Appeals that prosecutors systematically excluded whites, without giving justification, to help gain a conviction. At the same time, the defense was prevented from doing the same with prospective black jurors, he said. As it turned out, only one black was on the 12-person jury. There were also six whites, three Asians and two Hispanics. Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes, who was appointed special prosecutor in the Howard Beach case, praised Thursday's decision. ``It means that 12 judges in two separate rulings have unanimously affirmed that the defendants received a fair trial,'' Hynes said. In criminal cases, lawyers for each side may exclude a set number of jurors without having to give a reason. However, prosecutors may be stopped if the court believes they are rejecting jurors because of race. In the Howard Beach case, prosecutors asked that the same standard be applied to defense lawyers. The Court of Appeals also rejected arguments that the three men were convicted with insufficient evidence. Lester was sentenced to up to 30 years in prison and is in jail. Kern was sentenced to up to 18 years and Ladone up to 15 years in prison. Kern and Ladone were still out on bail Thursday, said Pollok.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Lebanese Hijacker Tries to Escape
DOC.TEXT: A Lebanese radical imprisoned after hijacking a jetliner and killing a passenger was captured following an abortive escape attempt, Swiss authorities reported Thursday. Hussein Hariri sawed through the steel bars of his cell window late Wednesday, but he set off an alarm when he approached the outer wall of Bochuz prison, authorities said. He offered no resistance when guards arrived. Hariri commandeered an Air Afrique DC-10 on a flight from Brazzaville, Congo, to Paris, on July 24, 1987. He was pressing demands for the release of Lebanese and Palestinians held by Israel, France and West Germany. On a refueling stop in Geneva, he shot to death a French passenger when his deadline for readying the plane expired. He was later overpowered by crew members and Swiss police who stormed the plane. There was unconfirmed rumors that the kidnappers of two Swiss Red Cross workers in Lebanon in October wanted to obtaining Hariri's release. No group has so far claimed responsibility for kidnapping Elio Erriquez and Emanuel Christen, who are still missing. But when a Swiss Red Cross delegate was kidnapped in Lebanon three months before Hariri's trial, the Swiss government said the abductors sought leniency for the defendant. Hariri was later sentenced to life in prison. The Red Cross delegate, Peter Winkler, was freed after one month in the hands of unidentified captors. Swiss authorities said no concessions were made to win his freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Economy Headed for Polish-Style `Shock Therapy'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet economy is heading inevitably toward Polish-style ``shock therapy'' to introduce a market system _ if consumers do not become so disgruntled that they block all reform, a senior official said Thursday. Vyacheslav Senchagov, chief of the State Price Committee, told deputies of the Supreme Soviet that under the most radical of three alternatives being considered, prices for raw materials and consumer goods are likely to rise drastically, the value of the Soviet ruble will plummet and unemployment will soar. The government favors a more moderate approach with a transition period, he said in remarks before his committee carried by the Tass news agency. But Tass said Senchagov acknowledged that choosing the most radical approach is ``inevitable, if during the transitional period ... the population's confidence in the government does not fall so low as to make no reforms possible.'' Senchagov said the government has not yet decided which approach it will try to implement. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said after being sworn in as the country's first executive president on March 15 that his most important task was to take more radical steps to cure the economy. Last week a source confirmed previous news reports that Gorbachev economists are working on a 17-point program leading to a market system and convertibility of the Soviet Union's currency on world markets. The source, who is working on the program, said Soviet economists were encouraged by Poland's tough measures that went into effect on Jan. 1, but were worried they might create huge unemployment and the need for a vast welfare program. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. Many reports in Moscow say a radical economic shake-up will be put into effect this summer. Senchagov's bureaucracy sets Soviet prices without regard to actual costs, creating artificially low prices for oil and gas and many natural resources, as well as for food and basic consumer goods. But the artificially low return for Soviet industry stifles production and initiative. Subsidies to keep prices low now cost the government the equivalent of one-fifth the total volume of the country's retail trade, Senchagov reported. Soviet consumers have become used to a system that offers a minimum of choice for low prices, and many react with alarm to reports that the government is planning to free prices. Public concern has forced the government to delay key price reforms several times. As a result of government management of prices, one videocassette costs about twice as much as a 1,200-mile airline trip. Also, the country has long told its people they have a right to a job. But many enterprises lose money because of bloated payrolls. Poland's prices have increased 1,366 percent during the 12-month period ending Feb. 28, the Warsaw government says, and more than 200,000 people are unemployed. But inflation has dropped from 79 percent in January to an estimated 6 percent in March. Poland has restocked its store shelves, while Soviets see their stores becoming emptier and emptier. The most conservative of the three approaches in Moscow would raise some prices for raw materials and some manufactured goods by fixed amounts. Another would free completely up to 30 percent of all prices, set an acceptable range for other prices, and control prices for staple goods. Under the most radical approach, oil and coal prices will increase 3-5 times. The number of collective and state farms, known for their inefficiency, will drop by 80 percent, ``unprofitable enterprises will be closed and unemployment will increase fast,'' Tass quoted Senchagov as saying. The official ruble rate against convertible currencies ``will drop many times.'' Even in the most moderate plan, the ruble's value will be cut in half. A ruble now ranges in value from $1.59 for locals in the Soviet Union to about 16 cents when foreigners exchange their hard currency.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Heads South
DOC.TEXT: Snow and heavy rain fell on the South and Southwest and in the Rockies on Thursday, with some local flooding along the South Carolina coast. The midweek storm over the central Rockies continued to move southward during the morning, while thunderstorms continued to grow across southeast Texas and western Louisiana. From 2 to 4 inches of snow fell overnight across northern New Mexico. Snow fell during the day across northeast New Mexico, the northern portion of the Texas Panhandle, the Oklahoma Panhandle and central Wyoming. Snow over eastern Colorado was mixed with rain in the lower elevations. In the West, rain was scattered over the northern Pacific Coast, central Utah, west central Colorado, southeast New Mexico and northwest Texas. Rainshowers and thunderstorms extended from the Texas Gulf Coast across eastern Texas, Louisiana and Arkansas. Elsewhere, rain reached from southeast Iowa across Illinois, southern Wisconsin, northern and central Indiana, southwest lower Michigan and northwest through central Ohio. Rain also reached from western Pennsylvania across Maryland, Delaware, eastern West Virginia, Virginia, South Carolina, North Carolina, eastern Tennessee, Georgia and eastern Alabama. Showers and thunderstorms extended along the Georgia and South Carolina coasts and very heavy rainfall caused local flooding over portions of the South Carolina coast near Beaufort and McClellanville. The low temperature for the nation Thursday morning was 2 degrees above zero at both Caribou and Houlton, Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 23 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 87 degrees at the Naval Air Station near Jacksonville, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Parliament Votes to End Abortion Ban
DOC.TEXT: Parliament moved to end a 123-year ban on abortions Thursday by voting to allow abortion during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy if the woman is deemed to be in distress. The Senate approved the bill last November and it now must be signed into law by King Baudouin. That would leave Ireland as the only European Community nation with a total ban on abortions. The House of Representatives voted 126 to 69, with 12 abstentions, to scrap an 1867 law that made abortion a criminal offense and provided terms of up to five years in prison for offenders. That law has been spottily enforced in recent years. Belgian women have been getting abortions for years with little interference from authorities. Also, many traveled outside Belgium to have abortions. Thursday's vote split Prime Minister Wilfried Martens' center-left coalition along Christian Democratic-Socialist lines, but coalition partners agreed beforehand the vote would not result in a government crisis. Church officials in in this overwhelmingly Catholic country vigorously opposed the bill, though opinion polls indicated most Belgians feel abortion should be decriminalized. Under the new measure, a woman can get an abortion during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy if she and her doctor feel she is in ``distress'' due to the pregnancy. Opponents attacked the term ``distress'' as too vague, creating a situation of abortion on demand. Conservative legislator Annemie Neyts, who supported the bill, said, ``I have trouble with claims saying the bill is the dawn of an age of moral depravation.'' Christian Democrat Paul Hermans, who opposed the measure, said supporters considered ``the fetus an inferior being which merits only inferior protection.'' The government of Flanders, Belgium's Dutch-speaking northern half, meanwhile granted $5.1 million in subsidies for an information campaign on preventing undesired pregnancies. Over the last 20 years, the abortion issue became a bitter political fight. Thousands took to the streets in the 1970s over the issue. Protests heated up in 1973 when a doctor was jailed for more than a month, accused of performing hundreds of abortions. He was later released. The bill approved Thursday capped a 16-year period in which more than a dozen pro-abortion bills were voted down in parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Haitians Celebrate Restored Constitution
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ About 10,000 demonstrators shouting ``Justice!'' and ``Democracy!'' rallied at City Hall on Thursday to celebrate the restoration of Haiti's suspended 1987 constitution. The new civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot announced Wednesday it was restoring nearly all articles of the constitution. A national holiday was declared for Thursday, the third anniversary of the constitution's ratification in a popular vote. The government said it restored all but a few, unspecified articles of the constitution dealing with certain government functions, including those of parliament, because no lawmaking body is in place. The restored constitution turns the police force over to control by a civilian justice minister. The force is now incorporated into the army. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was named provisional president March 13 after military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled the country during a popular uprising. ``The constitution is stronger than bayonets,'' said the Rev. Antoine Adrien, spokesman for the Unity Assembly, a coalition of political parties that called the rally. ``We have taken a giant step forward, even though we do not have a just society yet,'' said Adrien, speaking on a platform next to other political leaders in front of City Hall in Port-au-Prince, the capital. The two-hour rally was peaceful. Schools and shops were closed for the demonstration, the first authorized by police in more than 18 months. The constitution, ratified by 99 percent of the voters March 29, 1987, was suspended by then-dictator Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy in July 1988. It was partially restored by Avril in March 1989. The demonstrators Thursday also protested against the political violence that has terrorized the population of this impoverished Caribbean nation since Avril's ouster. Demonstrators carried cardboard signs bearing such slogans as ``Arrest all Criminals'' and ``Justice Now.'' One group of youths hoisted a marcher on their shoulders and put a tire around his body in a mock lynching. From March 18 to March 23, nearly 40 people were killed and dozens wounded in a rash of crimes allegedly provoked by opponents of democracy and Avril supporters. The government Wednesday ordered all paramilitary agents to hand over their weapons to police within 72 hours or face prosecution. The dreaded paramilitary thugs, known as Tonton Macoutes, were outlawed after dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier was forced from power by another popular uprising in February 1986. However, many former Tonton Macoutes were integrated into the army as special agents and have often been accused of state-sponsored terrorism. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot did not attend Thursday's rally for security reasons, said Social Affairs Minister Claudette Werleigh. She has promised to hold free elections as soon as possible.

Drug Lords Hint They'll Retaliate for Renewed U.S. Extraditions
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cocaine cartel hinted Thursday it will retaliate for the government's renewed extradition of drug suspects to the United States. The cartel's message came in a communique a day after the government of President Virgilio Barco sent 29-year-old Fernando Gutierrez to Arizona for trial on drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges. It was the first extradition of a drug trafficking suspect since Jan. 21. The cartel, which has been waging a war with the government, claimed Thursday it had been betrayed by officials who started and then backed out of talks aimed at a settlement to a bloody conflict that has left more than 200 Colombians dead since the August slaying of a presidential candidate. Accusing the police of murdering suspects, the group said, ``We will not remain indifferent in the face of betrayal, torture and killing of our companions.'' It did not elaborate. It again called extraditions illegal and ``attacks against Colombian sovereignty.'' The traffickers' communique, given to Medellin news media, was signed by the Extraditables, the name adopted by the Medellin cartel. The government has been using extraditions, feared by the traffickers, as a weapon in its U.S.-backed war with traffickers. Extradition is considered necessary because traffickers often evade Colombian justice by killing and bribing judges. Gutierrez was the 15th Colombian extradited since August, and police are holding 17 more Colombians wanted by the United States. In a statement Thursday, Barco said the government this year had captured 845 drug suspects and seized more than 19,000 pounds of cocaine. Other seizures include $31 million in cash, 387 pounds of gold and about 21,000 pounds of dynamite. On Jan. 17, the cartel declared a unilateral truce. It said it was prepared to surrender to the government in exchange for an end to extradition. Speculation about possible talks between the government and traffickers increased during the last two months because no one else was extradited. That speculation peaked Sunday, when Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds resigned. He said the government had lost its will to fight the traffickers. In Thursday's communique, the cartel said two businessmen acted as intermediaries in the talks. It said they were received by Barco on various occasions to negotiate the release of the son of the president's closest adviser, German Montoya. The cartel kidnapped Alvaro Montoya on Dec. 20 and released him on Jan. 23 in one of a series of what it called goodwill gestures to show the government its desire for peace. Barco denied Thursday that the government had negotiated with traffickers and said it would continue fighting the criminals. ``There has not been _ nor will there be _ official nor extra-official contacts between the government and representatives of drug traffickers, much less pacts, treaties and agreements between the government and drug traffickers,'' Barco said in his communique Thursday. Barco acknowledged that the businessman had been received, but he called it an informal gathering without official status. The cartel communique claimed that while the government was negotiating with traffickers, it sent police death squads to wipe them out. The cartel accused police of murdering 40 of its members. The Barco administration took more action Thursday against traffickers, declaring martial law in a Medellin area township that is reportedly controlled by Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar. The move allows a military administrator to take over policing power from the popularly elected mayor of Envigado.
