Astronomers From Virginia and Australia Find What May Be Brown Dwarf Star
DOC.TEXT: Astronomers have identified for the first time what they believe is a brown dwarf star, a stellar body that lacks the mass to trigger the fusion reaction that gives stars their brilliant light. The National Science Foundation announced Thursday that Philip A. Ianna of the University of Virginia and Michael S. Bessell of the Stromlo and Siding Spring Observatories in Australia identified the candidate brown dwarf after taking measurements of its brightness and mass. Visible only in the skies of the southern hemisphere, the dim, red stellar body equals about 5 percent of the mass of the sun. The sun emits about 4,000 times more light than the dwarf. The dwarf is in the Milky Way, the galaxy which includes the sun, and is about 68 light-years away, the astronomers said. A light-year is the distance light travels in a year, a bit less than 6 trillion miles. Brown dwarfs have been theorized to exist for years with most experts predicting they would have 7 percent to 8 percent of the mass of the sun. This would not be sufficient mass for gravitational forces to compress it and heat it to the point where its hydrogen fuses into helium. Without fusion, such a stellar body would give off only a faint red glow caused by its modest gravitational compression. Ianna and Bessell said they found the candidate brown dwarf by studying a group of very, very faint stars first discovered by Michael R. S. Hawkins of the Royal Observatory in Edinburgh, Scotland. ``We have measured the distance from Earth to what seemed like the dimmest of these stars and found that the star is truly faint,'' Ianna said in a statement released by the foundation. ``This supports the hypothesis that this whole group of stars is faint and contains other brown dwarf candidates.'' Some astronomers have suggested that brown dwarfs may be the so-called missing matter of the universe. The missing matter question arose when astronomers studying the movement of stars and galaxies concluded that gravitation forces acting on visible stellar bodies are too great to be explained by the mass of the observed objects in space. Some believe that up to 90 percent of the matter in the universe is not seen. Brown dwarfs, it has been proposed, could be part of the undetected matter. There is also a theory that the missing mass is cold, dark matter such as interstellar molecules, black holes and a subatomic particles called neutrinos, which cannot be observed. Ianna and Bessell studied the candidate brown dwarf using an electronic camera on the one-meter telescope at the Siding Spring Observatory. Sighting from two different perspectives within the Earth's orbit of the sun, the scientists were able to calculate the distance of the object from Earth. The mass of the object was estimated based on studies of its luminosity, or brightness.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Accused of Taking Bribes in Airbus Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede to CORRECT typo in ``government''; SUBS one graf for 9th `Prassad resigned...' to CORRECT spelling of Prasad; pickup graf 10 `The crash...'
DOC.TEXT: The country's top investigating agency Thursday accused four former government officials of accepting bribes from Airbus Industrie to award a $1.47 billion contract to the European consortium. The Central Bureau of Investigation filed preliminary charges against S.S. Sidhu, the former aviation secretary; R.K. Prasad, Indian Airlines' former managing director; Kamini Chadha, another former managing director of the airline; and former deputy managing director B.K. Bhasin. Also accused were unidentified officials of Airbus Industrie, based in Toulouse, France, and International Aero Engines, a company based in Switzerland and East Hartford, Conn. It manufactured the V-2500 engines used in the A320s. Under Indian law, preliminary charges are registered before the court and state that enough evidence exits to investigate. Final or regular charges are filed when investigations are completed. The charges said the officials accepted kickbacks to reverse a decision to purchase U.S.-made Boeing 757 jetliners and instead buy 38 Airbus A320s. They did not say how much the alleged kickbacks amounted to. Airbus officials in France said they had not been notified officially about the investigation. They said they were surprised by the allegations and refused further comment. The charges also said other public servants _ a term that would include politicians in office at the time of the alleged wrongoind _ were involved. The bureau began investigating the deal, completed in June, after an Indian Airlines A320 crashed Feb. 14 while landing at the southern Indian city of Bangalore. The crash killed 92 of the 146 people on board. Prasad resigned after the accident. The crash triggered criticism in the Indian press. It questioned the roles played by members of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's government in awarding the contract to Airbus. ``The previous government pushed through the deal with undue haste,'' said India Today, a respected news magazine, a month after the crash. ``It ignored other options as well as warning signals about the inadequacy of the ground support system and brushed aside the need for more time to evaluate the aircraft.'' Indian newspapers said the Bangalore crash was a result of the plane's engines not responding in time to a computer command by the pilot when he found the aircraft was coming in too low for its landing. It was the second crash involving an A320, the only passenger aircraft with computerized flight controls. Three people were killed in June 1988 when an A320 crashed during an airshow in France. The government grounded all Indian Airlines A320s pending the report of a committee investigating the Bangalore crash. Further deliveries of the plane have been halted. The investigation is the third launched by Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government into deals made by previous governments. Singh replaced Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister in December after triumphing in parliamentary elections. He campaigned on a promise to end government corruption. The Central Bureau of Investigation is also inquiring into the purchase of artillery guns from the Swedish company A.B. Bofors and the purchase of submarines from the West German firm Howaldt Deutsche Werke. Both have been clouded by allegations of kickbacks.

DOC.HEAD: Police Reservist Slain in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed a police reservist Wednesday night at his home at Armagh, 35 miles southwest of Belfast, police reported. No group immediately claimed responsibility but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. A police headquarters statement in Belfast said the assailants were believed to have fired through a window, killing the officer instantly. It said he had been recovering at home from leg injuries suffered in a road accident seven weeks ago. Police also said the office of the director of public prosecutions ruled out trying the case of Seamus Duffy, a 13-year-old Catholic boy killed by a plastic bullet fired by police last summer during riots in west Belfast. A police statement said investigations disclosed the boy was hit minutes after he threw a gasoline bomb at security forces. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite the Protestant-dominated province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Estonian Lawmakers to Debate Gradual Move Toward Independence
With AM-Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: The new legislature of the Baltic republic Estonia on Thursday agreed to debate a more gradual path to restoring independence than that of Lithuania, a legislator said. The Supreme Soviet of Estonia, on the first day of its session, also elected Arnold Ruutel president of the republic, reported the official Soviet news agency Tass. Ruutel is a former chairman of the legislature's presidium. Mart Laar, an independent deputy, said in a telephone interview that the legislators Friday are to debate a declaration saying the republic will work toward restoring the independence Estonia enjoyed before it was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. A second proposal calls for the legislature to cooperate with the Estonian Congress, an informal group of 500 people that met earlier this month. They consider themselves the real representative of Estonians. A bill calling for a transition to independence is on the agenda, but the legislation probably will not be discussed Friday, Laar said. He said the length of the transition period so far has not been set. Tass said the proposals had been put forward by the Estonian People's Front political movement, which controls more than 40 of the 105 Supreme Soviet seats. The legislators were elected in contested balloting March 18. The Estonian legislature's approach to restoring independence mirrors the path taken by the republic's Communist Party. Meeting Sunday, the party established a six-month transition period to full independence from the Soviet party. Estonians have taken a more cautious approach than Lithuanians. That Baltic republic declared independence from Moscow on March 11, and it has been embroiled in a tense standoff with Soviet authorities ever since. Estonian activists say they must act more cautiously because they do not have such large ethnic or legislative majorities as the Lithuanians do in their republic. The Estonians also say they want to establish the conditions for independence before formally breaking with Moscow. The deputies also must elect a premier. Tass said a close election was expected between the current head of government, Indrik Toome, and the leader of the People's Front, Edgar Savisaar.

DOC.HEAD: CDC: `No Evidence' of Cancer Risk From Agent Orange; Vets Assail Study
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 25th graf, ``Payments, which...,'' to CORRECT subsequent-year annual cost from $2 million to $25 million.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A long-awaited government study of cancer among Vietnam veterans found no evidence linking the disease with exposure to the herbicide Agent Orange, officials said Thursday. The study by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, which looked only indirectly at Agent Orange, did find veterans at increased risk of a relatively rare cancer called non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. But researchers noted the risk was greater among veterans who served on ships than those who served on land, where the herbicide was used. In Washington, Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski quickly said he would order the Department of Veterans Affairs to pay disability compensation to vets suffering from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The study was immediately attacked by veterans groups, which complained it failed to sufficiently examine the cancer risks among the thousands of soldiers who actually worked with the dangerous herbicide during the war. ``It is not an Agent Orange study,'' objected Mary R. Stout, president of the Vietnam Veterans of America. ``This is only a look at Vietnam veterans'' who had cancer, added John Hansen, spokesman for the American Legion. And Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., co-chairman of the Vietnam-Era Veterans in Congress Caucus, said: ``This action has been a long time coming. However, it is not the final word. We cannot forget the many other veterans who are also suffering and dying from Agent Orange-related diseases and who have just as much evidence supporting their claims.'' Agent Orange, sprayed by the U.S. military to remove jungle cover and crops in Vietnam, contained dioxin, a highly toxic chemical which some studies have found to increase cancer risks. Criticism of the study focused on its methods, which involved comparing cancer patients of Vietnam-veteran age to healthy counterparts. The study ``only indirectly evaluated'' Agent Orange exposure, because of the technical difficulties in determining two decades later how much a patient may have been exposed to the herbicide, the CDC said. Specific analysis of dioxin exposure was impractical, partly because researchers don't know how cancer may skew the results of blood tests for dioxin levels, said Dr. Daniel A. Hoffman, assistant director for science at the CDC's Center for Environmental Health. ``Our study was designed to look at Vietnam experience and history, and secondly to ascertain the likelihood of exposure,'' Hoffman said. The study, conducted over five years, surveyed 2,067 cancer patients who were of approximate Vietnam service age _ between 15 and 39 in 1968, at the height of U.S. troop involvement. They were compared to 1,776 men of similar age who had no history of cancer. Both groups were studied for risk of six kinds of cancer, including soft tissue cancer and similar sarcomas, a group of cancers that the CDC concedes has been ``of great concern among Vietnam veterans.'' Vietnam vets were found to have a roughly 50 percent increased risk for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. ``The study did not find any evidence that the increased risk might be due to Agent Orange exposure,'' said CDC Director William L. Roper. That conclusion, the CDC said, came in part because the cancer risk among Vietnam veterans ``seemed to be the opposite of the pattern for use of Agent Orange.'' Vets from the Navy's ocean ships had somewhat higher cancer risks than those who served on land. And veterans from the region of heaviest Agent Orange use were at ``somewhat lower risk'' than others, the CDC said. Specifically, the yearly risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is about one in 10,000 for men 35-59, the age group of most Vietnam vets. The risk for Vietnam vets overall is about 1.5 per 10,000, Roper said. The risk nearly doubled _ 90 percent higher _ for Navy veterans stationed on ocean ships. The 50 percent higher risk is what epidemiologists call ``a weak association,'' Hoffman said: It is statistically significant, but ``anything less than a twofold increase can sometimes be caused by other factors.'' The CDC found ``no increased risk'' for sarcomas, usually cancers of the body's connective tissues, or for other cancer types. The VA had been awaiting the study before deciding whether to award benefits to vets exposed to Agent Orange. Nearly 35,000 claims have been filed citing the chemical as a cause of disabilities including cancer, skin disease and miscarriages by soldiers' wives. In announcing the non-Hodgkin's lymphoma benefits, Derwinski mentioned only the link between Vietnam service and the lymphoma. He didn't say the connection was because of Agent Orange. Payments, which would be retroactive, are expected to cost $23 million the first year and $25 million a year in succeeding years, VA officials said. Based on the study, the VA estimated 1,800 veterans are due compensation, and there will be 450 new cases each year. The complaints before the VA aren't the only ones about Agent Orange. A class-action lawsuit against the seven manufacturers of Agent Orange was settled in 1984 in U.S. District Court in New York, and payments began last year. The court has estimated that 30,000 veterans and 18,000 survivor families would be eligible for benefits from a settlement fund of at least $240 million. The settlement's court-appointed administrator, Washington attorney Kenneth Feinberg, had yet to see the CDC study and couldn't say what effect, if any, it might have on the case, his office said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: More Bodies Found Near Stalin-era Camp
DOC.TEXT: Authorities uncovered hundreds of human skeleton parts near a camp where Soviet soldiers kept Nazi prisoners after World War II, East Germany's news agency said Wednesday. The ADN news agency said remains of 200 to 1,000 people were unearthed from mass graves near a former Soviet internment camp in the district of Oranienburg, about 30 miles north of Berlin. Authorities began excavating at Oranienburg after a 66-year-old resident told local officials last week that he remembers watching Soviet soldiers shoot 100 to 400 German prisoners in the area from 1946 to 1948. East Germany's Berliner Zeitung newspaper said last week that up to 12,000 German inmates may have died at another Soviet internment camp near Fuenfeichen, about 80 miles north of Berlin. Many of the camps used by the Soviets had been used as prison camps by the Nazis. Although the paper said most were Nazi soldiers, it said many innocent people, including youngsters, died at the camp at Fuenfeichen. There have been reports for years that large numbers of Nazi prisoners died in Stalin-era prison camps, but little evidence until East Germany shed its hard-line Communist government in last year's popular revolt. During the Nazi era, 6 million Jews were exterminated and hundreds of thousands of gypsies, Poles and others were killed. A West German official said this week that 65,000 to 70,000 German prisoners may have died at the post-war Soviet camps.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Leader Says Most Rebels Have Returned to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 12,000 Contra rebels have returned to Nicaragua from Honduran base camps and the rest will return by this weekend, ahead of an April 20 deadline, a Contra chief said Thursday. ``They did not wait for the U.N. forces and turn in weapons,'' said Oscar Sovalbarro, a military chief of the Nicaraguan Resistance, the rebels' umbrella group. ``Only about 3,000 war-wounded and their families remain in the camps.'' Under an agreement reached Friday between the Contras and representatives of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the rebels are to disband and turn in their weapons five days before the new government takes over April 25 from the leftist Sandinistas. Rebels in Nicaragua are to gather in U.N.-supervised security zones under the Toncontin Accord but there is no deadline for their demobilization. The agreement takes its name from the Honduran air base where it was signed. ``A large majority of our combatants have already crossed the Honduran border to go to Nicaragua,'' Sovalbarro said. ``The Nicaraguan Resistance in that way fulfills its promises.'' U.S. Ambassador Chris Arcos congratulated President Rafael Leonardo Callejas for his role in getting the rebels to leave Honduras. ``The Contras have been dissolved ... and Callejas resolved that problem,'' Arcos said in a news conference at the presidential offices. ``It was a notable feat by Callejas.'' Callejas sponsored the negotiations, in which Nicaraguan Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, archbishop of Managua, also participated. ``In our camps in Yamales there are few weapons and few combatants left and before the end of the week they will be in Nicaragua,'' Sovalbarro said. Yamales, 125 miles southwest of Tegucigalpa and just inside the border with Nicaragua, has been used by the rebels since the start nine years ago of their U.S.-backed war to overthrow the Sandinistas. Sovalbarro, 29, known as Commander Ruben, signed the agreement with the incoming government. ``We want to turn in our rifles in Nicaragua because if there is going to be democracy in our country then we will exchange our weapons for the plow to cultivate the land,'' he said. ``The camps will be completely deserted in the next three weeks. No one will remain here,'' he said. Reporters who visited camps this week said they were nearly deserted. An estimated 80,000 Hondurans displaced by the rebels, including 20,000 coffee producers, were forced to move to the interior of the country or traveled illegally to the United States or Mexico to find work.

DOC.HEAD: First Lawsuit Filed in Fire That Killed 87
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 8 grafs with lawsuit filed; pick up 5th graf, `Julio Gonzalez ...'. SUBS 11th graf pvs, `The building ...', with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Dinkins aide's involvement with illegal establishment; pick up 12th graf pvs, `The city has ...'
DOC.TEXT: The mother of one of the 87 people killed in a fire at an illegal social club filed a $510 million lawsuit Thursday, the first stemming from the inferno, an attorney said. The lawsuit seeks that amount in damages from the owners, lessees and proprietors of the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx. It also names the man charged with setting the fire. Attorney Harry Lipsig said he filed the lawsuit in Bronx state Supreme Court, New York's trial-level court, on behalf of Jennie Mae Danzler, mother of Natalie Danzler, 31. Lipsig said he also notified city officials he planned to sue the city ``because of its reckless conduct in connection with the club.'' Earlier Thursday, angry City Council members pressed top city officials about how Happy Land could have remained open despite repeated warnings that such clubs were catastrophes waiting to happen. ``If you don't learn from the past you're condemned to repeat its mistakes,'' council member Sheldon S. Leffler said as he questioned Police Commissioner Lee Brown at a meeting of the council's Public Safety Committee. ``We all bear the blame,'' Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said outside the meeting. ``We've got to keep the heat on until we can resolve this problem.'' The fire occurred early Sunday as the club's patrons, many of them Honduran immigrants, danced and drank liquor in a building that lacked a liquor license and violated much of the fire code. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was charged with 87 counts of felony murder, 87 counts of murder through depraved indifference and one count of attempted murder and arson. Police said he had argued with his former girlfriend, a worker at the club. The City Council itself has come under criticism since the fire because a bill that would have increased penalties for operating clubs illegally was allowed to die in committee. But on Thursday, council members criticized fire and building officials over enforcement of existing laws. Several council members said they were surprised to learn that laws giving the city authority to ``seal'' premises were interpreted as meaning only that a notice could be posted on the door. During several hours of testimony, city officials insisted a crackdown on unlicensed social clubs was more than a paper threat. Brown said eight clubs were closed Wednesday night and 15 on Tuesday by a beefed-up task force of police, fire and buildings inspectors. One establishment ordered closed last year and again Monday was El Caney, whose board of directors included Mayor David Dinkins' Hispanic affairs commissioner, William Nieves, the Daily News disclosed Thursday. Dinkins defended his aide at a news conference Thursday, saying the East Harlem establishment was a non-profit cultural and educational center, not a commercial social club. But he acknowledged that fire and building inspectors found the building had faulty fire doors and should have been closed. He said Nieves had resigned from the establishment's board of directors before taking the city post. The building housing Happy Land was owned by real estate developer Alex DiLorenzo and leased to a group called One Peach Associates, which is partly owned by Jay Weiss, husband of actress Kathleen Turner. One Peach sublet the building for $1,950 a month to club proprieter Elias Colon, who died in the fire. The city has been trying since 1988 to close another illegal Bronx social club in a building owned by DiLorenzo and leased by Weiss and his partner in One Peach, Morris Jaffe, New York Newsday reported. Weiss's attorneys have said they never were formally notified of the violations the city found at Happy Land. DiLorenzo is the landlord for two other illegal clubs ordered closed Nov. 20, 1988, The Daily News reported. Those clubs were ordered shut again this week. Separately, DiLorenzo has been accused of 1,585 violations in four Harlem apartment buildings he owned, 150 of them for conditions considered imminently dangerous, the News said. DiLorenzo's attorney, Mark Friedlander, did not immediately return a telephone call to his office Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Special Aid for Miners in Key Clean Air Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs: ``The vote,'' with three new grafs bgng: ``In separate,'' to note additonal House and Senate action on clean fuels
DOC.TEXT: The Senate by a razor-thin margin turned back pleas for special aid to coal miners Thursday, rejecting a measure Senate leaders and the White House said could have jeopardized broader clean air legislation. The $500 million assistance amendment was voted down 50 to 49 after five hours of debate during which supporters argued the miners needed help because they would be adversely affected by tougher air pollution controls. The measure was seen as the biggest remaining obstacle to passage of major air pollution control legislation that is scheduled for a final vote next Tuesday. A similar bill is pending in a House committee. The government has estimated more than 5,000 miners of high-sulfur coal are likely to lose their jobs as Midwest utilities switch to other fuels to meet new pollution requirements in the coming years. The narrow vote was a victory for Senate leaders of both parties _ George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Bob Dole, R-Kan. _ as well as the Bush administration which had opposed the assistance proposal as too expensive and discriminatory against other workers. The White House had threatened to withdraw support from any bill that exceeded the current estimated $21 billion-a-year cost, and Mitchell said the amendment pressed by Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., probably would have pushed the total beyond that level. In separate action late Thursday, the Senate agreed to an amendment that would require the use, by 1993, of a cleaner blend of gasoline in automobiles in the nine cities with the worst smog problems. The measure was approved by a voice vote after an attempt to kill it failed 69-30. In the House, the Energy and Commerce Committee beefed up a provision in its clean air legislation with a similar requirement calling for the use of reformulated gasoline in the same nine cities by 1995. A proposal to require the cleaner fuel in a broader area covering as many as 40 cities was rejected. The vote on the Byrd amendment to help coal miners came after days of intense lobbying from both sides, including last minute telephone calls from the White House to key senators _ some calls coming even as the vote was under way. Byrd, whose power as chairman of the Appropriations Committee is widely respected, had visited dozens of senators in search of support. He got the votes of 38 of the Senate's 55 Democrats and 11 of its 45 Republicans. Byrd said later that under intense White House pressure ``three of my votes took wings.'' Among those voting with Byrd was Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, who suffers from cancer and was brought into the chamber in a wheelchair. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., said he voted against the proposal in the last minutes after a telephone call from White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, who told him President Bush would veto the clean air bill if the assistance proposal were included. Senate leaders also had feared that if the measure were approved other senators would seek similar financial aid for workers in other industries. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, promised to do just that. ``This amendment discriminates against all workers who are not coal miners,'' declared Mitchell minutes before the vote. Mitchell and other senators said thousands of workers in other fields, including the steel and petrochemical industries, also could suffer job losses and would not have such benefits. Byrd, who has been a staunch advocate for miners for years, argued that the issue was a matter of ``fairness ... and justice'' because of the severe impact that new acid rain controls would have on Midwest utilities and, in turn, on miners in high-sulfur coal fields. The main clean air bill, which is scheduled for a vote in the Senate next week, calls for sweeping pollution controls on industry, automobiles and utility plants. New controls on sulfur dioxide emissions from Midwest electric power plants _ an effort to combat acid rain _ are expected to cause utilities to shift away from high-sulfur coal to cleaner fuels, causing mines in Appalachia and the Midwest to close and miners to lose their jobs. Calling on senators to ``hear the cries of people'' and respond to them, Byrd said help for the miners is no different that the federal assistance given to victims of a hurricane or earthquake, who suffer because of no fault of their own. ``We're not asking for welfare,'' he declared. For nearly two weeks, Byrd, a former Senate majority leader who still wields considerable power as chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, has cajoled, pressured and pleaded with senators to line up in support of his proposal. At the same time, Mitchell, his successor as Democratic leader, has sought to persuade Byrd to go along with a cheaper compromise proposal that might be acceptable to the White House. Byrd on Wednesday said the compromise ``doesn't do what needs to be done.'' Under the Byrd proposal, miners of high-sulfur coal, who lose their jobs because utilities switch to other fuels, would receive up to 70 percent of their salaries for three years and also additional funds if they undergo a special retraining program. The benefits would be available as long as the miner is unemployed. Byrd originally sought a six-year assistance program, costing $1.3 billion, but he scaled down the proposal twice to garner additional Senate support. The government estimates that about 5,000 miners of high-sulfur coal _ many of them in Byrd's West Virginia _ are likely to lose their jobs as Midwest utilities switch to other fuels because of the new curbs on sulfur dioxide emissions.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky House Passes to Schools-and-Taxes Bill
DOC.TEXT: An education bill that would radically overhaul a school system declared unconstitutional by the state Supreme Court won final passage Thursday in the state House. House Bill 940, which also raises taxes by $1.26 billion and which many called the most important bill of the century in Kentucky, was passed by the Senate on Wednesday with several amendments. With a single vote Thursday, the House accepted the changes. It then voted 58-42 to pass the bill and send it to Gov. Wallace Wilkinson. Senate Majority Floor Leader Joe Wright said Wilkinson has assured him he would not veto the bill. ``We're going to do innovative things in Kentucky for once,'' said Rep. Greg Stumbo, the majority floor leader. ``We're not going to be a follower anymore. We're going to be a leader.'' The bill repeals and replaces all Kentucky laws on elementary and secondary education. The Kentucky Supreme Court last year declared the entire school system unconstitutional because its quality varied so greatly between rich school districts and poor. The court found that Kentucky students were performing in the lowest quarter nationally, as measured by standardized tests. The legislation will mean more money for schools in general and dramatically greater funding for poor districts. It also calls for a large-scale investment in technology, emphasis on early childhood education and extra help for potential dropouts. Under the current system, spending for the state's 570,000 students varies from $1,800 to $4,200 a year per student, depending on the district. Under the new plan, the minimum spending level would be $2,900 in the 1990-91 school year. Overall state financing for elementary and secondary education would increase from $1.5 billion this year to $1.9 billion next year. Under the plan, local districts will gain more control over day-to-day operations of schools, which are to be judged by how successfully their students learn. Cash rewards will await employees of schools that improve each year. In addition, control of the system would be shifted from an elected state superintendent to an appointed education commissioner. About half of the money from the tax increase would be spent on schools. The Senate's most important amendment would eliminate immediately the state deduction that residents receive for federal tax payments, raising $141 million in the next two years. The House version of the bill would have phased out the deduction. The governor hailed the Senate's passage of the bill Wednesday as ``history in the making.''

DOC.HEAD: Underground Artist Surfaces _ at Lincoln Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with 6 grafs to UPDATE with details, quotes from performance.
With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: After 20 years of playing his violin in the subways, James Graseck had nowhere to go but up. The underground artist surfaced Thursday night in Lincoln Center, trading the A train for Alice Tully Hall. The special show for Graseck's straphanging fans was a new experience for the violinist, who usually plays Beethoven over screeching brakes or performs Paganini on a packed platform. ``It is a dream come true in a way,'' Graseck said hours before his performance. ``But at the same time, the main thing is I've worked very hard to develop a rapport with my fellow New Yorkers.'' Those New Yorkers _ 1,096 of 'em at $16 a pop _ bought out the hall at Lincoln Center for Graseck's show. The violinist planned a 75-minute program of classical music but played at least a dozen encores. Most were excerpts running no longer than three to five minutes _ about the time one has to wait for a train. ``I learned these playing you-know-where,'' he told his fans with a grin. After the show, he hung out with the audience in the lobby. ``Elaine, from the World Trade Center stop! Good to see you,'' he said, hugging one straphanger fan and waving to another. ``Bob, I'll see you at the Long Island Railroad, OK?'' Lillian Binder said she knew him from the Broadway-Lafayette stop on the D line. ``I can't tell you how many times I've missed my train listening to him,'' she said. ``One time I was late to work and told my boss, I'm sorry, I was listening to this guy in the subway play `Scheherazade.' My boss said, 'I know that guy. He's great.' `` ``Everyone in the hall, with the exception of my family, is someone I've met playing on the street. I'm taking them from outside in the subways to inside at the concert hall,'' said Graseck. His subway supporters actually helped finance his show. Graseck said the $5,000 he has paid to rent Alice Tully Hall for the night came partially from the change tossed his way by commuters. Graseck studied at Juilliard; one of his teachers, Christine Dethier, planned to attend Thursday's performance. He also taught for a few years in Columbus, Ga. His initial mass transit performance came in 1968 on a Long Island Rail Road car, Graseck said. He made $10 in five minutes, and a star was born. These days, a subway performer can make about $100 a day, said Graseck, who also does freelance orchestra work. And make no mistake _ Graseck loves the music, but he started in this line of work for the money. ``At first I did it just for the money,'' he confessed. ``But the applause, the smiles, made me feel as though I was reaching the hearts of people. It's very spontaneous, very communicative.'' Graseck has played on and on since then. His favorite platform to play on is at 53rd Street and Lexington Avenue, although he pops up at stations throughout the system. He has memories _ some of them pretty strange _ about each spot. He remembers playing ``The Nutcracker Suite'' for a nude, dancing man in the 77th Street subway station. He met his wife, Suzanne, while playing beneath 666 Fifth Ave. He once handled a request for ``The Billy Tell Overture'' in Times Square. And through it all, he says, he's kept smiling. ``The enjoyment, the benefit, is when you've finally gotten through, you know you've touched some people,'' said Graseck. ``It's a nice feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: WGerman Chancellor Calls on Poles to Admit Harm Done to Germans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with Die Welt interview, details, minor editing. Picks up 17th, `Kohl said a...
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Thursday called on Poland to acknowledge that it inflicted ``an injustice'' on innocent Germans who came under Polish rule after World War II. Kohl quickly added that there was no obligation to apologize to his country, saying, ``We Germans are not entitled to such words, and even less must we try to balance accounts in one way or another.'' But he indicated such a gesture would be appreciated in his speech at a dinner with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The occasion in this English university town marked the 40th anniversary of the Koenigswinter Conference, set up to foster Anglo-German relations five years after the Allied defeat of Nazi Germany. Kohl recalled that one of Vaclav Havel's first acts as president of Czechoslovakia was to express his country's remorse at the expulsion and persecution of its German population after the war. He suggested Poland could follow Havel's example. Mrs. Thatcher declared in her own speech that German unification should not weaken security and said U.S. and British troops and NATO nuclear missiles must remain in a united Germany. She also unveiled a plan to turn a 35-nation East-West summit this year into a newly enlarged alliance of democracies across Europe. In the aftermath of World War II, about 13 million Germans were expelled from prewar German territories that now are part of Poland and Czechoslovakia. Germany also became divided into Communist East and capitalist West Germany, but with the reforms that swept Eastern Europe last fall also came the present drive toward German unification. Kohl said Thursday that he had ``time and again ... recalled the untold suffering inflicted on the Polish people by Germans'' during the Nazi occupation of Poland. But, departing from his prepared text, Kohl toned down his remarks to refrain from directly accusing Poland of mistreating Germans. The prepared text said: ``It would no doubt be beneficial for the relationship between our two people if Poland were to refer with equally clear and noble words, as President Vaclav Havel did for Czechoslovakia, to the injustice committed by Poles against innocent Germans.'' When he spoke, Kohl noted that Havel had mentioned ``the injustice that was also inflicted on innocent Germans,'' and said ``it would be good'' if such words ``were also possible now between German and Polish people.'' He said ``such a word, such a gesture, would point the way to a future in which the relationship between the Polish and German peoples is marked by a spirit of good-neighborliness in a common Europe.'' The West German newspaper Die Welt quoted Kohl in its Friday edition as suggesting in an interview that Poland show ``understanding'' to the millions of Germans forced to leave land _ now Polish _ after the war. His comments were seen in West Germany as suggesting a new effort to keep the exiles and their offspring on his side with federal elections coming up Dec. 2. ``We know that horrible things happened in Poland in the name of the Germans. We should never forget that,'' the paper quoted Kohl as saying. ``But it is also completely true that at the end of the war a nightmare was created for innocent Germans through flight and expulsion. A word of remembrance, of understanding, and of reconcilation sent to those Germans concerned would be a good deed.'' According to Die Welt, Kohl added, ``Naturally, I know we cannot make such a demand.'' One-third of Poland was German territory before the war, and Kohl indicated in his Cambridge speech that he was not making a Polish apology a condition of honoring his pledge to respect Poland's borders. Kohl said a united Germany will enshrine Polish borders in ``an internationally binding treaty'' with Poland after German unification. He finally made a forthright pledge last month about Poland's borders after months in which his position on the issue appeared equivocal, upset Poland and worried officials in other European countries, particularly Britain. Kohl said the West German government and the new democratically elected East German government should both quickly issue identical declarations reaffirming the inviolability of the Polish borders. ``This declaration should unequivocally express the idea that immediately after unification of the two German states the all-German government and Parliament will definitively settle the border question along these lines in an internationally binding treaty with the Republic of Poland,'' he said. Days before Kohl's arrival in London, the Polish issue became a source of friction when the Hamburg magazine Der Spiegel said Mrs. Thatcher claimed Kohl was still saying he did not recognize Poland's western border. A Kohl spokesman denied it, saying the prime minister misinterpreted Kohl's comments. A Thatcher spokesman would say only that Der Spiegel accurately reported the interview with her. Mrs. Thatcher suggested Thursday that the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe should stipulate conditions for free elections, hold formal meetings of foreign ministers twice yearly and call emergency sessions in times of crisis. The summit is expected to take place this fall. She also said every nation should guarantee private property and private enterprise. The conference consists of the United States, Canada and all the nations of Europe except Albania. The prime minister said her proposals would stress that West Germany's defense remains with the 16-nation NATO alliance. ``We cannot push aside history, it would be absurd to try to do so,'' she said. ``We must try to learn the lessons of past peace settlements. The Americans must not go home, nor must Britain retreat from the Continent.'' Her stipulations on NATO troops and nuclear missiles remaining in a united Germany could make waves for the six-nation group overseeing the external aspects of German unification. The group, the so-called ``two-plus-four,'' consists of the two Germanys and the victorious World War II allies, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. Their agreement is to go before the CSCE summit. Kohl also said a united Germany must remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``Secession from NATO must not be the price for German unity,'' he said at the dinner.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Legalize Home Confiscations
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly, still dominated by Sandinistas, late Thursday legalized the confiscation of thousands of houses during a decade of leftist rule, including the luxurious residences of party leaders. Property ownership has been one of the touchiest aspects of the transition talks between the outgoing Sandinistas and the United National Opposition, which won February elections. The Sandinistas have armed thousands of people and urged them to ``defend conquests of the revolution.'' The conservative, pro-business UNO includes many victims of the confiscations among its supporters. Thursday's move by the assembly also lets party organizations keep the confiscated homes and buildings they occupy. ``When the Sandinistas were in power, they said they wouldn't own property, that everything belonged to the state and they would leave as poor as they came,'' complained opposition deputy Carlos Cuadra of the Marxist Leninist Popular Action Movement. The law is expected to benefit about 10,000 people who live in homes confiscated between the victory of the revolution on July 19, 1979, and the Feb. 25 election. UNO leader Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is to take over the presidency from Daniel Ortega on April 25. The legislation provides some compensation, guaranteed by the Finance Ministry, to former owners on a sliding scale with 20 years to pay. However, Cuadra lambasted the compensation as absurdly low. ``For $2,000, a top Sandinista ends up in a home worth $50,000 or $100,000 or more,'' he told reporters. He said the law amounts to ``institutionalizing the spoils of war.'' The law says it is intended to ``contribute to social order, national reconciliation and the tranquillity of Nicaraguan hearths.'' A transition accord between UNO and the Sandinistas said the new government will respect the property rights of people who obtained confiscated homes. The Sandinistas have pushed through several measures in the final weeks of their term, including an amnesty for party members as well as the U.S.-backed Contra rebels they fought.

Hoping to defuse weeks of tension with Moscow, Lithuania's president has told citizens of the Baltic republic not to resist if Soviet troops tried to confiscate their weapons. A deadline set by the Kremlin passed Wednesday without incident in the republic, which has been at odds with Moscow since it independence March 11. Both sides showed restraint Wednesday, with Lithuania also shelving plans for border guards and the Soviet army refraining from seizing more Lithuanian buildings or rounding up more military deserters in the republic. ``At present, establishing border points would be stepping up confrontation,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told a news conference in the capital of Vilnius.

Cancer cells have been killed in the test tube by sabotaging their genetic machinery, an early step in what could someday become a new form of therapy, a researcher says. Scientists used a molecule that latched onto a key substance in cancer cells, preventing a crucial gene from relaying its orders to the cells. The research is among early work in the so-called ``anti-sense'' strategy that seeks to block the effect of particular genes in cancer cells. The new results were described Wednesday, at an American Cancer Society science writers seminar, by Dr. John Reed of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

President Bush's nominee for top savings and loan regulator is getting a chilly reception from Democratic senators who question his experience and ethics. T. Timothy Ryan Jr., 44, a former senior Labor Department official, parried mostly hostile questions from the Senate Banking Committee during a 4{-hour confirmation hearing Wednesday. Now a private attorney specializing in pension and employee benefit law, Ryan has no direct experience in banking or savings and loans. Nevertheless, Ryan replied, ``Absolutely,'' when senators asked if he was fully qualified to direct the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which supervises 2,600 thrift institutions. Ryan said he was an experienced manager of large organizations, citing his 1981-83 tenure as solicitor of the Labor Department where he managed 600 attorneys working in Washington and 16 field offices.

Horst Bauernsachs looks at the blackened, prewar factory buildings where outdated Trabant cars are built and says, ``It can only get better.'' ``I may well wind up unemployed for a time, but that's not the end of the world,'' says the 47-year-old forklift driver, one of 11,500 workers at the plant. ``I'll just have to look around. We won't starve.'' Optimism prevails at the Sachsenring plant. Even though many of its workers are likely to lose their jobs, they are looking forward to the promise of Western-style prosperity once Germany is united in a free-market economy. Volkswagen, West Germany's largest car maker, has signed a nearly $3 billion deal to build models for the Western market at the plant, which dates back to 1904 and uses virtually no automation.

Another new Nixon emerges from Richard Nixon's new book _ at 77, a man at peace with himself who says that despite the ordeals and crises ``I can look back and say that the day has indeed been splendid.'' Nixon still has the media to kick around _ ``too often they shoot first and literally ask questions later,'' he says, adding that Watergate ``has elevated Peeping Tom journalism and character assassination to a new level of respectability.'' Still, instead of an enemies list, Nixon prints a list of his friends among journalists and says, ``I could not possibly have gone as far as I did in the political arena without having the benefit of some balanced as well as negative coverage.'' ``In the Arena,'' his seventh book since leaving the presidency, is his most personal. ``In the end what matters is that you have always lived life to the hilt,'' he writes. ``I have won some great victories and suffered some devastating defeats. But win or lose, I feel fortunate to have come to that time in life when I can finally enjoy what my Quaker grandmother would have called `peace at the center.'''

DOC.HEAD: Turkish System Stops Trafficking, but Farmers Unhappy
By EMEL ANIL
DOC.TEXT: Anti-narcotics inspectors now supervise cultivation of opium poppies, which have grown on the dusty Anatolian plain for 5,000 years. That pleases narcotics police, but farmers say they're losing money. In 1971, poppy production was halted by a military-controlled government under pressure from the United States to cut the supply of opium to heroin traffickers. Cultivation resumed in 1974, after civilian rule was restored, with controls intended to restrict production to pharmaceutical use. U.S. and Turkish narcotics police praise the system, which they say is smuggle-proof. A small army of inspectors makes sure the crop is used exclusively for medical purposes and does not make its way to traffickers. Farmers do not share the official pleasure. They say the program costs them money. ``In the old days, we could marry off two sons in one season with the earnings from our poppy fields,'' said Halil Altimtas, headman of Ozburnu village in Bolvadin township. ``Now the bride prices are up, but the price for poppies remains too low.'' Just as the current U.S. battle against cocaine focuses on South American coca leaves, Turkish poppies were the target of an anti-heroin campaign in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The United States claimed at least half the heroin reaching its territory originated in the poppy fields spread across seven provinces of central Turkey. Most problems encountered since the new system took effect in 1974 have to do with production and pricing. U.S. narcotics officials say no heroin from the Turkish poppy crop has been discovered on the illicit market. One important reason is that farmers must use the ``poppy straw'' harvesting method. Instead of slitting the tangerine-sized pods to let opium gum ooze out, the method used for heroin, they let the pods dry in the fields. Morphine derivatives, used as painkillers, can be extracted from dried poppies only in a sophisticated alkaloids plant. Turkey spent $90 million to build the world's largest and most advanced alkaloids factory 150 miles southwest of Ankara, the capital, in the heart of the poppy-growing region. Over a decade, while the factory was being built, the government paid another $15 million to farmers, whose poppies it was legally obligated to buy. About 76,000 tons of unprocessed pods piled up in storage because it was difficult to export something of such light weight and great bulk. That kept the factory going at full capacity for four years. Low official prices for the poppy pods discouraged cultivation and the plant was in full production by 1986. The Turkish Alkaloids Board captured more than half the U.S. market and 40 percent of the world market for morphine and codeine, and earned about $10 million a year. The good times did not last. The plant has been idle since December for lack of pods to process. Last year's pod crop was only 3,000 tons because of autumn drought, winter frost and the unwillingness of farmers to grow poppies for the equivalent of 14 cents for a kilogram _ 2.2 pounds _ of dried pods. India is the only other legal producer of poppies on a large scale, but Australia recently entered the market. The United States supports the control efforts of India and Turkey with a pledge to buy 80 percent of its needs from them. Demand for morphine and its derivatives is not flexible and averages about 200 tons a year. Competition is fierce and the price has dropped to about $180 a kilogram. It was $800 when Turkey drew the plans for its factory. The government tripled its price for pods this year to encourage growers, but Attila Yildirim, manager of the akaloids plant, said paying too much could put Turkey at a competitive disadvantage. Farmers and officials agree the poppy is the most suitable cash crop for the sandy soil of the arid Anatolian plain. Yildirim and officials of the State Soil Products Office are proud of their security arrangements. About 600 inspectors, aided by reconnaissance planes, keep track of the fields to prevent unlicensed cultivation or slitting of pods for opium gum. Morphine is stored behind steel doors at the alkaloids plant. Armored trucks with military and police excorts carry the products to cargo planes. ``This place is better protected and less accesible to outsiders than most military bases,'' Yildirim said.

DOC.HEAD: Decades of Rapid Population Growth Causes Problems for Mongolia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Most Mongolians use only one name
DOC.TEXT: The government says having many children is a woman's patriotic duty, but decades of large families have overloaded the school system and created a serious unemployment threat. In the 1950s, the communist government set out to increase the population of Mongolia's 930,000 square miles by offering money and special privileges to couples with more than four children. ``In other countries ... the population policy is to keep it at the same level or to keep it low, but Mongolia is different,'' Navch, head of the government demography department, said in an interview. ``We have a small population,'' she said. ``That's why we have such a policy,'' Mongolia's population was 649,300 when it became independent in 1921. It experienced a baby boom in the 1960s and 1970s and the birthrate peaked in 1963 at 43 per thousand people, well over the 1980-1985 world averge of 27.7 births per thousand. By 1989, government incentives combined with better living conditions and health care had raised the population to 2.09 million. Yanjinsuren, a 46-year-old herdswoman who lives outside Ulan Bator, the capital, has 10 children ranging in age from 28 to 2. ``I like babies,'' she said. ``I think it's lucky to have many children. I'm a working woman, but still, the Mongolian family and Mongolian traditions are the most important thing.'' Mothers with more than four children receive $133 to $1,033 annually for each child under 16, depending on the child's age and the total number of children. Those with more than five children get a medal and the title ``mother of the second degree,'' and a woman with eight or more children is a ``mother of the first degree.'' The records say 92,600 women received medals and titles in 1988. Encouraging large families had unforeseen results. Nursery schools can accommodate only one child in six and kindergartens only one in three, the Communist Party newspaper Unen reported. Three shifts operate at some schools in Ulan Bator, where one-fourth of all Mongolians live, the paper said, and only 21 percent of the nation's doctors are pediatricians. Unemployment is a major potential problem. About 50 percent of Mongolians are under age 18 and will create a glut when they enter the labor market unless the economy grows more rapidly. ``Now our policy is not just increasing the population, but also to raise the quality of the population,'' said Gerel, head of the population bureau. ``We have to look at the labor force and balance everything.'' A new health law that took effect in January gives women the right to decide how many children they will have, and when. It makes abortions free to all and lengthens maternity leave from nine months to two years. Abortions previously were restricted to women over 35 with four or more children. Many younger women balk at raising large families and feel they can show their patriotism in other ways. Navch, 35, has a 12-year-old daughter and a son of 9. She does not intend to have more. ``That's enough,'' she said. ``After 35, it's too old.'' A recent survey found that 57 percent of women questioned thought four was the ideal number of children. Last year, the average number of children per woman of child-bearing age was 4.8, down from seven 20 years ago. Baasay, 44, a herdswoman with eight children, said a married daughter told her recently she wanted only two. ``Two is okay,'' Baasay said. ``The times are different, the family is different. Young women don't want many children.''

DOC.HEAD: Familiar Faces In Two New Shows, Including Carol Burnett
DOC.TEXT: This has been a season in which many new shows gave bush league a bad name. But miracles do occur, like CBS' ``Bagdad Cafe,'' premiering tonight, and a Saturday preview of NBC's ``Carol & Co.'' CBS' show, a situation comedy, co-stars Whoopi Goldberg and Jean Stapleton. NBC's effort, which will get a regular Saturday slot, is anthology comedy, a series of different shows performed by Carol Burnett and a talented troupe. Each debut episode is excellent in its own way, particularly ``Carol & Co.,'' which has the different kind of look and feel a network needs to battle the diverse wares offered by the ever-growing cable TV monster. ``Bagdad Cafe,'' adapted from the 1988 movie of the same name, is by no means revolutionary. But it is unique in that it's from the same network that this year has given you ``Sydney,'' ``Normal Life,'' ``City,'' and ``His & Hers,'' all examples of how not to commit comedy. ``Bagdad'' shows how to do it right _ not with a string of feeble one-liners, but with believeable characters, a fine cast and the awareness that the best humor often has the edge of sadness to it. At the show's start, Stapleton, the sweetly dense Mrs. Archie Bunker of ``All In the Family,'' becoes somewhat of a middle-aged waif when she can take no more of her husband's verbal abuse and walks out on him. A small problem. She's in the middle of California's Mojave Desert when she walks. Their car has broken down. But in time, she wearily trudges into Goldberg's dingy, rundown cafe and motel, located somewhere between desolation and hard times. In future episodes, she'll start working there, even though tonight's episode indicates the place should be called Cafe Woe. Goldberg's philandering husband (Cleavon Little), caught while attempting adultery, walks out on her. Her teen-aged daughter (Monica Calhoun), takes up with a greasy-haired biker whose idea of speech is to grunt. There are problems, too, for her grown son (Scott Lawrence), a decent guy and the father of a baby girl. His wife has run off, leaving him to tend the tyke and help his mother. All this might be fodder for a situation tragedy. Instead, it's a forum for gentle humor _ even with Goldberg's explosive style _ and compassion, both neatly illustrated when Stapleton notices that Goldberg has been crying. Goldberg nods. ``I've been peeling a husband,'' she explains. These and other scenes are well-sketched and well-played, with nice little off-beat touches here and there _ like the son playing classical music on an ancient upright piano in the cafe or the lecherous old cowboy who introduces himself to Stapleton thusly: ``My name is Rudy. I'm from Hollywood.'' Written by Mort Lachman and Sy Rosen, this is the kind of show that's both interesting and easy to like. So is the debut Saturday of Carol Burnett as an NBC regular after her long, successful stay at CBS as the star of an hour series famed for its comedy sketches. In ``Carol & Co.,'' which starts with a chap giving her roses and saying, deadpan, ``Welcome back, Nancy,'' she greets the studio audience and explains the premise of the evening's story. In tonight's case, she is a perfect, loving wife who discovers that her overbearing husband, Paul (Richard Kind), is cheating on her for the third time. She decides to have him bumped off after a neighbor, a young widow, explains that's what she did, as did another new widow down the block. The idea is to make it look like an accident. With that established, Darrel Campbell's script proceeds toward daft doom, namely a Murder Inc. operation lurking in the phone book as Hit Parade Parties. The company offers a wide range of fatal services, among them Midnight Grenade and A Floozy With An Uzi. ``I just don't know,'' Burnett sighs to the salesman who comes calling. ``Paul is so hard to shop for.'' It gets sillier, yet each plot twist is turned with precision and generally acted straight, which makes things funnier than if the players were called on to ham it up a bit or even mug. The players working with Burnett are first-rate. In addition to Kind, they are Terry Kiser, Meagan Fay, Anita Barone and Jeremy Piven. Alas, NBC's press release on the show specifies only the role Kind plays. On the bright side, ``Burnett & Co.'' definitely will be on NBC on coming Saturday nights. True, that isn't the best of all nights. It's when the fewest viewers watch network programs, generally speaking. But those who do tune in for Burnett's return to weekly TV will find a well-written, solidly professional show. As the trombonist said when he missed his bus, I rest my case. __ Elsewhere in television ... HO-HO HISTORICAL NOTE: ``60 Minutes'' may have Andy Rooney, The Beleagured Humorist. But humor of a different kind _ reruns and new stuff _ is afoot Sunday from cable TV's ``HA! The TV Comedy Network.'' The newcomer will start at 7 p.m. EDT, which by sheer coincidence is when CBS' durable news show begins. The first ``HA!'' offering is a ``Saturday Night Live'' repeat featuring Eddie Murphy. The night's only first-run show is ``The Big Room,'' featuring Mort Sahl. ``HA!'' will bring to two the number of 24-hour chuckles channels in cable, the other being The Comedy Channel begun last fall. Whether there's room enough for two has yet to be decided by viewers and cable system operators.

DOC.HEAD: World Events Prompt Curriculum Changes at Military Colleges
DOC.TEXT: Sweeping changes in the world political order and localized conflicts such as Panama and the Persian Gulf are prompting swift, wholesale revision of the lessons being taught at America's advanced military colleges. At the Naval War College, the nation's oldest such institution, officials say 98 of the 145 readings assigned to students last fall no longer are on the list for the third trimester that began this month. ``That's just one measure of the changes that are taking place,'' said William E. Turcotte, a former naval officer who heads the school's National Security Decision Making Department and is a key planner of its curriculum. As the morning fog rolls in from Narragansett Bay, the 360 students at the NWC are focusing their attention on ``contingencies'' _ military scenarios involving U.S. forces in a role far more constricted, and less predictable, than the NATO-Warsaw Pact showdown that has been the basis of military doctrine for 40 years. Increasingly, say officials of the college, their curriculum and war gaming will stress urban warfare, terrorism and ``low intensity'' crises in which the United States' interests are ambiguous and its capacity to act is affected by special political or geographical factors. Students also will be asked to consider monetary costs, a factor the officials say has not figured significantly in classroom discussions before. The cost of military operations is one of many questions that must be examined in a new light, Turcotte said. ``This year will be especially traumatic for the students, but it's also a great time for the students, a very dynamic period in which they will be as close to the problems as the major policy advisers, the Congress and the press,' he said. Turcotte also said that for the school's faculty experts, the supposed end of the Cold War is doing much more than simply altering their lesson plans. ``Never have we spent so much time trying to learn for ourselves what's happening,'' he said. ``But it is the most exciting time that I've ever been in the classroom here.'' The Naval War College, founded in 1884 in this picturesque seaport famed as a summer resort of the superrich, is one of a half-dozen colleges run by the Defense Department to provide advanced schooling in military and political subjects for career officers, government officials and other selected individuals, including military officers from other countries. While each school is mainly concerned with the mission of one branch of the armed forces, the Pentagon's policy of ``jointness'' in military affairs means faculty and students are drawn from all services. Thus a typical NWC seminar of 15 to 20 students might be led by a civilian or an Army officer, and include officers from the Navy, Army, Air Force, Marines and Coast Guard. Turcotte, who has taught at the NWC since 1974, said curriculum changes reflecting political upheavals in the Soviet bloc actually began last summer, and the first trimester ended just as the Berlin Wall was starting to crumble in November. In place of the Cold War doctrines spawned by four decades of tension between the two superpowers, the revised program will concentrate on the types of crises that might now arise and how U.S. strategy and forces should be designed to deal with them. ``In any contingency we are most likely to have the preponderant force, but the objectives are confusing,'' said Turcotte. ``We will win, but the nature of how we win and what we leave behind is complex. There are a lot of dark alleys in contingencies.'' Among new issues to be examined, he said, are such questions as whether smaller countries, freed from superpower influence, become less stable and more aggressive toward their neighbors, and whether the United States can or should continue to press Japan and Germany to spend more on self-defense as Washington cuts its military costs and the two Germanys draw closer together. The Persian Gulf, where the Navy conducted a major operation in 1987-88 to safeguard commercial shipping endangered by the Iraq-Iran war, offers an important case study: a regional conflict in which the United States is not directly involved, but has crucial interests to protect. Another model for the classroom was provided by the Bush administration's invasion of Panama, which NWC officials said raised not only political issues but moral and practical questions about the conduct of urban warfare in which civilian lives are at risk. They also cite the proliferation of missiles and other modern technology, possibly even nuclear weapons, among smaller nations, the question of whether U.S. military forces should be used in drug interdiction, and the lack of an effective policy on terrorism and hostage-taking. Turcotte said the changes in Europe have led NATO to extend its presumed warning time for a Soviet attack from several days to six months, but might also increase the relative importance of strategic nuclear forces, which remain in place, and Moscow's internal security forces.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-AP Arts: Disney's World
DUELING FANTASY WORLDS: Mickey vs. King Kong
Hollywood Comes to Florida in Challenge to Disney Film Park
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: From King Kong's banana breath to E.T. From Jaws to the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. Universal Studios is arriving in Orlando like gangbusters to compete with the oldest established entertainment show in town. The $600 million Universal Studios Florida, based on some of Hollywood's great movies, goes public in May, exactly a year after the Disney-MGM Studios theme park opened for business a few miles down the road. ``Come to Universal and ride the movies,'' says Steven Spielberg, the bearded movie genius acting as creative consultant for the 440-acre attraction. Company executives speak in terms of waging war against Walt Disney World for the hearts, minds and pocketbooks of the millions of tourists who will be dividing their attention between the competing studio theme parks. ``I think they're very vulnerable,'' says Jay Stein, an MCA vice president, about the Disney-MGM Studios. ``It IS a little like war. It means that when you invade you make damn sure that your army is big enough and strong enough to win.'' The Florida attraction is a bigger, modernized version of Universal's studio tour in California and is owned jointly by MCA Inc. and the Rank Organization of London. Stein is president of the division that created and built the park, MCA Recreation Services. Company officials say the key differences between their park and Disney's is Universal's more sophisticated technology and its ``full-fledged involvement of the customer'' in each of the 15 attractions. They speak of ``super-realistic technology'' providing ``wrap-around experiences'' for young and old. In a blunt attack on the competition, Stein said in a recent interview that ``what the Disney-MGM Studios are offering their guests is approximately one-third of what we're offering. ... Across the board, we're going to deliver a more impressive entertainment experience.'' Stein acknowledged, however, that the Disney organization was ``a strong, well-financed company with a marketing potential that is intimidating at worst.'' Because of that, he said, Universal ``needs to create and deliver an entertainment experience that is so different and superior that we can assure ourselves that we're going to capture enough segments of the market to make this thing profitable.'' Stein and MCA President Sid Sheinberg have for years disputed Disney Chairman Michael Eisner's claims that the Disney-MGM Studios theme park is the realization of Walt Disney's ideas from 50 years ago. Stein and Sheinberg contend that Disney copied the concept from Universal's Studio Tour, which has been in operation in the Hollywood area since 1964, and that Eisner rushed into construction to beat Universal into Florida. Eisner and other Disney officials usually soft-pedal the criticism and the rivalry, insisting that the competition is good for each other as well as Florida. Besides the theme park attractions, Universal Studios Florida has the largest movie and television production area outside Hollywood. It has three times the amount of sound-stage space that Disney has. Production has been under way since 1988. Scheduled to go before the cameras this year, studio executives say, are 13 feature films and 500 television episodes. The back lot tour includes 50 locations, including famed Hollywood Boulevard, a New England Village, the San Francisco Wharf and New York's Penn Station. There are 40 restaurants and snack shops, including Schwab's Drug Store, the Studio Commissary and Mel's Diner from ``American Graffiti.'' Also a part of the complex will be the first Hard Rock Cafe in Florida. With Universal's long tradition of blending public participation and filmmaking, the Florida park encourages superlatives: _ ``Kongfrontation'' pits a skyway tram containing 50 people against the 37-foot tall, computer-animated gorilla in what is billed as the largest sound stage in the world. King Kong will be so real that visitors will be able to smell his banana breath. The six-story King Kong building has 50 facades modeled after midtown Manhattan. _ In ``Jaws,'' a 24-foot-long, computerized shark weighing three tons crunches its jaws onto a 40-passenger boat on 7-acre Amity Bay, rocking the craft in both directions before the shark is ``killed.'' _ A subway train carrying 200 guests into a San Francisco station is buffetted by an ``earthquake,'' a re-creation of the 1906 San Francisco temblor that measured 8.3 on the Richter scale. Trains crash into each other, the overhead roadway comes tumbling down and 60,000 gallons of water flood the scene. _ ``Ghostbusters'' is a re-creation of the largest set ever built on a Hollywood sound stage: eight-stories high. The action is a special effects thriller, with 13 larger-than-life mechanical ghosts getting zapped by Neutrana Wand beams until their ectoplasmic energy explodes. _ Spielberg's pet project, ``E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial,'' is a soaring, obstacle-filled adventure on a dirt bike. It starts with a chase through a forest and takes the visitor all the way to E.T.'s home, the Green Planet. The movie-themed rides and participatory attractions include a high-speed chase inside the world of Hanna-Barbera cartoons, a ``Phantom of the Opera'' horror make-up show and visitor input into Alfred Hitchcock's stylized thrillers. And so it goes, one ``funtastic'' happening after another in the park that officials say will take visitors two days to cover fully. Universal plans a ``soft opening'' in early May. The official grand opening is June 7, with Spielberg and a collection of Hollywood stars presiding. Spielberg, who dreamed up ``E.T.,'' ``Jaws'' and other film fantasies, calls his job as creative consultant a storyteller's dream come true. ``We've made the movie experience something that fans can see, feel, touch and smell,'' he says. The park's most ambitious undertaking, ``Back to the Future,'' will not be ready for the park's opening. It will have two adjacent theaters, each measuring 80 feet in diameter, and use projected images along with complex motion simulators topped with Delorean automobiles. Visitors will ride 12 of the cars in each dome as they go crashing through the centuries with the mad scientist Doc Brown. Because of the complex technology, it is taking longer to build than originally contemplated, said its inventor, Peter Alexander, vice president of shows and rides for MCA's Recreational Services Group. ``It's probably the most responsive and complex motion simulator ever built,'' said Alexander. Nickelodeon, the TV network for kids, celebrated its 10th birthday in March by beginning construction of a new home at the Orlando park. The Nickelodeon production complex will consist of two sound stages and an interactive entertainment area for children. It will produce shows here throughout the year, and visitors to the park will be able to audition for shows as well as to view production, video, audio and control room operations. Universal expects to draw at least 5 million people in its first year, and Stein and other officials say those who see will become ``instant converts'' passing the word on to others. ``We're going to be the new kid on the block, and people are going to give us a try,'' he said. ``And we're going to deliver.''

For Release Sunday April 1 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Struggle To Find Common Voice
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Democrats used to dine out on the old Will Rogers wisecrack: ``I belong to no organized party _ I am a Democrat.'' The joke doesn't fit these days. Democrats are organizing all over the place, choosing up sides and lining up in factions and caucuses. But they can't get together on policy or on spokesmen to carry it to the voters. Their congressional majorities seem immobilized more often by intramural disputes than Republican opposition. Theirs always has been a fractious coalition; that's what Rogers was joking about. But they usually found ways to glue it together at campaign time. Sometimes they kept warring; then they lost. What's happening now is not so dramatic or clearly defined as the old battles over civil rights or the escalation of America's involvement in the war in Vietnam. In confrontations like those, Democrats acknowledged their unyielding differences on one point, bargained over them, then quietly collaborated on other matters. Their differences now are more mundane, and the handling is more businesslike. That won't necessarily make them easier to bridge. The situation is a mirror image of the one Republicans faced 25 years ago, out of power, lacking a pulpit and a spokesman. They dealt with it by creating the awkwardly-named, soon-to-be-forgotten Republican Coordinating Committee, a panel of party leaders convened periodically to issue policy pronouncements. The better-known voices of the GOP came from Congress, in regular joint appearances by Sen. Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois, the minority leader, and his House counterparts. That became the Ev and Jerry Show, when Rep. Gerald R. Ford of Michigan was the House leader. It featured a Senate showman and a House straight man. Congress is short on showmen these days. The Democrats' leaders, Sen. George J. Mitchell of Maine and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, tend to business, work together, but usually speak separately. They tried a joint appearance before the television cameras late last year, but it didn't click. Ev and Jerry had one clear advantage over George and Tom. The speaker and the majority leader have to make Congress run. Minority leaders don't. But in a divided government, Congress is the Democratic branch, and could become the platform for opposition initiatives and rebuttals to President Bush. So far, that's been done as a series of solos, with no clear message or voice. That tendency was underlined last weekend by conflicting schedules that put the Democratic National Committee in Indianapolis at the same time the Democratic Leadership Council was holding a conference in New Orleans. The national committee is dominated by state party leaders; the leadership council is an organization set up five years ago by moderate and conservative Democrats seeking to pull the party toward the center. After three months of congressional hedging, the national committee endorsed Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's bill to cut Social Security taxes, so as to bar government use of surpluses they produce to offset deficit spending on current programs. ``The Democratic National Committee can do exactly what it wants,'' said Rep. Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. ``They are not in the Congress and they don't have the responsibility to actually produce a budget.'' So much for consensus on what would seem a popular, salable Democratic proposition: cutting a payroll tax. The Moynihan measure used to make the White House nervous because the Democrats could have used it to force Bush into vetoing an election-year tax cut. That prospect has faded. Organized into their rival caucuses and umbrella groups, sometimes with competing agendas, the Democrats show no sign of progress toward finding their voice. Gephardt insists that they are the ones coming up with ideas for national leadership, even if the message is not coming through that way. In the familiar lament of the party out of White House power, he said that is because the president is the dominant player, the only leader who can push a program to national acceptance and block congressional moves with vetoes that one-third minorities in either house can sustain. ``He has a pen in his pocket that's worth two-thirds of us,'' Gephardt said.

DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.
