DOC.HEAD: Littlest Pushers _ Felony Narcotics Charges on Rise Against Children
An AP Extra
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The cops raced up the subway station stairs, looking for two men who'd robbed a passenger at knife point. They wheeled into the park and almost bumped into a girl holding out a plastic bag of crack. ``Her jaw dropped,'' said Officer William Smith. ``And my jaw dropped.'' She was just a child, all baby face and wide eyes. Then she opened her mouth. ``She called us every name you can think of,'' Smith said. Jeanette, at 12, was carrying a beeper and 20 vials of crack. Twelve days before Christmas, in the middle of Herald Square, she became one of three dozen boys and girls her age arrested last year on felony narcotics charges. Jeanette also was not the first in her family arrested in connection with crack. A year earlier her mother, known on the street as Miss Candy, was arrested at the same spot; police said they found 430 vials of crack inside her brassiere. Now, they say, she has someone else to hold her wares: her kids. Jeanette _ The Associated Press agreed to a judge's request not to divulge her last name in return for access to Family Court hearings _ turned heads in the prosecutor's office. But more and more children are entering the lower levels of the cocaine business as touts, lookouts, runners, holders and dealers. In the first 10 months of 1989, New York City police arrested 1,330 children 15 and younger on felony narcotics charges, a 20 percent increase over 1988 and a 530 percent increase over 1983, when the crack epidemic was just emerging. Nationally, according to the FBI, arrests of children 16 and younger for dealing in cocaine or heroin have risen 900 percent in five years. To a drug dealer, a child can seem the perfect employee: inconspicuous, loyal and _ perhaps their chief attraction _ almost immune. Children are overlooked by officers who can't believe the kid in braids on the corner is a drug courier. If arrested, children go free faster than adults; if convicted, they are less seriously punished. In one crucial sense, children are more reliable: they are less apt than older teens to use crack. The kids are rewarded with danger, long hours and irregular wages. Terry Williams, a sociologist who has studied the crack trade in New York, says big payoffs are a myth; children are attracted, he said, because legitimate opportunities are so limited. The crack kids don't get rich; they just get hard. ``When you read `12 years old' in a newspaper, that sounds young,'' said Officer Thomas McHale, who patrols the area where Jeanette was arrested. ``But these kids are 30-year-olds.'' Jeanette's mother says she was herself a crack addict. She doesn't admit to dealing but says that ``in the world of survival, anything is possible. ... I've had to do a lot of things in my life to make ends meet.'' She is a big woman _ almost 6 feet tall, well over 200 pounds. Her hair is pulled back in a neat bun. In conversation she is articulate, forceful and intelligent. Jeanette is hefty, too. She has smooth chocolate-colored skin, large brown eyes and short, curly brown hair. At a recent court appearance, one tuft protruded from under her knit hat, sticking out over her forehead. Her lawyer, a young public defender, declined requests for an interview with Jeanette, who five weeks ago was found guilty of crack possession and faces confinement to an institution for up to 18 months. Her mother told the family's story. The mother was born 34 years ago in Harlem. Her own mother wasn't around much, so her father placed the kids in foster care. She had her first child when she was 15. A year later she married a man who was not the child's father. They had four children but divorced after he infected her with a venereal disease and she caught him with another woman. Besides Jeanette, her children are Keesha, 18, who has one child and is expecting another; Edward, 16, who has been arrested several times on drug-selling charges; Jalanda, 11, who has stayed out of trouble, and Rasheen, 10, who has one robbery arrest. About five years ago the family was evicted from a Brooklyn housing project for not paying rent. They wound up at the Martinique Hotel, the city's most notorious welfare hotel. Built in 1897, the Martinique was a massive essay in French Renaissance elegance. By the time the family moved in, it fugee camp. Roaches roamed the rooms, pimps, pushers and muggers the hallways. The children of the Martiniwas an urban reque literally played in traffic. Some imitated drug dealers in their games. Some went further. ``Children never recover from an environment like that,'' the mother said. ``My kids sort of went astray. ... Jeanette got in with a bad crowd at the hotel.'' The family was crammed into two rooms. Outside the only place to gather was Greeley Park, a concrete and asphalt triangle in the middle of bustling Herald Square. On Aug. 6, 1988, the mother said, she was sitting on a bench with her boyfriend, handing out bags of potato chips to neighborhood kids. The four officers who arrested and searched her found a black, zippered pouch in her bra, crammed with 430 vials of crack. Despite the amount of crack seizof a hard-line Shiite Moslem cleric who is the leader of pro-Iranian militants holding Western hostages, witnesses said. The witnesses spoke on condition of anonymity for reasons of personal safety. They said Sheik Subhi Tofaili, Secetary-General of Hezbollah, was not hurt in the attack in south Beirut. His car was riddled with bullets, the witnesses said. The motive of the attack was not immediately clear. It was not known if it was related to the 18 Western hostages held in Lebanon. Most of them are believed held by factions linked to Hezbollah and imprisoned in hideouts in the southern slums, Hezbollah's main stronghold. Tofaili's convoy came under fire at 2:50 p.m. as the clergyman was heading for a mosque in the Bourj el-Barajneh shantytown. Witnesses said Tofaili's bodyguards engaged the Syrians in a firefight. Hundreds of people ran for cover as dozens of Hezbollah gunmen took to the streets. The witnesses spoke by telephone from buildings overlooking the scene of the clash. Police confirmed there was shooting for four hours in Bourj el-Barajneh, where a sprawling Palestinian refugee camp is located. They said four civilians were wounded before the gunfire tapered off at nightfall. They did not say who was involved in the fighting. The Syrians have lately tightened a ring around the southern slums to prevent the kidnappers from smuggling the hostages out. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said the Syrians were ``even stopping funeral processions and searching coffins'' in southern districts of the city. The shootout flared hours after Iran's president, Hashemi Rafsanjani, was reported to have sent his brother to Lebanon in a fresh effort to win the hostages' release. Beirut's conservative ad-Diyar daily said Mahmoud Hashemi, whom Rafsanjani has frequently used on sensitive missions, slipped quietly into Lebanon last week for an unannounced visit. The newspaper said Hashemi, a deputy foreign minister in charge of affairs with Lebanon, Syria and other Arab countries, met some Hezbollah leaders before leaving Tuesday. They included Hussein Mousawi, leader of the Islamic Amal movement based in the Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon's Bekaa valley. His group forms Hezbollah's pro-Syrian wing. The hostages include eight Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in Beirut March 16, 1985. Several other hostages have been held almost as long. A spokesman at the Iranian Embassy in Beirut refused comment on the newspaper report. President Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, seeks to improve links with the West. But he is opposed by anti-Western Iranian radicals. In Damascus, the Syrian capital, Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa met Anglican Bishop John Brown on Thursday to discuss efforts to free the hostages. ``I'm concerned about all the hostages, especially Brian Keenan, who's a member of the Church of Ireland,'' Brown said after his 50-minute meeting with Sharaa. Keenan, 39, an English teacher at the American University of Beirut who holds dual British and Irish nationality, marks his fourth year as a hostage April 11. Brown would not make any statements about his talks but said he was optimistic the captives will eventually be freed. Sharaa refused comment. Elsewhere, Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen exchanged artillery fire north of Beirut Thursday, straining a 26-day-old cease-fire. Police said 155mm howitzers, multi-barreled rocket launchers and tank cannon were used in the sporadic exchanges that broke out before dawn and continued through mid-morning. No casualties were reported. The rival Christian forces are fighting for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: Greeley Park.
DOC.TEXT: At a hearing in Family Court, Jeanette admitted she had a bag with crack that night but said it was given her by a neighborhood boy named Sean. ``He didn't say (what was in) the bag. He just asked me to take it to Brooklyn for him.'' The judge who convicted Jeanette described her story as ``incredible.'' Smith says he saw Jeanette near the park about 10 days after her arrest _ at 1:30 in the morning. ``She just smiled at me and said hello. I didn't know what to say.'' The mother blames the Martinique period for Jeanette's run-ins with the law and, notwithstanding the girl's arrest, maintains her daughter has been better behaved since the family moved. She says Jeanette regularly attends junior high school, where she does well in reading but needs work in math. Other than that, she stays home and helps care for the younger children. ``Jeanette loves the house,'' the mother said. ``She doesn't like to jump, to go out. ... She loves singing. She's always wanted to write rap music.'' The mother was standing on the street, next to her boyfriend's car. As she spoke, Jeanette looked on silently, occasionally nodding in agreement. Finally, bored, she slapped a cassette into the car tape deck, closed her eyes and moved to the rhythms of rap. When police are told the mother's story, they laugh. ``She's running the park'' _ controlling crack sales there, said McHale. He said he hadn't seen her at night in several months, but was told she now has youngsters, including some of her own, doing most of the street dealing. The family continues to visit Herald Square, even though they now live almost an hour's subway ride away, even though they complain of police harassment. The mother said they return because they know the shops and the people; Smith says it's because ``they know the neighborhood and the customers. That's their turf.''

For Release Sunday, April 1, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Adirondack Battle: `Millions of Acres for Bugs, Little for People'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is another in a series of stories planned in advance of 20th anniversary observances for Earth Day in April.
With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: For this time of year, it was a deceptively warm day. Tall pines and hemlocks reached for a cloudless sky. Big, thick-coated dogs sprawled along dusty roads. Locals walked to lunch in shirtsleeves. But breaking through the still mountain air was the rhythmic thwack of hammers, the whine of drills, the beep of heavy equipment backing up and the roar of bulldozers. In North Creek these days, modern ``townhouse communities'' seem to sprout from the mountainsides more thickly than wildflowers, and a developer is reshaping two blocks that make up nearly half of the business district in this tiny Adirondack village. This kind of development has environmentalists worried about the future of the Adirondack Park, a 6 million-acre tract of forest and mountains bigger than any other state or national park in the lower 48 states. But it also represents the kind of economic revitalization that some North Creek natives, like restaurant owner Francis Smith, have been waiting for. Smith's Restaurant, a pine-paneled coffee shop and tavern, has been in his family since the early 1920s. ``I'm a businessman, so to me the development is a good thing,'' said Smith, sitting in a worn red vinyl-padded booth. ``On the other hand, there seems to be just too much construction going on. Maybe it's going overboard.'' How much is too much is on the minds of many in the Adirondack Park, a vast patchwork of private and public land, much of the latter guaranteed by the state constitution to remain ``forever wild.'' The state regulates all new development in the park through a 21-year-old land-use plan. Its provisions have made for plenty of strife among those wanting to protect the park's undeniable beauty, those trying to make a living and a home within its boundaries, and those looking to make money exploiting its riches. With the 20th anniversary of Earth Day just three weeks away, the battle over land use in the 98-year-old park has flared in anticipation of a report, to be presented to Gov. Mario Cuomo on Sunday, from the Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century. Cuomo cited increasing property values, development and land speculation last year when he appointed the commission to help map the park's future. In 1969, a similar commission appointed by then-Gov. Nelson Rockefeller devised what was at the time considered a bold plan to control development seen as a threat to the Adirondack wilderness. Of the park's 3.5 million acres of private land, 53 percent was restricted to having just one house for each 43 acres. Home sites of 7{ acres were mandated for an additional 35 percent. The remaining 12 percent of private land fell into six various use categories. The plan slowed development immediately but bred contempt among many local residents, officials and developers. The next several years were a time of angry words, broken windows, slashed tires and punches. Mounds of animal waste were delivered to the Adirondack Park Agency, the state body set up in 1973 to regulate development. Bad feelings are welling again as many Adirondack people anticipate the Cuomo commission will recommend even stricter land use controls. ``When these people were picked (for the commission) we knew their position,'' said Francis Casier, a 71-year-old Saranac Lake builder. ``The state has designated 1.5 million acres as wetlands for grasses and bugs, but only a few thousand acres for human beings,'' he said. ``The highest and best use for our land should be for homes and amenities for people and their families.'' Development would bring jobs and money to a region where ``the quality of life is great, as long as you don't need to spend any money,'' said Barbara Delczeg, who works for the Gore Mountain Region Chamber of Commerce. The per capita income of the 130,000 park residents is just 72 percent of the state average. It's about 94 percent of the average for the state's rural counties. ``We need this growth so much,'' said Delczeg. ``We need the jobs, we need the money. We need it to survive.'' North Creek isn't the only place ringing with the sounds of development and dissent. In Lake Placid, a developer wants to rebuild the Lake Placid Club, a rambling, turn-of-the-century hotel that is on the National Register of Historic Places but has fallen into disrepair. But the development would include hundreds of luxurious second homes and a golf course. ``We're seeing increased development pressure everywhere,'' said Eric Siy of the Adirondack Council, a regional environmental group. ``If we don't act now, we may not have a park by the year 2000.'' The Adirondack Council advocates a two-year building moratorium in much of the park, as well as major additions to the park's wilderness and wild forest areas. They say developers, fearful about the Cuomo commission recommendations, are rushing to build while they still can. Development and subdivision applications submitted to the Adirondack Park Agency will rise by 75 percent, from 631 in 1989 to about 1,100 this year, agency Executive Director Robert Glennon predicts. The commission itself, in an interim newsletter, gave a strong indication that tighter controls might be in the cards. ``Controls once seen as daring and stringent are now considered weak and ineffective,'' the newsletter said. ``Environmental policies and laws once heralded as being on the cutting edge of environmental protection now seem outdated.'' George Davis, executive director of the Cuomo commission, helped create the current Adirondack land-use map while working for the Rockefeller commission. Davis said the original plan failed to foresee that wealthy city dwellers in the 1990s would be able to afford ``little mini-wildernesses'' _ 50-acre building lots for second homes that fit the land-use restrictions. Like Davis, Casier has noted the impact of rich second-home owners. ``People come in from the city and they want their little piece (of the Adirondacks),'' said the developer. ``The minute they get their little piece, they don't want anyone else to have a little piece.'' But he regards George Davis as ``an enemy of Adirondack people.'' The lot-size limitations have made it almost impossible to build affordable housing in the region, Casier said. To keep things affordable and save jobs, some environmentalists are concentrating less on halting development and more on persuading officials to expand the state easement acquisition program. Under this, the state buys development and recreation rights to a parcel of land, but the property owner keeps title and can use the land for timber production. The easements, cheaper than buying the land outright, also give the state more for its money, said Neil Woodworth of the Adirondack Mountain Club. And, he noted, even when loggers are finished with the land, the state will control the development rights. ``A lot of the land we need to preserve, to protect from development, is also land critical to the forest products industry and provides an awful lot of jobs,'' Woodworth said. ``So (preservationists) can't just buy it all up.''

DOC.HEAD: Family Behind Robins Company Out of the Business Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT spelling of Robitussin, PICKS UP 2nd graf, ``Today, A.H. ...''; longer version moving on financial wires
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It once was known as the Fortune 500 drugmaker that soothed millions of throats with Robitussin cough syrup, coated dried lips with Chap Stick balm and gave generously to charities and higher education. Today, A.H. Robins still makes those products and other remedies, but it's owned by another company after a long bout with bankruptcy court. To many women, its name now is more synonymous with cruel stinginess, all tied to one of the most notorious products ever sold, the Dalkon Shield birth control device. The family that formerly ran the company still has considerable wealth but keeps a low profile, partly because of the furor over the Dalkon Shield. The device, which maimed thousands of women in one of the nation's worst product liability cases, is no longer sold. As the leading family member said when he surrendered the company late last year, ``Some of the unhappiest people I've known are people who have a lot of money.'' The surrender was one of the most traumatic moments in the life of E. Claiborne Robins, a millionaire whose grandfather, Albert Hartley Robins, founded the company as a three-employee apothecary shop. E. Claiborne Robins took over the business in 1933, parlaying it through hard work into one of the largest U.S. pharmaceutical companies. As the business prospered, Robins and his relatives became known for their philanthropy, with gifts to the University of Richmond. Its graduates include Robins, 79, and his son, E. Claiborne Robins Jr., 46. The senior Robins and other members have donated millions of dollars to the university, including $50 million in 1969 that at the time was the largest personal gift ever made to a private U.S. college. Women seeking payment for Dalkon Shield injuries have a different view of the Robins' largesse. Many argue that despite immense public and legal pressure, the company erected obstacle after obstacle to prevent them from receiving compensation. Earlier this month, 85,000 Dalkon Shield claimants, the last of the 200,000 eligible for redress, were mailed packets explaining options for receiving payment for injuries. Some had used the device more than 15 years ago. ``They made it very difficult for the women they injured to get compensation,'' said Linda Hightower, director of the Dalkon Shield Victims Association in Atlanta and herself a former Dalkon Shield user. In the users' eyes, Robins never has provided a simple, direct public apology, not to mention a sympathetic attitude toward compensation. E. Claiborne Robins has said he doesn't consider money important and that any amount above what's needed to live comfortably ``means nothing really.'' Yet money, or the lack of it, has shaped his life. Two years after Robins was born in 1910, his father died, leaving to his mother the responsibility of holding together the family business founded in 1878. Robins worked his way through the University of Richmond by stacking books at the city library for 25 cents an hour. He graduated at the height of the Depression in 1931 and enrolled in pharmacy school at the Medical College of Virginia, where he graduated with honors in 1933. ``It was a case of financial necessity,'' he once said of attending summer school to finish pharmacy college early. Later Robins borrowed $2,000 to take over the family business and went on the road selling pharmaceuticals. His work and salesmanship turned the company into a multimillion-dollar enterprise by the time the Dalkon Shield was added to Robins' product line in 1971. Before long, however, the corporation began hearing complaints from doctors and women who used the IUD. Some users suffered miscarriages; some became sterile. A few died. As concerns multiplied about the Dalkon Shield's safety, the company yanked it off the market. That same year _ 1974 _ Robins began to have health problems, suffering two heart attacks. He stepped down the next year as president of the company, but stayed on as board chairman. Both Robins and his son, who became the company's president in 1977, have refused numerous requests for interviews in recent years as they watched a wave of lawsuits seeking damages from Dalkon Shield injuries tear at the foundation of their business. In 1985, the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Last Dec. 15, the case ended, a $2.5 billion trust fund was established to compensate Dalkon Shield claimants and A.H. Robins was taken over by the American Home Products Corp. of New York. Neither Robins has a role in the business anymore. Still, they emerged from the 4{ years of bankruptcy proceedings with their personal fortunes intact. Forbes magazine has reckoned the family holdings are worth $325 million. Lawyers for Dalkon Shield users long have charged that the IUD was rushed to market without adequate testing and that attempts were made to mask its flaws. A federal judge once accused E.C. Jr. and two other company executives of creating ``monstrous mischief'' with ``an instrument of death, mutilation and disease.'' ``You have taken the bottom line as your guiding beacon and the low road as your route,'' U.S. District Judge Miles Lord of Minneapolis said. ``This is corporate irresponsibility at its meanest.'' The Robinses and their aides never were charged with criminal negligence in the Dalkon Shield case, and the younger Robins said later that Lord had committed ``gross abuse of judicial discretion and power.'' Friends of the family are reluctant to talk about the father and son, but some say privately that they were more distressed at losing the company than at the high price of the Dalkon Shield settlement. The men said in a joint farewell letter to employees that they would remember ``shared times both difficult and rewarding. We have been tested, and the results achieved in spite of those difficult times are witness to what good people can accomplish.'' The troubled history of the Dalkon Shield has affected what the elder Robins once called the most satisfying accomplishments of his career. ``One has been the joy of watching the company grow,'' he said. ``And there's the fact that you've made some contribution to public health.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctor: Education, Helmets Will Cut Down on Head Injuries in Children
With BC-Head Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A doctor's recommendation that a young patient wear a helmet while skateboarding or bicycling brought a familiar rebuke. ``The mother was appalled by that recommendation,'' said Stephanie Rifkinson-Mann, a pediatric neurosurgeon at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. ``She said wearing a helmet was socially unacceptable among her son's friends because of the peer pressure.'' Rifkinson-Mann already was treating the boy for a head injury, which would have been prevented if he'd worn a helmet in the first place, she said. More parents might consider Rifkinson-Mann's recommendation. Trauma, including head injury, is among the leading causes of death in children under 14, said Samuel Kasoff, neurosurgeon at Westchester County Medical Center. Many head injuries, such as ones suffered in school bus accidents, could be avoided if the proper precautions are taken, Rifkinson-Mann said. ``School buses don't often load children up appropriately,'' she said. ``Usually they're two-by-two. In some cases they put them three together. The kid in the middle is the least protected.'' Making a child wear a helmet for some recreationl activities is another way to prevent head injuries. Good-quality helmets can be lightweight and not hamper movement, Rifkinson-Mann said. Rifkinson-Mann also would like to see better safety education for children in schools. She suggests using a symbol children are comfortable with, such as Big Bird, to educate youngsters on accident prevention. Parents need education, too, she said. But it often takes a tragedy to make people aware of the high incidence of head injury to children, she said. ``It's the gory part that piques people's interest,'' she said. ``Cancer is a generalized fear we all have. The only way to make people know head injury is to be equally feared is to get the image of how absolutely crippling it can be, especially to a young child.''

DOC.HEAD: Big-Ticket Science Items Threaten to Crowd Out Smaller Grants
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: From the newly initiated quest to send people to Mars to the decades-old search for a cure for cancer, the government's science programs are a source of technological breakthroughs and national pride. Federal spending on science is far from the largest or fastest-growing part of the budget, but it is a favorite target for budget-cutters. This is the first in a series of articles this year that will track the progress of one portion of the federal budget _ science spending.

When the White House's chief science adviser visited the Senate Budget Committee recently, he spent much of his time responding to a single, recurring complaint. The panel's chairman, Rep. James Sasser of Tennessee, said costly projects such as the space station, $30 billion over several years, short-change other researchers and science students in favor of ``a high-visibility, high-media type operation.'' The adviser, D. Allan Bromley, countered that the expensive projects will benefit thousands of scientists and ``make possible scientific understanding of the world, of our universe.'' The dispute was left unresolved. But it sums up a growing concern in today's era of relentless federal deficits: that a burgeoning array of big-ticket science programs threatens to crowd out a much larger number of less expensive but valuable efforts. As part of his proposed $1.2 trillion budget for next year, President Bush wants to spend $68 billion on research and development, or R&D _ the studies and experimentation that are at the core of science. Billions more, spread throughout the budget and not totaled, would be spent for scientific work that has progressed beyond the R&D stage, such as the space shuttle. More than $4 billion would be devoted to five science projects alone: the space station, a study of climatic change, missions to the moon and Mars, a giant atom smasher called the superconducting super collider, and a study of human genes. ``Investment in research and development is a top priority for an administration that believes in investing in the future,'' Bush's budget request said. But with congressional work on the fiscal 1991 budget just beginning, Sasser and many of his colleagues are questioning whether the government can afford long-term costly initiatives that threaten to become more expensive each year. ``Exploring and uncovering the mysteries of the universe stirs us all,'' Sasser said. ``But I am afraid we are looking at the stars right now from a rather deep fiscal hole.'' Federal spending on science is not large relative to the rest of the budget. For example, the military will take close to $300 billion this year. Nor are federal science expenditures growing at an alarming rate, compared to other accounts. Adjusted for inflation, they are barely larger than in the late 1960s. Medicaid spending, meanwhile, is expected to grow by 15 percent, to $40 billion, this year alone. But the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law is forcing Congress and the White House to find new sources of savings every year, making science vulnerable. Large parts of the budget such as Social Security are too politically sensitive to be cut dramatically. Nor can the $176 billion in this year's interest payments on the national debt be cut without causing the government to default. Despite pressure to reduce deficits, many people argue that the United States can't afford to eliminate large-scale science programs. Supporters make the same arguments that were heard in 1957 after the Soviets launched their Sputnik satellite: The United States must remain at the forefront of technology, and not just for economic reasons. ``This country had a goal and a dream when we went to the moon. What this country is looking for now is goals and dreams,'' said Robert Roe, D-N.J., chairman of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee. ``One thing this country still has is an advantage in its science and technology base,'' says Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences. ``From that point of view, the total investment in science is justifiable.'' But others worry about the trade-offs. ``Science is an unmet need, but it's competing against housing, education, the human side of the ledger,'' says House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Still others complain that too many science spending decisions are made by politicians interested primarily in jobs and other economic rewards for their home districts. ``It's like everything else; people are getting re-elected by delivering the bacon,'' says former Sen. William Proxmire, D-Wis., who until 1989 chaired the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that oversees NASA spending. Congressional support for science is widespread, and rarely breaks down along party lines. But to generalize, it has stronger backing from conservatives than from liberals, who from time to time try to shift some science spending into social programs. As with many areas of the budget, support for specific projects tends to be strongest from those whose congressional committees oversee the programs or whose districts will benefit from them. Hence, Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, one of Congress' most fervent advocates of spending cuts, strongly supports the costly super collider because it is to be built in his state. Many who question federal support for expensive science programs say they soak up money that would be better spent for small projects that involve basic science. That work, often conducted by individual researchers, involves a search for basic knowledge regardless of its potential application. For example, they note that this year, for the first time in a decade, the number of research awards by the National Institutes of Health will fall below 5,000. Money also is scarce because of the way the government spends its research and development money. Of the 1990 $64 billion total, only $24 billion will be for civilian projects. Nearly two-thirds _ $40 billion _ will go to military work, largely weapons testing with little or no application to the rest of the economy. Adding pressure are the peculiarities of the federal budget process, which pits programs against each other. The budget committees will make recommendations for spending levels that are politically influential but not legally binding. The appropriations committees make the final decisions. Their subcommittees have jurisdiction over seemingly random groupings of programs. It is at that level that dollars are distributed among competing demands. Rep. Robert Traxler, D-Mich., chairs the appropriations subcommittee that oversees NASA, the National Science Foundation, housing, veterans and environmental programs. ``What am I supposed to do for science?'' he asked. ``Take money from the homeless?''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Science Spending Barely Above 1960s Level
With BC-Science Budget
DOC.TEXT: Jockeying for federal science dollars is intensifying as demands increase, but the money available remains roughly constant. When inflation is considered, the government spends barely more for research and development today than it did at the height of the Apollo moon program in the late 1960s. Adding to the competition is the sheer number of participants involved in distribution and pursuit of science funding: dozens of congressional committees and federal agencies, thousands of private companies and institutions, and an estimated 5.3 million American scientists and engineers. When World War II ended, the government was spending less than $1 billion annually on research and development, most of it for atomic weapons work. Spending grew slowly until the Soviets orbited the Sputnik satellite in 1957, provoking concern about the competitiveness of American science and sparking the growth of the U.S. space program. As a result, government science spending grew well into the 1960s, leveling off during the Vietnam War. Dollar amounts increased with the energy crisis of the late 1970s and President Reagan's defense buildup of the 1980s, but spending adjusted for inflation changed little. President Bush is proposing $68 billion in science spending for the next fiscal year, up about $4 billion from this year. Translated into 1982 dollars to even out the effects of inflation, the government will spend the equivalent of $48.2 billion this year for research and development _ barely more than the $46 billion it spent in 1967. But nearly two-thirds of the spending goes for military research, mainly on weapons, making the competition for civilian research and development money even more intense. Again using 1982 dollars, the government will spend $18.1 billion on civilian research and development in 1990 _ less than the $22.4 billion spent in 1966. Today, 26 House and Senate committees are involved in science policy and spending. Ninety-six federal agencies and agency subdivisions play a role in research and development, according to the National Science Foundation. But just five agencies spend 95 percent of the money: the Pentagon, the Department of Health and Human Services, the Energy Department, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and the National Science Foundation, which distributes grants and keeps track of federal science efforts. In 1988, 15 agencies accounted for more than 99 percent of federal academic support for science. They distributed money to 2,769 universities and colleges, 46 offices of academic systems such as state university headquarters, and 717 non-profit, independent institutions such as hospitals. To conduct its own scientific work, ranging from the study of AIDS to development of high-speed trains, the government employs 218,000 scientists and engineers, according to the science foundation. Some work at the more than 700 national laboratories the government either operates directly or pays other institutions to run. On the large end of the scale are the 8,400 employees at the Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., and Livermore, Calif. At the other extreme are the 16 workers at the Kodiak National Laboratory in Kodiak, Alaska, where shellfish are studied. In his proposed 1991 budget, President Bush is pressing for annual installments for a number of major scientific initiatives that will take years to complete. Six of the biggest, and their projected overall costs, are: _A $3 billion effort to map human genes in an effort to treat genetic diseases and advance agriculture, medicine and other fields. _The $8 billion super collider, a circular atom-smasher that will measure 54 miles around, about to be built in Texas. It will be the world's most expensive scientific instrument. _The so-called mission to planet Earth, involving NASA and other agencies, to study global change at a cost of at least $20 billion over 20 years. _The $30 billion space station, scheduled for construction in the mid-1990s. _A return by astronauts to the moon in the 1990s and a manned mission to Mars early in the next century, which NASA says could cost $541 billion. _The aerospace plane, considered part of the moon-Mars effort but which could be developed independently. It would take off and land like a conventional airplane yet reach speeds above 4,000 mph. If approved, construction of two aircraft would begin in 1993, take four to five years and cost more than $5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Soviet-U.S. Project Studies How Injuries Heal in Space
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: U.S. scientists are examining bits of leg muscle removed from high-flying rats as part of a joint NASA-Soviet experiment to determine how injured astronauts would heal in a weightless environment. ``Our hypotheses go everywhere from disaster to normal healing,'' said William Stauber, a physiologist at West Virginia University Medical Center and one of two scientists conducting the study. ``A disaster would be if the muscle healed but you got cancer or just useless cells growing that wasted away,'' said Stauber. ``My guess is the answer is somewhere in between.'' Soviet researchers used forceps to crush the calf muscles of 10 specially bred rats from Czechoslavakia before placing them aboard a Vostok spacecraft for nearly two weeks last September. ``The bruise was similar to something a batter would get if he was hit by a pitched baseball at home plate,'' Stauber said. ``They tried to make it equivalent to a real-world situation.'' Within hours of the landing, researchers removed the rats' calf muscles and froze them. Once in the United States, the muscle samples were shipped to Stauber and Barry Festoff, a neurologist at the Veteran's Administration Hospital in Kansas City, Mo. Festoff and Stauber are analyzing slides containing the red and white tissue to trace the healing and regrowth of the rats' muscle cells and nerve fibers. ``We're taking a look at the muscles themselves to see if they are any different from the rats who suffered the same injury but healed on Earth,'' Stauber said. He and Festoff brought Soviet officials up to date on their research recently at a meeting at NASA's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif. ``Long-term space flight may cause deconditioning of the cardio-vascular, musculoskeletal, blood and immune systems,'' A.S. Kaplansky, who oversees the program for the Soviets, said through an interpreter. ``It is of crucial importance to clarify mechanisms underlying the changes and to develop effective countermeasures.'' The study is expected to be completed this fall. The results will be reviewed by Soviet scientists before the findings are published. ``Our very preliminary data would seem to indicate that repair after the crushing did not take place in the flight animals,'' said Festoff. Stauber said researchers also hope to gain a better understanding of how the human body reacts to heavy work in outer space _ a critical consideration in light of a planned U.S. space station. ``I think there is a fair amount of knowledge of what happens to man if you're out there floating around for a long time, but we really don't know what happens when you start doing hard physical labor in space,'' Stauber said. Stauber said there may be ``occupational hazards that we don't know about.'' It has been known for years that astronauts' muscles atrophy during space flights, even relatively short ones. And overuse injuries caused by working in a weightless environment are another concern, Stauber said. ``Behavior is going to be very different when we start working in space,'' he said. ``Legs will become perching devices used to push off and other light work while the upper body will be used more.'' The project is part of a long-standing agreement between the two superpowers to collaborate on space research. ``It goes back to 1973 and the Nixon administration,'' said Richard Grindeland, bio-specimen program manager for the Cosmos program at Ames. ``We have collaborated on seven space flights since 1975 using everything from guppies to monkeys,'' Grindeland said. ``It's been an extremely good relationship, regardless of what the political climate has been.'' The experiments have included studies on the effect of space on the brain, immunity, red blood cells, and the endocrine, reproductive and digestive systems. The Soviets are committed to participating in an American space flight slated for 1991, and the United States is scheduled to take part in a Soviet flight in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Inventor Working on Garbage Shredder
DOC.TEXT: Russ Eide says the centrifuge machine he built to mash garbage encompasses two basic scientific facts _ winds in a tornado can drive straw through a board and paper is sharp enough to cut skin. Challeged with a dare, the 51-year-old inventor, who grew up remodeling worn-out farm equipment, designed the Dynaforce garbage processor, a $220,000 centrifuge that may help communities looking to conserve landfill space. The machine is slightly larger than a pair of telephone booths and uses the cutting edges of garbage itself to shred waste and reduce its bulk by up to 80 percent. ``It is like a big washing machine,'' said Eide, owner of Light Work Inc., based in Minneapolis. Eide, a former mechanic and a one-time auto parts store owner, has worked on the LW 421 for six years, investing most of his life savings. ``It can revolutionize the handling of a lot of things,'' said Eide, his 6-foot-4, 250-pound frame circling his invention at the Ashland landfill where it is being tested. A marketing company is hoping to soon sell 130 units to Toronto, Canada, Eide said. Some cities in Ohio are looking at the machine. Ashland is leasing one and allowing Eide to do more testing on it. Henry Simon, Ashland's director of public works, believes that coupled with the city's mandatory recycling program, the processor could prolong the life of the town's landfill from 7.5 years to 50 years. A market exists for the machine if Eide can develop conveyors for moving the garbage in and out of the machine and a way to detect heavy metals before they get dumped, Simon said. ``If he can deal with those two items, the machine is golden,'' he said. Sant Arora, a mechanical engineering professor at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, and some of his students spent several weeks studying Eide's invention and his theories about garbage disposal. Arora said the machine's design is ``similar to old rock crushers,'' a concept that hasn't been widely applied for shredding garbage. Eide's basic theory is right, but more testing is needed, Arora said. Bob Ham, a professor of civil and environmental engineering at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, said he had no knowledge about Eide's invention, but the concept was developed by a British company years ago. ``Unfortunately in (the garbage-handling) business, there are a lot of new companies that keep reinventing the wheel,'' Ham said. But Eide is undaunted, noting he has applied for two patents and has refused offers for rights to the machine. Dumped into the top of the machine, garbage falls onto a series of 1{-inch thick steel bars that spin at 850 revolutions per minute, creating a tumbling action. ``Things are thrown against the wall. You get that constant impact. If things are flying around in there, they are going to cut things up,'' Eide said. Shredded garbage flies out of the machine, ready to be composted or buried, Eide said. ``Do you smell anything here? A slight musty smell,'' he said, sifting shredded garbage through his hands. ``When it goes through this machine it practically deteriorates it.'' The processor, driven by a 300-horsepower engine, can reduce 22, 55-gallon barrels of aluminum cans into one barrel of what looks like shrapnel, Eide said. ``I did run a mattress in it. It shredded it up. It was gone except for the wire,'' the inventor said. Eide said his idea started out as a dare over drinks. ``Somebody probably said it can't be done. You can't cut without knives,'' he recalled. ``Having cut myself with paper, I knew how sharp it was when you put in the right position.'' Eide and his son built the first processor in the family garage. ``I have sold everything I own to do this,'' the inventor said. ``I even had to get divorced. My wife told me I was crazy. But I believe in it.''
