DOC.HEAD: Water Managers Join Melaleuca Fight
DOC.TEXT: Water managers have joined the fight against the thirsty melaleuca tree, an Australian import that in less than a decade may take over three-quarters of the Everglades. Wiping out the tree will take more than $10 million and as long as 25 years, a task force has concluded, and the Souh Florida Water Management District governing board has provided $75,000 for the first year's work. Introduced in 1906 by a University of Miami forestry professor who saw it as a potential timber source, the melaleuca had no natural enemies. Scientists believe it infests 625 square miles. More than 60 square miles of that _ an area nearly as big as Washington, D.C. _ is solid melaleuca, the report says. The tree overwhelms habitats, disrupts food chains and takes three to six times as much water as sawgrass and other plants. It burns hot and spreads its seeds after fires. It also has a foul odor and may cause respiratory problems. The task force has suggested using chemicals for now and eventually introducing insects that are its natural enemies. But there is concern the bugs could become as much a threat as the trees they kill. The task force concedes the tree will never be eradicated. Its goal is to stop its spread and manage it. The tree thrives in warm climates with infrequent frosts, tolerates a range of soils and water qualities and can grow in flooded and dry areas. The melaleuca is identified by a papery bark and white flowers that look like bottle brushes.
DOC.HEAD: Organization for Fat People Wants Discrimination Protection
DOC.TEXT: A national organization for fat people wants to make discrimination based on size illegal in Minnesota. The National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance recently asked several state senators and state Human Rights Commissioner Stephen Cooper to amend the Minnesota Human Rights Act to protect large people. The act protects against discrimination in housing, employment, education, public accommodations and public services on the basis of race, color, gender, religious beliefs, marital status and age. Fat people, often the target of cruel jokes throughout their lives, need human rights protection, said Sarah Johnson, chairwoman of the group's 20-member North Central chapter, which includes Minnesota, Iowa and western Wisconsin. ``You can get hired into an organization and you can do a very good job, but you will never be put out in front if you're a big person,'' she said. Michigan is the only state in the country which bars discrimination on the basis of size, Johnson said. Cooper said it is probably too late to get an amendment through the present legislative session. He also said the group would need to establish that fat people are losing opportunities for jobs, housing or public services because of their size. ``I am willing to talk to them between now and next session and listen and learn,'' Cooper said.
DOC.HEAD: Use of Battery-Powered Heart Aid Planned
DOC.TEXT: Texas Heart Institute surgeons plan to implant a battery-powered heart assist device in a patient this summer if they get federal approval. If successful, the patient could move freely and perhaps leave the hospital while awaiting a transplant, said Dr. O.H. Frazier, director of the Houston-based institute's cardiovascular surgical research laboratories and heart transplant service. THI and Thermo Cardiosystem Inc. have applied for a Food and Drug Administration exemption that would permit them to use the battery-powered device in patients awaiting transplants. THI and the Massachusetts-based bioengineering company have worked together on heart pumps for several years, and their experts believe the battery-powered device is an important step forward. Currently, such devices are powered by large air-driven pumps, making movement difficult. ``With this newer electrical pump, you do have a wire through the skin, but it's battery controlled,'' said Frazier. The heart assist pump or left ventricular assist device performs most of the pumping function of a normal heart's left ventricle. Many patients can live for months with such a device. The battery-powered pump is vented to the outside through a small tube, Frazier said. The only other part that passes through the skin is the wire that leads to the external battery worn under the patient's arm. Frazier said sending patients home while they await surgery will save tens of thousands of dollars. Those who have sedentary jobs might even be able to go back to work, he said.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for April 2

DOC.TEXT: American General Corp. said it received an unsolicited $6.34 billion cash and stock buyout offer from another insurance and financial services firm, Torchmark Corp. The Birmingham, Ala.-based Torchmark on Wednesday offered to buy about half of American General's 126.7 million outstanding shares of common stock for $50 per share, and would exchange $50 worth of Torchmark common stock for each of the remaining shares. Torchmark said all aspects of the offer were negotiable, including the possibility of an all-cash deal.

The U.S. economy grew a modest 1.1 percent in the last quarter of 1989, better than previously believed, the government said. Analysts predicted the rebound will continue this year, but at its slowest pace since the last recession. The Commerce Department first reported in January that fourth-quarter growth had edged up a barely perceptible 0.5 percent, then revised the rate upward in February to 0.9 percent before issuing its final 1.1 percent estimate Wednesday.

High interest rates and declining consumer confidence somewhat depressed new home sales in February although they bounced back slightly from steep declines the previous two months, according to Commerce Department figures. The department said Wednesday that new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 607,000 units in February after plummeting 6.8 percent in January and a revised 8.0 percent in December.

Procter & Gamble Co. said it will expand the use of recycled plastic in containers for liquid Tide, Cheer and other products to create a new demand for the material and keep it out of landfills. The bottles will be specially marked and will start to appear on supermarket shelves this fall, the company said Wednesday. Procter & Gamble estimates its expanded recycling effort will keep 80 million milk, water and soft drink plastic bottles out of U.S. landfills in its first year.

Import car dealers counterattacked as Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca continued his road show to tout his company's cars as being just as good as Japan's. As Iacocca visited New York on Wednesday on his six-city tour in search of image and market share, the Washington-based American International Automobile Dealers Association accused him of blaming consumers for poor sales of U.S. cars. ``Lee Iacocca became famous for ending his commercials by saying `If you can find a better-built car, buy it.' Now he is complaining because the American consumers have taken his advice,'' said the group's president, Walter E. Huizenga.

Economic activity reached five-year highs during the fourth quarter in 18 of the nation's 24 biggest cities, according to a survey released by the consulting firm Grant Thornton. The quarterly survey Wednesday indicated that, based on an index measuring a number of indicators, San Diego led in economic activity during the final three months of 1989, followed by Minneapolis-St. Paul, Cincinnati, Atlanta and Milwaukee.

Richard Miller, president of Wang Laboratories Inc., was named the company's new chairman and chief executive officer succeeding computer maker founder An Wang, who died of cancer last weekend. The board of directors' action Wednesday was expected by analysts, who noted that Miller already assumed much of the leadership last year when he was named president.

Thomson McKinnon Inc.'s brokerage unit filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection to wind up its liquidation eight months after selling most of its operations. Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. listed $89 million in assets and $139 million in liabilities in its U.S. Bankruptcy Court filing Wednesday that seeks protection from creditors. The firm said the filing was ``long anticipated.''

The sluggish laser video disc market got a shot in the arm with the announcement that a Sony Corp. division has begun making the movie discs in the United States. The new source of discs could ease a bottleneck that has slowed the growth of the technology, which provides higher-quality pictures and sound than videotaped movies. The discs are based on the same distortion-free digital technique as music compact discs. Digital Audio Disc Corp., an Indiana-based subsidiary of the Japanese electronics company, said Wednesday it had begun making the discs at a plant in Terre Haute.

Stock prices drifted aimlessly Wednesday, drawing little inspiration from a stronger-than-expected reading on the state of the economy. The Dow Jones industrials average, down about 10 points at its early low, closed with a 6.75 gain at 2,743.69. The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen. Bond prices finished slightly higher. Cocoa futures prices rocketed to seven-month highs; soybean futures tumbled; copper futures surged; precious metals were mixed; petroleum futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Dumps Riney as Ad Agency, Hires Waring & LaRosa
DOC.TEXT: Hal Riney & Partners created the advertising that said ``It's perfect. It's Perrier.'' But last month, bottles of the sparkling water were recalled because they were contaminated. Now Riney has lost a job. Perrier Group of America Inc., the U.S. importer of Perrier, said it was dropping the San Francisco-based agency after four years of making ads for the Perrier brand, which had been the leading imported water in the United States. The announcement Wednesday was a surprise. Company officials had said earlier this month that Riney was working on a new ad campaign expected to be launched once the brand is restocked in stores, bars and restaurants. The company never announced it was looking for a new agency. ``We strongly feel it is the right time for a totally new strategic and creative thrust for our brand,'' said Kim E. Jeffery, senior vice president for sales and marketing for Perrier Group. Perrier said it had hired Waring & LaRosa Inc., a New York-based firm which preceded Riney as Perrier's ad agency for five years ending in 1986. In its first tour of duty for Perrier, Waring & LaRosa created an ad campaign that described the brand as ``Earth's first soft drink.'' Perrier expects to spend $8 million to $10 million on the new advertising campaign, which is expected to start this summer. At the moment, the importer is using advertising that relies heavily on humor to keep consumers interested while new shipments of Perrier are brought into the United States. It is now expected that the first new bottles, carrying the special mark ``Nouvelle Production,'' will be available on the East Coast in late April or early May and later elsewhere. Calls placed to Riney's offices in San Francisco and New York seeking comment were not returned. Perrier said Riney continues as its agency for four other bottled waters _ Arrowhead, Calistoga, Ozarka and Zephyrhills. Riney was the agency that created the ad characters Frank Bartles and Ed Jaymes for the wine cooler from the Gallo Winery and is also remembered for its lush portrayals of weddings and family celebrations for Gallo wines. Its advertising for Perrier described the unique set of ecological events that resulted in the creation of the spring in Vergeze, France, from which Perrier is drawn. In February, traces of the chemical benzene were discovered in bottles of Perrier in North Carolina. Eventually, Perrier was recalled worldwide. The problem was traced to a dirty filter at the bottling site. Perrier said steps have been taken to prevent recurrence of the contamination. Jeffery said Waring & LaRosa's past association with Perrier provided ``a unique historical perspective and comprehensive understanding'' that was a major factor in Perrier's decision to change ad agencies. The new ads will remind ``consumers of the 1990s how Perrier fits into their changing lifestyles,'' Jeffery said. Joseph LaRosa, chairman and creative director, said Waring & LaRosa got the assignment after ``a series of discussions that evolved over time'' and grew more intensive in the past few weeks. He declined to say what his agency had in mind for the new advertising campaign. LaRosa said the brand can rebound. It had been the biggest selling imported bottled water in the United States and the third best-seller overall with about 5.7 percent of the $2.2 billion U.S. market in 1988. ``It's a terrific product, and should be back to its original status,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board Meets; Deal Seen As More Likely
DOC.TEXT: Directors of the UAL Corp. have met for the second time in a week but aren't saying whether they are any closer to approving a buyout deal for the parent of United Airlines. ``The meeting is over and there is no statement,'' UAL spokesman Robert Doughty said Wednesday night following the latest board session. UAL is the Chicago-based parent of United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier after American Airlines. A group representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants _ nearly two-thirds of UAL's 71,000 employees _ proposed on March 19 a buyout that would give UAL's entire workforce 75 percent ownership of the company. The proposed deal for $150 a share in cash and $25 in debt securities plus non-voting stock would leave 25 percent of UAL in the public's hands. The board is seeking a higher price and also is exploring the possibility of selling some of UAL's assets to make a big payout to shareholders in an effort to bolster its share price. The bid is supported by UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, which is threatening to wage a proxy fight to oust UAL's board at the company's annual shareholders meeting April 26. UAL's board agreed last week to negotiate with the unions but cited ``serious deficiencies'' in their offer, including the price and a lack of financing commitments. The board has been wary of the unions' overtures following the collapse last October of a $6.8 billion attempt led by the pilots and UAL's senior management. The offer failed for lack of financing. UAL's stock closed at $160.87{ Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, down 62{ cents. But the price was well above $153, the closing price on March 21 before the last UAL board meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Top Stock Manager Announces Retirement
DOC.TEXT: For Peter Lynch, retiring as head of the nation's largest stock mutual fund at the young age of 46 was just another step that set him apart from most other money managers. Lynch managed the Magellan mutual fund for Fidelity Investments for 13 years, guiding it through bull markets and the Wall Street crash to establish an unparalleled record of strong growth and performance. On Wednesday, he announced he was cutting short his phenomenally successful career to spend more time with family and community. ``I spent about 21 years with Fidelity,'' Lynch said. ``I'd like to spend 21 years doing something different.'' The Magellan fund has $13 billion in assets today compared with approximately $100 million in 1981, when it became publicly available to investors. Helping draw assets was the fund's performance: $10,000 invested in the fund on May 31, 1977, would have grown to $270,007 on Dec. 31, 1989, according to Fidelity estimates. Lynch also amassed a personal fortune, estimated by Boston Magazine at $25 million, and now wants to spend his days more leisurely with his wife and three children. Lynch noted that his father died of cancer at age 46. ``There's nothing magic about 46,'' he said. ``But you think about those things.'' Lynch, who officially retires May 31, will join the board of trustees for Fidelity, the nation's largest operator of mutual funds. Fidelity Chairman and Chief Executive Edward C. Johnson 3rd issued a statement saying: ``Even if he never invests another dollar, Peter Lynch has won a place of honor in the history of money management.'' During the last five years, when it was the nation's largest common stock fund, Magellan has outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500 by an average of 6 percent annually, the company said. Underpinning Lynch's success was his method of long-term investing in sound companies, rather than trying to outguess the market as a whole _ a strategy he outlined in his best-selling book, ``One Up On Wall Street.'' Despite this success, Lynch said in recent months it was becoming more difficult to find underperforming stocks that can yield big returns, because stock prices have continued their annual growth. Lynch said Magellan now has about 13 percent of its assets in cash, about $1.7 billion, a level company officials say is an all-time high for the fund. ``What you need is a drop in the market or a big recession for big winners,'' he said. But Lynch said he's still finding stocks to invest in and is confident the Magellan fund can continue outperforming the stock market as a whole. ``Fidelity is loaded with talented people,'' he said. ``It's possible Magellan will do better in the next five years with another person.'' Magellan's new portfolio manager will be Morris Smith, 33, currently manager of Fidelity OTC Portfolios. Smith's fund, which focuses on smaller companies listed in the national over-the-counter market, also has performed well. In the five years ended Dec. 31, 1989, the fund had an annualized average return of 25.05 percent, compared with 13.96 percent for all small company growth funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Magellan shareholders will be notified of the changes in the fund's annual report, due to be mailed in May, officials said. Joy Smith, a Fidelity spokeswoman, said the company was not immediately seeing many redemption orders from Magellan investors in the wake of Lynch's announcement.

DOC.HEAD: Thomson McKinnon Files for Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection to hasten its liquidation after failing to find a buyer since the 1987 stock market crash. The 105-year-old firm, once the nation's ninth-largest brokerage, said the filing was ``long anticipated.'' The firm stopped doing business eight months ago after selling most of its operations. Wednesday's filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court freezes pending legal action against the collapsed Wall Street house and places other contentious issues in liquidating the firm under the auspices of a federal judge. Thomson McKinnon listed $89 million in assets and $139 million in liabilities in filing for protection from creditors. Last July, the firm sold its retail brokerage offices and customer accounts to Prudential-Bache Securities Corp. for about $60 million. That deal followed the collapse of a proposed merger of the two firms that would have created one of the largest securities houses on Wall Street. Since then, Thomson McKinnon has sold its seats on the nation's stock and commodity exchanges, but it still needs to liquidate part of its securities portfolio and other assets. ``It became apparent that we were at a point where we could do better if we have the assistance and protection of the bankruptcy court,'' said Donald G. McCabe, Thomson McKinnon general counsel. Brokerage firms generally are not permitted to seek Chapter 11 protection voluntarily. But Thomson McKinnon officials said the filing was allowed because the firm no longer had active accounts and most of its holdings had been liquidated. The firm has been liquidating under the auspices of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Securities Investor Protection Corp. The officials said both agencies endorsed the bankruptcy filing. The securities firm has been reduced to about 100 employees from 4,700 before the Prudential-Bache deal, McCabe said. Thomson McKinnon said it lost $33.7 million in 1987 and $38.5 million in 1988. In addition to stock and bond losses, the company said losses from a real estate investment trust heightened its need for a buyer. The bankruptcy filing names Commonwealth Bank of Australia as its largest unsecured creditor, owed $27.5 million from a subordinated loan. The second largest claim is an $11 million subordinated loan from Hill Samuel Bank of London. The filing also says Thomson McKinnon wants to segregate $22 million in assets for the accounts of former customers. Several class-action lawsuits filed on behalf of former Thomson McKinnon employees recently were consolidated in federal court in New York. They allege broad financial mismanagement, including buying apartments and a yacht with company assets. At least one suit seeks $100 million in damages. Under federal law, all legal action against the brokerage unit is suspended during bankruptcy proceedings. The lawsuits, though, also name the parent company, Thomson McKinnon Inc., and that action can proceed. The parent still is seeking to liquidate all its assets. The company said in a statement that its efforts are focused on attempting to sell its 63 percent interest in its other operating entity, Thomson McKinnon Asset Management LP. That unit, a mutual fund and private account money manager for $6.7 billion in assets, is not affected by the bankruptcy filing. It has operated as a separate entity since a public stock offering in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Slide in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the yen in Tokyo today following dollar selling by Japan's central bank and by profit-takers. Stock prices declined. The dollar ended the day's trading at 156.65 yen, down 1.98 yen from Wednesday's 158.63-yen finish. It opened at 158.30 yen, its high for the day, and fell as low as 156.40 yen. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 237.41 points, or 0.75 percent, ending the day at 31,026.16. The rise in the yen followed the U.S. currency's downturn Wednesday afternoon in New York after intervention by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, dealers said. ``It was about time for the yen to recover after so much dollar-buying,'' said Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a dealer with Daiwa Bank. The dollar has gained 6.87 yen since March 1, when it ended trading at 149.78 yen. ``Considering the recent rise in the dollar, the yen's jump today is significant,'' Kinugasa said. ``But we have to wait for a few more days to see whether this is a sign of a real change in the recent trend.'' He said the dollar continued to weaken during afternoon trading in Tokyo as participants sold the U.S. currency for profit-taking, while the Bank of Japan intervened intermittently. The Bank of Japan was seen selling at least several million dollars in an attempt to support the yen. The total amount was not available immediately, as the bank does not usually comment on its market interventions. Fuji Bank dealer Kenzo Shinomiya said many market players have accumulated large dollar positions over the recent weeks. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said Thursday he hopes exchange rates will come to reflect real economic conditions, Kyodo News Service reported. Kyodo also quoted Hashimoto as saying he intends to urge cooperation among the Group of Seven industrialized nations in currency stability at their meeting scheduled for April 7 in Paris. Analysts have attributed the stock market's recent plunge in part to higher interest rates resulting from the yen's weakness against the dollar. On March 20, the Bank of Japan boosted its official discount rate by one percentage point to 5.25 percent in an attempt to head off inflation and strengthen the yen. Traders attributed the Nikkei's fall today to index-linked selling that triggered sales by other participants. They said the Nikkei index failed to maintain an early upswing because of continuing pessimism in the market. ``Although the yen jumped today, market players are still cautious about currency trends because the yen's strength could be just a temporary movement,'' said Yoshio Shimoyama, a senior trader with Nikko Securities Co. ``Also, individual market players have come to pay more attention to company performance instead of to day-to-day changes in currency and interest rates for their investment criteria,'' he added. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds ended at 86.72 points, up from Wednesday's 86.14. Their yield fell to 7.2 percent from the previous day's close at 7.32 percent.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel More Than Doubles Bush Request for Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Should stand. Consideration of Central America aid begins late afternoon EST; also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A House panel is proposing $719 million in new aid to Eastern European countries overhauling their economies, more than double the amount President Bush is seeking. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., who proposed the enlarged package for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1, said it would help soften the shock as countries such as Poland undertake ``cold-turkey'' switches from centrally planned to market economies. As inefficient state enterprises are shut down and people are thrown out of work, unrest will inevitably result that could threaten the new democratic governments, Solarz told the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``It could create a socially and politically explosive situation,'' he said. ``We need to do more than we've done so far.'' Poland and Hungary are receiving $293 million in U.S. cash aid this year, and the administration has proposed $300 million for Eastern Europe in the new fiscal year. Meantime, the House speeded up the ide the U.S. Supreme Court the context it needs to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Proxy Fights Mean Ad Revenue Windfall for Some Newspapers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS style of The Telegraph in 10th and 24th grafs.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lockheed-Simmons Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Proxy fights could be good news for newspaper advertising managers. About a dozen newspapers shared in an advertising windfall generated by the proxy fight for control of Lockheed Corp. when the combatants decided to plead their cases in full-page ads over the past month. Neither Lockheed, the California-based defense and aerospace concern, nor the group led by Harold Simmons that is trying to put its own slate of nominees on the Lockheed board would estimate Wednesday how much they spent on ads. But it is likely their month-long courtship of Lockheed shareholders cost them several million dollars for advertising. The extra ad revenue has been a welcome, if short-lived, respite from the recent sluggishness in ad spending, especially in financial advertising. More pleasant surprises could be in store if proxy fights replace takeover offers as the weapon of choice in deciding who rules the boardroom. Ads for Lockheed and Simmons showed up in The Wall Street Journal, the New York Times, the Los Angeles Times, San Francisco Chronicle and the Washington Post. In the past 10 days alone, Lockheed and Simmon's group each have purchased eight full page ads in the Journal and four to five each in The New York Times. Both sides also bought ads in papers near sites where Lockheed has plants such as the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News, the Marietta (Ga.) Daily Journal and The Telegraph in Nashua, N.H. ``We are getting some lift, particularly in the last couple of weeks,'' said Roger May, a spokesman for Dow Jones & Co., publisher of The Wall Street Journal. ``If proxy fights are back in vogue, we would be the beneficiaries of it.'' The Journal's overall advertising linage was down 5.1 percent per issue in the first two months of the year, May said. Most of the Lockheed-Simmons proxy fight has been fought in March. The Journal charges $99,384 for a single full-page national ad although companies with regular contracts for ad space pay less, May said. The comparable one-time charge for a page in Barron's is $14,478. The Lockheed fight ``has made a significant impact on our financial advertising linage,'' said spokeswoman Laura Morgan of the Los Angeles Times. She estimated the paper has carried 15 pages of ads related to that battle alone in the past month. The one-time full-page rate is about $50,000. The New York Times ``has seen some increase in business from the proxy fight but not enough to call it a trend,'' said spokeswoman Nancy Nielsen. She said financial advertising linage was up by an unspecified amount at the Times this year, owing mostly to ``strong mutual fund activity.'' The New York Times charges $51,408 for a single national full-page ad in its business section during the week, she said. The Simmons group developed about a dozen ads. One had photos and descriptions of its 14 nominees, another outlined the group's credentials and others featured comments from individual nominees. Sidney Herman, a lawyer for the Simmons group, said it planned to spend $6 million on the proxy fight, including the costs of mailing, proxy solicitation and advertising. Lockheed, based in Calabasas, Calif., said it would spend $8 million on all aspects of the proxy fight, including advertising. The company said it developed at least 10 different ads, including one offering an open letter from its chairman and another in which the Lockheed board advised, ``Don't Risk Your Investment on NL's Promises.'' Both sides said the advertising supplements the message they deliver shareholders by mail, telephone and in person. ``It's just a matter of keeping the message in front of the shareholders,'' said Lockheed spokesman Ron Meder. Jack Von Deck, advertising manager for The Telegraph in New Hampshire, where a Lockheed division plant is located, said the proxy fight generated ``some linage we didn't expect'' but that the increase was short-lived and would not significantly raise profits. He estimated the paper, which charges $1,795 for a one-time full-page ad, got about 10 to 12 pages of ads as a result of the proxy fight. ``It has been helpful and we are glad to get it ... but we are not going to Florida on it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Import Dealers Say Iacocca Blames Problems on Consumers
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca is wrongly blaming consumers for Chrysler's stumbling sales, foreign car dealers say. ``Lee Iacocca became famous for ending his commercials by saying `If you can find a better-built car, buy it,''' said Walter E. Huizenga, president of the American International Automobile Dealers Association. ``Now he is complaining because the American consumers have taken his advice,'' Huizenga said. Iacocca visited New York on Wednesday as part of a six-city campaign to convince buyers his company's cars are as good as Japan's. He launched his tour earlier this month, traveling with an array of 1990 Chrysler models. In addition to touting Chrysler, Iacocca has criticized trade barriers that keep U.S. companies from competing in Japanese markets. ``What we sell in one year in Japan they sell in 46 hours here. This crap has got to stop,'' he said at Wednesday's New York news conference. Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said the company wasn't bashing imports or telling Americans not to buy them. ``What we are saying is Chrysler builds as good a product or better,'' he said. ``What we are doing is speaking out to dispel the myth that U.S. cars are inferior.'' Cars with Japanese nameplates made up 25.8 percent of the U.S. car market last year, up from 21.1 percent in 1982. The combined share of the Big Three domestic automakers _ Chrysler, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. _ slipped from 69.8 percent to 67.5 percent during that period. In 1989, for the first time, the best-selling car had an import nameplate, Honda Accord, although 60 percent of Accords are built in the United States. Chrysler's 1989 domestic sales totaled 917,506 cars. Among the imports, Honda was closest at 389,472. Chrysler's national television advertisements featuring Iacocca contend that Chrysler's quality is as good as Japan's. ``Nobody knows it, and that's going to change,'' he says in the commercials. Huizenga said Wednesday, ``The free market is an excellent barometer of relative automobile quality and the American consumer is an excellent judge of that quality.'' ``They know the quality of imported cars is better _ and they are better,'' he said. ``No amount of complaining is going to change that.'' The import group said Japanese vehicles sold under Chrysler nameplates, such as the Dodge Colt and Ram 50 pickup truck, accounted for 7 percent of Chrysler's 1989 sales. It also said more than half the 400,000 Plymouth and Dodge minivans sold last year had Mitsubishi engines. Huizenga's association represents 9,700 dealers selling Japanese and other imported cars. Among other things, it lobbies for an end to the voluntary import restraints on Japanese automakers, spokesman Paul Donnellan said.

The stock market pulled back a bit today amid uncertainty over the outlook for interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 5.40 to 2,738.29 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 349 up, 563 down and 498 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 19.72 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Interest rates rose modestly in the market for U.S. Treasury bonds this morning. Prices of the longest-term bonds dropped nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.5 percent-8.55 percent range. Analysts said the activity in bonds continued to reflect worries that an apparently budding revival in economic growth might tend to push rates higher in the months ahead. The latest figures from the Commerce Department, issued on Wednesday, showed a slightly stronger pace of business activity than had been previously estimated during the fourth quarter of last year. Losers among the blue chips included Exxon, down [ at 46[; Coca-Cola, down \ at 75|; General Electric, down \ at 64|, and International Paper, down \ at 51|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .18 to 187.59. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off .44 at 360.79. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.75 to 2,743.69. But declining issues slightly outpaced advances on the NYSE, with 700 up, 720 down and 552 unchanged.. Big Board volume totaled 142.30 million shares, against 131.61 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: White House Defends Nominee; Says It Had `Trouble' Finding Candidate
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs White House comments; picks up 4th graf pvs, He told ...
DOC.TEXT: The White House today rejected Democratic criticism of its selection of attorney T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to regulate the savings and loan industry, but acknowledged it ``had a little trouble'' finding a banker who would take the job. At a confirmation hearing, Democrats on the Senate Banking Committee gave a chilly reception to Ryan, questioning his ethics and lack of experience in banking or savings and loans. In response, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``Frankly we've had a little trouble finding people in the banking industry who want to take this job. ``And also, frankly, I think it's not at all certain from the track record from the S&L industry that that's the best place to draw on expertise,'' the press secretary added. ``I think the feeling here is, we need somebody who is a tough enforcer, who knows how to go in there and get things done and clean up this mess and knows how to use the law and use the resources at his command to crack some heads and get things moving,'' Fitzwater said. Ryan, 44, a former senior Labor Department official, now is a private attorney specializing in pension and employee benefit law. He told senators complaining about his lack of relevant experience that he was surprised when Treasury Department officials approached him about the job about four weeks ago. Nevertheless, Ryan replied, ``Absolutely,'' when senators asked if he was fully qualified to direct the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which supervises 2,600 thrift institutions. ``I am not ... an absolute expert on the thrift industry. I can tell you, though, that in the last four weeks, I've spent an enormous amount of time trying to educate myself,'' he said. Ryan said he was an experienced manager of large organizations, citing his 1981-83 tenure as solicitor of the Labor Department where he managed 600 attorneys working in Washington and 16 field offices. Despite their misgivings, senators are under intense pressure to confirm Ryan quickly. President Bush nominated him March 22, hoping to blunt a constitutional challenge that has put its S&L bailout program in limbo. A U.S. District Court judge in Washington ruled last week that the acting director of the thrift office, Salvatore Martoche, and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, lacked the constitutional authority to close failed thrifts because they were never confirmed by the Senate. The Banking Committee could vote on the nomination as soon as its next meeting on April 3, but Chairman Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., said he could not guarantee the outcome. ``Some members have already expressed to me serious reservations about your nomination,'' Riegle told Ryan. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who is not a committee member but attended the hearing, contended that conflicts of interest between the nominee's public and private careers ``raise basic questions about Mr. Ryan's sense of propriety.'' While in government, Ryan helped select former Attorney General William B. Saxbe as independent counsel overseeing the Teamsters union's central States Pension Fund. After Ryan left the department, Saxbe received court permission to join Ryan's law firm, bringing hundreds of thousands of dollars in fees from the pension oversight contract. In 1985, the Labor Department asked Ryan to resign as a member of an advisory council on pension fund issues after it discovered that he was also serving as counsel to a trade group, the Employee Stock Ownership Association of America. Metzenbaum also criticized Ryan for sitting on the council while a client, the Washington Business Group on Health, had an interest in issues before it. And, he said Ryan should not have advised the National Maritime Union of America on a union election that the Labor Department had begun investigating shortly before Ryan left government. In his defense, Ryan said a federal court concluded it was not improper for Saxbe to join his firm. He said he never participated in employee-owned stock matters while working for the advisory council, did not represent the business group on the pension matter that came before the advisory board and never dealt with the Labor Department directly concerning the maritime union. Ryan was strongly dfended by Sen. John Warner, R-Va., who employed him as an aide in his last three campaigns. ``The president, the secretary of the Treasury and to some extent I have been involved in this nomination and we're going to stand by this man,'' Warner said. ``The man's tough. The man's fair. The man's honest.'' Some Democrats also are uneasy about Ryan's record as a Republican activist. He served as an aide or attorney in presidential campaigns for Richard Nixon in 1972, Gerald Ford in 1976 and George Bush in 1988. He was a legal counsel to Ronald Reagan's 1980 transition team. ``I pledge to you this (agency's work) will be done on a fully non-partisan basis,'' Ryan told the committee.

DOC.HEAD: Stockholder Outlines Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: A major shareholder of embattled General Development Corp. has outlined a rescue plan calling for the sale of assets of the scandal-plagued Florida builder. United Capital Corp. filed the restructuring plan Wednesday in response to a letter from the indicted builder saying serious inquiries had been received about buying the Miami-based company, its assets or stock. GDC pleaded guilty to a mail-fraud conspiracy charge March 22 in federal court amid allegations the company priced 10,000 homes well above fair market values and kept buyers from learning the difference. United Capital, a New York-based real estate company that holds 12.6 percent of GDC's common stock, has asked GDC's board to delay any major decisions until its annual meeting May 4 to give stockholders a voice in the company's future. United Capital paid an average of almost $13 a share for GDC stock in 1988. GDU stock was up 50 cents to $4.75 a share in early New York Stock Exchange trading today. The restructuring plan filed by United Capital with the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed selling the company's time-sharing and utility businesses and undeveloped commercial property. The plan also offered short-term operating funds and pledged to complete infrastructure improvements in GDC's planned communities, a big worry for homeowners. GDC acknowledged it ``is experiencing severe financial pressures in large part'' because of the criminal investigation. In a separate SEC filing Tuesday, United Capital called for the ouster of six directors and suggested a replacement slate. GDC responded Wednesday by naming Chesterfield Smith, a senior partner with the Tampa-based law firm of Holland & Knight, to fill one of the vacancies left by the resignation of GDC's top two executives days before the indictment. Smith is a former president of the American Bar Association. ``It's my hope that whatever harmed (GDC's) reputation in the past, my associates and I will correct,'' Smith said. Prosecutors alleged that the 35-year-old GDC, which has developed nine Florida communities, pitched its houses at inflated prices primarily to out-of-state buyers looking for retirement homes.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Rebound Weakly; Grain Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rebounded weakly today from a steep decline in the previous session while grain futures were narrowly mixed in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. The slight recovery in the soybean market after Wednesday's tumble of more than 11 cents a bushel mainly reflected speculative buying, analysts said. But commercial players were said to be inclined to sell soybeans on any significant price increase, keeping a lid on the gains. ``The cash attitude is to let 'em rally, then sell 'em,'' said William Biedermann, director of research for the futures brokerage Allendale Inc. ``We're in a two-sided market.'' Corn and wheat futures were narrowly mixed in cautious trading ahead of Friday's Agriculture Department report on quarterly grain stocks and spring planting intentions. The reports are scheduled for release after the close of trading Friday. The plantings-intentions report is expected to show that farmers plan to sow more corn while cutting back on soybean and spring wheat acreage. In early trading, wheat futures were 2{ cents lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.48} a bushel; corn was unchanged to { cent lower with May at $2.59\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with May at $1.45} a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 3 cents higher with May at $5.89} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .35 cent lower with April at 77.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .27 cent lower with March at 82.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .45 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 52.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .55 cent to .66 cent lower with May at 53.30 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Casino Spells Boom or Bust for Atlantic City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Many say...', with two grafs to UPDATE with Trump getting gaming license today from casino commission. Picks up 4th graf, `Both Trump...'.
DOC.TEXT: The glitter of the casinos that began operating here 12 years ago is fading, and many say a billion-dollar Donald Trump resort could make or break Atlantic City following its debut next week. The unsafe streets, trash-strewn lots and rusting casino projects that surround the city's swank gambling districts suggest the casinos have failed to deliver the financial well-being promised when they began reopening in 1978. Many say the key to the future of the $3 billion business is the Taj Mahal Casino Resort, the third casino to be opened by Trump, who received a one-year gaming license today from the state Casino Control Comission. ``We think it's going to be a tremendous success,'' Trump said today. Both Trump and his competitors hope the novelty and sparkle of the giant casino will widen the city's drawing power. City officials hope more money will be generated to cure its problems. ``The casinos can be very successful,'' Trump said in a telephone interview Monday. ``Atlantic City can still be an entertainment island.'' The Taj Mahal wilwhere we want to keep it for a while.'' The satellite was intended for a geosynchronous orbit 22,300 miles high, from where it would have transmitted three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously for more than 13 years. It was to have eventually replaced two older satellites over the Atlantic. Martin Marietta Corp., which conducted the $272 million launch, has blamed the failure on a faulty design. Officials of Intelsat and Hughes Aircraft Co., which built the satellite, met Tuesday in Washington with NASA representatives to discuss the possibilities of saving the spacecraft. It was the second time the groups had met. Among the possibilities being considered is a space shuttle rescue. ``Things are looking quite positive,'' Trujillo said. ``Obviously, there are a lot of technical issues that have to be dealt with, but we're very heartened by NASA's willingness to explore the possibility with us.'' The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has said a rescue attempt is technically feasible but more talks are needed before any decision would be made.

DOC.HEAD: New Agency the Lucrative Prize in Power Struggle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 3, The battle, with meeting scheduled.
DOC.TEXT: A new agency that controls millions of dollars in federal housing money is the prize in a power struggle pitting top aides to Housing Secretary Jack Kemp against Kemp's handpicked choice to head the panel. Kemp's personal involvement in the fight for control o the Federal Housing Finance Board is unclear, but actions by a top deputy conflict with statements by Kemp and others that the Department of Housing and Urban Development still wants Mary K. Bush to lead the agency. The battle could come to a head today; Kemp summoned Ms. Bush for an afternoon meeting in his office. The board was created as part of the savings and loan bailout legislation. It oversees the 12 Federal Home Loan Banks and is to channel some of their profits into housing programs. The board selects which projects get housing funds _ nearly $80 million in the current fiscal year and roughly $100 million annually within a few years. Seven months after Ms. Bush assumed her duties as acting director, her promised appointment as chairwoman has yet to be made. Nor have appointments of the three other board members been made. Publicly, HUD and Finance Board officials blame the agency's slow start on delays in recruiting candidates and a disagreement over whether board members should serve full time or part time. The effect has been to leave the independent agency _ and the subsidies _ under Kemp's control. The agency has about 100 jobs, including about a dozen with annual salaries in the $100,000 range. About 50 of the staff positions have been filled. ``This place is a lot more important than they thought,'' said one congressional source. ``Now we have a big fight, they are trying to take control and she (Ms. Bush) isn't going along with them.'' According to several agency sources, HUD Undersecretary Alfred DelliBovi is at the center of the effort to guarantee that HUD keeps considerable influence over the Finance Board. DelliBovi, however, denied in an interview that he was trying to discredit Ms. Bush or exert undue influence over her or the agency. DelliBovi has longstanding ties to Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., and is not among Kemp's inner circle. But his efforts have been supported by Scott Reed, one of Kemp's two top aides, according to sources. In Congress, meanwhile, Democrats who pushed for the new infusion of housing money are critical of the delays in naming a board and wary of HUD's motives. At a recent Senate Banking Committee hearing Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., told Kemp he was worried HUD was trying to set agency policies and make major hiring decisions before a board was named. Several attempts to reach Kemp through top aide Mary Brunette this week were unsuccessful; she did not return repeated telephone calls. Ms. Bush, who refused to be interviewed, said in a statement: ``There have been rumors circulating for some time that there are people who would rather see someone else in this position. My loyalties are to Jack Kemp and to the missions of this agency.'' DelliBovi's public statements appear to conflict with comments he made seven weeks ago in an internal HUD memo obtained by The Associated Press. Among them: _DelliBovi told the AP on Friday that Kemp had slashed Ms. Bush's contracting powers after learning earlier in the week of three no-bid contracts she had given to friends. The agency does not have to put contracts out for competitive bids. DelliBovi said HUD officials had been unaware of the contracts, including one to Kemp's former chief of staff, Wendell Gunn, until last week. But DelliBovi's memo, written Feb. 5, refers to ``Wendell'' twice, once in a listing of people paid by the agency. Gunn, in an interview, said he told Kemp of the consulting arrangement ``face to face'' last late year. Gunn wrote an angry letter to DelliBovi this week accusing him of ``media mischief'' that ``sets a dangerous trap for you and, unfortunately, Secretary Kemp.'' _Supporting Kemp's public statements, DelliBovi said in the interview that he and the secretary stood by Ms. Bush for the job despite the concern over the contracts, and dismissed assertions from Capitol Hill sources who said DelliBovi wanted Ms. Bush to leave. But in his memo to six HUD officials, DelliBovi mentioned that ``Wendell'' was hoping to soon end his consulting arrangement. ``If he goes, let's hope he takes Mary with him,'' is how DelliBovi concluded the memo. The struggle is for an agency that at first was treated by the administration as an unwanted orphan of the S&L bailout. Congress made the housing secretary the only permanent member of the board and left control of the agency with Kemp until a full board was named. The White House passed its power to find a chairman to Kemp, who recruited Ms. Bush. HUD has kept a presence at the agency since its inception, at first temporarily assigning Kemp aide Russell Paul to the staff. When Paul returned to HUD full time in February the agency hired an $83,000-a-year consultant, Patrick Pizzella, who according to several HUD and Finance Board sources was appointed over Ms. Bush's objections at DelliBovi's insistence. DelliBovi's memo recounted Pizzella's efforts to get details of the Finance Board's hiring and staff structure. Several sources said Ms. Bush accepted the job with the understanding that she would be nominated a full-time chairwoman, only to be told later that HUD officials had determined all board members should serve part time. That word came, according to HUD sources, after Kemp deputies determined he would have more influence over a part-time board. HUD has persisted in saying the board can be part time despite being repeatedly told by Congress that the positions are full time. Said a Senate aide who helped draft the bill: ``We didn't authorize paying $100,000 a year for part-time people.''

DOC.HEAD: Mobil To Delete References To Bag Degradability
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp., criticized by environmentalists for allegedly misleading advertising, said today it would delete all references to degradability on its Hefty trash bags. Mobil's announcement follows a Federal Trade Commission investigation started earlier this month into charges of deceptive advertising and packaging. The investigation was prompted by environmental claims made by a variety of consumer products _ from trash bags to hair spray _ and criticized by consumer groups as misleading. Mobil Chemical Co., a division of the nation's second-largest oil company' said it would continue to make Hefty trash bags with an ``environmentally safe additive'' which speeds their decomposition when exposed to sunlight, but will delete the references to degradability on the packaging. Mobil spokesman Allen Gray said the company was taking the action in response to confusion regarding the definition of degradability. Environmentalists say the reference to degradability is misleading because the majority of trash bags are not exposed to sunlight long enough to biodegrade but end up in landfills that are rarely exposed to sunlight. ``If left out in Arizona somewhere a bag with the additive can quickly decompose in a couple of months,'' Gray conceded, ``but in a northern climate like Chicago it could take well over a year.'' FTC Chairman Janet Steiger said earlier this month the agency had joined a task force of state attorneys general to determine whether environmental claims made by various products could be substantiated. No specific companies were named by the FTC, but various environmental groups had targeted claims made by various manufacturers as misleading and in many cases false. Mobil Chemical has said its claims that the bags degrade in sunlight have been fully substantiated by tests and that the company never said the bags would be the answer to the country's waste disposal problem. Gray acknowledged that the company began marketing the degradable bags because of competitive pressures. Gray said the phaseout of the labeling is expected to take several months.

DOC.HEAD: Eurotunnel Director Ridley Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Eurotunnel PLC, the Anglo-French consortium building a rail tunnel under the English Channel, said Thursday that Tony Ridley had resigned as a director. Ridley's departure was widely expected after a management reorganization last month that effectively left Ridley without any day-to-day management responsibilities of the company. Seventeen members remain on the board. The executive shake-up last month came during a cost dispute between the consortium and its main contractors. At that time, American John Neerhout, an executive vice president of Bechtel Group Inc. of San Francisco, was brought in as the project's chief executive. Ridley was the project's managing director. Ridley, 56, joined the Eurotunnel board 14 months ago. He previously was head of London's subway system. The consortium is aiming to complete the 31-mile link between Britain and France by 1993 despite the spiraling costs and some delays.

Stocks opened on a cautious note on a weak performance earlier in Tokyo. Investors then spent the morning examining a stream of mixed corporate earnings results. The market drifted lower for the rest of the day. ``These are the features of a typical bear market,'' said a director at a large U.S. brokerage firm. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 12 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,263.0 at the close. Volume amounted to a modest 435.2 million shares, compared with 359.5 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: British Telecom Announces Restructuring, Managing Director To Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Iain'' in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: British Telecommunications PLC on Thursday announced a major restructuring that its chairman said was designed to make Britain's predominant telephone company ``leaner and more supple.'' The restructuring substantially reorganizes the company, but does not involve any major layoffs. However, some managers might be let go after the restructuring is completed in about a year, a spokesman said. British Telecom also said that Managing Director Graeme Odgers would leave the company shortly by mutual agreement. Odgers' departure was not related to the restructuring, said the spokesman, who was not identified in accordance with British practice. But he declined to be more specific. Analysts speculated that Odgers would have preferred more cost-cutting at the company. British Telecom Chairman Iain Vallance is more customer-minded, they said. The analysts said the streamlining was not particularly significant beyond improving customer service. British Telecom still needs cost-cutting, they said. The spokesman said the changes would ``remove substantial barriers and provide a firm foundation'' for cost control. ``A company the size of BT does present a challenge with control,'' he said. British Telecom said it would divide individual and business customer services into two divisions and eliminate the confusion of dealing with 27 service districts. Businesses with operations spread across Britain and multinational corporations will be able to coordinate their various telecommunications needs with a single branch of what will be the Business Communications division, the spokesman said. In addition to the business service and the Personal Communications division, British Telecom said it would gather its special business operations, such as telephone directory information, into a third unit. The company also said it plans to unify its British sales and marketing team under single management, which eventually will absorb the international sales force. ``Our objective is to become a leaner and more supple organization, structured to meet the differing needs of all our customers,'' Vallance said.

DOC.HEAD: Western Europe Looks at Setting Up U.S.-Style Central Bank in 1993
DOC.TEXT: Western Europe should be able to set up an American-style central banking system in 1993, under an accelerated timetable for economic and monetary union, according to a European Community official. Henning Christophersen, vice president of the trading bloc, said in a recent interview that the economic merger of the 12 countries ``is now going to be part of the European architecture.'' ``It is not only an ambition for some governments or for the commission,'' the European Community's executive body, he said. Finance ministers of the Common Market nations plan to meet this weekend in western Ireland to discuss informally their plans for a monetary union that eventually would lead to a single currency in Western Europe. In advance of the meeting, Christophersen said the governments could follow a faster schedule to meet their ambitious goals. The monetary plans are part of the community's campaign to remove trade barriers among the dozen nations by late 1992 and create a single market of some 320 million consumers. The recent political upheavals in Eastern Europe have prompted many to urge a stepped-up pace in efforts to tightly link the nations. Many of the trading partners want West Germany's powerhouse economy firmly anchored in the community. Many of their currencies are tied to the strong German mark and decisions by Germany's inflation-conscious central bank affect their economies as well. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl traveled to Brussels last Friday to reassure trading partners that Germany had no intention of going its own way. The community is considering a three-stage blueprint for economic and monetary union that calls for a European System of Central Banks, dubbed EuroFed, and use of the Ecu _ the European currency unit _ as the common currency. Christophersen said the plan's second stage, marked by the central bank system, could begin as early as Jan. 1, 1993. Last week, he unveiled a proposal drawn up by the community's executive body to establish the new EuroFed institution to coordinate monetary policy among the dozen nations. Each country now has its own central bank to set monetary policy. EuroFed was patterned after the independent central banks of the United States and West Germany. It would be controlled by a council made up of the 12 central bank governors and a smaller group of directors. Directors would be appointed for long terms. The Common Market leaders plan a special conference next December in Italy to make needed revisions in their founding Treaty of Rome for putting the EuroFed system in place. Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand have indicated the talks should end by mid-1991. Once the treaty revisions are drawn up, it will take a year or so for ratification by all nations, said Christophersen. He gave no date for the start of the third stage on monetary union, during which the Ecu would be introduced as the joint currency. But, he said, it would be better for the economic system to move quickly to that phase. The first stage of the monetary plan will go into effect on July 1 when governments coordinate much more closely their economic and monetary policies. Moreover, capital and exchange controls will be abolished so money can move freely among the nations. The plan calls for all currencies to be linked in the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, which keeps their values roughly steady within certain ranges. The currencies of Britain, Portugal and Greece remain outside the linkage. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has resisted entering the pound into the mechanism, has promised to do so but has given no timetable. She has opposed calls for the sweeping monetary changes, arguing that such plans would force countries to give up some of their sovereignty to new institutions. However, a British alternative proposal to make all European currencies legal tender throughout the Common Market has gathered little support.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Airlines Settles Lawsuit Against United
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines has settled a $336 million lawsuit against United Airlines that charged United with unfair competition in the use of its computerized reservation system. The airlines agreed not to disclose the amount of the settlement reached Wednesday. ``I think it's fair to say we're pleased,'' said Continental attorney David Boies. As part of the agreement, Houston-based Continental will drop another suit that alleged Chicago-based United breached its contract with Continental in operating the reservation system between 1980 and 1984, Boies said. ``At this point, both companies have put all differences between them behind them,'' he said. United spokesman Joe Hopkins said the company had no comment on the agreement. The settlement was reached shortly before the beginning of jury deliberations in the 10-week trial of the suit in federal court in Los Angeles. Continental had sought $336 million in damages, claiming United programmed its computer reservation system to unfairly favor United flights over those of competitors, even if a competitors' flight was more convenient for a customer. ``They rearranged the order in which flights appeared on the computer screens,'' Boies said. Last year, American Airlines settled with Continental over similar allegations for a reported $100 million. In the suit, Continental, a division of Texas Air Corp., also accused United of overcharging it and other carriers for the reservation service. United, a UAL Corp. division, last December prevailed in a similiar suit filed in 1984 on behalf of 11 other airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Chairman Promises Concessions to Major Shareholders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with meeting under way and concessions by chairman. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Simmons says ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. Chairman Daniel Tellep, bowing to pressure from major shareholders, promised today at the aerospace company's annual meeting to make major concessions to them in the future. The concessions came at the behest of big pensions funds and other institutional shareholders, many of whom defected to the side of Harold Simmons, the Texas investor who bought 19 percent of Lockheed and wants to oust the company's board and replace it with his nominees. Results of voting at the meeting, held in a vast hangar, won't be known for at least a week. Tellep said he met with 70 institutions during the proxy contest over the past two weeks and he considered this his ``baptism by fire and a highly valuable experience.'' ``We believe in shareholder democracy,'' he said, offering the following concessions to prove it: _If there is significant support, as expected, for a resolution that voting by shareholders be confidential, Lockheed would develop such a procedure. _A provision to opt out of the strict anti-takeover provisions of law in Delaware, where Lockheed is incorporated. Tellep said even if that provision does not pass but there is a ``significant'' minority vote for it, he would recommend that the Lockheed board support an amendment at the next meeting to have Lockheed opt out of those provisions. _A promise to seat up to three shareholder representatives on Lockheed's 15-person board. He earlier offered only one. _An offer to meet regularly with representatives of Simmons' NL Industries Inc. to discuss the future of Lockheed. Simmons says Lockheed, with a recent history of sagging earnings and underestimating costs of developing new programs, must insist on better profits in its non-core businesses or sell them off. The company portrays him as a corporate raider intent on personal profit with no knowledge of how to run Lockheed, the nation's sixth-largest defense contractor with 1989 sales of $9.9 billion. Simmons, who has lost $100 million on his $530 million investment in Lockheed because of a slumping share price, insists he can better focus the company to profit from its core space, missiles and aeronautics businesses. That would pull up the share price for all investors, he claims. Simmons says he has a solid track record of profitably running companies he purchases, like NL Industries Inc., Amalgamated Sugar Co., and Keystone Steel and Wire Co. He maintains he wants to run a leaner, more streamlined Lockheed, not just cash out. Win or lose in today's vote, ``We're in this for the long run,'' insisted J. Landis Martin, president of NL Industries and chief strategist for the Texas investor. Martin said he was particularly optimistic about the prospects for passage of Simmons-supported shareholder rights proposals, including measures to overturn Lockheed's anti-takeover provisions. Denied seats on the board by Tellep, Simmons solicited support for his own slate of directors, including John Tower, former head of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the former chief of naval operations and former member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Tellep and Simmons spent Wednesday the same way they have spent most of the past few weeks: trying to persuade big pension funds and other institutional investors that their strategies would serve the companies best. Historically, few proxy battles have succeeded in unseating directors. However, Harris and other analysts said Simmons has made surprisingly strong inroads into the ranks of the institutional investors, who hold 60 percent of Lockheed's shares. Simmons' chief coup was persuading California's huge public employees' pension fund, known as Calpers, to vote its nearly 1 percent of Lockheed shares for him, Harris said. Calpers has led institutional investors in pressing for more control over companies they own, and its defection was seen as likely to influence other big investors. ``I still think the incumbent will win the proxy fight,'' said Harris. ``But given the indication by Calpers recently, it probably will be closer than I had anticipated.'' He noted that under Simmons' assault, Tellep had made concessions to shareholders, saying he would appoint at least one representative of shareholder groups to the board after today. ``The company is sensitive to some of criticisms Mr. Simmons has made and may pay closer attention to ... return on investment, earnings per share and cash flow,'' Harris said. However, he said that without the speculative interest stirred up by Simmons, Lockheed shares would be selling for less than their $36.87{ closing price Wednesday. ``I believe the shares would be fairly priced in the $30-$32 range.'' Lockheed stock sold for as high as $54.75 a share last year but has fallen along with other defense stocks amid expectations of a steep drop in military spending. Martin characterized Tellep's overtures to shareholders as ``deals cut at the last minute for votes.'' ``We feel very good about the response we're getting from institutions and we're very hopeful about the outcome,'' he said. Asked if he were surprised by the strength of Simmons' challenge, Tellep said early this week: ``I think that he's waged a strong campaign. It will be up to the institutions to decide how strong it is.''

DOC.HEAD: Maurer, Bahrenburg Get New Posts at Hearst
DOC.TEXT: Hearst Corp. announced Thursday that Gilbert Maurer, executive vice president of the corporation and president of its magazine division, had been named chief operating officer of the parent company. Maurer, 61, will retain his title as executive vice president but will give up the post with Hearst Magazines Division, which publishes 15 consumer magazines including Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping, Victoria and Country Living. D. Claeys Bahrenburg, 42, has been named to replace Maurer as president of the magazine division. He had been executive vice president and group publishing director at Hearst Magazines. The appointments were announced by Frank A. Bannack Jr., president and chief executive of Hearst Corp., which also has interests in newspapers, radio and television stations, books, TV programs and cable TV networks. Bennack said Maurer did an outstanding job in his 18 years as an executive at the magazine division, and noted that since Maurer took over as president of the unit in 1976, the group launched or acquired six magazines, circulation grew by more than 8 million copies a month and ad revenues grew more than four times. ``I believe he is eminently qualified to share with me the most important processes of decision making, planning and general management responsibilities for the whole The Hearst Corporation as it is structured at the beginning of this new decade of the '90s,'' Bennack said in a statement. Bahrenburg was named to his current posts at the magazine division in 1987. He joined Hearst Magazines in 1981 as publisher of House Beautiful and became publisher of Cosmpolitan in 1984. Before joining Hearst, he was associate publisher of Rolling Stone for five years and was a sales representative at the Saturday Review and The New York Times.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Gain In Hopes of Bullish USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely reflecting expectations for a bullish government report on spring planting intentions. The Agriculture Department report, scheduled for release after the close of trading Friday, is expected to show that farmers plan to sow more corn than last year while cutting back on soybean and spring wheat acreage. William Biedermann, director of research for the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc., said anticipated demand requirements suggest farmers may have to plant even more corn than the 75.2 million acres projected by market analysts. Last year's corn acreage totaled 72.3 million acres. At the close, wheat futures prices were 1 cent lower to 2\ cents higher with May at $3.52\ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1 cent higher with May at $2.59{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1{ cents higher with May at $1.46\ a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents to 3{ cents higher with May at $5.91 a bushel.
