DOC.HEAD: Weak Car Sales Blamed for Spending Slowdown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `The spread ...,' to CORRECT that savings rate was 5.7 percent, sted 5.7 percent increase. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending narrowed to a 0.4 percent increase in February, the government said Thursday. Analysts blamed weak car sales for the slowdown, and some said buying momentum was building in other areas of the economy. The Commerce Department said personal consumption totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.63 trillion, the smallest increase since a 0.3 percent gain in October. Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, jumped 1 percent in December and January. The January increase was even stronger than the 0.6 percent originally reported. Personal income rose 0.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.64 trillion, after a 0.7 percent increase in January, which was revised down slightly from 0.8 percent first reported. The February income gain matched a 0.9 percent advance November. ``The spread between income and consumption growth in the near term is a negative (for the economy), because consumers have buying power but are not unleashing it,'' said Michael P. Niemira, an economist with the Mitsubishi Bank in New York. ``But over the longer term, building up savings is a positive for future consumption growth,'' he said. The spread contributed to a savings rate of 5.7 percent _ savings as a percent of disposable income _ compared with a 5.3 percent rate in January. The increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, totaled $15.9 billion. Spending on durable goods _ expensive items expected to last more than three years _ dropped $14.6 billion, due in part to weak car sales. ``Autos were still a depressant going into March,'' Niemira said. ``But, on the other hand, department store sales were doing quite well in March. ``There seems to be a momentum that is building in the non-automotive area. Consumer confidence is up'' in recent surveys, he said. Purchases of non-durable goods gained $10.9 billion, while spending on services rose $19.6 billion. ``The February and January increases in personal income were affected by several special factors,'' the department said, including farm subsidies that both raised the February change and lowered the January change. ``A pay raise for federal government employees raised the changes in both months,'' it said. ``The January change was also boosted by cost-of-living adjustments to several transfer payment programs and was lowered by an increase in personal contributions to social insurance.'' Payroll increases were spread through all industry categories, it said. Government payrolls also were up, reflecting the federal pay raise. The report said Americans' incomes after taxes rose 0.9 percent in February, up from 0.8 percent the previous month. The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, jumped $23.5 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate.

DOC.HEAD: West German, Spanish Phone Companies Reach Cooperation Accord
DOC.TEXT: The Spanish and West German telephone companies, Telefonica and Deutsche Bundespost Telekom, signed an agreement Thursday to improve communications links between the two countries. The agreement also includes sharing know-how and setting up joint ventures. It provides for the establishment of digital circuits between the two countries and the linking of electronic mail systems, videotex data banks and toll-free numbers, Telefonica said in a statement. Telefonica said the accord is intended to ease the creation of the European single market among the European Community's 12 member countries, which include Spain and West Germany. The single market is slated to take effect in 1992. The Spanish company said it has signed similar agreements with telecommunications companies in France, Britain, Portugal, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: Smaller Firms Show Signs of Recovering From Crash
DOC.TEXT: As Wall Street's big investment houses rein in their payrolls and egos during a broad consolidation, the nation's regional firms are recovering steadily from the 1987 stock market crash. Profits slumped 28 percent industrywide last year but doubled at the smaller regional firms, which specialize in trading stocks and bonds for individual investors and operate in limited geographic areas. The reasons: regionals didn't expand like the major houses during the heady 1980s, have lower overhead costs and rely on customer service rather than on marketing newfangled investment products. ``Turning the battleship around is always a lot more difficult than turning a speedboat around,'' Raymond ``Chip'' Mason, chairman of Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. in Baltimore, said Thursday. Fourth-quarter performance showed regional superiority: the industry lost $92 million, while regionals made $12.3 million. The overall loss was the first since 1987's fourth quarter, when the stock market crashed. Preliminary figures show that for all of 1989 the industry made $1.8 billion, down 28 percent from $2.5 billion in 1988. Regional income rose to $215 million, but still was the third lowest in the 1980s and far short of the record $546 million in 1986. Since the crash, all forms of business are down, from mergers and securities underwriting, which fueled Wall Street's boom, to stock market activity that regionals rely on for retail brokerage business. But regionals such as Legg Mason; A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis; Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis; and Raymond, James & Associates Inc. in St. Petersburg, Fla. all reported record 1989 earnings. The nation's two biggest securities firms, Merrill Lynch & Co. and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which have huge retail networks, both had disappointing years. Together they have laid off more than 5,000 employees in recent months. Shearson recently closed 50 retail offices. ``The bigger firms wanted to become financial supermarkets and I think they're backing away from that now,'' said Carter Jones, executive vice president of Boettcher & Co., a Denver-based brokerage. ``We don't seem to be facing the same trauma financially.'' Disgust with Wall Street engendered by publicity about turmoil at Shearson, the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and problems at companies financed by junk bonds also may steer investors to local brokerage firms, analysts said. A public perception of greed on Wall Street _ fueled by current best-sellers such as ``Barbarians at the Gate'' and ``Liar's Poker'' _ doesn't help. ``In the '90s the client is going to be attracted to service,'' Jones said. Regionals are ``already doing that and it's easier for them to move to that if they're not.'' Long-term relationships with brokers are more likely to be found at a regional firm, analysts said. ``Joe trusts Bill and Bill's going to get the business,'' said Donald F. Howard, deputy chairman of Gray Judson & Howard, a Cambridge, Mass., firm that consults for regional brokerages. Securities executives and analysts said with Wall Street layoffs soaring _ total industry employment is down by more than 40,000 since the crash _ regionals are hiring top-flight brokers from large firms. Boettcher, a subsidiary of Kemper Financial Companies Inc. of Chicago, has added about 90 brokers in the last 15 months, many from major brokerages, boosting its staff to 300. Legg Mason has hired nearly 200 brokers in the last three years. Honing broker skills and improving relationships appears to be paying off. Productivity per broker increased to $169,000 in commissions generated at regional firms last year from $140,000 in 1988. Still, a slow stock market is slow for everyone. Average daily volume on the New York Stock Exchange so far this month is 151 million shares, down from 165 million last year and 5.6 percent below the Big Board's 1990 projection. But in a Securities Industry Association survey, 83 percent of 35 regional executives said the 1990s will be good for retail. The graying of America, with the oldest baby boomers hitting age 45 next year, was cited as a factor that will help. ``They are moving into their prime savings and investment years,'' Adrian L. Banky, an SIA executive vice president, told a regional brokerages' conference in Chicago Wednesday. ``They are becoming our kind of people.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Clash on Minimum Standards, Church-Run Day-Care Centers
DOC.TEXT: House members clashed Thursday over establishing minimum standards for day-care centers and subsidizing church-run centers as they began debate on competing versions of major child-care legislation. Their disputes obscured earlier bipartisan agreement on key portions of the bills, however, and came as the White House renewed its threat to veto the more ambitious Democratic proposal. Both versions would expand tax credits for poor working families that have child-care expenses and create a system of state-issued subsidy vouchers for parents who want to use religious day-care centers. Both would expand the Head Start program for poor children. The more expensive, Democratic version would go further to establish minimum standards and provide money for a new program of day care based in public schools. ``The time has come for us to put our money where our mouths are,'' said Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., a sponsor of the Democratic version. ``Children are our most important national resource in our country, and for too long we have neglected them.'' Republicans said the more expensive Democratic plan would face a veto by President Bush. ``This bill does not pay as you go; it spends as they went,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn. ``What a wierd, tortured way of taking care of children _ by giving them an IOU for $30 billion.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, meanwhile, said Bush would veto the Democratic version if enacted. The White House's budget office issued a statement calling the Democratic version ``an exercise in fiscal irresponsibility.'' Fourteen Democratic governors and one Republican, Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, signed a letter to House Speaker Thomas Foley endorsing the leadership's version of the child-care bill and opposing a proposed conservative alternative. The House planned a vote on the alternative, sponsored by Reps. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, and Clay Shaw, R-Fla., and backed by the White House. The House defeated on a 243-182 vote a Democratic amendment that would have made the voucher system optional for states. It faced another that would prohibit subsidies for church-run centers that offer religious instruction. Republicans attacked the Democratic version because it instructs states to set minimum standards for day-care centers, including a requirement that day-care workers receive 15 hours of training a year. Rep. Thomas Tauke, R-Iowa, charged the regulatory requirements ``reduce the choices available to parents'' and harm church-run centers. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., said Congress has passed regulations for the handling of farm animals and should do no less for children. ``This is not a philosophical argument,'' Miller said. ``This is an attack on America's children and quality child care.'' The cause of child care has been embraced by both political parties, with President Bush supporting some form of increased assistance to parents during his 1988 presidential campaign. But the bills bogged down in Congress last year amid partisan and internal disputes. ``If the child-care legislation were an actual child, Congress would be charged with abuse and neglect,'' said Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine. The Senate approved its version of a child-care bill last year, when the House approved conflicting versions. The latest House action was an effort to reach a new position going into a conference with the Senate, where a final version will be forged. ``The conference report will reflect a broad, multi-faceted approach to child care which, I believe, the president will sign,'' said Foley, D-Wash. A principal difference between the two versions centered around school-based day care. The Democrats would provide federal funds for school systems to set up programs of year-round, before- and after-school care, and pre-school care for 3- and 4-year-olds, based in the public schools. The Democrats' version gives conservatives much of what they wanted on the issue of religious care. It requires states to provide subsidy vouchers to families that want them for use in sectarian day-care centers, including those that offer religious instruction and discriminate based on church membership or tenets. The Stenholm-Shaw version would not set minimum standards for day care. It would create an additional tax credit for families with infants. Both child-care packages would be financed in part by ending the existing dependent care tax credit for upper-income families. That credit would be reduced for families earning $70,000 a year and eliminated for those earning more than $90,000.

DOC.HEAD: Criticism of Japanese Lobbyists in U.S. Provokes Protests
DOC.TEXT: Japanese business executives once thought they could solve their image problems in the United States by making corporate charitable donations and hiring lobbyists to represent them in Washington. Now, in response to accusations that Tokyo has been buying support from U.S. officials and academics, some Japanese protest what they call a ``Japan-lobby hunt'' reminiscent of McCarthyist anti-communist campaigns. The criticism, they say, is souring constructive ties between the world's two largest economic powers. ``Why pick on us? The consultants and lawyers who have the misfortune of representing a currently unpopular ally are the very people that senior business executives and government officials in Japan have lent an ear to,'' said Kazuo Nukazawa, managing director of Keidanren, or the Federation of Economic Organizations, Japan's most powerful business group. ``Today's trade policy McCarthyites seem determined to ostracize those scarce few who have experience and expertise on the country the U.S. has serious business negotiations with,'' he wrote in a recent commentary in the Japan Times newspaper. Other Japanese also express frustration over accusations in the United States that many American trade negotiators and scholars are suspiciously vulnerable to Japanese influence. The debate was created largely by a Jan. 22 article in The New Republic, a prominent American magazine, titled ``The Japanese Megaphone: Tokyo's Americans That Say Yes.'' In it, author John B. Judis wrote that the hundreds of millions of dollars funneled by Japanese corporations to U.S. think tanks and lobbyists are ``tilting the debate about America's economic future without the public being aware of it.'' ``Japan has assembled a virtual who's who of lobbyists and advisers in Washington,'' Judis wrote. ``This army of lobbyists and advisers furnishes Japanese companies with the troops necessary to win battles in Washington.'' Such charges have generated ``a `Japanologist hunt' reminiscent of a McCarthyist `Red hunt,''' Tetsuya Shibayama wrote in a recent issue of the weekly Asahi Journal, alluding to Sen. Joseph McCarthy's diatribes over what he saw as Communist subversion of the U.S. government circles in the 1950s. Shibayama blamed the problem on what he calls Japanese ignorance of exactly how their wealth and power are perceived overseas. One of Japan's top authorities on the issue agrees. ``Japanese companies spare no expense to hire big names, but often their money is wasted,'' said Masatake Takahashi, a commentator who has published several books on lobbying in the United States. ``I keep telling executives of companies they should be more selective. They're being criticized mainly because their approach is wrong. You have to know how to use lobbyists properly or it's not worth the trouble and expense,'' he said. Japanese officials at several major companies declined to comment on the issue. ``Our activities are mainly community oriented. We commit 0.1 percent of our total sales to grass-roots activities, and we make academic contributions to professorships at top universities. But we have no particular comment on lobbying activities,'' said Akira Nagano, spokesman at Matsushita Electronic Industrial Co., maker of major electronics brands like National and Panasonic. The accusations of excessive Japanese influence have led to congressional hearings on tightening U.S. control of foreign agents, with emphasis on lobbyists for Japanese business. Unlike the U.S. Congress, Japan's Parliament does not have institutionalized lobbies, and influential Japanese rarely accept requests to lobby on behalf of foreign interests. The American tobacco, pharmaceutical, rice and electronics industries have offices working on their behalf in Tokyo. They, and executives at major U.S. firms like IBM and AT&T, have managed to cultivate support for easing restrictive regulations through practices similar to lobbying. But they keep a much lower profile than lobbyists in Washington. ``American firms mistakenly have paid little attention to getting things done through private discussions with elected officials,'' said John P. Stern, executive director of the U.S. Electronics Industry Japan Office and perhaps Tokyo's best-known U.S. lobbyist. Stern said the criticism of the Japanese lobby in the United States is understandable. ``The main reason it's subject to so much criticism is it's so huge,'' he said. ``It is used to stifle American misgivings about Japan and to drown out American voices. It's properly the subject of criticism.'' Nukazawa, however, said those criticizing Japan's lobbyists are using ``smear tactics'' to force U.S. officials to adopt tougher attitudes toward Tokyo in trade disputes. He said criticism of Japanese corporate contributions to U.S. academic and research institutions could backfire if the donors reconsider their generosity. ``Some in Tokyo who have responded positively to past solicitations are now saying that if the U.S. starts pointing fingers at Japanese contributors, it is a situation of `damned if you do, damned if you don't,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices posted their first loss of the week Thursday in light selling attributed to worries about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had risen 39.41 points over the previous three sessions, dropped back 15.99 to 2,727.70. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 584 up, 861 down and 518 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 132.19 million shares, down from 142.30 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 159.53 million shares. Interest rates rose Thursday in the market for U.S. Treasury securities. Prices of the longest-term government bonds dropped more than $10 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.59 percent-8.63 percent range. Analysts said the activity in bonds continued to reflect worries that an apparently budding revival in economic growth might tend to push rates higher in the months ahead. The latest figures from the Commerce Department, issued on Wednesday, showed a slightly stronger pace of business activity during the fourth quarter of last year than had been previously estimated. Brokers also noted a downturn for the dollar against the Japanese yen in foreign exchange. A recent rise in the dollar had been cited as a plus for U.S. interest rates, in part by serving to attract foreign investors into American securities. Thursday's losers among the blue chips included Procter & Gamble, down | at 68\; Coca-Cola, down ] at 75{; General Electric, down ] at 64{; American Telephone & Telegraph, down \ at 42|, and International Paper, down } at 51[. Amax, up 2| points Wednesday on takeover speculation, rose another \ to 28~ as the most active Big Board issue. Curtiss-Wright, also a subject of much takeover conjecture, gained 1} to 65\. Bairnco tumbled 3{ to 10 for the day's biggest percentage loss. On Wednesday the company said new uncertainties about its finances had been raised by asbestos claims against its wholly-owned Keene Corp. subsidiary. Intertan Inc., which estimated a 50 percent earnings decline for the fiscal quarter ending this week, slumped 4{ to 36|. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $9.36 billion, or 0.28 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .60 to 187.17. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.39 to 395.42, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.21 at 340.79. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 1.27 to 435.42. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.23, down 1.00.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Non-Union Workers Hire Legal Help In Buyout Talks
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s non-union employees are seeking legal advice after failing to arrange discussions with union workers who are trying to put together an employee buyout of the airline. The move, revealed in an internal UAL newsletter, appears to signal resentment among the company's nearly 26,000 management and salaried workers, who face certain wage and benefit cuts if the buyout of United Airlines' parent succeeds. Meanwhile, UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf is likely to come face-to-face with employee frustration in a series of meetings announced Thursday in a company newsletter. In Wednesday's edition of the newsletter, the company said representatives of non-union workers had authorized their financial adviser, First Chicago Corp., to negotiate on their behalf with the buyout group. The company also said First Chicago had retained the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver and Jacobson to provide legal advice to the non-union group. According to the newsletter, First Chicago told non-union representatives it had been unable to determine the fairness of the union group's $4 billion acquisition plan. First Chicago said it would continue its efforts to initiate a dialogue with the union leaders and their advisers, the newsletter stated. The union group, representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants, proposed on March 19 a buyout estimated at $185 a share that would give UAL's entire work force 75 percent ownership of the company. The three union groups represent about two-thirds of the company's 71,000 employees. UAL stock closed at $159 Thursday in New York Stock Exchange trading, down $1.87{. The union bid is supported by UAL's largest shareholder, the New York investment firm Coniston Partners, which is threatening to wage a proxy fight to oust the company's directors at an April 26 shareholders meeting. UAL's board met Wednesday to discuss the bid but has not issued a statement about the meeting. In documents filed earlier this month with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the union group stated that non-union employees would provide $55 million in wage and benefit cuts in the buyout's first year. The SEC filing did not disclose the value of wage-and-benefit concessions that the union group has offered to make in proposed five-year contracts. Wolf is on a tour of United facilities in seven U.S. cities to meet with employees and answer questions about the company's future. The newsletter said Wolf met Wednesday with more than 3,000 employees in San Francisco and would meet with more employees Friday in Washington. Meetings are planned next month in Honolulu, Los Angeles, Denver, Boston and Newark, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Chairman's 1989 Pay Reflected The Company's Sagging Fortunes
DOC.TEXT: IBM Chairman John Akers' pay was cut last year as the computer giant's profit tumbled, according to IBM's annual proxy statement. But although Akers' compensation was shaved, the 3 percent reduction didn't compare with the 35 percent earnings slide at International Business Machines Corp. IBM's 1989 profit totaled $3.76 billion, compared with $5.81 billion in 1988. The company blamed a costly restructuring plan and unfavorable currency exchange rates for most of the decline. Akers received $1,420,713 cash and IBM stock worth $519,976, bringing his total compensation as head of the world's largest computer company to $1,940,689, according to the statement. In 1988, Akers received $2,000,500 in cash and stock. That was the first year his pay exceeded $2 million, said IBM spokesman Peter Thonis. Thonis said the company's profitability was just one factor in setting Akers' salary. ``His pay isn't just a reflection of the year,'' but includes other factors, such as the company's long-term management, Thonis said. In addition, the chairman's compensation is kept competitive with that of heads of other major corporations, he said. The pay and bonuses of IBM's top executives are set by the Executive Compensation Committee, a group of the company's board of directors that are not covered by the compensation plan. Akers' actual salary last year was $712,500. The remainder of Akers' compensation came from IBM's ``long-term performance plan,'' adopted by stockholders last year to reward executives ``whose performance ... can have a significant effect on the success of the company,'' according to the proxy statement. Akers received a cash award of $708,213 under this plan. He also received the $519,976 in stock under the plan, which he must forfeit if he leaves the company within the next two years, according to the plan's terms. None of IBM's executives received cash or stock last year under IBM's ``variable compensation plan,'' which is closely linked to the company's fortunes. In 1988 and 1987, Akers received a combined $1,776,812 under the plan. IBM President Jack Kuehler received total compensation last year of $1,179,000, according to the proxy statement, down from $1,195,000 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Fell $522.1 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 506 money market mutual funds fell $522.1 million in the latest week to $391.62 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $1.1 billion rise in fund assets the previous week to a record high of $392.14 billion. The week-earlier figures originally were reported as a rise of $199.04 million to an all-time high of $391.23 billion but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group subsequently revised those totals. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 246 general purpose funds rose $495.6 million to $133.87 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $414.0 million to $166.36 billion, and assets of 158 institutional funds declined $603.7 million to $91.39 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.69 percent from 7.67 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield rose to 7.66 percent from 7.65 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 45 days, up from 44 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.25 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.05 percent from 5.06 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.89 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, up from 7.88 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.02 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 8.01 percent; 8.04 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 8.01 percent; and 8.08 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.06 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil To Delete References To Bag Degradability
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp., targeted by environmentalists for alleged misleading advertising, said Thursday it no longer will refer to its Hefty trash bags as degradable. But the head of a task force of state attorneys general investigating deceptive advertising and packaging by Mobil and other companies claimed the oil giant merely was trying to deflect potential liability ahead of a scheduled negotiating session next week. ``People need to know this didn't come out of the blue,'' said Hubert Humphrey III, Minnesota's attorney general. ``It comes as the result of a meeting two weeks ago with state and federal agencies that are very much looking at enforcement action.'' Mobil has been criticized for advertising on its Hefty trash bags that claims the product decomposes ``after exposure to elements like sun, wind and rain.'' Environmentalists say the reference to degradability is misleading because more than 80 percent of trash bags are not exposed to sunlight long enough to degrade but end up in dry landfills that rarely are exposed to sunlight. In Thursday's announcement, Mobil said its chemical division would continue making Hefty trash bags with an ``environmentally safe additive'' that speeds their decomposition when exposed to sunlight. But the company will delete the references to degradability on the packaging. Mobil spokesman Allen Gray said Mobil Chemical Co. was taking the action in response to ``mounting confusion'' regarding the definition of degradability. Gray conceded that, ``If left out in Arizona somewhere a bag with the additive can quickly decompose in a couple of months, but in a northern climate like Chicago it could take well over a year.'' Nontheless, Gray said claims that the bags degrade in sunlight have been ``fully substantiated'' by tests and that the company never said the bags would be the answer to the country's waste disposal problem. Humphrey and other task force members said Mobil's action could send a signal to other companies making similar claims. ``This retreat by Mobil, however admirable, is just the opening victory for New York and other states in our war over dishonest advertising claims about the environmental benefits of certain products,'' Robert Abrams, New York's attorney general, said in a prepared statement. Gray said the company began marketing the degradable bags because of competitive pressures. He said the phaseout of the labeling was expected to take several months. Mobil officials are scheduled to meet Monday in St. Louis with legal representatives from the eight-state task force, including California, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, New York, Texas, Washington and Wisconsin. Humphrey said Mobil may be subject to fines or further injunctive relief, including a binding legal agreement to halt similar advertising on other Mobil products, such as styrofoam plates and plastic grocery bags. Officials from the Federal Trade Commission, which joined the investigation earlier this month, are expected to attend the meeting, said Ed Barbini, spokesman for Abrams. FTC Chairman Janet Steiger said earlier this month the agency had joined the task force to determine whether environmental claims made by various products _ from trash bags to hair spray _ could be substantiated. No other companies have been named by the task force or the FTC, although several companies are under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Only version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 227,426 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 228,872, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's scheduled production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 205,533 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 138,531 cars this week, compared with 138,912 a week ago and 130,416 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 88,895, compared with last week's 89,960 and last year's 75,117. Canadian automakers were to build 21,891 cars this week, down from 22,180 a week ago but up from last year's 20,400. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 20,919, compared with 21,488 a week ago and 20,208 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Supply Fears Keep Cocoa Futures Climbing
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices surged to new seven-month highs Thursday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange on persistent speculation that economic turmoil in Brazil and the Ivory Coast could cause significant supply disruptions. On other markets, livestock and meat futures mostly were lower; grains and soybeans advanced; precious metals rose; and energy futures were mixed. Cocoa futures settled $21 to $27 higher with the contract for delivery in May at $1,190 per ton, the highest settlement of a near-month cocoa contract since Aug. 16. The rally followed a rise of $47 in the May contract on Wednesday. Analyst Harry Schwartz of Cargill Investor Services Inc. said most of the buying was again by speculators and for the same reasons as on Wednesday: fears of supply disruptions from the world's two largest cocoa producers. No disturbances were reported Thursday in the Ivory Coast, the No. 1 cocoa grower, after Wednesday's violent confrontation between police and demonstrators in Abidjan, the capital of the West African nation. Last year's collapse of cocoa prices to 14-year lows was disastrous for the Ivory Coast. Citizens recently have been calling for the resignation of 30-year President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, who has ordered strict austerity measures to save the country from bankruptcy. Meanwhile, cocoa movement out of Brazil remained extremely slow amid continuing confusion about economic reform measures introduced two weeks ago in an attempt to halt hyperinflation. Schwartz discounted fears of supply disruptions. ``In the fullness of time, Brazil will get its house in order and start exporting again,'' he said. He noted there had been no indication of shipping halts in the Ivory Coast and said the price rise could trigger the release of ``a significant amount'' of Ivorian cocoa in storage outside the country as well as hedge selling of futures by the cocoa trade. ``I haven't seen any concrete evidence of anything occurring other than apprehension about what could happen,'' he said. Livestock and meat futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by the pork markets on selling ahead of Friday's quarterly Agriculture Department hogs-and-pigs inventory report. The report is expected to show a 2.6 percent decline in U.S. hog herd but analysts said market gains earlier this week may have overestimated the bullishness of the report. Live cattle futures settled .33 cent lower to .03 cent higher with April at 77.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent to .45 cent lower with March at 82.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .57 cent lower with April at 52.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent to 1.10 cents lower with May at 53.12 cents a pound. Most grain and soybean futures advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely reflecting expectations for a bullish USDA report on spring planting intentions. The report, scheduled for release after the close, is expected to show that farmers plan to sow more corn than last year while cutting back on soybean and spring wheat acreage. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to 3 cents higher with May at $3.53 a bushel; corn was { cent to } cent higher with May at $2.60 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 1} cents higher with May at $1.46} a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 4 cents higher with May at $5.89{ a bushel. Precious metals edged higher on New York's Commdodity Exchange as the dollar weakened against most major currencies. Gold settled $1.70 to $1.90 higher with April at $370.80 a troy ounce; silver was 2.9 cents to 3.1 cents higher with April at $4.946 a troy ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 5 cents lower to 13 cents higher with May at $20.03 a barrel; heating oil was .06 cent to .44 cent higher with April at 56.17 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .22 cent to .60 cent higher with April at 57.67 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended mixed in moderate trading Thursday, with crude oil under pressure from short-term softening in demand. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, lost 5 cents to close at $20.03. June and July crude also posted small declines while later months rose. Among refined products traded on the exchange, April wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 0.22 cent to 57.67 cents a gallon, May advanced 0.55 cent to 65.11 cents and June added 0.37 cent to 63.94 cents a gallon. Heating oil for delivery in April gained 0.44 cent to finish at 56.17 cents a gallon. The May contract ended at 53.78 cents, up 0.28 cent and June rose 0.35 cent to settle at 52.95 cents a gallon. Analysts said crude oil prices remained under pressure from slackening seasonal demand and building inventories. Conversely, gasoline and heating oil supplies have declined due partly to the slowdown in refinery operations since last month for annual maintenance and repairs. ``Crude still looks heavy because of high inventories,'' said Tom Bentz, director of futures trading for United Energy Inc. However, Bentz said, the market may soon stage a reversal as refineries step up operations in time for the spring driving season.

DOC.HEAD: Hanson Buys The Rest of Peabody for $715 Million
DOC.TEXT: Hanson PLC said Thursday it would take full control of the United States' biggest coal producer by buying Newmont Mining Corp.'s 55 percent stake in Peabody Holding Co. for $715 million. The British conglomerate bought a 45 percent stake in Peabody for $504 million last month. Newmont, which is 49 percent owned by Hanson, said the sale would yield about $600 million after taxes and expenses and help it to reduce its debt. ``The sale of our Peabody shares will not only realize a fair price, but it will also achieve Newmont's basic objective to reduce debt to appropriate levels,'' Gordon R. Parker, chairman, president and chief executive of Newmont, said in a statement released from the company's Denver headquarters. Peabody has excellent cash flow and coal should continue to be an important long-term source of energy in the United States, said Sir Gordon White, chairman of Hanson's U.S. arm, Hanson Industries. New technologies also are likely to increase coal's efficiency as a low-cost fuel, White said. Completion of the transaction is subject to regulatory approvals as well as approval by Newmont shareholders. Hanson bought its original 45 percent stake in Peabody last month from Boeing Co., Bechtel Investments Inc., and an energy company, Eastern Enterprises. Peabody last year mined about 87 million tons of coal in the United States, or 9 percent of the country's output. The company operates in all major U.S. coal areas and has estimated coal reserves of about 8.3 billion tons. Peabody had pretax earnings of $136.5 million on sales of $1.74 billion in 1989. After-tax profit figures were not available, Hanson said. Hanson's main businesses in the United States include SCM chemicals, Grove cranes, Jacuzzi whirlpools and spas, Kaiser cement and Ames garden tools. For the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the U.S. businesses had operating profit of $625 million on sales of $1.62 billion. Newmont Mining's principal asset is 90.1 percent of Newmont Gold Co., the largest North American gold producer. Newmont also has gold interests in Australia, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia.

DOC.HEAD: M1 Unchanged, M2 and M3 Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose slightly in the week ended March 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose $1.5 billion to a seasonally adjusted $3,271.0 billion from $3,269.5 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose $600 million to a seasonally adjusted $4,070.4 billion from $4,069.8 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, remained virtually unchanged at a seasonally adjusted $802.5 billion, vs. $802.2 billion the previous week. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. For the latest 13 weeks, M2's growth rate has averaged 6.8 percent, within the Fed annual target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate of M3 in the past 13 weeks has been about 3.4 percent, slightly below the Fed annual target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $141 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $294 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $304.2 billion in the two-week period ended March 21, up from $301.4 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Announces Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp., which has been reorganizing since fending off a hostile takeover effort two years ago, said Thursday it would take additional steps to restructure itself to boost sales and respond better to market demands. ``The reorganization is a major step in redirecting the company toward growth,'' said I. MacAllister Booth, president and chief executive of Cambridge-based Polaroid. Polaroid officials said the announcement caps a company-wide restructuring Polaroid undertook in 1988 while fighting a hostile takeover attempt by Shamrock Holdings. Key elements of the new organization are three business units _ family imaging, business imaging, and technical imaging _ that will focus on specific markets and product applications. Separately, the company will create three major groups that will provide support in research, sales, and product development and manufacturing. The executives overseeing the business units and support groups will report directly to a newly created office of the chief executive officer. Sheldon Buckler, Polaroid's executive vice president, will join that office and share responsibilities with Booth. Analysts said the changes are important because Polaroid must show stronger sales growth. Polaroid earned $145 million last year, compared with a $22.6 million loss in 1988 during the takeover fight. But sales grew only 2 percent in 1989 to $1.9 billion. Analysts said the improved earnings resulted from cost cutting. To have further increases in profits, the company must accelerate its sales, they said. Eugene Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the new organization should help accomplish this task by making Polaroid a more ``market driven company.'' ``Historically, this company has been research driven,'' he said, adding that Polaroid's philosophy was ``great inventions create new markets.'' An example of Polaroid's new strategy is the way it has marketed instant photography. The company increasingly has promoted instant cameras not only for family use, but also for businesses such as insurance agencies. Buckler said, however, the company's direction will not be dictated completely by market forces. ``What you really need is a blend of market drive and technology drive,'' he said. ``When you combine those forces right, you getting your batting average way up.''

DOC.HEAD: Discount Broker Raises Commission Rate
DOC.TEXT: Discount stockbroker Quick & Reilly Inc. said Thursday it had raised commissions by about $5 a trade, in order to provide new services for customers. Thomas Quick, president of the firm, said the 8 percent increase was not prompted by the downturn in the retail brokerage industry stemming from the October 1987 stock market crash. Quick said the New York-based firm recently installed a 24-hour telephone stock quote system for investors in 25 cities and added free check-writing privileges for money market account clients. ``These things cost money,'' Quick said. ``In light of inflation we didn't feel we were really being piggies.'' He said the nation's third largest discount brokerage had not raised its commissions since 1983. The move left Quick & Reilly commissions still slightly lower than the leaders in the field, San Francisco-based Charles Schwab & Co. and Boston-based Fidelity Investments. Charles Schwab last raised its commissions by 6 percent in February 1988 and said it has no plans for another increase. A spokesman for Fidelity could not be reached for comment. Under the change at Quick & Reilly, which took effect Monday, individual investors will be charged according to the principal amount of a transaction. Before, Quick & Reilly calculated commissions based on the number of shares bought or sold and the price per share. Quick said while the average commission was $5 a trade, charges would be higher for trades involving small principal amounts and lower for transactions involving high principals. Quick & Reilly on Wednesday reported its fourth-quarter profits rose to $2.52 million, or 27 cents a share, for the period ended Feb. 28, from $2.09 million, or 22 cents per share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $28.3 million from $22.1 million. For its full fiscal year, Quick & Reilly's profit increased about 15 percent to $11.4 million, or $1.21 a share, from $9.97 million, or $1.05 a share. Revenue climbed to $106 million from $77.6 million a year earlier. Discount brokers have reported healthier profits than large Wall Street firms despite a decline in stock trading activity since the stock market crash. Disounts have low expenses and benefit from high business volume because of their relatively lower commission rates.

DOC.HEAD: Norton Board Rejects Takeover Offer From British Firm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `BTR representatives ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with BTR response.
DOC.TEXT: Norton Co.'s board of directors rejected a $1.6 billion buyout offer Thursday from the British conglomerate BTR PLC and said it might open itself to minority investors and buy back some of its stock to thwart a takeover. But analysts said Norton apparently was trying to raise the BTR bid, and they expected the company eventually would accept a deal. BTR, based in London, announced the $75-per-share offer this month for Norton, a Worcester, Mass.-based maker of abrasives such as grinding wheels and sandpaper. Since then, Norton stock climbed above that level, and the company's board described the BTR deal as inadequate. The stock closed Thursday at $73.87{, down $1.12{ a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading after the board's announcement. John Nelson, Norton's chairman and chief executive officer, also said the acquisition ``would have a significantly adverse effect on Norton's employees, suppliers and customers and the communities served by the company.'' BTR Chief Executive John Cahill responded with a statement criticizing the board for ``spurning all our repeated attempts to meet with it'' and said the company would proceed with its offer. He urged Norton officials to meet with BTR to ``achieve a friendly transaction.'' Alvin Donius, an analyst with Altman Brenner Wasserman & Co. in New York, said a bidding war likely has just begun. ``I think BTR has been holding back,'' he said. ``They have given body language that they will go higher. ``In my judgment, Norton eventually will negotiate with BTR or with someone else,'' he said. He said the action by Norton's board was ``to negotiate a better price.'' BTR has encountered protests from Norton workers and local officials who fear the company would be dismantled, but BTR officials have disputed those claims. Norton said it needed more time to consider various alternatives to counter the offer, and as a result the board canceled the company's annual shareholders meeting scheduled for April 26 and called for a special shareholders meeting on June 26. Nelson said the BTR offer, which was made the day after Norton mailed its annual meeting notice, apparently was intended to leave the board ``with the shortest possible amount of time to consider the offer and develop and explore alternatives.'' The company said it was discussing with other parties the possibility of ``strategic, minority investments'' and that it has approached banks to see whether they might lend money for Norton to buy its own stock.

DOC.HEAD: Former Merrill Lynch Trader Settels with SEC
DOC.TEXT: A former top mortgage-backed securities trader at Merrill Lynch agreed to a nine-month suspension Thursday to settle allegations that he made an off-the-books trade that cost the company $85 million. The Securities and Exchange commission announced it had agreed to accept the settlement offer of Howard A. Rubin, of New York, who neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. The SEC had accused him, in an administrative action, of failing to disclose to Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc. in 1987 that he had made a $500 million proprietary trade in stripped mortgage-backed securities. Such securities are backed by mortgages but unlike conventional bonds, the interest and principal are sold off separately. The trade obligated Merrill Lynch, which lost approximately $85 million on the deal, to sell $500 million in Government National Mortgage Association interest-only securities, according to the SEC. ``The importance of this case is that if this had happened at a firm that was not as well capitalized as Merrill Lynch, it would forced them to liquidate, harming the investing public,'' said Martin A. Kuperberg, associate regional administrator of the SEC's New York regional office. Rubin, who left Merrill Lynch in 1987, was not available for comment. His lawyer, Ira Lee Sorkin, said that at the time the trade became known ``there were wild allegations of fraud. This order today identifies it as a books and records problem _ nothing more _ which he neither admits or denies.'' In addition to a nine-month suspension from association with any broker, dealer, investment company, investment adviser or municipal securities dealer, Rubin will be barred from acting in a supervisory capacity for at least four years. Rubin joined the mortgage trading department at Bear Stearns in November 1987. ``While at Bear Stearns, he has been an exemplary employee,'' the securities firm said in a statement that added: ``We look forward to his return and reassociation with Bear Stearns in nine months.'' At Merrill Lynch, a spokesman, Bill Clark, said: ``We're gratified that the SEC has imposed a serious sanction which should serve as a deterrent for this type of conduct.''

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Chairman Promises Concessions to Major Shareholders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 18-19, `Martin and ... those grounds' to UPDATE with 30 percent of employees failed to vote, Lockheed saying ESOP voted over 90 percent for management; picks up 20th graf pvs, `Simmons contends ...'
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. Chairman Daniel Tellep promised major concessions to big shareholders Thursday but predicted victory in his battle with Texas investor Harold Simmons over control of the company. ``I'm expecting a clear majority in every category of shareholder, except of course, Mr. Simmons,'' Tellep said at a news conference after the aerospace company's annual meeting. Simmons, who owns 19 percent of Lockheed, and his chief strategist, J. Landis Martin, said they believed the contest was too close to call, although Martin later seemed to acknowledge they had lost. ``It's like a political campaign,'' he said. ``Sometimes you just have to come back again the next time.'' Simmons, however, claimed victory in pressuring Tellep to make concessions to the concerns of big investors seeking more input in running the company. ``I think we achieved an awful lot,'' Simmons said, claiming he also forced Lockheed to concentrate on profits rather than merely increasing the amount of business the company does. Lockheed spent about $8 million on the proxy battle, while Simmons said he spent about $6 million. Both sides said they wished they had not had to do so. ``It was a tremendous drain of energy away from running the company,'' Tellep told reporters. During the meeting, held in a giant hangar adjacent to Burbank Airport, Tellep told shareholders that he met with 70 institutional investors during the proxy war over the past two weeks and that he considered it his ``baptism by fire and a highly valuable experience.'' Concessions were forced by big pension funds and other institutional shareholders, many of which defected to Simmons, who sought to replace Lockheed's board with his representatives. Simmons' slate included John Tower, former head of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the former chief of naval operations and former member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Preliminary voting results may be available next week. Tellep told the meeting he believes in ``shareholder democracy'' and offered several future concessions, including secret votes if that is what a significant number of shareholders want. Other promises included: _A provision to opt out of strict anti-takeover provisions of law in Delaware, where Lockheed is incorporated. Tellep said that even if the provision did not pass but there was a ``significant'' minority vote for it, he would recommend that the board support an amendment at the next meeting to have Lockheed opt out. _A promise that he would ask for a list of possible shareholder representatives to Lockheed's 15-person board and would select up to three directors from that list. He earlier offered to select only one. _An offer to meet regularly with representatives of Simmons' NL Industries Inc. to discuss the future of Lockheed. Martin and Simmons objected to the way in which some of the shares belonging to an employees stock ownership plan had been voted. They said the trustee of the plan, which holds 19 percent of Lockheed stock, had wrongly voted all the shares even though about 30 percent of the employees failed to vote. The 30 percent was voted in proportion with the rest of the plan's votes, which Lockheed announced late Thursday had gone for Tellep by more than 90 percent. Martin suggested that if they lost by a narrow margin, the result might be challenged on those grounds. Simmons contends that Lockheed, with a recent history of sagging earnings and underestimating costs of developing new programs, must insist on better profits at its non-core businesses or sell them. The company portrays Simmons as a corporate raider intent on personal profit, with no knowledge of how to run Lockheed, the nation's sixth-largest defense contractor with 1989 sales of $9.9 billion. Simmons, who has lost $100 million on his $530 million investment in Lockheed stock, insists he can better focus the company and has a good record of profitably running companies he purchases, including NL Industries, Amalgamated Sugar Co. and Keystone Steel and Wire Co. During the meeting, Simmons and Martin were bombarded with questions from Lockheed employees and shareholders worried that Simmons might want to merely dismantle the company for his own benefit. The most vigorous defense of Tellep by an employee came from Bob Strickland, a worker at Lockheed Aircraft Services in Ontario. ``Mr. Tellep and I have one thing in common _ a great love for our company. Lockheed has always been there for me and now I feel it's my duty to be there for him,'' Strickland said about voting his 38 shares for the current board. Historically, few proxy battles have succeeded in unseating directors. However, analysts say Simmons made strong inroads into the ranks of the institutional investors, who hold 60 percent of Lockheed's shares. Simmons' chief coup was persuading California's huge public employees' pension fund, known as Calpers, to vote its nearly 1 percent of Lockheed shares for him, said Lawrence Harris, a securities analyst at the Bateman, Eichler, Hill Richards brokerage in Los Angeles. Calpers has led institutional investors in pressing for more control over companies they own.

DOC.HEAD: Riegle Predicts Defeat for Nomination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's nominee for top savings and loan regulator appears headed for defeat in the Senate Banking Committee, the committee chairman said Thursday evening. T. Timothy Ryan Jr., a former senior Labor Department official nominated only last week, met skepticism by committee Demnocrats during a hearing Wednesday on his nomination as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. They questioned his lack of direct experience in banking and raised concerns about possible conflicts of interest in his work as a private attorney after leaving government in 1983. Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., after caucusing with Democrats on his committee for several hours and consulting the senior Republican, Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, said in a Senate speech he did not believe Ryan would win the committee's endorsement. ``My sense of the canvass of the votes would be _ and it's not complete, I have not talked with every member directly _ but I think that, based on the vote count that I have, that there are not the votes to confirm this nomination,'' Riegle said. Riegle scheduled a vote Friday. An adverse recommendation from the committee could still be overturned on the floor, but that would be unusual. It was unclear whether the administration would withdraw Ryan's name. It has had difficulty finding a candidate since M. Danny Wall announced in early December that he would resign. Treasury spokeswoman Desiree Tucker-Sorini said officials had not discussed what they would do if the committee failed to endorse Ryan. ``We hope he will pass the committee. We stand behind him 100 percent,'' she said. The administration has portrayed Ryan as an experienced manager who supervised 600 attorneys at the Labor Department and a tough enforcer who helped clean up corruption in the Teamsters Union Central States Pension Fund. Democrats have express dismay with his lack of familiarity with the thrift industry and questioned whether At the department, he helped hire former Attorney General William B. Saxbe as independent counsel overseeing the pension fund. After Ryan left the government, Saxbe joined Ryan's firm, bringing with him hundreds of thousands of dollars in fees from the fund.

DOC.HEAD: First 747 Retired to Museum
DOC.TEXT: The first 747 jumbo jet, which changed the look of jet travel with its huge size and distinctive upper-deck hump, has flown into retirement, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said. The red-and-white jumbo jet rolled off the assembly line near Everett on Sept. 30, 1968, made its first flight on Feb. 9, 1969, and won certification on Dec. 30 that year. Boeing has used the aircraft as a test plane for 21 years. Now, the ``City of Everett'' is being donated to the Museum of Flight in Seattle. Pan American World Airways signed the first contract for 747s, ordering 25 for a total of $525 million. Today, that amount would buy four of the jets, Boeing said. The test plane's only break in service was from October 1983 to August 1986, when it was in storage in Las Vegas. It was then sent to Wichita, Kan., where it was used as a mock-up for two 747-200s that the Air Force will use to carry the U.S. president and his staff. The plane had only 5,208 hours of flight time. That's very low, considering a jet in normal commercial service flies 3,000 to 4,000 hours every year, company spokesman Tom Cole said. ``But it was tough stuff. They were always putting it into dives and stalls,'' he said. The plane, officially known as RA001, had a short final flight Wednesday: about 25 miles from Boeing Field in Seattle to Paine Field, where 747s are built near Everett. There, its engines will be taken off and returned to Pratt & Whitney, which owns them, followed by some restoration work. Eventually, the plane will be displayed at the museum's restoration facility or at a new large-aircraft interpretive center the museum hopes to build at Paine Field, said Cindy Upthegrove, the museum's special events manager. About 800 747s are in service around the world, Boeing said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Control Data Boss Leaves With Whopping Severance Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Price did ...' to CORRECT that Price retired as employee sted CEO in March.
DOC.TEXT: Former Control Data Corp. chief Robert Price, whose four-year reign yielded $923.9 million in net losses, has received $4.24 million in retirement and severance pay and will get $450,000 a year under a three-year consulting contract, it was disclosed Wednesday. In addition, Price received $1.07 million in bonus income during the past 3{ years under two separate stock award programs and possibly could get more bonus money under Control Data's Long-Term Performance Incentive Plan. His pension _ good for the rest of his life _ will bring another $300,000 a year. The compensation was detailed in the company's annual proxy statement, distributed Wednesday to stockholders, analysts and the media in advance of the company's May 2 annual shareholder meeting. Roger Redmond, a stock analyst for Minneapolis-based Piper Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., said Price's compensation is excessive considering the computer company's performance since Price took control in January 1986. Lawrence Perlman replaced Price as chief executive officer in January after the company posted a net loss of $680.4 million in 1989. The company posted $21 million in profits in 1988 and 1987 but suffered a net loss of $264.5 million in 1986. ``Control Data has a history of awarding bonuses arbitrarily, and that is absolutely incorrect,'' Redmond said. ``Any and all bonuses should be tied with stockholder equity and company performance. ``It's unconscionable that these senior executives are receiving that much compensation,'' Redmond said. Stockholders and employees complained about the company's severance agreements at last year's annual meeting, booing retired deputy chairman Norbert Berg when he was introduced. Berg, still a member of the board of directors, received nearly $4 million under a severance package while the company earned a mere $1.7 million in 1988. Price defended such severance agreements at last year's meeting. ``What kind of company is it that doesn't honor its contracts?'' he asked. Price did not return a phone call to his office Wednesday. He retired as an employee on March 15, but the company is providing him office space and secretarial support under his consulting contract, the proxy statement said. He also remains chairman of the board. Control Data spokesman Frank Ryan said Price's severance package was part of a contract signed in 1986 when the company was faced with an ``arduous'' restructuring. ``Certainly over the life of these contracts the stockholders and Bob would have liked to have seen better performance,'' Ryan said. ``But having a contract that protects against the risks and takes into account the tasks before the individual, the contracts do not seem inappropriate.'' Price's contract brought him severance pay of $2,774,800, an amount equal to three times his final annual base pay of $873,600 and the amount of his accrued vacation, according to the proxy statement. He also was entitled to $163,054 in annual supplemental pension, but elected to receive the lump sum present value of the benefits, $1,469,932, upon his retirement. The supplemental pension is above Price's normal annual pension of $300,000, Ryan said. Price also had earned options to buy 120,000 shares of Control Data common stock as of Dec. 31, 1989, but the option price of $22.27 a share is above the stock's current trading price of $19 to $20 a share, making the options worthless. But if the stock price rises substantially in the next year, Price would stand to get additional bonus money under the company's Long-Term Performance Incentive Plan, the proxy statement said.
